HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Bush Brings Largess of Office Along on the Campaign Trail

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PENSACOLA, Fla., March 6

 BODY:
If conservatives should be grateful to Patrick J. Buchanan for pushing President Bush to the right on issues like welfare and taxes, then state officials who have been waiting for Federal largess may also have to send Mr. Buchanan thank you notes.
As Mr. Bush charges across the country, his campaign forced out of the White House by Mr. Buchanan's challenge and showing new signs of fear and confusion, the President ends up at times looking like a political rich uncle visiting his poor relations. 
 Landing his enormous red, white and blue airplane in three or four states a day, Mr. Bush scatters plums as he goes: a $514 million reclamation project for Florida, a relaxation of regulations on natural gas for Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana, the promise of new pollution control rules for Michigan, a boost for biotechnology companies in California.
White House aides deny that they are playing politics with the Federal purse, which has always been one of an incumbent's more formidable weapons as he seeks to drown out his opponents with Presidential noise.
But each of these gestures of Federal largess has been timed for Mr. Bush's campaign needs in the Republican nominating contest, and they are one of several indications of the Bush campaign's increasing anxiety as it tries everything it can think of to blunt Mr. Buchanan and get Mr. Bush on the offensive for the first time in this campaign.
Some Republican strategists say they are worried that Mr. Bush is squandering the power that his incumbency should give him in the campaign.
"With Bush, people just want to grab the guy and say, 'Damn it, act Presidential. Look strong. Act strong,' " said Edward C. Rollins, a former Republican Party official who is a frequent critic of the Bush White House.
So far, though, the President's campaign remains reactive. Mr. Bush has been following Mr. Buchanan around the country as the challenger chooses where to contest the President. Bush aides have been using television commercials in markets selected by Mr. Buchanan, going on the air in Texas today, for example, after Mr. Buchanan started advertising there.
Republican strategists say Mr. Bush is growing angry at the disjointed nature of his schedule and his speeches, and at his advisers' failure to help him reduce the voter discontent evident since the first primary in New Hampshire last month.
This has produced some signs of a fearful campaign. The fear is that Mr. Buchanan's showing reflects problems that Mr. Bush will encounter in the general election, and that its efforts to correct the situation are not working.
In response, Bush aides are searching for somewhere to fix the blame. The campaign complains one week that the White House is not producing policies to back up Mr. Bush's candidacy. The next week, the White House complains that the campaign has the President on the road too much.
Both seem convinced that their problem was not that things were going badly, but that outsiders, particularly the press, simply did not recognize that Mr. Bush was doing a good job and that his campaign was going strong.
 
Salty Words for the Press
 Today, an irritated Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, concluded that reporters traveling with Mr. Bush were writing critical articles because they sometimes skipped going to the events and stayed in the newsrooms set up by the White House, where they can listen to Mr. Bush's words on loudspeakers and watch him on television monitors.
"I'm sick of you lazy bastards," Mr. Fitzwater shouted this morning outside the press room in a Bible study center at Oklahoma Christian University near Oklahoma City. He ordered his staff to cut the audio line feeding Mr. Bush's remarks into the room.
Alarmed by the immediate news reports of his remark, Mr. Fitzwater later apologized for his language. But Republican strategists saw the outburst as a symptom of a campaign that cannot seem to regain its footing.
"Sometimes you just can't get good press, but you have to get through it," said a veteran Republican strategist. "I also don't like to see them contradicting each other and criticizing each other. Their view is very short term, the primaries, when they should be looking at the larger picture, November."
To help him through these hard times, Mr. Bush has been trying familiar political tactics.
To seem more in tune with his audiences, his speeches are peppered with regional and local references: allusions to the race car driver Richard Petty when he is in the Carolinas, references to Elvis Presley in Memphis.
Mr. Bush offers lectern-pounding denunciations of abortion to conservative Christian organizations, denounces Fidel Castro before Cuban-Americans and brings home builders to their feet by proposing a $5,000 tax credit for first-time homebuyers.
 
Political Motives Denied
 White House aides deny they are playing politics with those tactics or with the Federal purse. But extending Government generosity has always been one of the primary tools available to incumbents and the timing of Mr. Bush's gestures have coincided with his campaign needs.
Today, in Oklahoma, he announced that he was relaxing regulations on the natural gas industry, important to the state. In Jackson, Miss., Mr. Bush announced that he was naming a state resident, James B. Huff, as head of the Rural Electrification Administration. When Mr. Bush arrived in Florida on Wednesday, the White House announced a tentative agreement on a $514 million program to clean up the wetlands of the Kissimee Basin.
Administration officials said the White House had put pressure on the Environmental Protection Agency to drop a new pollution control proposal that could cause Mr. Bush trouble in Michigan, where unemployment is high and Mr. Buchanan is expected to campaign.
Such actions have already drawn criticism. Mr. Buchanan accused Mr. Bush of catering to his political needs before the New Hampshire primary with three Federal initiatives that would create 400 jobs and pump more than $274 million in financial aid and loan guarantees into that state.
"These are legitimate needs that we're responding to and which people are concerned about," said Judy Smith, the deputy White House press secretary. "The President highlights these issues when he comes to the states."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Increases to 7.3% In a Mixed Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate climbed two-tenths of a point in February to 7.3 percent, the highest since mid-1985, the Labor Department reported today. But other job data, notably a gain of 164,000 payroll jobs, pointed to a slight upturn in the economy.
Most private economists said they were encouraged by the sizable payroll jump, as well as by a lengthening of the average workweek and a sharp rebound in total production hours. Some contended that the recession -- by technical rather than popular definition -- probably ended last month if it had not done so previously. 
 But Democrats seized on the higher jobless rate in the report, the first look at overall economic performance last month, as evidence of continued economic weakness and worker hardship, a theme they plan to push forcefully during the campaign year.
 
 
'Grim News Indeed'
 "Very grim news indeed," said Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, at a hearing on the job figures.
Campaigning in Baton Rouge, La., President Bush was asked if joblessness would hurt him. "I don't know," he responded. "We've just got to worry about those who don't have jobs. It's a good argument for passing our program."
The President's top economic adviser, Michael J. Boskin, emphasized the favorable elements of today's mixed report but was careful not to raise expectations too high.
 
Hard to Interpret
 "We're deeply concerned about the rise in the unemployment rate," he said in an interview. "While the gains in non-farm payroll jobs, the workweek, overtime and earnings are positive signs, the economy is not yet growing rapidly enough to prevent a rise in unemployment. Speeding, strengthening and insuring that growth is the President's first priority to get Americans back to work."
 By all accounts, this month's report was unusually hard to interpret, as reflected in bond prices that first tumbled, driving interest rates higher, and then regained the lost ground.
The report contained conflicting evidence, including a 74,000 decline in jobs as measured by the survey of households, compared with a gain more than twice that big for company payrolls, as measured in the separate survey of employers. This, combined with revisions and statistical aberrations, compounded the normal analytical task.
Generally, however, most economists agreed that the report depicted an economy moving ahead ever so slowly and unlikely either to slip back into recession or to grow fast enough in the foreseeable future to generate inflation pressures.
"It's positive," said Kathryn Eickhoff, president of a New York consulting firm carrying her name, adding that the economic "stirrings" cited recently by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, had grown stronger. "But it's certainly nothing to get very excited about."
Private analysts said they also tended to think that today's report was sufficiently encouraging that it added no pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates yet again as a spur to the economy.
Nonetheless, the figures disclosed areas of increased job-market distress, including another substantial rise in the ranks of those out of work for long periods. While those idled for less than five weeks actually declined by 278,000, this was more than offset by a rise of 235,000 in those jobless from 5 to 14 weeks and a rise of 145,000 in those jobless for 15 weeks or more.
 
 
Jobless Spell Climbs
 The average jobless spell climbed to 17 weeks, from 16.4 weeks in January and 15.3 weeks in December. Moreover, the number of unemployed Americans expanded by 315,000 last month to 9,244,000, the highest level since December 1983 and 2.8 million above the total when the latest recession started in July 1990.
So while it appeared from one set of statistics that the economy was no longer throwing people out of work in recent weeks, neither was it generating enough jobs to absorb an ever-larger pool of people seeking them, including the hard-core unemployed. At the same time, however, the report also showed a rise of 541,000 in "job losers," those forced to leave their jobs, during February.
The labor force grew by another 241,000 last month, a major factor in raising the unemployment rate. The jobless rate typically continues to move higher during the early stages of recovery as people who had given up looking for jobs become hopeful enough to start searching again, and are thereby restored to the statistical work force.
Yet the figures show that there were 190,000 fewer of these jobless "re-entrants" last month, a total of 2.16 million, compared with 2.35 million in January. The number of unsuccessful new entrants to the labor force -- like college graduates and other first-time job hunters -- rose 33,000, to 823,000.
One partial explanation of what was happening was that the long-term jobless who had exhausted their benefits had been induced by the latest extension of benefits to visit their unemployment office to re-establish eligibility.
The household survey also showed a sharp increase of 1.7 points, to 20 percent, in the jobless rate for teen-agers, a group that has been hit especially hard over the last two years. Black teen-age men now have a jobless rate of 39 percent, or 42.4 percent without benefit of seasonal adjustment. The jobless rate for Hispanic people rose last month to 11.6 percent from 11.3 percent.
 
 
Longer Jobless Periods
 Over all, the number of people out of work six months or more has nearly doubled over the last year and the proportion of such jobless has risen to 1 in 5 from 1 in 10.
The department's survey of payrolls produced a far bigger expansion than analysts had predicted, but the 164,000 rise proved less impressive when subjected to close inspection. Of the total, 133,000 of the increase was reported as coming in retail trade, a result that analysts said was not credible in light of a decline of 158,000 before seasonal adjustment.
William G. Barron Jr., Deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee that "recessionary forces have modified the seasonal patterns" for retailing.
Factory jobs rose 12,000 in February after five months of decline that averaged 40,000 each month. But there would have been another loss had it not been for the recall of 30,000 auto workers from layoffs.
At the same time, however, the length of the average private-sector workweek expanded a hefty 24 minutes, and factory hours and factory overtime also rose. This was a favorable sign, economists said, because longer hours are a precursor to new hiring, as employers seek to meet higher demand for their goods.
"I think they show the recession has finally ended," Lacy H. Hunt, chief United States economist for the Hongkong Bank Group, said of the data released today. "But the prospect is for no meaningful recovery," he added, with the unemployment rate probably rising for many months to come.

NEW YORK CITY
 
FADE-OUT IN ASTORIA 
 In the way that life has of imitating television, Bill Cosby -- a.k.a. Cliff Huxtable -- sent all of his children out into the world yesterday. It was the final episode of "The Cosby Show," which finished taping at the Kaufman-Astoria Studios in Queens, where it has become an institution, and on April 30 will be brought into the living rooms of America, where it is an institution as well. Page 1.
 
CHILDREN OF VIOLENCE
As city officials call for tighter school security in the wake of two killings at Thomas Jefferson High School, many students say the problems go far beyond guns, ultimately to a kind of corrosion of the spirit. A report from the front, in their own words. Page 28.
 
MORE ANGER THAN PROGRESS
There was little progress toward resolving the issue that will decide if organizers of the St. Patrick's Day Parade will be legally compelled to admit a homosexual group that has applied to march. What emerged instead, at a hearing before an administrative judge, was the enmity of the two sides that has always been apparent but has been infrequently expressed. Page 29.
 
NEW TROUBLE FOR BRONX DISTRICT
Corruption is a perennial ailment for School District 9 in the west Bronx. Now, a former acting principal has charged in a $1 million lawsuit that a school board member asked her for $18,000 in exchange for a secure appointment as principal of Public School 4. Page 29.
 
 A 15-year-old youth is shot to death in a crowded subway car in Brooklyn at rush hour. Page 29.
A new chief for the transit police. Page 29.
REGION
 
ABORTION BATTLE IN BUFFALO
Three years after throngs of anti-abortion protesters from a local chapter took to the sidewalks and created havoc in Buffalo, Operation Rescue is on its way back. Protesters from around the country plan to arrive for a month of picketing and blockades beginning April 20. Two court injunctions and a City Council vote have tried to bar the group from setting up their blockades. In the middle of it all, Mayor James Griffin, an opponent of abortion, has set the city on its ear by announcing that Operation Rescue is "welcome" in Buffalo. Page 31.
 
FATAL FIRE IN WESTCHESTER
A fire in a 10-story apartment building in the Village of Tuckahoe killed a man, and his elderly mother was critically injured when she jumped from their third-floor balcony in panic just as firefighters were coming to her rescue. Page 31.
 
MANAGING GROWTH IN NEW JERSEY
New Jersey's pending statewide growth management plan would not harm the state's economy, but would save billions in coming decades by discouraging sprawling, scattered development, according to a new state study. The study concluded that the state would add about the same number of people and jobs with or without the broad statewide land-use plan that is to be published this summer. Page 31.
 
YALE COST REDUCTIONS ARE CRITICIZED
A committee of Yale University professors has criticized an administration proposal to cut the Yale faculty by 10 percent and eliminate several academic departments to reduce a growing budget deficit. Page 31.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The unemployment rate climbed to 7.3 percent in February, the highest since mid-1985, the Labor Dept. reported. But other data, notably a gain of 164,000 payroll jobs, pointed to a slight upturn in the economy. Most private economists said they were encouraged by the sizable payroll jump, but Democrats seized on the higher jobless rate as evidence of continued economic weakness and worker hardship. [Page 1.] Unemployment in New York City, a dismal picture throughout the recession, hit 10.9 percent in February, the highest level for that month in 16 years. [43.] 
 Four regulatory changes intended to raise natural gas demand, and thus help an industry that has been badly hurt by low prices, were supported by President Bush. [39.]
Paying bills by phone has not caught on, despite bankers' best efforts. But bankers hope a generation of customers who came of age with computers will stop writing checks. [39.]
A "smog exchange" for Southern California, in which polluting companies would buy credits from clean ones, won preliminary approval. [49.]
The Michelangelo computer virus came to life as scheduled but from all reports the infection caused barely a sneeze. [8.]
 
International
A preliminary ruling that Canada was subsidizing lumber exports was issued by the Commerce Dept., which increased temporary duties on Canadian products to force their prices up and help American companies compete. [39.]
Thorn EMI agreed to buy Virgin Records for roughly $960 million, which will put some of world's best-known record labels and singers, from Garth Brooks and the Rolling Stones, to Janet Jackson and Hammer, under a single umbrella. [39.]
The euphoria disappeared from Mexico's bank privatization effort with the disclosure that an investor had overbid for a leading bank and had to back out of the deal. [40.]
 
Companies
By rejecting the $1.3 billion Drexel settlement, the Government is gambling that it can somehow do better than the $500 million it would have received. News Analysis. [39.]
Keycorp has offered to acquire Puget Sound Bancorp, in a deal that could be worth $700 million or more. [40.]
Federated Department Stores said it was consolidating internal functions of its Abraham & Straus and Jordan Marsh store groups to save an estimated $25 million a year. [41.]
 
Markets
Stock prices closed lower after a stronger-than-expected job report. The Dow ended at 3,221.60, down 19.90 for the day and 46.07 for the week. It is now at its lowest level since Jan. 13. [42.]
Prices of Treasury securities rose, despite employment data seen as far stronger for the economy than expected. [42.]
The dollar declined in choppy trading, as the markets reacted with ambivalence to the latest U.S. economic statistics. [48.]
Futures prices for hogs and pork bellies leaped after a pork industry official said Washington was moving closer to approval of a proposal to sell subsidized pork to former Soviet republics. [48.]
 
Today's Columns
An ill-chosen word in a financial statement intended to make things easier for 600,000 New York State taxpayers has resulted instead in considerable confusion. Your Taxes. [40.]
What could be the first drug to prevent and treat cataracts has been patented. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [40.]

HEADLINE: Life at 'Jeff': Tough Students Wonder Where Childhood Went

 BODY:
New Yorkers and indeed the nation were shocked when two students were gunned down in the hallway of Thomas Jefferson High School in East New York, Brooklyn, on Feb. 26. Khalil Sumpter, a 15-year-old student, was arrested and charged with the slayings of Tyrone Sinkler, 16, and Ian Moore, 17.
For the 1,800 students who attend "Jeff," in one of the poorest and most violent sections of the city, murder and mayhem are as much a feature of teen-age life as pep rallies and proms. 
 To learn more about the lives, hopes and fears of these "children of war," as their principal calls them, The New York Times invited two diverse groups of Thomas Jefferson students -- 19 altogether -- to discussions last Saturday and Wednesday.
Even as city officials called for such measures as more metal detectors in the schools, many of the students said the problems went far beyond guns, ultimately to a kind of corrosion of the spirit.
The young people said they coped with life on the hard streets in ways that ranged from wearing bulletproof vests to pinning their hopes on careers that will take them far from East New York.
The following text was taken from the transcript of three hours of conversations with three reporters: E. R. Shipp, Felicia R. Lee and Mary B. W. Tabor.
MARIANA BRYANT: Last night we was looking through my junior high school yearbook and my friend pointed out a number of people in that book that was dead.
Q.: About how many would you estimate?
MARIANA: Ten, all guys from eighth and ninth grade.
CAROLINE GRIFFITH: There was a shooting around my building over this girl. I was on my way to school. Two guys were going with one girl, so after one found out then he just pulled out his gun and shot him. . . . The one that got shot was 17.
SEAN WILLIAMS: One of the guys that died from this school was Wesley. . . . He got shot in a barbershop right across the street on Pennsylvania. . . . I think he was 16.
He was caught on the wrong side of Pennsylvania Avenue, the demarcation line in long-running guerrilla warfare between those who live in the Linden housing project and those who live "on the other side."
NEREIDA TORRES: I had a boyfriend that recently died. He got killed right there across the street at a party over an argument and they decided, well, if they couldn't get him to fight . . . He wasn't a punk. Why you gone fight over an argument, something stupid? So they just decided just to come up and kill him. . . . They shot him in the neck.
NORVEN CHARLES: A couple of months ago there was a drive-by shooting and one of my friends died.
KAREEM SMITH: I already got shot. . . . I ran into this kid that I had a little problem with.
Q.: Larry, how many do you know who have been shot?
LARRY BUGETT: A lot. That's all I can say is a lot of people I know.
Q.: More than five?
LARRY: More than 20. People that's 18 and under. Cause we used to be in a posse called V.I.P.: Vanderveer International Posse.
Q.: Over what period of time were these people shot?
LARRY: Like two years, three years. Some is dead. Some crippled. Some of them is still selling. Some of them is in jail now.
Nearly all of the students agree that life was not nearly as rough for them when they were in elementary school.
SHAWN CAMERON: You'd fight in the morning, but by afternoon y'all laugh together, y'all best friends again and then it starts all over. Y'all going to the store buying each other things and talking about girls and everything and walk home together.
Now, it's like I could look at you wrong. We could have words right now and that afternoon you don't know what's gone happen to you when you walk out the door.
KAREEM: Now you get some beef, just get a burner and do what you got to do. Back in them days you used to fight and it used to be over.
KENAISHA WARREN: When I was young, I'm used to, like, go into the park, stay out late at night just playing with the kids. But now, you can't do that. If you go to the park, you're liable to get shot. . . . When I was young, if you don't get your way, you tell your mother. They settle it.
Now they got guns at age of 10 years old, going to elementary school, and elementary school is even terrible as high school. . . . Next we're gone hear that they're shooting in the elementary schools.
The students, boys and girls, say they have to walk the streets ever mindful that there are certain blocks that are unsafe for them because of ongoing gang rivalries and "beef" that someone may have with them personally. 
Q.: How do you know what the rules are, that you can walk on one side of a street and not the other side?
EUGENE ROBICHAUX: Examples. They make examples of people. They catch somebody and kill 'em and then you know: don't be over on this side.
Q.: Are you afraid that you could be the next victim?
MARIANA: I'm afraid. Right now it's a dispute between these two guys, a rivalry over two gangs. My brother said he was sitting in a barbershop and they came in there and shot through the window. . . . It gets to the point where I don't walk up that block no more because I heard the guys that cut hair there, they've got to wear bulletproof vests.
SHAWN: I got one.
Q.: Where did you get a bulletproof vest?
SHAWN: My uncle.
Kareem said that he also has a bulletproof vest that he bought for "a buck fifty" -- that is, $150 -- after telling his mother he needed the money for new sneakers.
KAREEM: I wear it on Fridays and Saturdays. . . . Sometimes I wear it when I'm going off my block, out my projects. Like if I'm going to Bed-Stuy to see this other chick, I wear my vest.
Q.: Isn't that an awful way to have to live, to have to wear a bulletproof vest when you leave home for parties or dates?
KAREEM: No, if you want to be safe.
Q.: Why don't you carry a gun?
KAREEM: Cause you'll get arrested for carrying a gun, not for wearing a bulletproof vest.
Q.: What about a knife?
KAREEM: I don't carry no knife. What am I going to do: stab the bullet?
Thomas Jefferson High School's reputation is now one of violence and hopelessness. It bothers many of the students that outsiders make no distinction between those who are thugs and those who are struggling to make it.
SHAWN: When you go out on the street, like, and say if a guy wants to talk to a girl, you tell them you go to Jeff, or vice-versa, if the girl say that she go to Jeff, then guys get queery and go, "Never mind. I don't want to talk to her." They want to change directions on you when you tell them what school you go to. They think you're part of the violence in the school.
Given its reputation -- one that goes back to when some of the students parents were there in the 1960's and 1970's -- and given the reality of life in East New York, few said they were surprised that two students could be shot to death in their school, even on a day the building was crawling with extra security guards and police officers in preparation for a visit by the Mayor.
AYANNA ROSS: Why would you be surprised? Look at the people that's in there.
MAESHAY LEWIS: It's like you have all these people from different areas like four blocks down, six blocks over, whatever . . . and they don't get along. It doesn't have anything to do with the school. It's like what happened during the summertime, during a vacation or on a weekend or something, and everyone comes into this one building and that's where it all just boils up.
KAREEM: It's a lot of guys in Jeff that think they're tough guys. They just want to be hardrocks.
MAESHAY: Like most of us here are involved in a lot of academic things and stay after school for certain things. People are like: "I'm not with that. You crazy? I'm not staying after school. What I look like doing that?" Everybody feel like they're going to be less of a man, less of a something, or they're not going to be down because they're trying to do something positive. It's like: "That's corny. You know you're never going to get anywhere." They all feel that it's hopeless. They feel that they're not going to get anything out of it.
But Shawn Cameron said he was surprised at the most recent shootings and, like many of his fellow students, angry that the Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, had failed them.
SHAWN: I was surprised because the school should have learned its lesson when the first guy got shot and Fernandez made a speech about how this won't happen and he was going to improve the security in the school, but three months later, there are two more people that's shot inside the school.
LARRY: If it wasn't for him, none of this would have happened. If he had tight, tight security. When Darrell Sharpe got shot, he should have put in security every day, not no once a week.
Q.: So do you all have faith in the Chancellor?
NORVEN: I don't have faith in no one. We can't depend on someone to protect us. We've got to protect ourselves. If we get searched in the doorway and we get outside and somebody got beef with us, we don't have nothing to protect ourselves. It's like we gone be killed.
[LAUGHTER]:
NORVEN: It ain't funny.
None of the students thought the metal detectors would improve safety or help save lives.
RETISHA MYATT: They might catch some of the people with the weapons, but if something's gone happen to you, it's gone happen to you. You can't stop it.
MAESHAY: It may not happen in the building, but it can happen when they come out the building, on the way to the building.
MARIANA: They have all these cops walking around with guns. One of the students may take it from them and use it on the other ones.
The daily presence of the metal detectors and the newly enforced rules about who can be in the hallways is succeeding in one thing: making even the good kids angry. They refer to the hallway pass they need just to go to the bathroom as "the Rikers Island pass."
SHAWN: Kids shouldn't have to come to school and get searched. It's like you're a common criminal in New York.
But there is a more deeply rooted anger that seems to lead to an ever-escalating level of violence. 
Q.: Why are people so angry, angry enough to kill?
SHAWN: The main reason is somebody in their family probably got shot or got murdered, and they just go out and have revenge on everybody they don't like.
RETISHA: I think it's peer pressure. It's a lot of guys that hang around other people just to be in the crowd. . . . Some people just got guns to have them and then a lot of them use them. Then the ones that do use them don't know how to use them. That's how a lot of innocent bystanders get killed, too.
Everyone wants some kind of "rep" or reputation -- and one way to earn one for being tough is to carry a gun, the teen-agers said. No one wants to be seen as a "herb" or wimp. 
SEAN: If a guy steps on your foot, it's one of your peers says, "Oh, you gone let that happen to you? He stepped on your foot." You know, you have the right mind that's like, "I'm gone ignore that." But your friend says, "You ain't gone do nothing about that?" That puts you to the limit. You be like "Ahh, what I'm gone do?" It gets you thinking and you say something: "Yo, what the hell are you doing?" or something like that. You start, you know, to break.
NATHANIEL EDWARDS: Say I was walking in the hallway and somebody bumped me and they meant to bump me. And now, me, I'm the herb. I will turn and I will walk away from them. Next day, he gone bump me again. Now it's a Friday, right? And he comes and bump me and he says, "Yo, what's up, man? If you keep walking away, we'll keep bothering you." . . . You can fight right there, but a gun gone come in sooner or later.
Disputes can start over what the teen-agers acknowledge to be "the stupidest things." Kareem Smith said he almost fought a friend who tried to grab his cheeseburger. Others have fought when someone stepped on their sneakers or looked at them the wrong way. Rumors -- "he said, she said," as Kenaisha Warren put it -- also lead to "beef." 
KAREEM: You get beef on a basketball court over a call or something. Be ready to fight. . . . People got shot over basketball right there at Gershwin. Got shot dead. Two times in the head. It wasn't in school but it was after they had played basketball.
Q.: Did you transfer to Jeff because you caught beef in Flatbush?
LARRY: In a way, yeah. They was threatening me and I didn't want to get killed. I'm too young to die.
Q.: Is there a difference in the way that girls settle disputes and the way that boys do?
NATHANIEL: Boys shoot and fight once in a while. But girls? When they get mad at each other, they all gone jump, a group jump one girl, or they get razors and they go and slice up the girl.
One way to assure status and protection is to join a "posse." Larry said that he was a member of V.I.P. until two years ago and, among other things, they stole money from kids who earned tips bagging groceries. 
MARIANA: Over here they don't really call it gangs. It's a posse. In L.A. it's a gang. But it's the same thing.
NATHANIEL: In L.A., right, they've got gangs and everybody is a brother and nobody will turn on nobody. But see out here, it's like they're all associates. Say we're all cool right now and then I would find a reason not to like him and then we're not cool no more and me and him got a beef. In gangs that don't happen. In gangs they're all brothers.
Members of posses are expected to seek revenge for any harm that comes to their friends.
KAREEM: If I can't get you and I see your boy, I'm tearing him up.

Thomas Jefferson has now become somewhat synonymous with the worst of urban education. And that bothers those who think of themselves as the "good kids," including seniors who have been applying for college.

GLOSSARY
 Posse: A loose association young people organized by projects, by blocks or even by subway stations.
 Got beef: To "have beef" with someone means you have an argument or feud. Beefs typically are setlled only by a confrontation involving weapons.
 Chill: To relax.
 Props: Either weapons or people used for protection.
 Juice: Power.
 Dolo: To be solo or on one's own.
 Trom: A term for marijuana. It comes from the word traumatize, which students say is the effect of marijauna.
 Herb: A weak person who is easily intimidated.
 Skid-bid: Time served in prison or juvenile detention.
 Lo-life: Young people with a reputation for stealing the clothes of Ralph Lauren, designer of the Polo, or "lo," line.
 Burner -- A gun.

HEADLINE: William E. Simkin Is Dead at 85; Federal Labor Mediator in 1960's

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
William E. Simkin, who helped prevent national strikes and resolved thousands of labor disputes as the Federal Government's chief labor mediator and as a leading private arbitrator, died on Wednesday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 85 years old.
He died of natural causes, his family said. 
 Mr. Simkin was the longest-serving director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, from 1961 to 1969. He expanded its scope and influence and played a critical role in averting or settling strikes in vital industries like airlines, automobile manufacturing and steel mills.
As the Government's chief labor peacemaker, he projected a soothing image that fit the part. A pipe smoker and lifelong Quaker, he was unflappable and patient and spoke with a deep but slow and soft voice. The labor mediator Theodore W. Kheel called him "a giant among neutrals in labor relations, who was trusted by both sides and had that essential ingredient of common sense."
 
Called Out of Retirement
 As a private arbitrator, Mr. Simkin was entrusted by labor and management in some of America's biggest businesses with deciding critical but deadlocked issues. The companies included Goodyear, Greyhound, National Can, Bethlehem Steel and others in the automobile, newspaper and clothing industries.
In the 1970's, Mr. Simkin was called out of retirement to grapple with a nearly century-old Indian tribal rivalry between the Navajos and Hopis over two million acres in Arizona. He helped resolve the dispute.
Born in Merrifield, N.Y., Mr. Simkin grew up in nearby Poplar Ridge. He graduated from Earlham College, where he was student president.
In 1928 he became principal of the high school in Sherwood, N.Y.. From 1930-32 he taught science at the Friends School in Brooklyn while studying economics at Columbia University.
His career evolved when he went to the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania from 1937-39 as an instructor and student under Dr. George W. Taylor, who became his mentor and asked him to help arbitrate a dispute in the hosiery industry. He began arbitrating full time, with a break from 1942-45 working for the National War Labor Board, heading its shipbuilding and steel commissions.
President John F. Kennedy appointed him mediation director, and President Lyndon B. Johnson retained him.
At the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, he stressed preventive programs to settle disputes before they became crises, started joint training of management and labor officers on grievances, revived a labor-management panel to help settle strikes and strengthened relations with state mediators.
He taught at Harvard University's business school from 1969-73 and wrote a major book in his field, "Mediation and the Dynamics of Collective Bargaining" (B.N.A., 1971). He was a former president of the National Academy of Arbitrators.
He is survived by his wife, the former Ruth Commons; two sons, Thomas, of Arlington, Va., and Peter, of Seattle; a brother, Robert, of Poplar Ridge, six grandchildren and three great grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Cambodia Mission Chief Sees Team as a Catalyst

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6

 BODY:
His job is unparalleled in the annals of the United Nations. When Yasushi Akashi leaves New York this weekend for Cambodia as a special representative of Secretary General Boutros Ghali, his assignment is to bring new economic and political life to the killing fields.
As head of the newly created United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia, Mr. Akashi will lead a team of thousands of professionals and volunteers who will oversee every aspect of Cambodian life from the police to banking, while setting the stage for elections in 1993. 
 "This is the most dramatic instance of what the international community can do in the post-cold-war age," Mr. Akashi said in an interview this week after meeting Congressional skeptics and critics of the mission. "If we can overcome this challenge, the U.N. will come out a much stronger body."
Setting up a transitional international administration in Cambodia is the most ambitious and expensive project of its kind undertaken by the United Nations, with a budget likely to run into billions. The team will work with the Supreme National Council drawn from the four warring Cambodian factions that signed a peace treaty in October.
The appointment of Mr. Akashi, a 61-year-old career United Nations official and author, also illustrates the growing visibility of Japan and a new breed of Japanese internationalists in United Nations operations.
As he arranges the return of at least 360,000 Cambodian exiles, Mr. Akashi will work with Sadako Ogata, a fellow citizen who is now the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. They speak to each other frequently, in Japanese, though both are also fluent in English and French.
 
Cambodia as Japanese Outlet
 "Japanese interest in Cambodia is extensive and genuine," Mr. Akashi said. "We want to show our sense of international responsibility."
He plans to stop in Tokyo on his way to Phnom Penh to make a few motivating speeches. "Cambodia is a good outlet for Japanese with humanitarian concerns," he said.
"This appointment clearly signals the arrival of Japan on the international stage as a major player in the resolution of regional conflicts," said Representative Stephen J. Solarz of New York, chairman of the House subcommittee on East Asia and the Pacific.
"If this is coupled with Japan's willingness to contribute more to the peacekeeping operation, that would be a great accomplishment," said the Brooklyn Democrat, who is a strong supporter of a full appropriation for the Cambodia effort.
"What is at stake here is the fate of a nation that has suffered more than any other in the 20th century," Mr. Solarz said after meeting Mr. Akashi.
In the Senate, Frank R. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said the United Nations had found the right person for a historic task.
Mr. Akashi speaks with a sense of urgency.
"The rainy season is coming in May, and this will hamper movement," he said. "And we have to bring in everything from outside, from vehicles to office equipment to prefabricated buildings."
In a country saturated by war, the United Nations team will have to disarm 200,000 troops and an equal number of militia members. It will have to find and destroy arms caches and root out mines. All of this will have to be achieved in an atmosphere where lawlessness is increasing, Mr. Akashi said.
A health care system, schools, a press, broadcasting and banks -- all targets of the Khmer Rouge and to some extent the Vietnamese-backed Communists who followed -- will have to be rebuilt from scratch. An electoral system and government institutions have to be created.
More than 12,000 United Nations staff members have volunteered to go to Cambodia with Mr. Akashi, who has been Under Secretary General for disarmanent affairs and Under Secretary for public information. He called their willingness to take posts of extreme hardship "touching and moving." In most cases, families will not accompany them.
Mr. Akashi sees his job as an opportunity for the United Nations to learn on the job how to deal with local conflicts.
Conscious of the need to preserve what fragile sense of national sovereignty has survived in that battered nation of seven million people, he insists that his team will limit itself to acting as a catalyst for Cambodians, who will have to do much of the work of rehabilitating their country. Many experts fear that so large an international presence will foster a sense of dependency.
"We cannot replace Cambodians," he said. "We have the opportunity to create a democracy that we and they devise for them. But they have to know that we cannot be there for good."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Prices Fall; Jobs Data Have Little Effect

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against most leading currencies yesterday in choppy trading. The foreign exchange markets reacted with ambivalence to new United States economic statistics.
Gold prices moved modestly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $349.50 an ounce, down $1.90 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $349.25, down $2.20 from Thursday. 
 An eagerly awaited report on February employment failed to inspire prolonged buying or selling of the dollar.
Figures released in the morning, showing the nation's business payrolls expanded by an unexpectedly large 164,000 jobs, touched off a temporary round of dollar buying abroad and at home. But the buying proved short-lived.
Other data in the Labor Department report offset the positive economic implications of the February growth in non-farm payrolls, the strongest gain since May 1990.
The department reported that the nation's unemployment rate rose to 7.3 percent in February, from 7.1 percent in January, the highest rate since July 1985.
Dealings in the dollar slowed by the afternoon in New York.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 131.63 Japanese yen, down from 132.00 yen at the Thursday close. Later, in London, the dollar rose to 131.65 yen. By the time trading ended in New York, the dollar was quoted at 131.85 yen, down from 131.90 yen late Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7200, from $1.7165 late Thursday. The pound brought $1.7190 late in New York, compared with $1.7170 late Thursday.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6690 German marks, down from 1.6720; 1.5155 Swiss francs, down from 1.5260; 5.6700 French francs, down from 5.6820; 1,251.00 Italian lire, down from 1,253.50, and 1.1914 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18725.
Gold prices were lower overseas, as well as in domestic trading. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $349.60 an ounce, from $350.65 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $349.50, from $350.50 late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped 22 cents, to $351.25.
Silver posted small gains. Bullion settled at $4.152 an ounce on the Comex, up from $4.133 on Thursday. Silver rose in London to a late bid of $4.16 an ounce, up from $4.14.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Saying Clinton Is Cynical, Tsongas Goes on the Attack

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6

 BODY:
Paul E. Tsongas unleashed his harshest attack yet tonight against Bill Clinton, assailing his Democratic rival as a "pander bear" who "will say anything, do anything to get votes."
Taking the offensive four days before Florida's high-stakes primary on Tuesday, Mr. Tsongas landed here after campaigning in the West and immediately declared that "we're going to take the gloves off." He went on to say "the American people are going to find out how cynical and unprincipled Bill Clinton is." 
 The former Massachusetts Senator said he was largely reacting to Mr. Clinton's comments at a debate Thursday night in Dallas, where the Arkansas Governor said he would support development of the Seawolf submarine, an attack submarine.
 
'Only to Win Votes'
 The Navy had originally planned to buy three or four Seawolfs a year. But the program's size has been cut sharply, so that the Navy will buy no more than one Seawolf a year.
He said Mr. Clinton knew that the Seawolf "won't be built" but supported its development "only to win votes" in Connecticut, where it is manufactured.
"I'm glad he did it now," Mr. Tsongas said, "so people see the real Bill Clinton for what he is."
At an airport news conference in Nashville tonight, Mr. Clinton said he had always supported building additional Seawolf submarines. "Why would I be pandering to the voters in Connecticut? If they're not going to vote for Senator Tsongas, nobody is. And they're not voting anytime soon." The Connecticut Presidential primary is March 24.
"It wasn't me who went to New York and said I'd be the best friend Wall Street ever had," Mr. Clinton said of the accusation of pandering. "It was Senator Tsongas."
 Mr. Tsongas also lashed out at Mr. Clinton, who on Thursday said in Denver that "We can not put our fairness under the guise of promising growth. It won't work, it's not America." The remark was erroneously quoted in some news accounts as, "It's not American," prompting part of Mr. Tsongas's harsh attack on Mr. Clinton.
"To say my economic plan is not American," Mr. Tsongas said. "That's a code word. There's nothing more cynical -- it's the ultimate example of cynicism." He also said that "people who are ethnic will understand what I am talking about."
Mr. Tsongas's comments to reporters tonight on the airport tarmac here signaled a new aggressiveness from a candidate who has repeatedly condemned Mr. Clinton and others for negative campaigning.
His attack also shows that Mr. Tsongas is seizing on an offensive strategy to win votes in Florida on Tuesday, the Southern state where his campaign advisers believes he has his best chance for an upset victory against Mr. Clinton, who is favored in most of the 11 contests that day.
With its large population of transplants from the Northeast and large Greek-American enclaves, Mr. Tsongas believes he can do well here.
"This is going to be a real battle," Mr. Tsongas said, "and boy am I ready."
Mr. Tsongas's attack came on the same day that his campaign launched a television attack on Mr. Clinton in Florida. In a 30-second commercial, the Tsongas campaign goes after Mr. Clinton, with the announcer saying "some people will say anything to be elected President."
Mr. Tsongas defended the commercial at a news conference in Phoenix earlier today. "It's not a change in strategy," he said. "We are simply responding. I'm simply in a counterpunch mode. He attacks and I have to respond."
Gerald Austin, a senior aide to Mr. Tsongas, said he had no apologies for the campaign's newfound aggressivness. "A campaign is a war," he said.
Mr. Tsongas was clearly aiming his attack at the local television news shows when he arrived in Florida. In an interview aboard the plane, he mentioned Mr. Clinton's citing of Seawolf at the debate but was not nearly as heated in his criticism. He also said he felt ncomfortable with the attack advertisements his campaign was preparing.
But, he said, "If I don't respond people will say this is Dukakis revisited."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Economic Roots;
Tsongas's Passion: Restoring Hometown to Glory

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 29

 BODY:
The day before the New Hampshire Presidential primary, Paul E. Tsongas, wearing a battered jacket and baseball cap, sat down in an ice cream parlor in his hometown here to review plans for a bookstore envisioned as the centerpiece of a downtown renovation plan.
When he learned that the project was stalled, Mr. Tsongas was incensed, and immediately called the official who was holding it up. Suddenly the logjam was broken. 
 "It shows Tsongas's state of mind, that he could be thinking about this the day before he won the New Hampshire primary," said Kendall M. Wallace, the general manager of The Lowell Sun, who was with Mr. Tsongas in the ice cream shop that day. "His roots go very deep here, and he's a very driven man who can be very tough when he thinks he's right."
For more than two decades, since he first entered politics as a member of the City Council in 1969, Mr. Tsongas has been the driving force behind the rebirth of Lowell, a city of 103,000 people about 30 miles northwest of Boston, say a variety of local residents, both friends and critics.
And Mr. Tsongas's experiences here have also shaped his pro-business political philosophy, with its stress on economic growth to rebuild America. In his 86-page campaign manifesto, "A Call to Economic Arms," Mr. Tsongas wrote that his memories of Lowell's decline "left me with an inability to view economic dislocation casually."
 
'Paul Was a Visionary'
 Once the nation's largest manufacturing center, Lowell sank into slow decline after World War I as its prosperous textiles companies moved south in search of cheaper labor and its cavernous red brick mills were left standing empty.
"A lot of people had lost faith in the city and were discouraged," said James L. Milinazzo, a former city planner who has been involved in the restoration of Lowell since 1978. "But Paul was a visionary, a person with ideas, who also wasn't afraid of playing hardball when he had to."
Mr. Tsongas has conducted his drive to revive Lowell -- some say it is an obsession -- no matter where he has been: first as a member of the City Council, then as a member of the United States House of Representatives, later as a Senator and since 1984 as a private citizen of Lowell.
Among the crusade's accomplishments, it has attracted almost $600 million in private and government investment, more than half of it private; it has enticed new high-tech companies to locate here, and it has spurred the creation, in the city's crumbling downtown, of the first urban National Park. The park, financed originally by $40 million from the Federal Government under a bill sponsored by Mr. Tsongas when he was a Senator, now includes eight renovated mill buildings recreating the mills, the water wheels and canals around them and the city in the 19th century. Last year the park brought 711,748 tourists to Lowell.
 
Bringing in Investment
 Together with several local officials, Mr. Tsongas devised a number of imaginative schemes to increase investment in Lowell and insure that local businesses participated in the city's reconstruction. First, the Lowell Development and Financial Corporation, a joint public-private group, was formed in 1975 when Mr. Tsongas persuaded the city's 11 banks to put up about $300,000, or one-twentieth of 1 percent of their assets, toward a fund for improving the blighted downtown. At the time, the banks were the unhappy owners of numerous foreclosed factories and homes, but individually they were powerless to revive Lowell.
"It was a very innovative idea, to get bankers who had never worked together before to do something for the good of the city," said Jim Cook, the corporation's executive director.
In 1978 came the move to establish the National Park, and to persuade Wang Laboratories, then a booming high-tech business, to locate in downtown Lowell.
The final piece of the revitalization effort came in 1979, when Senator Tsongas and the city manager, Joseph Tully, sat in a local restaurant and drew up a master plan for the city on a place mat. Out of these ideas grew a permanent planning agency known as the Lowell Plan, which shares some of its functions and staff members with the Lowell Development and Financial Corporation.
Both groups have focused on winning Federal Urban Development Action grants for Lowell, then devising ways to use the money to attract private investment. For example, when Mr. Tsongas wanted to persuade Wang to build its headquarters in the city's new industrial park, the development corporation got a $5 million Federal grant that it then loaned to Wang as an inducement, Mr. Cook said.
In the last decade Lowell has received about $50 million in similar Federal grants, which have also been used in the construction of a large parking garage, a 250-room Hilton Hotel and the rehabilitation of old houses around the city for affordable housing, said Mr. Cook.
Today the corporation's initial capital of $300,000 has been expanded to $28 million, making the agency a significant force in the city.
In addition to the mechanisms the planners devised to attract money to the city, Mr. Tsongas himself maintained a forceful presence. Both in Lowell and in Washington, he met with business leaders regularly to goad them into keeping the momentum for redevelopment going.
Mr. Tsongas's forcefulness has also produced some enemies. "He was a United States Senator becoming an officious meddler in local affairs," said Henry Mroz, a former school superintendent, who accuses Mr. Tsongas of being behind a campaign to force him out of office in a dispute over what to do with an empty school building. "He wanted to have his finger in the pie in every aspect."
Despite Wang's troubles, most people here acknowledge that Lowell is far better off than it would have been without the redevelopment effort led by Mr. Tsongas.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Journal;
Candidates' Big Hurdle: Conversation

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, March 6

 BODY:
The Democratic candidates for President were forced to confront a new and startling challenge Thursday night. At the start of their nationally televised debate, Peter Jennings of ABC News said he wanted to curtail his role as moderator and let the candidates take charge.
"We have decided that this evening," he said, "as much as possible they shall conduct their own debate, that they should be the ones to press each other for specific answers." 
 Conduct a debate? Press each other for answers? But this meant they would actually have to listen to other humans and ask questions. These skills tend to atrophy in powerful politicians. By the time they become Presidential candidates they have been pontificating for so long to so many captive audiences that they have lost the ability to carry on a polite conversation.
 
A Rarew Opportunity
 So the debate presented a rare opportunity to see who could talk with, not at, people. It would have been even more interesting if ABC had succeeded in its plan to let the candidates conduct the debate with virtually no supervision. But that last-minute proposal so unnerved the candidates that some threatened to walk out, and Mr. Jennings agreed to provide some questions and guidance.
Generally, though, he let them talk at will. What they said was familiar, but the way they said it was not. And after 90 minutes, perhaps the question to ask was: Which of these men would you be willing to sit down with to continue the discussion? For many viewers that would probably be Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. Sometimes he talked too much, but at least he seemed to enjoy taking part in a discussion.
By contrast, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts was the debater most likely to get ditched by everyone else after the debate. In previous debates Mr. Tsongas's lack of glibness had seemed appealing because of the way he combined self-deprecating humor, a silly smile and a thoughtful, confident zeal as he explained why America needed his economic plan. But on Thursday he skipped the humor, and the zeal turned into self-righteousness.
Instead of smiling, he wagged his finger incessantly and sternly delivered long-winded sermons. He looked primly imperious when the others criticized him. Instead of debating differences in economic policies, as Mr. Clinton tried to do, Mr. Tsongas tended to meander off and offer platitudes.
Mr. Jennings tried vainly to have Mr. Tsongas deal with Mr. Clinton's criticism of his proposed cut in the capital gains tax. "Can you at least address the question of what he has to say about your economic proposals?" Mr. Jennings asked. "He says you sound like President Bush."
"Well," Mr. Tsongas replied, "I was endorsed Sunday by The Atlanta Constitution. That's not a newspaper in my backyard. What they said was that I had a pro-growth, economic growth policy with a progressive social agenda."
What The Atlanta Constitution had to do with the capital gains tax or anything else was not clear. Nor was it clear a few minutes later when Mr. Tsongas had an exchange with former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, an exchange remarkable in that it is the sort of thing that passes for conversation between politicians.
"You are taking a pro-business position," Mr. Tsongas said, after Mr. Brown described his flat-tax proposal.
"Accompanied with my pro-justice, pro-empowerment-of-working-people position," Mr. Brown replied.
"Well, I quote The Atlanta Constitution when they endorse me: pro-economic growth with a progressive social agenda," Mr. Tsongas replied. "I'm proud of that. I'm very proud of that."
Mr. Brown's recent victory in the Colorado primary did not seem to have diminished his indignation at the political system. But most of the time Mr. Brown seemed only to be getting in the way, because he kept interrupting to issue and vague promises that were undebatable. How do you argue with someone who claims to be "pro-justice"?
Overnight ratings from metropolitan areas showed that the debate attracted 18 percent of the television audience, tying with the "Tonight Show" on NBC for the first half hour and ahead of the other two networks for the remaining hour.
 
Clinton's Best Performance
 The candidate likely to benefit most from that exposure is probably Mr. Clinton. In the previous debates he had come across as the most poised and articulate of the candidates, and Thursday may have been his best performance yet.
Like the others, Mr. Clinton may have spent most of the 90 minutes reciting parts of his standard speech, but at least he made a pretense of packaging the excerpts as answers to questions.
His enthusiasm was sometimes off-putting, and it became downright incredible toward the end of the debate, when he said that he wished Senator Bob Kerrey, who ended his candidacy Thursday, was still with them.
It was difficult to believe Mr. Clinton really wished his one-time rival was still there to share the microphone, but it was unusually polite. He deserved some credit just for being aware of Mr. Kerrey's absence from the discussion. Many politicians would never have have noticed there was one less person in the room for them to talk at.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Another Candidate?;
Billionaire in Texas Is Attracting Calls to Run, and $5 Donations

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
For the umpteenth time, H. Ross Perot is insisting that he does not want to be President. But by opening the door a tiny crack to his possible candidacy in this election year, the Texas billionaire is attracting telephone calls, letters and money to his Dallas office -- all urging him to run.
Call it just one more sign of voter disaffection with Washington politics as usual. In any case, Mr. Perot will probably not be appearing in television commercials, kissing babies or standing in front of an American flag, bemoaning the Federal deficit. 
 "I'm not going to be one of these people who hires handlers and image makers," Mr. Perot said. "What you see is what you get."
Theoretically, anyone from any state who wishes to support him as an independent candidate still has enough time to sign a petition calling for his name to be placed on the Presidential ballot. The earliest deadline is in Texas on May 11.
Mr. Perot's "candidacy," if it could even be called that, grew out of his appearance on the CNN program "Larry King Live" on Feb. 20. Since selling the data processing company he founded to the General Motors Corporation in 1984 for $2.5 billion, Mr. Perot has frequently spoken out publicly in favor of political and economic change.
Mr. King and callers questioned Mr. Perot about why he does not run for political office if he feels so strongly that the nation's economy and education system need fixing.
After stating several times during the talk show that he was not interested in becoming a politician, Mr. Perot, 61 years old, finally hedged his refusal. "If voters in all 50 states put me on the ballot -- not 48 or 49 states, but all 50 -- I will agree to run," he said. He also said he would not accept more than $5 from each supporter.
A week after appearing on the talk show Mr. Perot's secretary, Sally Bell, said that she had received calls from people in 46 states promising support, as well as many $5 contributions.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Blacks;
Clinton's Talk of Racial Unity Falls on Eager Ears

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., March 6

 BODY:
Oleta Hill, 36 years old, went to see Bill Clinton the other day in Jacksonville, Fla., in a quandary. She had voted for Jesse Jackson in the past and had not yet heard enough about any of the candidates to form a hard opinion on whom to vote for next Tuesday.
So Ms. Hill, an engineering clerk with BellSouth Telecommunications, was surprised when she heard the Arkansas Governor speak at a lunchtime forum. 
 "If he really believes what he's saying, we've got the ticket," said Ms. Hill, who is black. "His being a white person, I was surprised to hear it."
What Ms. Hill heard that day, layered within Mr. Clinton's basic economic campaign speech, was talk of racial unity that strikes a chord with black voters unaccustomed to hearing such appeals stated so unambiguously by white Presidential candidates.
 
Sounding Like Jackson
 "I began to hear a little Jesse Jackson coming out in him," she said.
Mr. Clinton, who received 70 percent of the black vote in Georgia and 55 percent of the black vote in Maryland on Tuesday, is in a position to inherit what is left of Mr. Jackson's 1988 support. But there is a flip side. Without Mr. Jackson in the race, as surveys of voters in Georgia showed, many black voters might simply stay at home.
Even so, Mr. Clinton decided early that he would undertake what amounts to a naked plea for black votes that some black officials and black audiences have found appealing, even when the Governor is asked to justify his position on issues like capital punishment and welfare changes, on which he differs with many prominent blacks.
He explains away these differences by noting that the death penalty, which he favors, more often punishes those who commit crimes against black people, and that his plan, in which he advocates making more recipients work, is based on suggestions he has received from people on welfare.
It is the sort of political finesse that Mr. Clinton brings to many thorny matters and on which he must increasingly rely to hold his Southern support base.
"Every time we have permitted ourselves to be divided by race in this region, we have been kept dumb and poor," he said at a recent speech at traditionally black Morehouse College in Atlanta, repeating a line that always draws applause from white and black audiences in the South. "The cheap politics of division in the 1980's have kept America divided."
By assiduously courting black politicians like Representative John Lewis of Georgia, Baltimore Mayor Kurt Schmoke and Representative Maxine Waters of California, all former supporters of Mr. Jackson, Mr. Clinton has sought to lay claim to a credibility on matters of race that has so far eluded his Democratic rivals.
Mr. Schmoke, for example, recently vouched for Mr. Clinton at his church in Baltimore by talking of the summers he spent with his grandparents in Hope, Ark., a small town where Bill Clinton happened to be growing up. Mr. Schmoke recalled standing in segregated lines to get into the movies and watching as white youngsters entered and sat separately.
"I wonder if, irony of ironies, one of those times when I went to the movies there, he was on one line and I was on the other," Mr. Schmoke said.
When Mr. Schmoke endorsed Mr. Clinton that day, evoking memories of segregation, and then going on to praise Mr. Clinton for rising above the racial limits of his Southern upbringing, he played into one of the candidate's recurring themes: that he can appeal to both black and white voters.
 
Pragmatism Among Blacks
 Mr. Lewis told the audience at Morehouse that Mr. Clinton would "inspire those who have been left out and left behind," adding: "He will move us all ahead. With this man, no one, absolutely no one, will be left behind."
Much of this support is rooted in cold-eyed pragmatism. Many black politicians and campaign workers reached political maturity after laboring in two Jackson campaigns and were unwilling to sit out this year. Mr. Clinton, they figured, at least talked about black people.
"Bill Clinton and I may not agree on every little thing, but we do agree on one thing," Representative Waters said last week at a Beverly Hills fund-raiser. "Bill Clinton can beat George Bush, and can take back the White House."
"I am committed to a mission of success this year," Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta said last week. "I believe we do not have another four years to wait around."
And now that the field has narrowed, with the withdrawal of Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who attracted a small number of black supporters, the choices seem even more limited for some black voters.
Only Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, whose South Carolina primary strategy depends on winning former Jesse Jackson supporters, has competed for black voters as energetically as Mr. Clinton. But his campaign is running out of money and has failed to catch fire across the board.
And Mr. Tsongas, when asked about civil rights, invariably talks about his Peace Corps experience in Ethiopia. Mr. Clinton, by contrast, talks about growing up in the segregated South.
"I just never took Tsongas seriously," said Gregory A. Samms, a lawyer who helped escort Mr. Clinton on a walking tour through Miami's predominantly black Liberty City neighborhood on Wednesday.
After hearing Mr. Clinton speak last week, Terrence Johnson, a Morehouse junior from Fort Wayne, Ind., said, "A lot of black people migrated from the South and know that tradition."
The Governor alluded to that strength today at a Dallas news conference. "I believe that the connections are deep and strong," he said when asked about his support among blacks who live in or migrated from the South.
Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker, predicted: "In the end, black voters are going to vote cultural affinity and acute economic distress. Paul Tsongas has nothing to say to poor voters."
Mr. Clinton recognizes the potential that the black vote could hold for him this time. When his state government schedule forced him to return to Little Rock last week, he sneaked away on the night of the South Dakota primary to attend a meeting of black church leaders in Memphis.
There he heard the Rev. Kenneth S. Robinson, the pastor of St. Andrew A.M.E. Church, exhort a sanctuary crowded with members of the clergy in a sermon titled "Use What You Got to Get What You Want." The sermon was really about Moses and Pharaoh, but Dr. Robinson did not miss the chance to note the reason Mr. Clinton was there.
"You got political power," he said, as the ministers murmured in assent. "That's why we have a guest here tonight. We've got power."
Mr. Clinton fares especially well in black churches, where he adopts some of the rhythmic cadence of black preaching and injects references from Scripture into his standard speech and refers easily to his own most recent political troubles. "The Scripture says, let him who is without sin cast the first stone," he said at a Memphis worship service last week. "All I can say is, in the last month, I've met a lot of perfect people."
Mr. Clinton has said that he considers himself "uniquely qualified" to deal with racial divisions. Many of his black supporters are less lofty in their assessments of why they will work for Mr. Clinton.
"I'm interested now in getting back to the White House," said Calvin Smyrie, a black Georgia state representative and former Jackson supporter. "Anything that distracts me from that, I will not tolerate."

HEADLINE: New York City Jobless: 10.9%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Unemployment in New York City, a dismal picture throughout the recession, hit 10.9 percent in February, the highest level for that month in 16 years, the Government reported yesterday. With 89,000 more people joining jobless rolls, February unemployment in New York State and New Jersey also rose to their highest levels in nine years.
Experts said the grim unemployment figures reflected a continuing weak economic performance in the region and warned that the numbers were likely to get worse before getting better. 
 "We're not seeing any bottoming out," Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said in releasing the figures. "It's more of a problem in New York City, but to a large extent it involves the entire region. In New Jersey, things looked better in January. These numbers are something of a setback."
The New York City unemployment rate, which is not seasonally adjusted, has been swollen by the loss of 50,000 jobs in the private sector in the last three months. It rose by half a percentage point in February, from 10.4 percent in January -- the highest level for a February since 1976, and up by almost 50 percent in the last year, from 7.3 percent in February 1991.
"The city is still posting hefty declines," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "No sector is able to buck the tide of decline, and the tide shows no sign of yet turning."
In New York State, the unemployment rate in February rose half a percentage point, to 8.9 percent from 8.4 percent in January and 6.2 percent one year ago. Mr. Ehrenhalt said the ranks of the unemployed in the state grew by 39,000 last month to more than 200,000 in the last year.
In New Jersey, unemployment increased by eight-tenths of a percentage point last month, to 7.6 percent from 6.8 percent in January and 6.3 percent a year ago. It was the state's worst February figure since 1983, and the biggest change in the national report among the 11 biggest states. Mr. Ehrenhalt said 35,000 people joined the unemployment rolls last month, 60 percent of the 58,000 who lost their jobs in New Jersey in the last year.

HEADLINE: Bush Seeks Rules to Lift Sales of Gas

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
President Bush announced his support yesterday for four regulatory changes that he said would raise demand for natural gas and help an industry that has been badly hurt by low prices.
The gas industry applauded the announcement, which came shortly before the primary election in Texas, a leading gas-producing state. But environmentalists and consumer advocates said it was not clear whether the changes, all of them under discussion in Washington for months or years, would mean that more gas would be sold, at least in the near future. They also said that one proposed change could cut gas sales and increase pollution. 
 The changes are intended to lower costs or remove regulatory barriers. They could result in greater use of natural gas in cars and power plants.
 
2 Problems Not Addressed
 Edwin Rothschild, an energy expert at Citizen Action, a consumer organization, said some of the proposed changes were desirable because they would promote use of natural-gas vehicles, lowering pollution and reliance on imported oil. But the natural-gas industry's real problems, he said, are two phenomena beyond White House control: warm weather and recession.
"I don't see this as stimulating a lot of demand quickly," he said.
But the president of the American Gas Association, Michael Baly 3d, said his industry was "deeply grateful."
Possibly the least controversial proposal was the President's announcement that the Environmental Protection Agency would soon issue an emissions standard for natural-gas vehicles that would help them compete. Federal standards for gasoline vehicles set a limit on hydrocarbon emissions as a way to control smog, but proponents of natural-gas vehicles complain that natural gas itself, while a hydrocarbon, is not an ingredient of smog. So the E.P.A. will issue a standard for emissions of hydrocarbons other than natural gas.
There are now no standards for the vehicles. Mr. Baly of the gas association said yesterday, "If you want to start mass-producing these, major equipment manufacturers want a standard."
 
 
A Greenhouse Gas
 But even if emissions of unburned natural gas do not contribute to smog, they are still a pollutant, environmentalists say, because natural gas is a greenhouse gas, contributing to global warming.
David G. Hawkins, an air-pollution expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council, said that allowing natural-gas emissions because they did not cause smog was "an example of tunnel vision," adding, "You could say the same thing about CFC's," which destroy the earth's protective layer of ozone.
The White House also said that the environmental agency would change the rules on when changes to a power plant become so extensive that the plant is considered new, and therefore subject to stricter pollution standards. Named after a case involving the Wisconsin Electric Power Company, the "Wepco fix" -- as it is known on Capitol Hill -- would allow utilities to make major changes to dirty old plants without becoming subject to the strict regulations governing new ones. But the fix was rejected by Congress in the debate over the Clean Air Act.
If utilities were not subject to rules on new sources of pollution, according to the gas industry, they might take inexpensive steps that would significantly reduce pollution, like "co-firing" coal with natural gas. In co-firing -- when the two fuels are burned together in the boiler -- chemical reactions reduce the total pollution, although the plant is still dirtier than a new one.
 
 
The Opposite Case
 But environmentalists say the Wepco fix might not help gas sales at all. Without it, they say, many utilities would be forced to scrap dirty coal-fired plants and build new ones that run entirely on gas; with the fix, they can continue to rely heavily on coal.
A third change would give gas-pipeline companies the option to be regulated under an incentive system, rather than the cost-based system that now prevails, but the details have not been established.
A fourth would remove a regulatory wrinkle that some people have said could hurt natural-gas vehicles: the issue of interstate regulation. In theory, according to some natural-gas executives, if a car were fueled with natural gas in one state and driven to another, the sale would be interstate and thus subject to Federal regulation, although in practice the issue has not arisen, experts said.
The proposed change would make it clear that sales of natural gas for vehicles were not subject to Federal regulation.
