HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Picking a Package for the Music Festival Season

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY; CLIFFORD J. LEVY works on the foreign news desk of The New York Times.

 BODY:
DRAWN by the promise of stirring performances amid celebrated surroundings, travelers from around the world descend upon the music festivals and concert halls of Europe each spring and summer, hoping to immerse themselves for a few days in opera, symphony, jazz and sightseeing.
But for many travelers, the charms of a famous music festival or an intimate Baroque opera house may be overshadowed by difficulties in getting to the event or in obtaining seats. Tickets, which can cost well over $100 for many events, are often sold out months in advance and schedules may be complicated. Language can be a problem, particularly for people going to out-of-the-way cities. And, as with tickets, hotels in the area of the event may already be reserved. 
 Mindful of these obstacles, some travelers entrust themselves to tour companies specializing in packages that include hotel reservations, meals, local transportation, sightseeing and, most important, good tickets to festivals and concerts. The tours are usually led by music-lovers who are eager to share their knowledge.
The tours may focus on one event, like the Bayreuth Festival in Germany, which celebrates the works of Wagner, or the Montreux Jazz Festival in Switzerland; a particular geographic area, like the opera houses of Italy; or a theme, like Mozart's Europe. Some include lectures by musicologists and reading materials to help travelers' appreciation of the performances they attend. Besides being convenient, such tours provide a chance for devotees to meet others with similar tastes. Most packages are limited to 15 to 25 people.
The recession has forced many nonprofit organizations, like the Houston Grand Opera Guild and some of the jazz educational groups, to eliminate their more expensive activities -- like music tours of Europe -- and instead concentrate on events closer to home, so there are fewer music tours overseas by these agencies. The economic slump has also prompted tour companies to cut back their music packages to Europe. Even so, they are turning their sights to Eastern Europe, seeking tickets to concerts in cities like Prague, Budapest and Warsaw. While the accommodations may not be as luxurious as those in Western Europe, the singers and musicians are often excellent, tour operators say.
Most of the travelers booking these packages are over 35. Younger people often cannot afford such expensive trips and may prefer less structured travel. Most of these tours are expensive; few cost less than $2,500 for 10 days or so, without air fare to Europe. But the price usually includes fine hotels and meals at good restaurants.
The following is a listing of tour companies and some of the music packages they have scheduled for this spring and summer. Prices are for double occupancy without air fare and usually include rooms, most meals, tickets, guides, transportation in Europe and assorted extras:
Great Performance Tours, 1 Lincoln Plaza, Suite 32V, New York, N.Y. 10023; (212) 580-1400, offers three tours of Europe in the spring and three in the summer. Christopher T. Clark, the company's president, has been leading trips to the Continent since 1979 and is a former executive of the Metropolitan Opera and the Spoleto Festival in Italy.
The Vienna Festival package, from May 10 to 18, includes works of Verdi, Wagner, Puccini, Strauss and Tchaikovsky; the cost is $3,570. Other spring tours include the London Spring Festivals and the Hohenems Schubertiade in Austria. In the summer, there are tours of opera houses in Italy, the Munich Opera Festival and the Salzburg Festival.
Dailey-Thorp Travel Inc., 330 West 58th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019; (212) 307-1555, has been leading music tours to Europe since 1971 and has about 10 planned for the spring and summer. Its packages usually include lectures with music scholars and some of its guides have graduate degrees in music, said Mary T. Dailey, the company's president.
Among the spring tours are Cultural, Historical Russia, from April 4 to 18, with opera, concerts and ballet in St. Petersburg, Suzdal, Moscow and Helsinki; cost is $4,375, including air fare from New York. Another package, Music Festival on the Danube from May 14 to 25, features concerts in Prague, Bratislava, Budapest and Vienna; cost is $6,350.
The Metropolitan Opera Guild, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10023; (212) 769-7062, sponsors two tours of Europe that are available only to its members, who pay annual dues of at least $50. Put together by Dailey-Thorp, they differ only slightly from the company's regular packages. The packages are Eastern European Odyssey from March 27 to April 13, featuring opera in Warsaw, Budapest, Bratislava, Prague and Berlin; cost is $5,140. A second package, from July 21 to Aug. 1, focuses on opera in Verona, Salzburg and Munich; cost is $7,975, which includes air fare to Europe.
Ovations International Inc., 2 Executive Concourse, Suite 206, Duluth, Ga., 30136; (800) 635-5576 or (404) 476-4007, was founded in 1985 and specializes in music tours of Italy; seven tours to Europe are scheduled for the spring and summer. Michael Paul Tisma, the company's president, said the average price for a 10-day package was $3,000 to $3,500. One tour, Sicilian Landscapes from May 18 to 28, focuses on opera in Palermo and Catania, with a performance of "Aida" and a recital by Marilyn Horne.
International Curtain Call, 3313 Patricia Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif., 90064; (800) 669-9070 or (310) 204-4934, is sponsoring seven music tours to Europe, one of which is already sold out, said Jerome J. Glaser, the company's director. A tour of Italy, from June 6 to 16, includes opera in Milan, Florence and Venice. A tour of France, from July 5 to 19, features performances of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" at the Paris Opera and visits to the Aix-en-Provence Festival and the Orange Festival in Avignon. Prices of the tours average $4,000.
Rudolph Travel Service Ltd., 77 Bloor Street West, Suite 1105, Toronto, Canada M5S 1M2; (416) 964-3553, features tours put together by its director, John Mainz, a German native who specializes in the opera houses of Germany and Austria. The company, which has been sending tours to Europe since 1971, has scheduled seven spring and summer packages.
The Vienna tour, from May 4 to 12, includes performances of "The Flying Dutchman" and "Don Giovanni"; cost is $2,895. Another package, from Aug. 3 to 17, combines visits to two of the region's most famous festivals, Salzburg and Bayreuth; cost is $7,950. Like other tour companies, Rudolph has built up connections with these festivals, so it is able to obtain what are very scarce tickets.
Now Voyager Tours, 101 Cooper Street, No. 6J, New York, N.Y. 10034; (212) 567-1924, is owned by a couple who have spent much of their adult lives studying Mozart. Norman Eagle, the company's president, said he and his wife, Betty, have visited nearly all the places where Mozart lived and performed, and they have crafted their experiences into tours of the composer's life and works. This year, Now Voyager is leading two Mozart tours, from Sept. 5 to 21 and Sept. 23 to Oct. 9. They cost from $3,041 to $3,679. The first includes three days in Prague, one of Mozart's favorites cities, and concerts at the theater where he conducted the premieres of "Don Giovanni" and "Prague Symphony."
Ciao! Travel, 2707 Congress Street, Suite 1F, San Diego, Calif., 92110; (800) 942-2426, offers packages to three of Europe's top jazz festivals -- Montreux in Switzerland, J.V.C. North Sea in The Hague and J.V.C. Grande Parade of Jazz in Nice, France. Ciao!, founded in 1987, sent 450 people to these events last year, said its owner, Bill Snider. Its packages, which include air fare from New York, hotel rooms and passes to the festivals, range from $1,399 for a four-day weekend at North Sea to $2,499 for a week at Montreux. The company's offerings are less structured than others' tours built around classical music; travelers are not guided from event to event, but they can consult an executive from Ciao! at each festival.
Montreux, from July 3 to 18, will once again be produced this year by Quincy Jones. North Sea, from July 9 to 12, will feature performances by Dizzy Gillespie, as well as a retrospective on Miles Davis.

PUB-DATE: March 8, 1992

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1598 words

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
The Haitian Beat Thrives in Times Of Suffering

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE; Daisann McLane writes about music for Vogue, Rolling Stone and The Village Voice.

 BODY:
Within a day after its release last month to radio stations in Port-au-Prince, "Kalfou Dangere" ("Dangerous Crossroads"), the new single from Boukman Eksperyans, had burned a fast track across the airwaves and into streets shattered by coup, terrorism and economic embargo. "Kalfou Dangere," the title track of Boukman's second album, to be released here in May, is a percussive assault on Haiti's "evildoers" that is steeped in the symbolism of voodoo and Haitian history. The song soon headed northward via teledyol, the grapevine that is the Haitian community's equivalent of a news service. Taped from radio broadcasts, then rebroadcast over shortwave and pirate radio stations in New York, "Kalfou Dangere," in only three days, became a hit from Port-au-Prince to Flatbush, Brooklyn. It also became an anthem for supporters of the democratically elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Terrorized by military dictatorship, strapped by embargo, Haiti would seem to be the last place one would expect to find bands making pop records. But neither political nor economic suffering seems able to repress the surge of musical creativity that began to surface in Haiti six years ago, with the departure of Jean-Claude (Baby Doc) Duvalier. According to Boukman Eksperyan's lead singer and composer, Theodore Beaubrun, nearly a dozen groups have released songs for this year's Haitian carnival season, which ended last Tuesday. 
 At least two distinct pop trends, one rooted in the country's past, the other determinedly modern, have emerged in the last few years. A third, Haiti's well-known dance music, compas, is waking up under the competitive pressure. The impulses behind this creative burst are as complex as the contemporary Haitian experience. Certainly the post-Duvalier political trauma has presented musicians with plenty of inspiration. But to attribute the boom solely to political events ignores a most important characteristic of modern Haiti: the diaspora. At least a million Haitians -- and many of the country's musicians -- live outside Haiti, in New York, Miami and Montreal.
Responding to this community's needs, Haitian music has become much more than entertainment. It's a radio of the heart, keeping Haitians, connected to their country, one another and themselves.
Politics propelled Boukman Eksperyans to the forefront of the Haitian new wave. In 1990, Boukman's metaphor-laced "Kem Pa' Sote" ("My Heart Doesn't Jump") was taken up by ecstatic crowds (who rewrote the words) and turned it into the battle cry of President Aristide's victory. With the release of "Vodou Adjae" ("Voodoo Trance Dance") by Mango Records shortly after the election, Boukman became the first Haitian group in years with an album on a major American label.
Boukman's is perhaps the most original music to come out of the Caribbean in the last few years. The music is a mixture of high-tech and traditional, in which searing Santana-like electric guitar and synthesizer riffs knife across the jumpy, uneasy drums and chants of rara -- Haitian street revelry. Voodoo rock, or rara rock, as some critics describe Boukman's music, is not completely new. In the 1950's, Haitian bands played "voodoo jazz," pop music based on the ritual rhythms of the Haitian religion and rara, its secular cousin. But Boukman's success with fusing the traditional and modern has sparked what amounts to a rara revival. "Figure out how many thousands of drummers there are in Haiti, then divide that number into units of three, and you'll get some idea of how far the voodoo-rock band boom can go," says Richard Morse, leader of a voodoo-rock band and promotor of Boukman's early performances.
Everybody is getting into the rara act. Bands like the New York-based Tabou Combo, which built its reputation playing compas, Haiti's most popular dance music, are now adding rara rhythms to their sets. A former compas session player, Clifford Sylvain, has gone further, naming his group Rara Machine and even lifting a song title from Boukman's album for the title of his new record, "Break the Chain," released by Shanachie Records.
The rise of rara rock has rekindled interest in the original form. For example, in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, a rum-fueled Sunday-afternoon jam of parading singers, drummers, and bamboo and tin horn players has been going strong for the last two summers. These raras attract young, culturally conscious Haitians (including Boukman members when they are in town), some with their hair in dreadlocks, others wearing straw hats and swinging the Haitian peasant sack, or macoute.
Part of the appeal of rara, and its newest incarnation, rara rock, is its subversiveness. Boukman's latest rara song shows how Afro-Caribbean music functions as a sanctioned channel for social protest. Why hasn't the Haitian military banned "Kalfou Dangere" from the radio or arrested the group, as it did the folk singer Manno Charlemagne several months ago? The answer lies in Afro-Haitian culture. Rara, like griot in Senegal and calypso in Trinidad, bestows upon its singer-composers the liberty to bash sacred cows, to speak the unspeakable. " 'Kalfou' is rara," says Theodore Beaubrun, "and besides, it's released for carnival. The military doesn't dare interfere with the people's expression at this time."
As Boukman and its followers reach back to traditional rhythms to create the sound of modern Haiti, other groups are jumping into the pop mainstream for inspiration. This "nouvel jenerasyon" (new generation) of musicians began to surface in the mid 1980's. The nouvel jenerasyon bands slowed the traditional compas rhythm, simplified the syncopation and substituted synthesizers for the familiar horns. But otherwise the groups are all over the pop-music map.
Members of the Phantoms wear mohawk haircuts and add Jamaican dancehall breaks in creole to their songs on their newest album, "Ouve Barie Ya" ("Open the Gate"), released by Josy Records. Riske, an all-female band based in Miami, specializes in a smooth, glossy synth-pop that is the Haitian answer to the Cuban-American Miami sound of Gloria Estefan. Second-generation Haitian New Yorkers like Zin and Partners have strong rhythm and blues hooks in their dance records, while the soprano Emeline Michel blends sophisticated jazz-rock with Brazilian and Afro-pop.
With so many elements that are uncharacteristic of Haitian music, it might look as if nouvel jenerasyon is simply a tag for crossover fever, which it sometimes is. But the restless invention of new forms and fusions springs from the experience of these younger Haitians struggling to define their identities both at home and in the multicultural seas of the United States and Canada. In this sense, the sparkling pop sounds of the nouvel jenerasyon have as much reason to be considered "political" as the most incendiary chant in rara rock.
Compas, on the other hand, is the best known Haitian music. Graceful and elegant, with a steady high-hat syncopation and its trademark intertwined lead and rhythm guitars, compas is still the most popular music with Haitian dancers. For the last 15 years, a handful of superb compas bands based in the emigre communities of New York and Miami -- Tabou Combo, Skah Shah, Magnum Band and System Band -- have dominated the Haitian music scene. Long associated with the Haitian diaspora, and especially its middle class, compas usually steers clear of politics or radical musical changes. But the Haitian new wave's burst of energy has infected compas, too. Once a genre of supergroups, it now has a superstar, and a politically minded one at that: Dieudonne Larose.
Larose, a 32-year-old emigre based in Montreal, recently hand-delivered his third album, "Democratie," to the L'an 2000 record store in Flatbush; as he stepped out of his chauffeur-driven Mercedes-Benz, a hush fell over the customers, who parted to let the slender, handsomely attired singer pass. But this is just surface style; underneath the trappings, Larose is transforming Haitian music as deeply as Boukman Eksperyans, but in a quieter way.
Larose's gentle bubbling songs are little jewels of melody that have the singsong staying power of children's schoolyard chants. In the 1930's and 40's, Haiti's European-trained urban composers scoured the countryside for traditional and voodoo songs, which they used as the basis for new tunes that became pop classics. Larose, who grew up in the countryside north of Port-au-Prince (most compas musicians come from the city), writes in the style of these old favorites, evoking a yearning for the pastoral life they represent. His rough-hewn tenor rings with pure feeling, reminding many Haitians of the legendary singer Ti-Manno, who died in 1985.
Larose's lyrics lack the Boukman bite; they are commentaries, not anthems. From the point of view of the Haitian immigrant, he tackling topics like democracy, the plight of Haitian workers in the Dominican Republic, the gulf war and his own sudden stardom. He can be as eloquent as a calypso singer or a black preacher, but he usually backs away from hard issues. In "Democratie," for example, he criticizes whites for their racist attitudes toward black governments but then admonishes fellow Haitians as if they were troublesome children: "Work hard . . . respect the law."
Speaking his mind while avoiding trouble, Larose reflects the confusing world of values the Haitian immigrant must negotiate. No wonder he strikes such a nerve with diaspora Haitians; he taps his community's dialogue and spins it into song.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

COUNTRY: HAITI (99%); UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%);

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 2d Phase in Milford;
Reefing Sails in a Recession

 BODY:
When the developers of Caswell Cove, a waterfront community in Milford, Conn. put up the first phase of their project four years ago, the recession was still off shore. The 48 two-bedroom condominiums on the marina there sold out at prices of $240,000 to $325,000, along with 48 slips at $1,000 a foot.
But when Milford Partners tried to build the next phase, few buyers came forward and construction stopped for 18 months. "We had a choice of throwing up our hands and going bankrupt or restructuring the project." said Kevin Bartlett, the only remaining member of Milford Partners, the developers. 
 In December, work started on another 48 condominiums. To bring back buyers, prices were slashed sharply -- $145,900 to $149,900 -- although slip prices are the same. A drop in construction costs helped make the price cuts possible. The layouts of the new units are nearly identical to those in the first phase, but features like electronic security systems are optional extras instead of standard. To sweeten the deal, the developer is offering financing that requires a 10 percent down payment on a 30-year loan at 7 3/4 percent interest.
The firm of Valus and Carpenters Associates of Westport designed both phases. The first units are to be finished in May.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Assisted Housing;
Managing the Newly Built Apartments

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
BEAUTY didn't abandon the Grand Concourse in the Bronx during the 70's, when property owners did. Linda Field spotted it on the corner of Tremont Avenue, in a city-owned property known as the Flatiron Building, which a doctors group had owned and operated for years as a medical center. Ms. Field won city designation to do a Federally subsidized gut conversion to create 43 apartments in the building.
That was not the last of the gut rehabilitations in the West Bronx done by Ms. Field, who set out on a housing career after a stint as a graduate student in art history at Columbia University in 1967. But in recent years development opportunities have contracted. 
 So she and her partner, Robert Garcia, an electrical contractor, have concentrated on management. Their company, Ashton Management Corporation, was formed in 1979, principally to manage the buildings they developed together. In the last two years management has come on strong, especially on behalf of nonprofit housing organizations in the Bronx that are recycling many vacant city-owned buildings.
Ashton is the manager of two major projects. One is New Settlement apartments -- 893 units in 14 newly completed buildings that were gut-rehabilitated under Department of Housing Preservation and Development auspices and are owned by the Settlement Housing Fund through an affiliated company. They are in the Morris Heights neighborhood, south of the Cross Bronx Expressway between Jerome Avenue and the Concourse.
The other project, still in construction, consists of 722 apartments in 23 scattered buildings in Highbridge and Morris Heights. The owner will be a housing affiliate of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, which sponsored the development through its housing arm, the Housing Development Institute. Again, the housing agency is handling the construction through private contractors.
These two assignments have made Ashton a major housing management company in the Bronx and given Ms. Field firsthand experience with issues that are current subjects of debate.
Ms. Field's most immediate concern for the future of the housing stock in lower-income neighborhoods -- whether publicly assisted or privately owned -- is the cost of water. As has been widely noted, the city is moving inexorably toward water metering in multifamily housing without any clear notion of what it will cost the buildings and whether they can afford it.
"This is the greatest potential enemy of the private housing stock," Ms. Field said. "It can be the death of the stock. The city will have to decide whether to go back to the frontage system or accept many buildings in abandonment."
Under the frontage system historically used by New York City, water usage was estimated on the basis of plot and building size. Under the metering system, buildings are to be billed by actual water use. The level of use is largely out of the control of the managements paying the bills. In lower-income areas, large family sizes and doubled up occupancy lead to extraordinary usage.
"We see apartments with 10, 15, 19 people living together," Ms. Field said. "It's extremely common. Often there is a family with a father, a mother and three or four kids in one room."
That overoccupancy is a precipitating cause of family homelessness -- usually a young mother with children presenting herself for city shelter, which the city in a consent decree 1981 agreed to provide to all who seek it when they have no apparent housing alternative. Having supplied it, the city is effectively, if not legally, obliged to seek out permanent housing as well, at least when the family fails to do it on its own.
No other city in the country has accepted a legal obligation to supply temporary shelter to the homeless. The New York City approach has set up a competition over which families should have first preference for that scarce but desirable commodity, the newly rehabilitated, city-subsidized apartment. Should it go to a family in the shelter, defined as homeless, or to a family still living doubled up that is not technically homeless.
INITIALLY, the city's standard tenancy mix was 30 percent homeless and 70 percent working low- to moderate-income people in the new gut-rehabilitated rentals. In December 1990 the housing companies were allowed to take half the "homeless" from the doubled-up category.
Ms. Field worked under these standards for two years to tenant New Settlement apartments for the Settlement Housing Fund. She sees them as promoting fairness, and also as an acknowledgment by city government that not all families in transitional housing can cope with independent living even after a 6- to 12-month stay. For perhaps 5 percent of the families with violent or criminal tendencies, permanent custodial care is necessary unless a change in behavior is clearly established, she said.
"There are people in the shelter system because of a temporary disruption in their lives," she said. "They do well in permanent housing. There are others who go there to get priority for permanent housing. They tend to do very well too. Then there is a group of people, and it's a fairly large group, with severe and long-term problems that don't function well in a private setting."
Under a plan offered last month by the Mayor's Commission on the Homeless, headed by Andrew M. Cuomo, applicants for emergency or transitional housing would be screened through a number of "reception centers." The commission recommended no changes in existing standards of eligibility, but said these should be more strictly enforced.
Once housed temporarily -- usually in a facility run by a nonprofit at a cost to government of about $100 per family a night -- the Cuomo commission recommends that the family get whatever welfare assistance is needed to attain "economic and social independence."
It views a permanent apartment as one family need among many. Other needs may include job training and assistance, instruction in independent living, substance abuse treatment and mental health care.
New York City does not consider people in transitional facilities to have an entitlement to permanent housing. But in practice, formal "homelessness" can become a good ticket both to independent living capability and a decent apartment.
"There is no fair way of allocating housing once you say that everyone who presents himself at a shelter establishes a path to permanent housing as an entitlement," Ms. Field said. "People need to have access to permanent housing without having to go through the system."
The tenanting process at New Settlement apartments provided a mix of 70 percent working families, many of them working families moving up to better housing from older buildings in Upper Manhattan. Only 30 percent of the tenants are in the homeless or doubled-up category. The Ashton Management staff dealt with 19,000 applications for the 893 apartments, and interviewed 5,000 candidates.
MS. FIELD and Mr. Garcia have spent years plowing money into their management company, which now operates from an office in a property they rehabiliated under the Government's Section 8 program. This is the 172-unit three-building complex known as Macombs Village, at 1674 Macombs Road. They have a main office staff of 12 and 150 additional employees as office, maintenance and security personnel at developments they manage in the West Bronx.
As developer-owners, Ms. Field and Mr. Garcia also completed the 78-unit Alexander Corprew apartments at 1200 Union Avenue in Morrisania. Mr. Garcia also works independently of Ashton as a general contractor. The partners hope to return to development some day, but meanwhile the focus is on management.
"Management is labor intensive and it requires absolute attention every day," she said. "We deliver services and collect the rent. It's that simple -- and an all-consuming task."

HEADLINE: The Shattered Vision of the Booming 90's

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
HAD the world turned according to plan -- or, at least, according to environmental-impact statements -- a desolate patch west of Ninth Avenue behind the General Post Office would now be shaping up as a center for some 10,500 workers in two new office towers.
Instead, it remains mostly an open cut, 60 feet below street level, through which a network of tracks runs to Pennsylvania Station. North of this cut is an Edison parking lot ("Garden Events -- Fast In -- Fast Out") and to the south there is a Kinney parking lot. Between them, about 12 people work on the site, or 10,488 fewer than envisioned in the late 1980's. 
 As New York City's real-estate market enters its fourth year of distress, the absence of the Ninth Avenue projects, as well as dozens of others proposed in the last decade, is keenly felt. The virtual freeze in construction has cost millions of dollars in tax revenues and thousands of jobs, underscoring the city's dependence on development not only as a prime stimulator of its economy but also as a prop for its civic identity, as a place that ceaselessly, impatiently renews itself.
One way to measure what has not happened to the economy as a consequence of the construction slump is to go back to the late 1980's and recall where New York was supposed to have been in the 90's, as predicted both in broad socio-economic forecasts and specific scenarios outlined in environmental-impact statements.
The tone may be gleaned in these words, almost poignant in their exuberance, which seem to have the distance of decades, although written only five years ago:
"New York City is once again crowded, energetic and exciting. Its economy is booming. Every day brings new businesses and new customers to a wide variety of neighborhoods. Retail stores are opening everywhere. Wall Street is again the world's capital in finance and auxiliary services of all kinds have sprung up to oil the machinery of finance, real estate and insurance."
This vision was offered by a panel whose ribbons could not have been much bluer: the Mayor's Commission on the Year 2000, composed of two dozen civic and academic leaders. Their report, "New York Ascendant," was released in June 1987, four months before the stock market plummeted.
"By the year 2000," members of the commission concluded, "the city's economy will have produced some 300,000 more jobs. This slow but continued growth in employment will probably see increases in construction, finance and services."
Economists at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, writing in 1986, forecast a gain of 231,000 jobs in New York City by 1995, with 23,000 of those new jobs in construction, an increase of 24 percent.
Although years remain before either of these forecasts can be fairly judged, recent history has not encouraged the view that job growth is imminent.
From December 1987 to December 1991, about 135,900 jobs were lost in securities and commodities, banking, business services and law, a decline of 19 percent. "If you think of this complex as the engine, then construction is the caboose," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional director of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "When the engine stops -- after a little bit of a lag -- then the whole train begins to reverse."
If every one of those jobs in finance, banking, law and related services carried a need for 200 to 300 square feet of space, the reduction in demand among those sectors alone -- never mind insurance or advertising or airlines -- would have totaled 27 million to 41 million square feet, the equivalent of 10 to 15 Empire State Buildings.
True to Mr. Ehrenhalt's scenario, construction jobs held fairly stable from December 1987 to December 1989, during the first major contractions in white-collar employment. But since then, following the completion of many big developments, construction jobs have plunged by 32,300, a drop of 26 percent. Similarly, architectural employment grew slightly in the years immediately following the stock market plunge. But since 1989, 1,600 jobs have been lost in that field, a 19 percent decline.
"CONSTRUCTION works both as a push and a pull factor," said Steven G. Cochrane, senior economist at the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., which uses housing starts and nonresidential real estate investment in its economic models.
"Development itself does a lot to fuel the economy both directly and in terms of wages," he said, "but the impact is usually more important indirectly. There are a lot of indirect benefits because construction needs materials, financing and services, down to the guy who drives the coffee truck up to sell coffee to the workers."
And on a subjective basis, Mr. Cochrane noted that "certainly, when one sees construction cranes all around, one says, 'This place is on the move.' "
Such cannot be said of New York today.
Among the projects that have stalled are the two on Ninth Avenue. The Reichmann family's Olympia & York real estate concern planned a 51-story tower at 31st Street, with 1.67 million square feet of space. It was to have been completed last year but was delayed by a lawsuit. The Reichmanns would not build now on a speculative basis on that site, said their spokesman, Peter Rosenthal.
Harvey Schulweis planned a 31-story, 1.08-million square-foot tower at 33d Street. It was to have been finished this year but it, too, was delayed by a suit. Last week, he said the project was approved and "ready to go, waiting for a tenant or a market."
Construction of the Reichmanns' project would have created enough work to keep 1,950 people directly employed for a year and an additional 2,000 people indirectly employed, furnishing goods and services to the contractors, according to the impact statement prepared by Allee King Rosen & Fleming and Vollmer Associates.
(Environmental-impact statements use a "person-year" measurement, which equals one year's labor by one person. For example, 90 "person-years" might be expressed as 90 people working one year, 45 people working two years or 30 people working three years.)
Building the Schulweis project was to have created enough work to provide a year's worth of direct employment for 1,300 to 1,510 people. In total, there would have been a year's worth of direct and indirect employment for 1,960 to 2,280 people in New York City, according to an impact statement by the Parsons Brinckerhoff engineering and planning concern.
From construction alone, the Reichmanns' building would have generated $4.7 million in tax revenues for New York City -- enough to pay the annual, entry-level salary and benefits package of 109 police officers or 132 teachers -- and $9.9 million for the state. The largest portion of revenues would have come from personal income taxes, with other money from sales taxes and corporate taxes both on direct and indirect activities. The Schulweis project would have generated $2.8 million to $3.3 million in city tax revenues during construction -- 65 to 77 police officers or 79 to 93 teachers -- with an additional $6.3 million to $7.3 million for the state.
EVENTUALLY, 6,400 people were to have been in the Reichmanns' tower, as office tenants, store workers or building employees. Although many of these jobs would have been shifted from other buildings in the city, the analysis noted that "there would likely be some net gain in jobs for the city as well, since office tenants often move to accommodate future expansion."
Real-estate tax revenues would not have been affected in the first four years, the statement noted, because the developers intended to apply for a deferral under the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program, but "property taxes would increase substantially" over existing conditions in the fourth year. No estimate was given.
The building was also to "generate substantial tax revenues for New York City and New York State to the extent that new uses would be on the site" -- including personal income taxes, corporate income taxes, sales taxes and commercial occupancy taxes.
Along with other projects, the Reichmanns' tower was seen as drawing new enterprises to the surrounding neighborhood. "The business support services, dining, entertainment and general-supply stores which would be attracted to the area would provide additional employment and tax benefits to the city," the impact statement said.
Meanwhile, the Schulweis project would have had some 4,070 office employees and 30 retail employees. And after the deferral under the incentive program, "the full assessed-value taxation of the property would be expected to range upwards to $8 million or $9 million annually," the statement said.
A half mile north, some 23,500 people -- nearly the population of Glen Cove, L.I. -- were to be working in the 42d Street Development Project, which was to have been completed by 1991, according to the environmental-impact statement by the New York State Urban Development Corporation. The project was also seen as displacing 3,300 jobs, for a net gain in the area of 20,200.
Of the new jobs, 13,300 were to have been in four office towers on Broadway and Seventh Avenue, 8,000 in a wholesale mart on Eighth Avenue, 1,200 in a hotel on Eighth Avenue, 500 in renovated theaters on 42d Street and 500 in the new stores throughout the project.
Through 2005, the office towers were expected to generate between $480 million and $507 million in payments in lieu of property taxes. The mart would have generated $200 million in a 22-year period, the hotel $86 million and the theaters $10 million.
Today, the state is still relocating tenants from two of the office tower sites, at the northeast and southwest corners of Broadway. On Feb. 20, six of the theaters were leased by the Urban Development Corporation to New 42d Street, which has been considering proposals for the theaters. And the mart and hotel, though they remain part of the plan, are in a state of suspension, as the state has not yet taken title to the sites.
Economic effects need not be measured in nine digits. The environmental-impact statement by Parsons Brinckerhoff for a residential project at Vernon Boulevard and 44th Avenue in Hunters Point, Queens, went so far as to examine annual household spending on prescription drugs and medicine ($167), reading material ($259) and alcohol ($545).
STARTING with such figures and then adjusting them for inflation, the impact statement concluded that the 1,962 new residents brought in by the project would be spending $14.11 million locally in 1992, $10.24 million of which would exceed the capacity of stores that were part of the development.
"It would appear that a substantial portion of this excess could be captured locally by existing retail establishments," the statement said, "particularly those located along the 21st Street neighborhood retail strip."
The project was expected to generate enough construction work to employ 1,800 people for a year and, in the end, to employ 50 people on the site, no net gain.
In downtown Brooklyn, construction of the Muss Development Company's Renaissance Plaza -- a combination office tower and Hilton Hotel -- was seen as providing a year's worth of direct employment for 1,170 people and a year's worth of indirect employment for another 1,230 people. The environmental-impact statement prepared in 1986 by Allee King also estimated that construction would generate $2.3 million in tax revenues for the city and $4.9 million for the state.
The building was to house 2,910 workers, 2,500 in the offices and 410 in the hotel. The environmental-impact statement acknowledged that most of the office employment would have been shifted from other locations in the city but also pointed out that "the 410 hotel jobs would represent new employment for the city and downtown Brooklyn which would otherwise not have occurred."
The project was given a considerable boost Feb. 25 with the signing of a 20-year lease by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office for 360,000 square feet.
Today, Joshua Muss, the developer, says that the hotel and garage at Renaissance Plaza may generate as many as 500 to 600 full-time jobs that "never existed before," as well as 400 part-time jobs for caterers or other enterprises that serve business conferences. He said it was not clear yet what the office population would be.
About construction-related jobs, Mr. Muss said direct employment might be close to the estimate and indirect employment was probably understated in the impact statement.
"When I think of the ad agencies, the P.R., the law firms, the accountants and the architects cumulatively," he said, "we've already spent an awful lot of money to bring it to date. Now, it will be productive money. We're looking forward to spending it."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Retroactive Rent Increase
 
Question: My apartment and many others in the building where I live are under rent control. Because of numerous code violations in the building there has been no rent increase since January 1987. 
 Last year, the landlord filed for bankruptcy and the court appointed a receiver to manage the property. Assuming that the new management corrects the violations, would there be a retroactive rent increase? . . . Gladys Brown, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. According to Joseph D'Agosta, acting deputy commissioner for rent administration at the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, in general there is no mechanism in the rules covering maximum base rent, or M.B.R., increases, for retroactivity.
"Assuming that the code violations are cleared," said Mr. D'Agosta, "and certain maintenance and operating criteria are met, then the M.B.R. increase would be granted according to what is allowed for the current application period."
 
Subletting in a Co-op
 
Question: About five years ago I bought a co-op apartment. Before buying I made certain that subletting was allowed, even though I planned to occupy the apartment myself.
About six months after I bought the apartment, the board decided to disallow subletting. I did not pay much attention to the change at the time because I had no plans to take a tenant.
Recently I have tried without success to sell the apartment. There is a good market for rentals in the area and I would like to rent rather than sell at a loss.
Was it legal for the board to change the rules without a vote by the shareholders? . . . Louise Hendrick, Long Beach, L.I.
 
Answer: Maybe. But it would depend on the language of the corporation's documents and how much authority they give the board on such matters.
According to Richard Barr, a spokesman for the New York State Attorney General's office, the subletting issue is usually addressed in the co-op's bylaws. The language in most co-ops requires a majority vote by the shareholders to make changes in the bylaws.
However, if there is no mention of the subletting issue in the document, the board would be within its rights to establish a ban without a shareholders' vote.
The right to sublet is sometimes granted to original buyers in co-op conversions by the sponsor as an incentive to buy. If this was the case in your purchase, there should be a reference to the subletting privilege in the prospectus.
In any case, you should check your co-op documents to determine whether the board acted properly.
 
Noisy Air-Conditioner
 
Question: My house is very close to my neighbor's. Last summer he installed a central air-conditioning system, which requires the component to be outside the house. It is so loud that we could not sit outside last summer. We could hear the system inside the back bedrooms even with the windows closed.
When I spoke to my neighbor about this problem, he said that the installer had told him that nothing could be done about the noise. Do we have to live with this noise? . . . Peter Bell, Brooklyn
 
Answer: Maybe not. According to Ian Michaels, a spokesman for the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, the city's noise-pollution code sets decibel levels for air-circulation devices, including air-conditioners. Your neighbor's system may exceed the legal limit.
But assuming that the air-conditioning equipment does not surpass the code's noise levels, there may be ways to muffle the sound. Some owners have had some degree of success with natural or man-made sound barriers like shrubs, wooden containers or masonry covers that reduce the noise by absorbing some of it.
For more information on the city's noise code call the environmental agency's hot line at (718) 699-9811.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Carroll Gardens Renewal;
28 Low-Income Rentals

 BODY:
Six vacant city-owned buildings in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn are being renovated into 28 low-income rental apartments by the Carroll Gardens Association
The project is being financed under a $2.2 million loan agreement with the City of New York and contributions from the Enterprise Foundation and the New York Equity Fund. 
 The renovated buildings, which will be called the South Brooklyn Renewal Project, are on the east side of Columbia Street from Sackett to Kane Street. Construction began last December and is scheduled to be completed by late July.
Depending on the resident's income, studios will rent for about $328 a month; the one-bedrooms, $351 a month; the two-bedrooms, $422 a month.
"This is for the very poor; 30 percent will be set aside for the homeless and doubled-up families," said Manual Ortiz Arroyo, the executive director of the association. The association is a not-for-profit neighborhood preservation company financed by the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal and the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

HEADLINE: Whalers' Woes: From Blue Line to Ticket Line to Bottom Line

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
ASHLEY GORDON was optimistic when she wrote to 146 corporate leaders in Fairfield County, inviting them to attend a reception, dinner and a Hartford Whalers hockey game last month at the Hartford Civic Center. Her optimism turned to chagrin, however, when only 40 responded to the invitations and just six showed up at the reception, which was to have included Governor Lowell P. Weicker Jr., whose son Gray once was a goalie in the Whalers' farm system and even played in a few exhibition games for the Hartford club. But even the Governor did not make it; his mother was ill, the team said.
Many of the invited executives "said they were going to be out of town on business, but in some cases I could tell they just weren't interested," said Ms. Gordon, a member of the team's marketing staff and daughter of its principal owner, Richard Gordon. "It was all part of a concerted effort we're making to reach out to get people in the lower part of the state interested in the Whalers." The Whalers were part of the old World Hockey Association when the team moved to Hartford from Boston in 1974. But ever since the club joined the National Hockey League in 1979, becoming the only major league team in Connecticut, it has never had a statewide appeal. Most hockey fans in Fairfield County are still oriented toward the New York Rangers. Now, primarily because of declining attendance, the Whalers are trying to expand their fan base beyond the Hartford area, where it is largely confined, hoping to reach as far south as Greenwich, home of the tennis star Ivan Lendl, one of the team's biggest fans. 
 "We've got to get more people from downstate interested in the Whalers, who really are a state team," said Mr. Gordon, a real estate developer in Hartford. "It's important that we increase our fan base. Maybe we should change the name of the team to the Connecticut Whalers, which we might do some day."
Given Hartford's location, some people feel that the Whalers name is a misnomer, too. Some, citing Hartford's position as a bastion of the insurance business, have suggested names like the Actuaries or Double Indemnities, rather than Whalers, the team's name in Boston.
By any name, the Whalers have fallen on hard times, both at the box office and on the ice. Through the first 34 home games this season, the Whalers have averaged 10,329 fans, about 2,000 less than at a comparable stage last season, in part because season-ticket sales fell to 7,300 from 8,600 in 1990-91. The current average attendance at N.H.L games is 14,550, down just 100 from last year, said a league spokesman, Gary Meagher.
Mr. Gordon said the Whalers' lower attendance was mainly attributable to the team's poor record and not the recession.
"If we win, people will come," he said.
Going into last night's game against Vancouver, the Whalers had won 3 of their last 4 games after having gone 14 games without a victory, leaving them with one of the worst records among the N.H.L.'s 22 teams.
 
'It's the Lack of Winning'
 But the Whalers and their fans have become accustomed to losing. Since joining the league the team has only had three winning seasons. The team's high point came during the 1986-87 season, when the Whalers finished first in the Adams Division, one of four divisions in the league.
That helped raise regular-season home attendance to a record 582,969 the following year. But attendance, which averaged 14,574 that season, has declined in each succeeding year.
"It's the lack of winning," said the 50-year-old Mr. Gordon, who has been a major figure in the redevelopment of downtown Hartford. "You have to win. It's the American way."
Things have also not been going well for the Whalers off the ice. The N.H.L. charged recently that the Colonial Whalers Limited Partnership, formed by four partners in Colonial Realty, which is now bankrupt, falsified financial information in obtaining approval by the league's board to buy 37.5 percent of the team's ownership. The board is sheduled to discuss the matter at a meeting in Chicago on March 20.
Mr. Gordon, who also owns 37.5 percent of the Whalers, said that he is now in the process of buying that disputed share, which previously had been owned by Donald G. Conrad. Mr. Gordon and Mr. Conrad bought 75 percent of the Whalers in 1988 from the a group of businesses in the Hartford area, including the Aetna Life and Casualty Company. The group has retained 25 percent ownership. Mr. Conrad sold his interest to Colonial, but Mr. Conrad has filed suit against Mr. Gordon and Colonial for nonpayment on their ownership agreement.
Because of the declining attendance in the league's smallest market, rumors have circulated that the club might leave the state.
"We're not going to leave, unless we're forced to" by "a lack of support," Mr. Gordon said. He conceded that the team had received overtures from other cities, but he said: "I don't want to leave. The Whalers are a key element in Hartford's revitalization and the glue that holds the city together."
 
Million-Dollar Man
 The Whalers are expected to lose about $5 million this season. Rising salaries -- the team average is now about $400,000, the same as the rest of the league -- have contributed to the deficit.
But in losing money, the Whalers are not alone in the N.H.L. As many as one-third of the league's teams have been operating at a deficit for the last three seasons. During the same period players' salaries have escalated.
The Whalers now have their first million-dollar player, the center John Cullen, who was obtained last month in a trade with the defending league champions, the Pittsburgh Penguins. Mr. Cullen, whose father and two uncles also played in the N.H.L., is earning $900,000 this season, along with a $300,000 signing bonus. He is to be paid $900,000 over each of the next three seasons and $1 million in the fourth year of his contract.
But neither Mr. Cullen nor any of the other current crop of Whalers have established themselves as stars with whom fans can identify.
"That's one of our biggest problems," Mr. Gordon said. "We have no identity, no players to form around."
The players who captured Whalers fans' fancies are no longer around. The legendary Gordie Howe, who finished his career with the Whalers, playing with his two sons for a while, is now a special assistant to Mr. Gordon, while the team's most popular players in recent years -- Ron Francis, Kevin Dineen and Mike Liut -- have all been traded.
"The fans just have to accept the new players and try to understand our basic philosophies," Mr. Gordon said when asked about those trades, which were unpopular with many Whaler fans. "We knew they weren't going to get any better, and we decided to go with younger players."
 
Top Ticket at $30
 Jim Baldwin, the director of ticket operations, said the vast majority of Whaler fans come from within a 30-mile radius of Hartford, including western Massachusetts. The club's appeal in Massachusetts has been helped considerably since the Springfield Indians of the American Hockey League, champions of their league in the past two seasons, became a Whalers farm team following the 1989-90 season.
Mr. Gordon, Mr. Baldwin and other club officials said the Whalers offer fans a good deal. The top ticket price is $30, compared with $65 for a New York Rangers game at Madison Square Garden. Ticket prices in Hartford range from $15 to $30, with about 45 per cent of the 15,500 seats in the Civic Center priced at the top.
One of the luxurious 12-seat boxes atop the arena goes for $75,000 for the season; a 10-seat box costs $60,000. Those prices, which are lower for a three- or five-year lease, include a wide range of other Civic Center events, like University of Connecticut basketball games.
Many of the fans at Whalers games come to cheer for the visting teams, especially the Boston Bruins. When the Montreal Canadiens played in Hartford on Feb. 19, at least 550 tickets were been sold to fans of the Canadiens, many of whom chartered buses to make the 400-mile trip from Montreal.
"Most of them can't get tickets to the Canadiens games at the Montreal Forum, which are always sold out, and so they come all the way to see their team play," Mr. Baldwin said. "And you sure know they're in the building."

HEADLINE: At Last, G.O.P.'s Bills See Light of Day

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
REPUBLICAN state senators who have spent their entire careers in the minority are facing a heady prospect. They are going to see some of their favorite bills voted on.
For the last two decades, Democrats have wielded the gavel of the Senate President, a position that carries the ultimate power to decide which bills are posted for voting. Republicans who came up with inspired pieces of legislation would sometimes have to watch from the sidelines as their bills were stolen -- copied word for word -- and put up for a vote by Democratic sponsors. 
 It has not been uncommon to see 10 Democratic Senate bills voted on for every Republican bill. That number would change when the Democratic leadership wanted Republican votes for a potentially controversial measure, creating an opportunity for some horse-trading.
Now it's the Republicans' turn. A landslide victory in the November elections gave them overwhelming majorities in both houses of the Legislature. That gives the Republicans the power to appoint the committees where much of the mischief is done, where bills submitted by the minority are often held and similar bills are released under the sponsorship of the majority.
The new Senate majority leader, John H. Dorsey of Boonton, said the Senate staff had been assigned to draw up a list of bills that have been denied a vote over the years and to single out some of them for early action in the legislative session just started. And Democratic leaders have begun to complain that their bills are being hijacked by the new Republican majority, though the gripes are not too loud.
The role of the majority carries with it important responsibilities -- passing a balanced budget, dealing with a revenue gap and the problems of controlling health-care costs and financing public education in a way that will meet constitutional requirements for fairness. But the prospect of seeing some of their long-delayed pet bills, important and otherwise, finally come up for a vote is bringing smiles to the faces of the new bosses in the Senate.
Gerald Cardinale of Demarest, an 11-year veteran of the Senate, recalls that he first introduced a bill eight years ago that would require restaurants to notify customers if they use monosodium glutamate in their cooking. "I got it out of committee, but John Russo would never put it up for a vote," he said, referring to the former Senate President.
Dr. Cardinale, a dentist, expressed surprise at the furor his bill had created. "The MSG people came out of the woodwork," he said, "and would convince restaurateurs that it would be costly, when all they would have to do was put a sticker on their menus until they printed new ones. I think the 3 percent of the population that suffers an adverse reaction to MSG are entitled to know if it is their food."
He also plans to get a vote on another bill that attracted 25 co-sponsors but was denied a spot on the voting board. This would require schools to begin each day by reciting that part of the Declaration of Independence that says people are "endowed by their creator" with certain rights, a phrase that is certain to raise anew the debate over school prayer and the separation of church and state.
"I saw John Russo the other day and teased him about not posting it in the past," Dr. Cardinale said.
 
Backer of Initiative Measure
 Mr. Dorsey said, "My bill is I. and R." An 11-year veteran of the upper house, he was an early champion of initiative and referendum legislation, which would give voters the right to propose and vote on changes in state law. The idea, supported by a number of voter groups, passed the Senate twice, only to die in the Assembly.
The only reason it made it through the Senate, Mr. Dorsey said, was that the Republican leadership was confident the measure would fail in the Assembly.
Senator Leanna Brown of Chatham, who is starting her ninth year in the Senate, said some of her bills would need reworking because of changed conditions since she had first sponsored them. "I'm told the last time there was this dramatic a change in legislative leadership, it took two years to get the process working smoothly," she said.
Mrs. Brown said she still wanted to pass her bill that would allow people to conduct businesses from their homes under certain conditions. Given the realities of the computer age, she said, the measure "makes sense."
But it would not permit the creation of businesses in a residential zone if they would attract a lot of traffic -- she cited a dance studio as an example -- or violate local zoning codes.
Because of the complexity of the issue, she said, she will probably first move to create a commission to study the proposal and recommend new legislation.
 
Office of Children's Advocacy
 Another of her initiatives that was bottled up would have created an office of children's advocacy within the government to coordinate all the services geared toward the needs of children. "The pundits say the 60's and 70's were the decades of the ombudsman," she said, "and this decade will be the time for a children's advocate."
Senator Robert E. Littell of Franklin said he had been frustrated by the failure of the Legislature to follow up on an old study that found a number of state dams to be in poor condition. He sponsored a Clean Water Bond Act in 1990 to provide $100 million to start a revolving fund that would support state and local projects in solving flooding and pollution problems.
The fund would also support conservation and recreational use of waterways. The bill was never voted on.
"In the case of private lakes that needed some dam repairs," he said, "money for the project could be applied for jointly by the owners and municipalities and paid back through assessments charged to the owners by the towns over 20 to 30 years."
 
Seed Money for Schools
 Senator William L. Gormley of Margate said he hoped to get action on a bill he had been pushing for some time -- along with two fellow Republicans, John H. Ewing of Bedminster and Joseph A. Palaia of Ocean Township, and a Democrat, Matthew Feldman of Teaneck -- to create a fund to provide seed money for school construction.
"The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey would provide about $400 million from tolls and lease payments at the World Trade Center to the state's Economic Development Authority," he said. "The toll revenue would have to be spent in the port district -- within a 25-mile radius -- but the revenue from leases could be spent anywhere, and this would provide the seed money to rehabilitate old schools or build new ones."
Mr. Gormley said the present situation, with the Legislature controlled by one party and the Governor belonging to the opposite party, offered a real opportunity for bipartisan cooperation on important initiatives like upgrading the state's aging stock of school buildings.

Ewing hope to create a fund to provide seed money for school construction and rehabilitation. (pg. 13) (Photographs by Ted Horodynsky)

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1592 words

HEADLINE: 48,000 Motorists May Face Delay In Injury Awards

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
ON a Friday afternoon in July 1989, 16-year-old Jaclynn Pazur was a passenger in a Ford Thunderbird when the car collided with another vehicle in Sayreville. Ms. Pazur's injuries included a fractured pelvis, fractured vertebrae and knee injuries that required surgery.
She sued both drivers, who were insured by the state-run Joint Underwriting Association, and her case was settled last December for $155,000.
About a week later, on Dec. 18, the State Department of Insurance issued an order deferring for one year such payments for pain and suffering arising from bodily injuries. As a result, Ms. Pazur will not receive her settlement until, at best, December 1992. Under a 1990 law that dissolved the bankrupt Joint Underwriting Association, deferments could last up to four years. 
 The deferment decision is expected to affect as many as 48,000 residents across the state who were involved in accidents while insured by the J.U.A., said Brian Hirst, an Insurance Department spokesman. Included in that number are those whose accidents occurred while their J.U.A. policies were in effect but who have not yet filed claims or resolved their cases. Mr. Hirst said that as much as $480 million in claims could eventually be deferred under the order.
For some people, the payment delay has caused financial hardship. Ms. Pazur, for example, was planning to use part of her settlement money to enroll at Middlesex County College in Edison.
The deferment has also been attacked as unfair and possibly illegal. It was adopted without public hearings or advance notice.
In January, the New Jersey branch of the Association of Trial Lawyers of America sued the Insurance Department, demanding that the deferment order be set aside until public hearings can be held.
"This is unfair and it's chaotic," said Robert Levinson, president of the chapter. "The innocent victims of accidents are being told, 'You can't have your money for a year,' while it's business as usual for everyone else."
The lawyers themselves must also wait, since their fees are not paid until their clients are paid.
For accident victims insured under the J.U.A., the payment delay has also thrown a monkey wrench into the claims process, affecting decisions about whether they should accept settlement offers from the J.U.A. or go to trial. The year's delay in payment puts added pressure on the victims to settle quickly, some lawyers say, since the clock does not start ticking on the deferment until a settlement is reached.
The Joint Underwriting Association was created to provide automobile insurance for drivers whose driving records prevented them from obtaining insurance in the private market. Claims filed against the association were paid out of these drivers' insurance premiums with the help of special surcharges paid by drivers insured in the private market.
The J.U.A. insured about two million New Jersey motorists. Before it was dissolved by Gov. Jim Florio's Fair Automobile Insurance Reform Act of 1990, the association had amassed an anticipated deficit of about $3.3 billion in potential claims and other losses.
Under the reform act, the two million drivers insured through J.U.A. were transferred to a new entity, the Market Transition Facility, which is scheduled to go out of business at the end of September 1993. By that time, 90 percent of the drivers will have been shifted to private insurance, and the rest, those with the worst records for accidents and traffic violations, will be placed in an assigned-risk pool.
 
Trustee Appointed
 The reform act provided for the appointment of a trustee to oversee the dissolution of the J.U.A., and Marshall Selikoff, a retired State Superior Court judge, was named to the post.
His chief task is to pay pending claims and claims that arise from accidents between the passage of the act on Oct. 1, 1990, and the expiration of the last association-insured policies on Oct. 1, 1991. Those claims would be paid out of money raised through automobile registration surcharges and assessments levied against insurance companies, doctors and lawyers in the state.
The whole process will end as of Sept. 30, 1993, when the two-year statute of limitations has expired and no further J.U.A. claims can be filed.
Judge Selikoff's job, however, had its own limitations. He needed money to pay off the claims, and it was lacking. Officials estimated that by January 1992, just three months after the last policy expired, the J.U.A. would face $38.7 million in claims it could not pay.
So, Judge Selikoff said, he asked the Insurance Commissioner, Samuel F. Fortunato, to issue the order deferring payments for pain and suffering arising from bodily injury claims, for a period of one year.
"The statute provides that we have the authority to defer claims for a period of up to four years," Judge Selikoff said in an interview, "but we don't want to do that."
He said it was too early to estimate the number of people currently affected by the deferment.
 
State Paying Interest
 The payment delay does not apply to medical expenses and economic losses, like lost wages or property damage, and the state is paying 6 percent interest on the deferred claims. Mr. Fortunato calls that "a fairly generous rate of interest in today's market."
It is not an argument that offers much consolation to people like Ms. Pazur, who said she felt that the Insurance Commissioner was insensitive to those in her position.
"He doesn't know what it's like to be in pain and suffering," she said. "If he were in my shoes, I'm sure he'd feel the same way."
The deferral order includes a hardship provision that can lead to immediate payment of at least a portion of a claim. For example, Mr. Fortunato said, a claimant may be entitled to an exemption from the payment delay if he or she can prove medical expenses in excess of $5,000 that are unrelated to the motor vehicle accident and are not covered by insurance.
The size of the exemption payment cannot, however, exceed the amount required to meet the financial emergency.
 
A $250,000 Settlement
 Richard I. Goldstein, a Pleasantville lawyer, has a client who was injured in a 1989 automobile accident and was covered by her parents' automobile insurance policy. Her case against the J.U.A. was settled for $250,000 several days before the day the deferral order was issued.
"Her parents had a good policy of insurance," Mr. Goldstein said. Then, he said, "the state turns around and says: 'We don't care what your contract was; you're not getting any money for a year.' "
"As an attorney," Mr. Goldstein said, "you have to consider whether you want to settle a case today or wait and let it go to trial." Time, he said, is typically used as a bargaining chip by both sides in the give-and-take of insurance settlement talks, and an injured party might accept a lower settlement if the amount is paid immediately.
The yearlong deferment of payment, he said, distorts that strategy in favor of the insurance company because the year begins to run only after a settlement has been reached or a judgment has been entered.
 
'You Better Settle Now'
 "They're basically saying that if you want to get your name on the list, you better settle now," Mr. Goldstein said. "People are basically being coerced to settle for less than they're entitled to."
Moreover, Mr. Goldstein fears that the payment delay may be extended beyond a year. "The big question," he said, "is, If they don't have the money now, and they're operating at a deficit, where do they expect to get the money a year from now?"
Mr. Fortunato thinks one year will be enough. "The J.U.A. has a closed book of business," he said. "No further exposure is being added. But it doesn't have a closed income stream." He was referring to the infusion of surcharges and assessments that will continue until 1997.
The Insurance Commissioner had harsh words for the J.U.A. "The J.U.A. was the most inefficient operation of its type in the United States," he said. "Once the cash dried up and no further premiums were coming in, the claims outstripped the income."
 
Reason for Lack of Notice
 Responding to complaints that the deferral order was issued without public hearing or prior notice, Mr. Fortunato said that "equity and fairness" had guided that decision.
"If we gave advance notice that we were going to put in a deferral," he said, "there was a danger that people would rush and get into settlements for figures lower than they might normally settle for. We have a public responsibility to protect the people who have claims against the J.U.A. I'm not saying that the attorneys don't protect them. They do."
Mr. Fortunato said his decision had caused "the least interruption of the settlement process."
Some lawyers disagree with that reasoning.
Marc Rogoff, the Woodbridge lawyer who represented Ms. Pazur in her accident case, said that had he known his client would have to wait a year for her settlement, he would not have been inclined to lower his settlement target. He said he might have recommended that the case go to trial. "There's not a chance I would have settled for less," he said.
Meanwhile, Ms. Pazur waits for her payment. Before the accident, she had played on the soccer team at Woodbridge High School, but now can no longer engage in sports and still experiences pain as a result of her injuries.
"I don't come from a wealthy background," Ms. Pazur said. "I was going to use the money to make something of myself."

HEADLINE: New Rochelle Protesters Demand Cut In School Tax

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
MORE THAN 400 frustrated taxpayers jammed into the grand ballroom of the Greentree Country Club last Tuesday night to denounce a 14.4 percent increase in this city's school property tax and to demand that the next school budget reflect a "return to fiscal sanity."
The predominantly middle-aged and middle-class audience listened attentively for two hours as leaders of the New Rochelle Citizens for Reduced Taxes, the ad hoc group that sponsored the meeting, criticized the New Rochelle Board of Education for levying the highest school tax in city history. The group also introduced its own school board candidates. 
 "We've never seen such a huge increase," said Anthony F. Sutton, a real estate broker and co-founder of the group. "What really upsets us is that it has happened during the recession." Other levels of government, he said, have been able to limit tax increases during these bleak economic times.
Leaders of the group argue that school administrative expenses can be reduced and that programs can be streamlined. But as its first priority, it is demanding that there be no additional tax increases "unless and until the citizens of New Rochelle have the right to vote on the new budget."
 
Joining a Growing Statewide Movement
 New Rochelle residents, like those in 56 other small cities around the state but unlike those in smaller municipalities, are prevented by state law from voting on school budgets. The ad hoc group here has joined a growing statewide movement that is urging legislators to change the law, in the belief that voting on school budgets gives taxpayers financial control and makes their elected school board members more accountable.
School officials and school board members disagree. Allowing cities to hold school-budget referendums, as outlined in legislation pending in Albany, would do little to control school finances, they say, because the problem must be solved at the state level, where budget items are mandated but where state aid to local districts is steadily reduced.
New Rochelle school officials say that state mandates will continue to determine budget priorities. Winning the right to vote on their school budget "may be a disappointment" for city residents, said Dr. Richard C. Schilling, assistant superintendent for business for the New Rochelle Schools. "All but 4 percent of our budget consists of mandated costs."
Paying those costs despite a loss last year of $5.1 million in state aid has caused the New Rochelle schools to rely more heavily on property taxes, Dr. Schilling said.
This has, in turn, increased the financial pressure on private homeowners because the city has lost $20 million in the value of assessed property in the last three years, Dr. Schilling said, as downtown businesses deteriorated or closed down. "School taxes went up 14.4 percent, but our budget has only increased 1.3 percent," he said.
 
'Other Industries Are Giving Back'
 "That's baloney," said Lee Rearigh, president of the WestchesterTaxpayers' Alliance. The alliance is based in Rye and was formed last year to fight tax increases at all levels of government. "Other industries are giving back like crazy," he said. "They simply have to stop giving teachers increases, and citizens have to have the right to say that at the polls."
It's a no-win situation, said Liz Jaffe, executive director of the Westchester-Putnam School Boards Association. "If you vote down a budget, and the school district goes on austerity, you still must honor all contracts and heat all buildings," she said. "What will get cut is transportation, intramural sports, extracurricular activities and library books."
Something has to give, Mr. Sutton, the group's co-founder, said in an interview last week. Tax increases are hurting home sales, he said, despite the insistence by school officials that "we have to have quality schools to draw people."
"We are not drawing people," Mr. Sutton said, "because of the high taxes."
School taxes in New Rochelle have increased almost 70 percent in seven years, said the new tax group's other founder, Hank Tanner, a self-employed businessman. In the last year, the average homeowner, with a home assessed at $20,000, paid an additional $400 in school taxes, Mr. Tanner said.
 
Five Social Security Checks
 "One woman called me to say she now takes five of her Social Security checks to pay school taxes," Mr. Tanner said. "Another is walking around her home in a bathrobe with a coat over it because she can't turn up the heat."
A way must be found to hold school board officials accountable to the public, he said, and gaining the right to vote on their budgets would make a difference for small-city residents in view of recent changes giving school boards more authority. Seven years ago, voters across the state agreed to eliminate the 2 percent taxing limit that had been imposed on small-city school districts. Many of those districts had complained that the state-imposed limit prevented them from obtaining enough property tax funds to pay for school needs.
Voters approved the constitutional amendment, but now many of those involved in the protests say they feel betrayed because Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had promised to introduce a bill giving residents of small cities the right to vote on school budgets if the proposition was approved.
"We have been submitting bills ever since," said Terry Lynam, a spokesman for the Governor. He said the measure had been opposed in the State Legislature by a coalition representing school boards and teachers unions. The bill has a better chance of passing during this session, Mr. Lynam said, because of growing pressure on legislators by taxpayers.
 
Growing Pressure on Property Taxes
 Although voter approval of the constitutional amendment set no maximum spending limits, the small-city school districts at first used their new powers conservatively. But increased costs and declining revenues have caused growing pressure on property taxes, prompting the growing statewide movement for repeal of the amendment.
Last summer, these school districts experienced the full impact of the state's fiscal crunch when a new deficit-reduction formula took effect. The loss in revenue affected some districts more severely than others; New Rochelle was especially hard hit and lost 46 percent of its state aid.
"Governor Cuomo said only 3 percent would be lost from any one school district, but some of our districts lost as much as 70 percent of their state aid," Ms. Jaffe said. Regional costs were never considered under the formula, Ms. Jaffe added. "It costs more to do business here."
Lorraine Werblow, a former member of the New Rochelle Board of Education, agreed last week that the Citizens for Reduced Taxes "had touched a nerve" in the city. "They are not that aware of the effect on New Rochelle of the loss of state aid or that they must be taxed directly because of it," she said. "It's healthy for people to object. There has to be a meeting of the minds."
Mrs. Werblow is co-chairwoman of the New Rochelle League of Women Voters, which is about to begin a study of ways to finance public education. It hopes other small cities will join in the study, she said. "We don't have any answers," she added. "But there must be a better solution than property taxes."
