HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The Rare Trades of Alpine Capital

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
There are some ideas that are simply catnip to the public. The Catholic Income Trust was just such a gimmick. This whimsical mutual fund was set up in 1989 by Alpine Capital Management in Denver, which already managed two other mutual funds. The new fund invested in the obscure and rarely traded bonds issued by Catholic institutions like colleges and hospitals. What could be more adorable?
But the predictable spate of stories didn't attract enough investors to keep body and soul together at Catholic Income. Its assets never totaled much more than $4.3 million, and fees ate up about 5.75 percent of each dollar investors chipped in. Last April, the Catholic Income Trust was quietly buried by Alpine and the estate was divided among its shareholders -- at $9 a share, a dollar less than its initial net asset value, according to Morningstar, the mutual fund service in Chicago. 
 Now, Alpine's two other mutual funds, the California Municipal Asset Trust and the National Municipal Asset Trust, are in the process of being liquidated. But this time, the Securities and Exchange Commission is presiding at the funeral -- after lodging a civil complaint against Alpine and the funds, which invested almost exclusively in municipal leases.
A taste for obscure and rarely traded assets, it turns out, is not always just a cute gimmick; sometimes, it is a fatal flaw.
As is customary in S.E.C. civil cases, Alpine Capital Management (which is not related to the finance group run by Oded Aboodi, the Time Warner adviser) did not admit any wrongdoing. But it agreed to the filing in December of a court order permanently barring the firm from violating securities laws in the future.
Both Edwin J. Pittock, Alpine's chief executive, and John I. Dickerson, its chief investment officer, were out of the office last week and staff members said they could not be reached. Questions about the fate of the firm's mutual funds were referred to Tom Waymire, who said he was a consultant hired by Alpine to handle the fund liquidations.
Mr. Waymire described the funds' experience with the S.E.C. as "quite cordial." The regulators' complaint, he said, was merely a technical device that permitted the S.E.C. to seek a court-appointed receiver. He said that Alpine had decided on its own to liquidate the two muni funds "as a purely economic decision," but found that their assets were taking longer than anticipated to sell.
And no wonder. Municipal lease obligations arise when property or equipment is leased to a town or other governmental unit; the future lease payments are supposed to produce the income stream for the lease investors. These instruments have become something of a fad among mutual funds because, like junk bonds in years past, they carry above-average interest rates and thus help boost a fund's advertised yield. That, in turn, can attract new investors.
But muni leases carry a higher coupon for a reason: They're riskier, because there is no ready market for them. "I wouldn't say they were 'illiquid,' because I think of that as something that cannot be sold," Mr. Waymire said. "But it just takes a while for somebody to buy them."
Well, it takes longer than a week, anyway. Especially if the leases are in default, as about 10 percent of these were. Thus, the funds were unable to honor their statutory obligation to redeem investors' shares within seven days, he explained.
"It wasn't that the funds did anything wrong," Mr. Waymire said. "The problem is that the S.E.C. does not have a way that they could have just allowed us to suspend redemptions while we continued with our asset sales. They don't have any middle ground, other than to enforce the seven-day rule. So they had to come up with something to permit them to appoint a receiver," he continued. "These were technical things. We're not mad at anybody," he added. 'And we don't think the S.E.C. is mad at anybody."
The S.E.C. officials in Denver, who handled the case, will say no more than they said on Nov. 20, when they went to their local United States District Court to ask that the funds' assets be frozen and a receiver be appointed to oversee the liquidation. But what the regulators said then seems to go a bit beyond "technical" violations.
They complained, for example, that Alpine and the funds were violating some basic provisions of the Investment Company Act of 1940, including the seven-day rule. The board of trustees overseeing the funds did not have the required number of independent members, the S.E.C. charged, and net asset values were not accurately calculated. The regulators further complained that the funds had taken out improper loans, had sold fund assets to an affiliate, and had kept inadequate financial and shareholder records.
A receiver has been appointed to try to sell the municipal leases, but no one can predict how long that process will take or how much money it will raise. Court documents showed that, as of Nov. 14, National Municipal Asset Trust had just $1.9 million in assets, down from $6.8 million on July 31, while the larger California trust had $17 million, down from $27.7 million just a month earlier.
Until this fire sale is completed, of course, shareholders cannot redeem their shares or estimate how much they will eventually get. But their predicament illustrates a paradox that worries a number of mutual fund regulators: People would never dream of sinking all their money into an exotic or risky investment; but they will not hesitate to put their money into a mutual fund that sinks all of its money into those same exotic instruments.
But Catholic diocesan debt that is difficult for an individual to price accurately may be no easier to evaluate when a fund owns it. And defaulted municipal leases, which a cash-strapped individual would find very difficult to sell in an emergency, are not any easier to unload just because the distressed seller is a mutual fund.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Banking Crisis Moves To Europe

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Just when Wall Street had concluded the worst was over for the banks, the rumblings of crisis have begun to arrive from Europe. If the good news for American banks is that the recession has exposed this continent's bad credits, the bad news may be that the process is just getting under way in Europe, where economies are weakening.
Last week, the European financial press was filled with stories of various bank problems. Christiana Bank, Norway's second largest, announced a huge loss and will need another capital infusion. Swedish banks saw their losses mounting and in Spain the central bank had to step in to salvage Banco Ibercorp. The Scandinavian problems appear to be bad loans exacerbated by falling real estate prices. The Spanish losses seem to have resulted more from freewheeling trading gone wrong, with the possibility of an overlay of political scandal. 
 Then, in Canada, rumors flew about Olympia & York, the big real estate company whose pioneering Canary Wharf development in London has turned into a money pit. Olympia & York is selling assets and says there is no danger it will default on its loans. But banks with exposure to Olympia & York, among them J.P. Morgan and Citicorp, saw their share prices slip.
For better or worse, the growing problems in European banks come at a time when world financial integration is more complete than ever before. The distinctions between various financial institutions has blurred, and they all trade innovative financial products with one another. Banks and industrial companies can place huge bets on such things as interest rates and currencies in all kinds of markets, and the existence of those bets may or may not show up on financial statements.
The result, regulators say nervously, is that they don't know what is going on. In an extraordinaary speech in London last week, Alexandre Lamfalussy, the industrial world's top central banker, talked of "a greater fragility of our payment and financial systems" and said globalization and financial innovations may have created "fertile ground for full-blown crises."
Mr. Lamfalussy, general manager of the Bank for International Settlements, known as the central banks' central bank, questioned whether anyone can calculate the risks involved in the current system. "The hard fact is that the resilience of our new financial environment has not yet been tested by a genuine worldwide recession," he said.
That test won't come if the American recovery proceeds, but at the moment the stock market's confidence in that is starting to slip. The Dow Jones industrial average fell to a seven-week low as the February employment report was weaker than expected. Cyclical stocks are no longer the stars of the market.
It still seems probable that the American economy has bottomed and is starting to recover. But it would be easier to say that with confidence if the news from Europe were better.

HEADLINE: Stealing Toward Russian Capitalism

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
Olga Romanova, a middle-aged woman in a babushka, painstakingly stamps out small copper parts for garden tools on a giant, inefficient metal press on the main floor of the state-owned Electropribor factory here. But instead of working for the factory, Ms. Romanova is working for one of the factory's senior executives, who has become an entrepreneur on the side. In effect, he rents machinery and floor space from himself and operates a profitable private business within a state factory.
The arrangement is typical of the creeping privatization in the old Soviet Union, a spontaneous process that is steadily shifting public property to private use, mostly as a result of the ingenuity, energy and adroitness of people like Ms. Romanova's boss, Viktor Todoryk. Nowhere else in the former Communist Bloc nations is privatization proceeding more rapidly today, or with less respect for master plans devised by economists and government officials. 
 "You can make the argument that the economic situation is so bad that the fastest way to save the Commonwealth is to give the assets to the managers, or to managers and workers, and let them get busy," said William Hogan, an expert on Ukraine at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. "It may be a form of robber baronry and a good idea, both at the same time."
That is one view, widely held. Boris Pinsker, a Russian economist, offers another, also widely held. "It is as if your President Bush set up a dummy company that leased the ground floor of the White House for $50 a month, charged tourists $100 a month and kept the profit," Mr. Pinsker said.
Despite the debate, managers of thousands of state enterprises, often acting in defiance of government rules, are using various strategies, among them Mr. Todoryk's, to gradually convert their companies into independent corporations, with themselves in control, much like chief executives in the United States control corporations owned by shareholders.
They are particularly active in Ukraine, whose capital is Kiev, and in Russia, the two most populous and industrialized republics. But they run the risk of having their enterprises canceled by government ministers increasingly irritated that insiders might be stealing state companies.
"One way to deal with this is to limit the activities of state enterprises so that managers no longer have so much power," said Dimitri V. Vasilyev, deputy chairman of Russia's Privatization Committee.
 
The Buccaneer Spirit
 But right now they do have the power, and examples of their buccaneer spirit are sprinkled through the Commonwealth of Independent States. The managers of a Russian aircraft company formed a private joint venture company with a British partner and gave the new air cargo operation control over four state-owned planes. The partners are flying cargo worldwide. The president of a consumer products company in Kiev with 5,000 workers leases the company from the state and is now angling to buy it for a token price. And the top executives of the Vaz Auto Works, the General Motors of Russia, are organizing a joint stock company that would give them long-term control.
Mr. Todoryk, who is 30, is typical of the new managers. He is not some outsider, but a senior engineer at Electropribor, and he has responsibility for the state factory's regular products -- small motors, electric water pumps, gauges and machinery parts. But clearly Mr. Todoryk's enthusiasm has veered toward his own endeavors, the latest a wooden-handled garden tool that can be used as a hoe, a shovel and a weeding rake. "People who have country dachas have told me that they need a tool like this for their summer vegetable gardens," he said.
The garden tool operation, which he claims is making a profit of 20,000 rubles a month on revenues of more than 75,000 rubles, is not the only venture of Mr. Todoryk, an intense workaholic whose worn gray suit, seedy by American standards, masks the catalytic role that he and other managers like him are playing in this early stage of the Commonwealth's capitalism. Most are men in their 30's and early 40's who were working their way up the old hierarchy of centrally controlled companies when that system began to collapse in the late 1980's.
Under the influence of Perestroika back then, Mr. Todoryk talked his older bosses into transforming Electropribor's trade division into a separate company that now sells the factory's products abroad, collecting fees for the service. Another venture, initiated by one of Mr. Todoryk's fellow managers, leases and runs the company cafeteria for the 2,000 employees. Yet another venture assembles electric heaters for export, using parts supplied by a foreign partner. And there are a dozen more examples -- all of them profitable in Mr. Todoryk's eyes, although his definition of profitability wouldn't pass muster with an American accounting firm.
Now, Mr. Todoryk and a few colleagues say they are preparing the next step -- setting up a shareholder's corporation that would purchase Electropribor itself at a nominal price. As Mr. Todoryk described the plan, a big chunk of the capital for the purchase would come from the ventures that feed off the company.
Initially, the Ukrainian Government, as Electropribor's current owner, would have a 30 percent stake, perhaps to be sold later. The managers would have the right to purchase about 5 percent, and the the workers would also be offered shares.
Managers like Mr. Todoryk are counting on the workers to be passive shareholders, accepting management's strategies. Many, like Ms. Romanova, have benefited from Mr. Todoryk's ventures, moonlighting in them and often adding 500 rubles to their monthly wage of about 1,000 rubles. So they might agree to such leadership.
"Electropribor, as a state company, already belongs to all of us," Mr. Todoryk said, by way of justification. "If the state were to auction the company to the highest bidder, then we, the true owners, won't have the wealth to buy at the auction."
 
An Irreversible Tide?
 But the Russian and Ukrainian Governments, like Mr. Pinsker, the Moscow economist, generally don't recognize such a claim on ownership. Nor do various Eastern European countries deeply involved in converting state enterprises into private ones. Having stifled creeping privatization early, Poland, and to a lesser extent, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are trying to sell control of state companies through government-sponsored programs, with workers and other nationals receiving shares either free or at low cost.
The result is that privatization in Eastern Europe is proceeding at a snail's pace. Acceptable buyers are in short supply, said Simon Johnson, an economist at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business and a frequent traveler to Ukraine, where he runs a study of managers of state enterprises. "I don't think that the Ukrainian and Russian governments will be able to stop the spontaneous privatization now in progress," Mr. Johnson said. "Government is weaker here than in Poland and Hungary."
But the governments are trying. Both are in the process of enacting roughly similar privatization programs. Small enterprises, retail stores, restaurants and the like are to be sold at auction or directly to the managers and workers who run them. Large companies -- 5,000 or so in Russia and a smaller number in Ukraine, according to government estimates -- would be turned into corporations with the Government as the majority shareholder.
Top managers would be offered 5 percent of the shares and workers an additional 25 percent, either free or at book value. But book value -- the original cost of a factory and equipment, less depreciation for wear and tear -- might be next to nothing.
This approach gives government, rather than management, control of an enterprise. And eventually, the government's majority stake would be sold at free-market prices to investors. Only certain key industries, among them oil, would remain under government control into the 90's, said Mr. Vasilyev of the Russian Privatization Committee.
And what of the companies that are slipping away through creeping privatization? Would Mr. Todoryk have to give up his garden tool operation, although his type of leasing activity was authorized during Perestroika to encourage economic activity?
"That is a very difficult question," Mr. Vasilyev said. "We would limit such activities in the future, but I am not a supporter of forbidding things."
Bogdan Budzan, chief of the privatization process for the Ukrainian Government, is not so hesitant. "We will bring such people to trial and through the courts reverse this de facto privatization," he said.
 
A Fight for Autonomy

Threats of trials and lawsuits aside, privatization proceeds, even at the Vaz Auto Works in Togliatti, 700 miles east of Moscow, a giant state company that makes 700,000 of the 1.2 million cars produced in the Commonwealth.
Nikolai Glushkov, Vaz's vice general director, does not want to exclude the Government from ownership. Instead, he is fighting for management's right to run the company without being second-guessed, whoever the future owners turn out to be.
"It is very essential that management has the power to run the company, or we will have 24-hour-a-day meetings of workers and bureaucrats trying to tell us what to do," said Mr. Glushkov, a 42-year-old former physicist and English teacher. Like managers throughout the commonwealth, Mr. Glushkov and his colleagues stepped in to fill the vacuum created by the collapse of the central system that controlled companies.
"Management, in a sense, has become the owner of Vaz," Mr. Glushkov said. "We are highly underpaid, but we run the company as if we owned it, although we don't really."
A soon-to-be-organized holding company is to own Vaz's various divisions, with the Government as a major shareholder, a provision no one disputes. Other shareholders will include Vaz's 150 top executives, who will be permitted to purchase 5 percent of the stock. The plant's more than 200,000 workers will get up to 25 percent. Both management and workers will receive their stock either free or at nominal prices.
The trouble spot? A challenge by Government to Vaz management's attempt to be, as Mr. Glushkov puts it, the trustees for all the shareholders. Alexander Kovrigin, an official in Russia's Ministry of Autos, clearly aspires to have a voice in Vaz's operations, as well as in those of other auto companies and suppliers.
 
Foreign Capital
 On the other hand, joint ventures -- partnerships combining Russians and foreigners -- are more buffered from government, partly because they have been the chief means so far of attracting foreign investment. Typically, they have served as another vehicle for transferring state-owned property to private hands.
One Russian-British venture flies cargo all over the world with four Russian An-124 planes, returning dollar revenue to the partners: Heavylift Cargo Airlines of Britain and Volga Dnepr, a new company formed by executives in Russia's state-owned aircraft industry. The shareholders are state-owned airframe and engine manufacturing companies.
The British investment in this joint venture, formed last October, is nothing more than expertise -- Heavylift's marketing skills. It drums up clients, schedules cargo flights and collects tens of thousands of dollars in fees. The Russian investment is millions of dollars worth of aircraft and the crews to fly them.
What complicates the venture -- and illustrates the potential pitfalls for foreign investors -- is the cloudy issue of who owns the airplanes. Two of the An-124's are carried on the joint venture's books as owned by the Russian military and leased to the Russian partners in the joint venture, who in turn lease the planes to the joint venture -- all for fees that are not made public. Two other planes are carried as contributions from the Russian partners, which made them.
That raises two questions. First, are the Russians getting an adequate return for their investment, or should they do the marketing themselves and keep all the revenue? Second, what happens in the unlikely event that the Russian Government insists on withdrawing the planes?
The Russians might, in fact, decide that they can handle their own marketing in the future, in which case the joint venture might dissolve, said Bruce Buck, a partner in Skadden, Arps, Slate Meagher and Flom, the New York law firm that helped negotiate the deal and drew up the joint venture contract.
As to the second question, Mr. Buck doubts the Russian Government will renege, although the aircraft makers gave up public property. "It is difficult to apply our Western ideas to Russia's ownership concepts," he said.
Not only are the Russians struggling with shifting concepts of ownership in a post-communist world bent on adopting capitalism, but they also are vying to determine who will be in control. The issues appear to be far from resolved.
"The dangers are that the managers will be denied control, but no one else will get it," said Mr. Johnson, the Duke economist. "Or the workers will get control and mess things up, or the managers will get control and have no outside pressure to make them perform and stay honest."
 
 
 
A DAUNTING PRICE FOR SERVICES
 Many big industrial companies in the former Soviet Union provide their workers with housing, nurseries, schools and clinics. As privatization proceeds, no one is rushing to buy these costly items or even to maintain them.
Until central planning and government subsidies collapsed -- and making a profit became a goal -- managers of state-owned companies spoke with pride of the amenities that went with the job. They still speak this way, but a new, contradictory view is also emerging.
The Varegan Oil and Gas Company, which pumps 160,000 barrels of oil a day in Western Siberia, provides social services to its 60,000 workers, who live mostly in Raduzhny, a company town. "I have to take care of the people of Raduzhny," said Anatoly Sivak, director general of Varegan and Raduzhny's former mayor.
But having recently resigned as mayor, he is negotiating with the city to assume the social functions now financed by Varegan, with the city presumably levying taxes to foot the bills. "We cannot drop people," Mr. Sivak said, "But I want to keep under my authority only what the company needs to be profitable. We are moving toward the U.S. model."
So is the Vaz Auto Works, which provides many services for more than 200,000 workers. Vaz's managers speak of shifting these services to government.
More immediately, Fiat is considering an investment in Vaz, and as part of the proposed deal Vaz would spin off the social services into a separate division. The goal would be to insulate the return on Fiat's investment from the costs of hospitals, schools, nurseries and housing.
 
 
 
THE PRICE OF SERVICES
 Many big industrial companies in the former Soviet Union provide their workers with housing, nurseries, schools and clinics. As privatization proceeds, no one is rushing to buy these costly items or even to maintain them.

HEADLINE: Technology;
Talk About a Slogan for the Back-to-Basics 90's: Electrify!

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
All over the United States, utilities are diving into the technology of conservation, helping consumers install new light bulbs, electric motors and heating and cooling systems designed to use less electricity. The current thinking is that the nation should do the same work with less power, to allow generating stations that burn coal to be closed. These plants emit the ingredients of acid rain and also a high level of carbon dioxide, the single largest cause of the greenhouse effect.
But according to a contrarian school, this approach is backward. If pollution or the greenhouse effect is really the problem, according to the counter-theory, there is a technical fix at hand. It is to use as much electricity as possible. 
 How can burning more coal, oil and gas in power plants help the environment? According to Mark P. Mills, a long-time energy consultant, some technologies can perform work better with electricity than with other fuels. The idea has been around for a few years, but Mr. Mills has refined it and given it a name: ecowatts.
Ecowatts, he said, means using electricity instead of another fuel and gaining benefits for the global environment, often as a side effect of gains in convenience or economy or perhaps in alleviating local pollution. He points to lawn mowers.
In southern California, air pollution officials have instituted strict rules on lawn mower emissions. According to Mr. Mills, to meet the rules mowers will come to resemble cars, with electronic fuel injection and catalytic converters. That, he said, means the debut of the $650 lawn mower, and prices that high will just turn the state into a magnet for all the nation's used mowers, defeating the regulation. The answer, he said, is electric mowers, a technology that is hardly new but, he said, is underappreciated.
By Mr. Mills's calculation, the standard gasoline mower, at three horsepower, burns a quart in two hours. But the same job could be done with 2.2 kilowatt-hours of electricity. (A typical home uses about 20 kilowatt-hours a day.)
Burning the gasoline releases 36,800 B.T.U.'s of heat, by Mr. Mills's calculation, taking into account the energy that was used to refine the gasoline. The electricity created 24,400 B.T.U.'s, for an increase in efficiency of about one-third.
The savings in carbon dioxide emissions depends on the fuel used to make the electricity. If the fuel that was saved by retiring the mower -- in this case gasoline -- was used to make the electricity, then some of the oil used to make that gasoline would be left over, and total savings in carbon dioxide would be 2.1 pounds. If the kilowatts were the national average, made from nuclear power, natural gas, hydroelectricity, coal and oil, the savings would be 2.5 pounds, he said.
The impetus for the homeowner to switch to an electric mower would not, of course, be carbon dioxide, but rules like those in California that aim to limit conventional pollutants, like carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxide. The power plant would also pollute, of course, but less.
Electrification has planet-wide potential. Chauncey Starr, an energy expert and philosopher, is fond of telling audiences that cooking dinner over an open fire, as is often done in the third world, is only 2 percent efficient. If the same wood were burned in a boiler to make electricity, it would cook 10 or 15 dinners. Dr. Starr, who founded the Electric Power Research Institute, a nonprofit utility consortium in Palo Alto, Calif., uses the example to describe a strategy against deforestation, but it is obviously important as a greenhouse control strategy too.
All of this is music to the electric-utility industry, which, with its prominent smokestacks, has become the whipping boy for greenhouse activists. In addition, while fuel use for transportation, heating, industry and other purposes has been roughly unchanged since 1973, the year of the first oil embargo, fuel use for electric utilities has been galloping ahead. Of all the fuel used in this country, about 36 percent is converted to electricity before it is used, and by the end of the decade this figure will approach 40 percent. Transportation is a distant second, at 27 percent.
Outside experts generally agree Mr. Mills's examples are correct, although they often doubt his bottom line. But trivial as the lawn mower example may sound, the United States has about 84 million mowers.
And many other electric technologies have great potential. Mr. Mills points out that the economy now produces far fewer pounds of carbon dioxide per dollar of gross national product. He credits electrification. For example, he cites gains from the electrification of steel, paint drying, glass production and a dozen other technologies, including document shipping, which these days often means a fax machine instead of Federal Express.
Beyond convenience, he says, there could be another major incentive for switching to electric technologies: money. The lawn mower is a good example; nobody likes dragging a cord around and few people buy electric mowers. But over a seven-year lifetime, Mr. Mills says, using an electric lawn mower will cut carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons and other pollutants by an amount that has a dollar value. If the user could capture that value, said Mr. Mills, electric mowers would become far more tempting.
Some technologies not in the marketplace yet and unlikely to make their entry primarily to save carbon dioxide would still achieve that goal, he said. These include the following:
* Stabilizing toxic wastes. Instead of digging up contaminated soil and hauling it to a lined dump with a water collection system, put electrodes into the soil and zap it with so much power that the soil turns to glass, immobilizing the chemicals. That would cut energy use 20 percent.
* "Flying" between cities by train. Compared with an airplane, a magnetic-levitation train moving at more than 300 miles per hour would use 76 percent less energy per passenger mile, Mr. Mills calculates.
* Driving electric cars. A nine-mile trip would save 2.4 to 3.3 pounds of carbon dioxide, depending, once again, on whether the power plant used the oil that was saved from the car or the national average fuel mix.
According to Mr. Mills, electrification thus far is the major factor in improving the ratio of G.N.P to carbon dioxide, from 4 pounds per dollar in 1973 to about 2.3 pounds per dollar today. He recognizes two "structural changes" in the economy that helped the trend along: the construction since 1973 of a nuclear industry that provides about 20 percent of the nation's electricity without carbon dioxide production and the increase in auto fuel efficiency, with cars going 50 percent further on a gallon, on average. But those together account for only about 22 percent of the improvement, he said.
Charles Komanoff, a utility expert and consultant in New York, described the ecowatts premise as "credible." But other factors muddy the waters, he said.
One reason the American economy is 30 percent more energy efficient now than it was two decades ago is that lights and refrigerators do the same work with less power, Mr. Komanoff said. This is not electrical technologies substituting for technologies that use natural gas or coal; it is new electric refrigerators substituting for old electric refrigerators.
And there are always innovations using other fuels. The Gas Research Institute, for example, will soon test a new glass melter, powered by natural gas, that is expected to be 20 percent more efficient than conventional gas furnaces and 40 percent cheaper than a conventional electric furnace.
There are other factors. Steel making has largely moved abroad, so the carbon dioxide accrues to some other nation. And a bigger part of the mix in the American economy are goods and services that require less energy to make and did not exist a few years ago, like computer software.

HEADLINE: All About/The 'Little Four' Auto Exporters;
Detroit's Not-So-Obvious Rivals

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Last month, while Detroit's Big Three were trading jabs with Japan's largest auto makers, the Daihatsu Motor Company quietly announced that it would stop selling its Charade subcompact and Rocky sport-utility vehicle in the American market.
That announcement, coming from one of Japan's smaller automobile exporters, caused only the faintest of ripples in the American auto industry. After all, Daihatsu held only the tiniest share of the market -- 0.1 percent. Still, Daihatsu's retreat marked the first time a Japanese car company halted sales in the United States since Toyota temporarily pulled back more than 30 years ago. 
 But if Daihatsu was unable to crack the American market, what then are the prospects for other small-volume nameplates, like Japan's Suzuki, Isuzu and Subaru and South Korea's Hyundai?
So far, they appear to be faring well. All but Hyundai had sales declines last year that were less than the 11.2 percent sales drop for the total American auto market. And Suzuki was one of only six brands to have had sales gains in 1991. But analysts concede the low-end, niche markets are especially tough places to be.
Competitive market or not, the "Little Four" are committed to America. They all have built assembly plants in North America. And their sales record in a down year is impressive given their mission: selling lower-priced vehicles to customers easily turned away by a recession.
These companies are also targeting customers who face a dizzying array of choices. Though Daihatsu will stop distributing its cars in five months, Kia Motors of South Korea said in January it planned to start selling a lineup of utility vehicles next year. "They're a brave organization," said Thomas Dukes, director of competitive assessment for J. D. Power & Associates. "This market just gets tougher and tougher."

 
 
ECONOMY
 In the early 1980's, established Japanese importers handed over a sales opportunity to their smaller rivals. In response to import quotas set by Washington, auto makers such as Honda, Nissan, Mazda and Toyota started building pricier, more profitable cars, vacating the lowest-priced segment. Companies like Hyundai and Suzuki charged in, capitalizing on price-conscious consumers.
When the automobile industry grew briskly in the late 1980's, there was room for everyone. Besides, profits were too small to be of much interest to the biggest auto makers. But as sales have turned down, auto makers in every price category have been scrambling.
The Big Three, for example, have fine-tuned their pricing strategies to appeal to cost-conscious consumers. They have done this, in part, by offering low-cost leases.
For example, Oldsmobile began selling its new import fighter this year, the Achieva, with an unusually inexpensive new-model lease special of $199 a month, no money down, for four years. One leasing consultant estimated the incentive costs Oldsmobile as much as $2,200 per car.
"When big players are that aggressive, they can squeeze the small players out," said Susan Jacobs, an automotive consultant based in Little Falls, N.J. As a result, "the time for easy entry has passed," she said.

 
 
How to Stand Out
Four Doors When Others Offer Two
 Despite the challenge of introducing a new car line in the United States, analysts note that there is always room for vehicles that capture the public's imagination. That was part of Daihatsu's problem, analysts say. Though uniformly praised for quality and reliability, Daihatsu's entrants did not stand out. According to Ms. Jacobs, even the lowest-priced models must do more than simply match the competition in order to sell.
Indeed, the most successful start-ups can be traced to an auto maker's ability to spot a niche and fill it quickly. Isuzu was the first to offer an inexpensive four-door imported sport-utility vehicle with its 1984 Trooper model. They have sold briskly ever since, giving Isuzu 0.2 percent of the market last year. While that's not much market share compared with Detroit's, it's about average for the Little Four.
Suzuki began offering a compact sports utility vehicle in 1985 called the Samurai. Initially, this smartly styled vehicle sold well. But then Consumer Reports magazine, after testing the Samurai, deemed it unsafe in certain circumstances. Though other studies disputed these findings, sales dwindled. In 1991, Suzuki had just 0.1 percent of the market. Last year, it introduced a utility vehicle with four doors.
Subaru and Hyundai's offerings are more conventional. But both companies are trying to brighten their image. Subaru, which had 1.3 percent of the market in 1991, introduced its innovation-laden SVX sports car last year. It hopes to win buyers with gadgets like windshield wipers with a winter "park" position for easier snow removal. While design of the SVX is unorthodox, its technology has won trade-press plaudits. "A lot of people have a vision of us as very basic transportation," said Christopher B. Wackman, Subaru's vice president of marketing. "That's not necessarily true any longer."
Hyundai Motor America, the largest of the Little Four with 1.5 percent of the market, is also trying to energize its generic-design image with a striking two-seat sports car that it displayed at recent auto shows. Hyundai plans to introduce the car in 1995. Company officials say it is designed to compete with Mazda's Miata.
Korea's Kia plans to create a new niche with a rounded, compact, sport-utility vehicle that is distinct from the traditional boxy designs other companies offer.
Analysts say the smaller manufacturers are often nimbler than the larger companies and can often bring out new models more quickly. That gives them a big advantage. "Large companies frequently get muddled into community affairs and politics," said Thomas F. O'Grady, who heads Integrated Automotive Resources, a consulting firm in Wayne, Pa. "Sometimes the heads of companies get turned away completely from the company's goals."

 
 
Dealer Loyalties
Smaller Lines Are The First to Go
 Distinctive products are only part of a successful niche franchise; creative marketing and enthusiastic dealers are also key. The smaller importers generally trumpet their products' value and hope the decline of conspicuous consumption will make their products right for the times.
Some new advertisements by Subaru and Isuzu, for example, poke fun at consumers who search for status in their vehicles. The message must be effective, analysts said, but also must be repeated frequently to be heard.
How tough is building name recognition? After five years in the United States, Daihatsu was regularly confused with Hyundai by consumers because of the common "dai" in their names. "It is hard to break through," said C. R. Brown, executive vice president of Daihatsu America Inc.
The smaller imports are also typically added on to an existing dealer's franchise to complement the core model lines. But when overlap occurs, the add-on is the first to go. One dealer who sold Chevrolets and Geos in Phoenix, Ariz., dropped Daihatsu because its Rocky diluted sales of the Geo Tracker sport-utility vehicle.
"If it ever gets to the point that they're competing with the big boys, they're asking for trouble," said Dick E. Strauss, president of the National Automobile Dealers Association. Mr. Strauss sells Fords in Richmond, Va., as well as Isuzus and Suzukis. "Unless they offer the buyer something that is not available to them in any other lines, they can't compete."
 
 
 
STUCK IN THE MINOR LEAGUE
 Japan's Mitsubishi Motors Corporation was once among the smallest of the new Asian importers. After its first full year of sales starting in 1982, it sold just 30,000 vehicles with a little-remembered lineup of the Tredia, Starion and Cordia. It is now an auto maker in transition, trying to establish a larger presence in the United States.
Several key strategic decisions enabled it to grow quickly. From the start, it insisted on stand-alone showrooms rather than teaming up with other franchises. Dealers signed on with the promise that competing Mitsubishi franchises would be few and far between. Mitsubishi also bought the Value rental car agency to expose its products to the public and insure a good stock of used cars for dealers. It built a manufacturing plant with Chrysler in Normal, Ill., and set up its own financing company last year.
"Mitsubishi never acted like a little guy," said Thomas F. O'Grady, an automotive consultant based in Wayne, Pa.
Mitsubishi has also solidified its image in recent years with new offerings of technologically advanced, value-oriented cars, like the Diamante luxury sedan and the 3000GT sports coupe. With a $100 million advertising budget, it has gained name recognition.
But will it ever graduate to the first tier? Not with its present strategy, some analysts say. For example, the largest Japanese importers all have separate luxury divisions and economy divisions. These distinct brands give the auto makers more reach and marketing focus. By contrast, Mitsubishi showrooms house models that range from subcompact cars to the Diamante and Montero, luxury models with prices that range above $25,000.
"Just selling cars under its main badge is going to keep them in the second tier," said Susan Jacobs, an automotive consultant in Little Falls, N.J.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: William and Mary;
Raising Money For One's School Before Graduation

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.

 BODY:
Students at the College of William and Mary are not waiting to become alumni before they start raising money for their college.
The college's Student Advancement Association, a 40-member group, has been working to help raise money for the Campaign for the Fourth Century, which is seeking $150 million in contributions by the time the college marks its 300th anniversary next year. The money would be used to finance scholarships, hire professors, make renovations and acquire museum art. 
 While alumni and development officials are expected to raise the bulk of the money, the student group has already begun to see results from its efforts.
 
$204,000 Endowment
 From a series of campaigns ranging from sponsoring bicycle races to auctioning William and Mary memorabilia at Christie's in New York City, the students have raised a $24,000 endowment for student scholarships, visiting professorships and library materials. A 1989 grant by an alumnus, who promised to match up to $25,000 raised by the students, continues to enrich the group's bank account.
The student association "was initiated by students to serve the needs of students," said John Graham, a senior who is the group's executive director. Although college officials say the Campaign for the Fourth Century addresses all areas of need at the university, "we wanted to make sure that student priorities were addressed," said Mr. Graham, a government major from Marion, Va.
This year, for example, the university fell about $800,000 short of its financial assistance goal, said the director of the university financial aid office, Edward Irish. In the fall, the student association awarded its first need-based scholarship of $450.
The association also serves as a "spirit club," Mr. Graham said. Its members have learned the words to the university's alma mater, a tune written in 1902, and the association initiated a course on the history of William and Mary University. The association sponsors concerts featuring student musicians and holds book sales to benefit the library as well.
 
Not Just Stuffing Envelopes
 At other universities and colleges, student fund-raising is limited to stuffing envelopes and telephoning alumni for contributions, said the president for university advancement, Edward Allenby, but William and Mary students also attend alumni functions and travel with development officers.
The program teaches students about business and communications, as well as "preparing students to be good alumni" themselves, Mr. Allenby said.
The association "really gives me a second education at William and Mary," said William Baxter, a senior from Richmond, who is majoring in government. That shadow curriculum, he said, is made up of public relations, finance and contacts with people in the business community.
"It puts you in touch with the real world," he added. "I'm finally getting a grip on how much money it takes to run the institution."
Although the association has asked local businesses that are patronized by students to become "friends of the college" for $250 donations, the students have raised only $500 this way. The group has also been researching foundations that give donations to universities and asking for pledges, but so far none have made donations.
"A lot of times you're too late," Mr. Graham said, noting that many businesses approached by the group have already allocated their philanthropy money to other organizations. "And sometimes they cannot give because of the economic conditions."
Despite the difficulties, Mr. Graham said, "It's exciting to know that you are helping other students while getting practical experience."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS: Jumping on Language, Prices and Such

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
THE mailbox overflows, so it's time again for a smattering of comment and query. But how to begin? Well. . . . 
 Dear Sir,
You used the term "jump-start" accurately in the recent column about your grandfather's old Chrysler, but I don't know if your usage was intended as a quiet protest or an effort to educate. Certainly, "jump-start" is one of this season's more widely misused terms.
My first letter on the subject was to the Times editor regarding an illustration accompanying an article on jump-starting New York City's economy. The illustration depicted a gaping automobile hood with snakelike booster cables in the foreground. Booster cables indeed!
I told the editor that it had been booster cables and not jump-starting that the writers in their ignorance had been thinking about. I concluded with my own thoughts about how the term may have derived, which was that the car hopped or jumped as one let in the clutch. My runner-up opinion was that when it was a solo operation, jumping on the running board was a key step in the process.
In any event, I never heard back from The Times. Apparently the editors didn't agree. I'd all but given up my quest as futile, but you've given me hope.
 
JOHN KOSTER
Wilton, Conn.
 
You're right that the term, which means use of the car's own momentum to turn the engine and thus start it, is oft applied in mistaken fashion. Part of the problem is that booster cables, used to connect a good battery to a bad one, have come to be known as "jumpers." And then there is the predominance of automatic transmissions and the difficulty, not to say impossibility, of jump-starting such a vehicle.
Your definitions sound likely, though, and they remind me of the time I tried to start my '51 Ford Victoria by rolling it down a hill in New London, Conn. I kept popping the clutch, all to no avail. When I got to the bottom, I discovered that the ignition was off. I think I should have begun by jump-starting my brain.

HEADLINE: We Must Restore Higher Tax on Top Incomes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Fake Fixes for the Economy" (editorial, Feb. 25), while assessing the tax proposals of Congress and the Administration, makes no alternative proposal. Last weekend, while doing calculations preparatory to filing my income tax, I came across some figures that I believe accurately reflect the problem of the middle class. 
 Assume that I had $50,000 of taxable income in 1979 and again in 1991. My income tax and self-employment tax for 1979 were $6,400; for 1991, $10,400. Medical insurance premiums for 1979, $2,100; for 1991, $7,100. Local property taxes (for the same house), in 1979, $2,118; in 1991, $5,623. Cost per year at an Ivy League college in 1979, $13,250; in 1991, $22,600. Cost of a midsize car in 1979, $9,800; in 1991, $19,000. The totals are, for 1979, about $34,000; for 1991, about $65,000.
The two bank stocks in my individual retirement account are worthless, both closed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. One insurance company in which I had tax-sheltered annuities is in receivership, after it invested in junk bonds.
I, like most of my peers, was not a member of the merger-and-acquisition, leveraged-buyout or real-estate-dealing fraternities, the ones who made the big bucks during the Reagan years. As you can readily see, I am no longer able -- despite being in the top 2 percent of wage earners in the country -- to spend to affect the economy. Even with another $1 or $2 a day, I will have to spend judiciously, whether for a car, a suit, theater in New York or an evening meal out.
When I started law school, the top-income bracket was taxed at 91 percent, dropping to 70 percent under President Kennedy. The huge loss of revenues to the Treasury caused by the Reagan tax cuts did not, as hoped, spur the economy. Most of the people who saved tax dollars seem simply to have lent that money to the Treasury, by buying long-term bonds, to cover the ever-increasing deficits.
The people who made the big bucks did so not by creating new businesses but in the way depicted in the play "Other People's Money." When Mobil bought Conoco, fewer jobs resulted. When Briggs & Stratton moved its production to Mexico, thousands of hard-working people with a strong work ethic lost jobs replaceable only at minimum-wage levels and without either pension or medical coverage.
This country's most pressing social need is a national health plan. Its most pressing economic need is to free tax revenues.
I urge a new tax at the rate of 75 percent on all incomes, however derived, in excess of $750,000, and at 91 percent on all incomes over $1 million, with the proceeds used exclusively to reduce the deficit. If the taxation necessary to pay interest on the national debt could be reduced from 25 cents of each dollar in taxes paid down to the 3 cents to 4 cents paid in the 1960's, all of us could have a substantial tax cut, and the heavy hitters could be assured of a steady stream of income.
The consumer, who is the ultimate payer of those incomes -- by paying property taxes to pay for municipal bonds, by higher product prices to pay for advertising to sell the cars and the beer -- could continue to consume.
 
MELVIN J. SILVERMAN
Norwalk, Conn., Feb. 25, 1992

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Is 'Local Content' The Smartest Way To Judge Imports?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Back when Detroit first woke up to the dimensions of the Japanese challenge in automobiles in the early 1980's, its leaders said they needed three concessions to compete fairly. First, the Japanese would have to build many of their cars in America, so that they would face the same costs and restrictions that dog American auto makers. Second, they would have to put numerical limits on their exports from Japan. And third, those import limits would have to stay in effect for a number of years, so that the Big Three would have time to get their act together.
They got all three, and a decade later Detroit is in worse shape than ever. Now the Bush Administration is raising a new set of "local content" hurdles and, to hear the Japanese tell it, systematically harassing Japanese business interests in America with regulations and investigations. 
 These days such complaints are not about to get much sympathy in Congress or a recession-mired America, and perhaps the Japanese are simply getting a small taste of what they have dished out for decades to American companies in Tokyo. But the Administration's recent actions have raised a question that few politicians in America seem likely to debate in any detail in an electoral season: Does cracking down on Japan in America truly help American workers in Detroit and elsewhere, or does it hamper the effort to get Japan and other countries to move their best technologies, their best plants and their best jobs to America?
The issue came to the fore clearly last week when the Customs Service came down on Honda for its import of cars built at its plant in Canada. The Government ruled that these cars do not meet the requirement that they contain 50 percent or more "North American content," and thus do not qualify for tariff-free import under the free trade pact with Canada. Honda and Canada dispute that.
 
Two-Sided Argument
 There are endless arguments on both sides over how to measure "local content," and a reasonable argument can be made as to whether Honda passed the test or failed it. In its calculations, Honda includes manufacturing processes and factory depreciation costs that Customs says do not really add to domestic content; the Government says many components of major car parts, such as Honda's Ohio-made engines, can be quickly traced back to a web of Japanese suppliers, even though they pass through American hands.
Indeed local content can be defined to fit any agenda. "It is easy to set up a sham 'domestic supplier' who is actually the subsidiary of a Japanese company doing minimal assembly on a Japanese-designed component," J. Michael Farren, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs, noted recently. The Japanese Government responded last week with a survey of 931 Japanese-owned manufacturing operations in the United States showing that more than 60 percent get more than two-thirds of their materials in America.
Japan's complaint -- echoing that of American firms that struggled to break into industries here -- is that America is making up the rules on the fly to insure that outsiders stay outside. Last week officials in Tokyo charged that election-year politics influenced the Honda decision and Kozo Watanabe, Japan's Trade Minister, ordered an investigation into whether Japanese companies were suffering discrimination.
In any case, Honda is an odd choice for a first victim. It is widely viewed as a model of "Americanization," and the United States came to its defense recently when the Europeans tried to classify Ohio-made Hondas as Japanese imports, not American. But emotion increasingly rules the day on Japan issues. The Japanese blanched last week when Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, a Democrat, told a group of American factory workers that they "should draw a mushroom cloud and put underneath it: 'Made in America by lazy and illiterate Americans and tested in Japan.' " The Japanese view such comments as part of an American temper tantrum. They lump into the same category efforts by Attorney General William P. Barr to change Justice Department guidelines so that he can pursue foreign business groups that collude to restrict American exports. Meanwhile Congress is toying with changing the definition of Japanese minivans to "trucks" so that they can be slapped with 25 percent duties.
All these moves are ultimately defended as tactics to protect American jobs. Local content rules, in theory, assure that Honda is forced to hire American assembly workers and buy American parts. That worked wonderfully when parts were designed, engineered and made in the same place. Unfortunately, the manufacturing world is no longer so simple.
As the Japanese have proven better than anyone, the trick is not simply keeping jobs in the country but keeping the right kind of jobs -- the kind that nurture skills and technologies for more industrial growth. Local content rules, however, are imprecise weapons, treating all car components as essentially the same, whether they are a hunk of engine block or a high-tech cluster of electronic engine controls. Often the least "value added" in a part comes from actually manufacturing it; the real value is in the design and the creation of the tools needed to make it.
But as a matter of policy, the United States seems unsure what kind of work it wants to assure for American suppliers.
The trick is not simply to force Japan to produce more goods in America, but to get it to perform its most complicated technological feats there, with American workers. That might seem like a variety of industrial policy, something the Bush Administation rejects. But local content rules, commitments for parts purchases and guarantees about how many American cars will be sold in Japan are all a form of industrial policy, too. The question is whether it is the right form.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
How the Cholera Scare Is Waking Latin America

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: IQUITOS, Peru

 BODY:
Cholera, as it turns out, may have saved more people than it killed in the Americas in 1991.
"Last year in Latin America, 4,000 people died of cholera," said Carlos Moreno Chacon, director of Peru's anti-cholera campaign. "During the same time, 100,000 to 150,000 Latin American children did not die of acute diarrhea. Public awareness over cholera and medical preparation made the difference." 
 Although cholera has hospitalized 440,000 people and killed 1 percent of those, many public health experts say that the most lasting effect of the cholera outbreak that began a year ago may be its scare value. Cholera is being used as a lever to force Latin America's governments to attack the less dramatic -- but statistically more deadly -- problems of dirty drinking water and untreated sewage. These conditions, reminiscent of 19th-century Europe and the United States, have been a major contributor to infant mortality in 20th-century Latin America. In 1990, 914,000 Latin American and Caribbean children died before they reached the age of five.
So the cholera outbreak serves as a reminder that Latin America, like the rest of the third world, remains overwhelmed by physical or social conditions that make easily treatable or preventable diseases into the biggest killers; the principal cause for child mortality in the region is still acute diarrhea caused not by cholera but by gastroenteritis. And the very fact that these diseases are accepted as a part of the social landscape makes it difficult to change the conditions in which they thrive. An agent for such change can be a dramatic scourge that threatens rich as well as poor, and that is now the case with cholera.
It is, in a way, similar to what is happening because of AIDS. The realization that 1 million Latin Americans are infected with the AIDS-causing virus has spurred health authorities to launch safe sex campaigns that are expected to reduce venereal diseases and unwanted pregnancies.
"There is an almost mythical sensitivity about epidemics," said Tomas Jimenez, a Spanish economist in Bogota who is a writing a book for Unicef on the health status of Latin America's children. "Cholera has set off a flashing alarm light over the lack of access to potable water and to sewage treatment for a great part of Latin America's population."
Citing the threat from cholera, a water- and food-borne disease that can kill a healthy person in six hours, health ministers from 10 South American nations met in Buenos Aires two weeks ago to draw up a plan to invest $200 billion over 12 years to upgrade water, sewage and basic health facilities for Latin America's poor. About two-thirds of the money is to come from Latin American governments and the rest will be sought from foreign governments and multilateral agencies.
"If cholera serves as a stimulus for these investments, it will have had a useful impact," said A. David Brandling-Bennett, chairman of the cholera task force of the Pan American Health Organization, a Washington-based group that backs the investment plan. "The program will eliminate cholera. But it will also reduce incidence of diarrhea in children, improve infant mortality and adult life expectancy."
Other factors also influence infant mortality rates in Latin America, of course: how much education the mother has, the prevalence of respiratory diseases, and whether infants can be immunized.
The concrete impact of aid against cholera can already be seen in Iquitos, the largest city of the Peruvian Amazon. At this time last year, the Hospital de Apoyo was receiving 70 cholera cases a day. Today, the rate averages one case a day. A major factor for the drop was the installation of a sewage incinerator, installed with a $15,000 grant from the Pan American Health Organization.
"Before, untreated sewage from the cholera wards was coming up at street level five blocks below the hospital," Segundo Pinillos Reyes, chairman of the region's anti-cholera campaign, said in an interview at the hospital. Despite such local improvements and the attention that the cholera outbreak has focused on the need to improve basic sanitation, epidemiologists believe that cholera will probably be present in the Americas through the 1990's.
Last week, one year's worth of Brazilian public health prevention was put to the test when hundreds of people suffering from cholera symptoms flooded hospitals in Recife, a major city on Brazil's impoverished northeast coast. On Friday, Brazil's Health Minister, Adib Jatene, declared cholera an epidemic in his nation. Over the last year, the bacteria has moved slowly down the Brazilian Amazon to the coast, hospitalizing 3,600 people, 54 of whom have died. With the exceptions of Paraguay and Uruguay, all Latin American nations have reported cholera cases.
 
Advance Warning
 But this is still relatively encouraging. Of the total of 441,000 cases, 81 percent have occurred in Peru. Many of the other countries have kept their case rates comparatively low by taking advantage of the advance warning offered by the initial appearance of the disease in Peru on Jan. 23, 1991. Hundreds of Latin American doctors flew to this country to learn how to prevent cholera and how to treat victims. "It was not as bad as we expected," Barbara Lopes Cardozo, a Dutch doctor for the international aid group, Doctors Without Borders, said in Manaus, capital of Brazil's Amazonas state. "People had been warned to cook food, to boil their water, and to wash their hands."
With the return of the Southern Hemisphere summer in December, Peru has been experiencing a resurgence of the bacteria, which is historically associated with coastal areas and which has thrived in Lima, a Pacific Coast capital of eight million people. On Friday, Los Angeles health examiners said food prepared in Lima gave cholera to 76 passengers on a Feb. 14 flight from Buenos Aires to Lima and Los Angeles. Because of a severe drought, half of Lima's population underwent water rationing in February. With water precious, drinking inevitably takes precedence over washing and sanitation suffers.
"Cholera is a misery thermometer," said Luis Antonio Loyola, an Argentine doctor who represents the Pan American Health Organization here. He and other public health officials hope that the highly visible cholera thermometer will provoke governments to treat the underlying causes.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Why International Statistical Comparisons Don't Work

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Living standards in the United States have fallen behind those in Germany, Japan, even Finland. The pay and productivity of once-proud American workers trail those of a dozen or so other nations. The short-sighted United States invests half as much as far-sighted Japan.
These dispiriting and widely cited statistics have one thing in common: They are wrong. 
 In fact, contrary to today's conventional wisdom, the United States remains the richest and most productive economy in the world. That's true even though other industrial nations have been growing faster -- and narrowing the gap -- practically since the United States became No. 1 in the first place, in about 1910.
Certainly, Americans can't afford to be complacent. If some of the worrisome trends in the United States economy -- from increasingly ill-prepared workers to skimpy savings -- continue long enough, today's dubious statistic could turn into tomorrow's hard fact.
But part of what's unnecessarily stoking Americans' anxiety is a handful of false comparisons based on faulty ways of calculating the economic scorecard. Much of the trouble arises in converting other nations' output, consumption or investment from yen, marks or lire into dollars of comparable buying power.
The widespread practice -- in place everywhere from the lofty World Bank to the nightly news -- of using currency market exchange rates seriously distorts comparisons because it does not take account of different price levels -- higher rents in Tokyo than Toledo, cheaper cherries in Bologna than Bristol, the fact that maids are affordable for most middle-class families in Mexico but for few families in Minneapolis.
Put another way, not taking account of different prices in different countries makes as little sense as comparing your pay today with your salary in 1978 without factoring in the doubling of prices in that interval.
Besides, exchange rates gyrate with wars, business cycles and urges by foreign investors to buy American bonds. None of these reflect real changes in economic fundamentals.
Economists rely on so-called purchasing power parity exchange rates. "If you're making comparisons using PPP's, you come much closer to the truth with a capital T, " said Robert Summers, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania who, together with his colleague Allan Heston, helped introduce the whole notion.
So what do the facts, correctly measured, say? Start with that most basic yardstick of wealth, economic development and well-being, a country's gross domestic product -- the sum of what it produces inside its own borders -- divided by the population. The United States is still on top, 17 percent ahead of Germany and a surprising 22 percent ahead of Japan.
What a nation produces, however, includes a great many things -- from missiles to private security guards to new factories -- that don't add immediately to the material well-being of its citizens. What about consumption, public and private -- which reflects how well people are living? According to Mr. Summers and Mr. Heston, the gap between America's consumer society and Germany's and Japan's, which devote more to investment, is even wider.
At this point someone is apt to point out that there's more to life than material goods -- namely, the time to enjoy them. As it turns out, busy Japanese workers work about 260 hours more a year than Americans -- 2,052 hours in total -- to achieve their lower living standard. Germans, on the other hand, may have living standards 15 percent below those of Americans, but they also work 10 percent fewer hours. In many peoples' eyes, these leisure-loving people -- who get six-week vacations -- may be very close to having it all.
What lets Americans live better while loafing more than their Japanese rivals is higher -- yes, higher -- productivity. Contrary to the widespread view that the Japanese economy is vastly more efficient, every comparison shows that output per employee is 40 percent greater in the United States. America also has the most efficient service industries and agriculture.
In some sectors of manufacturing, Japan and Germany are much closer to Yankee efficiency. Japanese productivity is about 80 percent that of America's, while Germany's hovers at about 75 percent. Canada's is the closest. What's more, factory productivity growth abroad slowed in the 1980's, just as it spurted in the United States.
Hard to believe? Japan is hyperefficient as a maker of cars, VCRs and industrial and office equipment. But not enough to offset being relatively inefficient at turning out pharmaceuticals, aircraft, textiles, construction material, processed food and raw materials.
 
$21.53 an Hour
 American politicians have lately been griping that American factory workers trail their counterparts in Europe badly when it comes to pay. Pay here is $14.77 an hour, they say, lower than in at least 12 other countries and positively paltry compared with Germany's princely $21.53 an hour. But adjusting for Germany's higher cost of living shrinks the German advantage to a few pfennig.
What matters for future living standards, of course, is how much a nation invests in new technology, plants and equipment. A rallying cry of late has been that Japan spends twice as much as the United States. That turns out to be a bit of a tall tale based on ignoring the high cost of building in Japan. Correctly measured, Japan invests about 28 percent of G.D.P., versus 19 percent for the United States -- nowhere near twice as much. Surprisingly, the American rate is not far below that of Germany, France and Italy, which plow just 21 or 22 percent of their G.D.P. into the next generation of machines, factories and office buildings.
The United States, not Japan and certainly not Finland, is still the richest and most competitive economy. But for the last 15 years, the United States has consumed more, invested less and grown more slowly than any other industrial nation. Will it remain in the lead? Simple extrapolation often fails because it ignores peoples' ability to change course. Which road is taken will depend on what happens from here on, not on the past.


GRAPHIC: Subtle differences in measurement can dramatically affect how the United States ranks against other countries.
Chart/Table: "Little adjustments make big differences"
In the first pair of tables, G.N.P. and G.D.P. are essentially identical. Using purchasing power parity when converting to dollars adjusts the result for differences between domestic prices -- like Japan's high housing costs or Italy's low food costs. But some institutions like the World Bank use currency market exchange rates, which gyrate wildly from year to year.
The United Nations' Human Development Index is a controversial standard of living measure that combines gross domestic product -- the goods and services a nation produces within its borders -- with other indicators of well-being. The basic index -- at left, below -- averages a nation's per capita income with its literacy rate and life expectancy. Though Japan's per capita income is less than two-thirds that of the United States, it is ranked highest because its citizens tend to live three years longer. The ranking at center adds a factor that penalizes countries with large gaps between the rich and the poor. The ranking on the right penalizes them for disparities between men and women. On it, Finland ranks as the world's richest nation.

Human Development Index adjusted for life expectancy, literacy and income distribution; U.N. Human Development Index adjusted for life expectancy, literacy and sexual equality. (Sources: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development; World Bank; United Nations)

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Business Incentives: A High-Priced Letdown

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

DATELINE: NORTH TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
The stunning decision by the General Motors Corporation to close its 91-year-old assembly plant here, coming after 15 years of huge subsidies aimed at keeping big business in the region, has provoked bitter criticism over the taxpayer support of corporations and which, if any, industries should qualify.
G.M. announced Feb. 24 that it would shutter the North Tarrytown plant in 1995, eliminating 3,400 jobs in a region where manufacturing, once dominant, has been in harrowing decline. 
 The bad news, coming during the most stubbornly persistent recession in decades, was a particular blow because it arrived without warning. The auto maker, whose losses for 1991 were the largest in United States corporate history, had said earlier that it would embark on a series of plant closings, but had identified only two of its large-scale assembly plants, in Michigan and Texas, as possibilities.
Worse still, the North Tarrytown assembly plant, G.M.'s oldest and Westchester County's largest factory, had been a showpiece of public initiative. After surviving for decades as a manufacturing anomaly -- sprawling along 97 acres of scenic riverfront in one of the country's richest suburban enclaves -- the plant received a 10-year package of incentives in 1985 from New York State and Westchester County worth over $100 million.
The incentives, although larger than most, were similar to public subsidies that have been extended to many companies in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and many other states since the 1970's.
"We have been left holding the bag, and it is empty," said Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive.
Many experts say G.M.'s decision primarily reflected its shrinking share of the global automobile market and the high costs of doing business in a region where even generous public incentives cannot give manufacturers a competitive edge.
"The question may be, 'Why are we trying to retain dying industries?' " said Vincent Tese, president of New York State's Urban Development Corporation and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's chief economic adviser, in an interview last week.
In G.M.'s case, though, he said the state would keep trying. Even though the auto maker called its decision "irreversible," Mr. Tese and other officials said Monday that they had formed a new task force and were beginning to package new incentives to try to persuade the company to stay.
"We can't replace 3,400 skilled and semiskilled blue-collar jobs," Mr. Tese added, "and we are going to fight tooth and nail to save them."
 
Good Money After Bad
 But to some economists and urban planners, public subsidies to large businesses, particularly manufacturers, have become the government's equivalent of throwing good money after bad.
"We have to refocus on whether we are supporting business activity that has reasonable long-term prospects in this region," said Hugh O'Neill, an urban planner at New York University who was a member of the state's task force that negotiated G.M. incentives. Many light industries, including biotechnology, computer and high-technology electronics, would be more suitable than auto plants or other heavy manufacturing, Mr. O'Neill and other experts said.
G.M. is merely one of dozens of companies that received such incentives. They are varied, involving reduced property taxes, the elimination of sales taxes on supplies, subsidized energy, and bridge and road improvements. And although the value of the incentives is impossible to measure with any accuracy, experts say such arrangements were worth hundreds of millions of dollars to the recipients in the 1980's.
Still, despite fiscal problems, states, counties and municipalities across the tri-state area still offer new subsidies.
 
Still Going
 Less than a week before G.M. announced its closing here, Governor Cuomo visited Auburn, in Cayuga County, to announce that SnyderGeneral Corporation, a maker of air-conditioning equipment that had threatened to move to Tennessee, would remain in the upstate village, expand its plant and increase its work force there from 375 to 600.
"SnyderGeneral is a New York success story," Gov. Cuomo said as he handed the company a check for $6.3 million, derived from a low-interest state loan.
Other state incentives extended to the company include a $500,000 investment in the roads and other infrastructure around its plant.
In New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio announced late last year that the General Electric Company had signed a 10-year lease on a new assembly plant in Camden for its aerospace manufacturing division. As part of the deal, the state is spending $65 million to buy a site for the plant and an adjacent office building and will lease it to a developer, who in turn will have General Electric as his tenant.
Yet some attempts to sway business have misfired from their inception. In Hoboken, where the Maxwell House Coffee Company had operated a plant for over 50 years and threatened last year to move to Florida, the city along with the state offered the company low-interest loans, subsidized water and other inducements worth $7.1 million to stay. Maxwell House declined, moved to Jacksonville, affecting 600 jobs, and the Hoboken plant stands vacant.
But the deepest doubts raised about the corporate subsidies involve those in which companies have accepted public support and closed their doors anyway or, as in the case of G.M., announced they would leave after meeting their minimum obligations.
"We have just about given away the store," said Alfred B. Delbello, a Westchester County attorney who was New York State's Lieutenant Governor in 1985 and chief negotiator when G.M. accepted its 10-year package of incentives for the North Tarrytown plant.
Mr. Delbello's experience with corporations reflects the risks. As Mayor of Yonkers in 1972, he approved a package in which the city spent over $4 million to build a new assembly plant for the Otis Elevator Company, which was one of the city's biggest employers and had threatened to close.
Three years later, Otis was abruptly acquired by the United Technologies Corporation, which abandoned its Yonkers operations, and left its gift from the city vacant.
Now, as an adviser to Mr. O'Rourke, the Westchester County executive, Mr. Delbello said G.M. has cast new doubt on the effectiveness of corporate inducements.
"Experience has left me and others somewhat jaded," Mr. Delbello said. "Maybe heavy industry just doesn't make much sense any more in this area."
