HEADLINE: Iraqi Aide Meets Jordanian King on Sanctions

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, March 7

 BODY:
Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister met with King Hussein of Jordan today en route to the United Nations headquarters, where he is expected to try to head off pressure for harsh measures over Iraq's failure to cooperate in dismantling its weapons program.
The Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, met with King Hussein and with the Jordanian Prime Minister, Sharif Zaid Bin Shakir, the Jordanian press agency said. A Jordanian official, who insisted on not being identified, said Mr. Aziz had asked for help in persuading the United Nations Security Council to ease sanctions against his country. 
 Mr. Aziz, President Saddam Hussein's top envoy in the negotiations leading up to the Persian Gulf war, set out on his trip after new accusations that Iraq has blocked United Nations inspectors assigned to eliminate weapons of mass destruction in line with the Security Council's cease-fire resolutions ending the gulf war a year ago.
A United Nations team assigned to destroy equipment used to manufacture long-range missiles left Iraq late last month, saying it was unable to perform its task because of obstacles placed by the Iraqis.
Iraq has said the equipment in question could be converted to civilian use or used to make short-range missiles allowed under the United Nations provisions concerning Iraq's weaponry.
That dispute was only the latest in a series of confrontations between the Iraqis and the United Nations inspection teams since the inspections began in May 1991.
The official Iraqi press agency, monitored in Cyprus, said Mr. Aziz led a delegation of "officials and experts." They traveled overland to Jordan because the route is Iraq's only link with the rest of world because of the international sanctions that followed the invasion of Kuwait. The agency said Mr. Aziz would address the Security Council on Wednesday and explain Iraq's position on the resolutions.
In addition to warning of possible military action, the United States raised the prospect of seizing Iraqi assets frozen in foreign countries after the August 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
The assets, estimated at $2 billion to $5 billion, are mostly held in the United States and Britain, which led the coalition in the war against Iraq last year.
In meetings with the Jordanian officials, Mr. Aziz was seeking help in easing economic sanctions the United Nations imposed on Iraq during the crisis, a Jordanian said.
The Jordanian did not elaborate on Mr. Aziz's request or how Jordan might respond, but indicated that Iraq wanted King Hussein to intercede with the United States.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Pentagon's Plan: 'Prevent the Re-Emergence of a New Rival'

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Pentagon's Feb. 18 draft of the Defense Planning Guidance for the Fiscal Years 1994-1999: 
 This Defense Planning guidance addresses the fundamentally new situation which has been created by the collapse of the Soviet Union, the disintegration of the internal as well as the external empire, and the discrediting of Communism as an ideology with global pretensions and influence. The new international environment has also been shaped by the victory of the United States and its coalition allies over Iraqi aggression -- the first post-cold-war conflict and a defining event in U.S. global leadership. In addition to these two victories, there has been a less visible one, the integration of Germany and Japan into a U.S.-led system of collective security and the creation of a democratic "zone of peace."

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
DEFENSE STRATEGY OBJECTIVES
 Our first objective is to prevent the re-emergence of a new rival, either on the territory of the former Soviet Union or elsewhere, that poses a threat on the order of that posed formerly by the Soviet Union. This is a dominant consideration underlying the new regional defense strategy and requires that we endeavor to prevent any hostile power from dominating a region whose resources would, under consolidated control, be sufficient to generate global power. These regions include Western Europe, East Asia, the territory of the former Soviet Union, and Southwest Asia.
There are three additional aspects to this objective: First, the U.S. must show the leadership necessary to establish and protect a new order that holds the promise of convincing potential competitors that they need not aspire to a greater role or pursue a more aggressive posture to protect their legitimate interests. Second, in the non-defense areas, we must account sufficiently for the interests of the advanced industrial nations to discourage them from challenging our leadership or seeking to overturn the established political and economic order. Finally, we must maintain the mechanisms for deterring potential competitors from even aspiring to a larger regional or global role. An effective reconstitution capability is important here, since it implies that a potential rival could not hope to quickly or easily gain a predominant military position in the world.
The second objective is to address sources of regional conflict and instability in such a way as to promote increasing respect for international law, limit international violence, and encourage the spread of democratic forms of government and open economic systems. These objectives are especially important in deterring conflicts or threats in regions of security importance to the United States because of their proximity (such as Latin America), or where we have treaty obligations or security commitments to other nations. While the U.S. cannot become the world's "policeman," by assuming responsibility for righting every wrong, we will retain the pre-eminent responsibility for addressing selectively those wrongs which threaten not only our interests, but those of our allies or friends, or which could seriously unsettle international relations. Various types of U.S. interests may be involved in such instances: access to vital raw materials, primarily Persian Gulf oil; proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and ballistic missiles, threats to U.S. citizens from terrorism or regional or local conflict, and threats to U.S. society from narcotics trafficking.

 	 	 		. . .	 	It is improbable that a global conventional challenge to U.S. and Western security will re-emerge from the Eurasian heartland for many years to come. Even in the highly unlikely event that some future leadership in the former Soviet Union adopted strategic aims of recovering the lost empire or otherwise threatened global interests, the loss of Warsaw Pact allies and the subsequent and continuing dissolution of military capability would make any hope of success require several years or more of strategic and doctrinal re-orientation and force regeneration and redeployment, which in turn could only happen after a lengthy political realignment and re-orientation to authoritarian and aggressive political and economic control. Furthermore, any such political upheaval in or among the states of the former U.S.S.R. would be much more likely to issue in internal or localized hostilities, rather than a concerted strategic effort to marshal capabilities for external expansionism -- the ability to project power beyond their borders.
There are other potential nations or coalitions that could, in the further future, develop strategic aims and a defense posture of region-wide or global domination. Our strategy must now refocus on precluding the emergence of any potential future global competitor. But because we no longer face either a global threat or a hostile, non-democratic power dominating a region critical to our interests, we have the opportunity to meet threats at lower levels and lower costs -- as long as we are prepared to reconstitute additional forces should the need to counter a global threat re-emerge. . . .
 
REGIONAL THREATS AND RISK

With the demise of a global military threat to U.S. interests, regional military threats, including possible conflicts arising in and from the territory of the former Soviet Union, will be of primary concern to the U.S. in the future. These threats are likely to arise in regions critical to the security of the U.S. and its allies, including Europe, East Asia, the Middle East and Southwest Asia, and the territory of the former Soviet Union. We also have important interests at stake in Latin America, Oceania, and Sub-Saharan Africa. In both cases, the U.S. will be concerned with preventing the domination of key regions by a hostile power. . . .
 
Former Soviet Union

The former Soviet state achieved global reach and power by consolidating control over the resources in the territory of the former U.S.S.R. The best means of assuring that no hostile power is able to consolidate control over the resources within the former Soviet Union is to support its successor states (especially Russia and Ukraine) in their efforts to become peaceful democracies with market-based economies. A democratic partnership with Russia and the other republics would be the best possible outcome for the United States. At the same time, we must also hedge against the possibility that democracy will fail, with the potential that an authoritarian regime bent on regenerating aggressive military power could emerge in Russia, or that similiar regimes in other successor republics could lead to spreading conflict within the former U.S.S.R. or Eastern Europe.

 	 	 		. . .	 	For the immediate future, key U.S. concerns will be the ability of Russia and the other republics to demilitarize their societies, convert their military industries to civilian production, eliminate or, in the case of Russia, radically reduce their nuclear weapons inventory, maintain firm command and control over nuclear weapons, and prevent leakage of advanced military technology and expertise to other countries.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Western Europe
 NATO continues to provide the indispensable foundation for a stable security environment in Europe. Therefore, it is of fundamental importance to preserve NATO as the primary instrument of Western defense and security, as well as the channel for U.S. influence and participation in European security affairs. While the United States supports the goal of European integration, we must seek to prevent the emergence of European-only security arrangements which would undermine NATO, particularly the alliance's integrated command structure.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
East-Central Europe

The end of the Warsaw Pact and the dissolution of the Soviet Union have gone a long way toward increasing stability and reducing the military threat to Europe. The ascendancy of democratic reformers in the Russian republic, should this process continue, is likely to create a more benign polcy toward Eastern Europe. However, the U.S. must keep in mind the long history of conflict between the states of Eastern Europe, as well as the potential for conflict between the states of Eastern Europe and those of the former Soviet Union. . . .
The most promising avenues for anchoring the east-central Europeans into the West and for stabilizing their democratic institutions is their participation in Western political and economic organizations. East-central European membership in the (European Community) at the earliest opportunity, and expanded NATO liaison. . . .
The U.S. could also consider extending to the east-central European states security commitments analogous to those we have extended to Persian Gulf states.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Should there be a re-emergence of a threat from the Soviet Union's successor state, we should plan to defend against such a threat in Eastern Europe, should there be an alliance decision to do so.
 
East Asia and Pacific
 . . . Defense of Korea will likely remain one of the most demanding major regional contingencies. . . . Asia is home to the world's greatest concentration of traditional Communist states, with fundamental values, governance, and policies decidedly at variance with our own and those of our friends and allies.
To buttress the vital political and economic relationships we have along the Pacific rim, we must maintain our status as a military power of the first magnitude in the area. This will enable the U.S. to continue to contribute to regional security and stability by acting as a balancing force and prevent emergence of a vacuum or a regional hegemon.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Middle East and Southwest Asia
 In the Middle East and Southwest Asia, our overall objective is to remain the predominant outside power in the region and preserve U.S. and Western access to the region's oil. We also seek to deter further aggression in the region, foster regional stability, protect U.S. nationals and property, and safeguard our access to international air and seaways. As demonstrated by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, it remains fundamentally important to prevent a hegemon or alignment of powers from dominating the region. This pertains especially to the Arabian peninsula. Therefore, we must continue to play a strong role through enhanced deterrence and improved cooperative security.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We will seek to prevent the further development of a nuclear arms race on the Indian subcontinent. In this regard, we should work to have both countries, India and Pakistan, adhere to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and to place their nuclear energy facilities under International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards. We should discourage Indian hegemonic aspirations over the other states in South Asia and on the Indian Ocean. With regard to Pakistan, a constructive U.S.-Pakistani military relationship will be an important element in our strategy to promote stable security conditions in Southwest Asia and Central Asia. We should therefore endeavor to rebuild our military relationship given acceptable resolution of our nuclear concerns.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Latin America
 Cuba's growing domestic crisis holds out the prospect for positive change, but over the near term, Cuba's tenuous internal situation is likely to generate new challenges to U.S. policy. Consequently, our programs must provide capabilities to meet a variety of Cuban contingencies which could include an attempted repetition of the Mariel boatlift, a military provocation against the U.S. or an American ally, or political instability and internal conflict in Cuba.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Far Right;
Duke's Followers Lean to Buchanan

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 7

 BODY:
Some subscribers to "The Truth at Last," a far-right publication partial to stories like "Negroes Never Had a Civilization -- Are Far Behind White Race in Mental Development," recently got something else mailed from the same address: campaign literature for Patrick J. Buchanan.
The Buchanan campaign says it had nothing to do with the mailing, which it says was unauthorized and apparently resulted from someone who picked up campaign literature and mailed it on his own. 
 But the incident illustrates the way Mr. Buchanan's angry conservative campaign is being embraced by many of the white-power and neo-Nazi groups at the darkest corner of American politics. Many are showing more interest in Presidential politics than at any time since George Wallace's Presidential campaign in 1968.
 
Conservative Thunder
 No one suggests such backers make up more than a tiny fraction of Mr. Buchanan's support. And he is quick to say he has neither sought nor wants such support.
"I don't welcome the support of anyone who is voting out of hatred of any group or out of bigotry," he has said. "We don't want it."
But critics and organizations who follow far-right groups say Mr. Buchanan, who has stolen the conservative thunder from the former Klansman David Duke, has done nothing to repudiate his most extreme admirers or to distance himself from Mr. Duke.
And some say that at a time when far-right groups, including the Ku Klux Klan, are openly pursuing an electoral strategy, Mr. Buchanan, consciously or not, is sending a message that goes far beyond a challenge to President Bush.
"What Buchanan has catalyzed is a racist movement, whether or not he is personally anti-Semitic," said Leonard Zeskind, research director of the Center for Democratic Renewal, a group that monitors the activities of so-called hate groups. "I don't know exactly what it will produce, but one of the things I expect it to produce is an extremist, conservative movement, in which race, ethnicity, nativism, nationalism, play a greater role than the anti-communism of the past."
 
Raw Nerves
 In his columns and in his campaign, Mr. Buchanan has touched some of the rawest nerves on race and ethnicity in American life. His campaign in the South has featured advertisements showing white families that are said to be imperiled by racial quotas. Some commercials warn that a restrictive immigration policy is needed to prevent the United States from becoming a "third world country."
In the past, Mr. Buchanan has asked, "Who speaks for Euro-Americans, who founded the United States?" But he has denied any racist content to his campaign.
"There has got to be someone who speaks for the victims of quotas, and I'm that guy," he said.
He said that "all Americans should be treated equally" and that he did not support group entitlements. "I believe in individual rights," he said.
But Mr. Buchanan has done almost nothing to distance himself from Mr. Duke. Asked how he differed from Mr. Duke, Mr. Buchanan said: "What his views are, I really don't care. I have my own views and I argue from my own vantage point."
But the similarities between the two men's views have not gone unnoticed on the far right. In obscure racist and anti-Semitic journals and in interviews, many of those usually thought to be outside the standard electoral system voice support for Mr. Buchanan.
 
'Two Dukes'
 A recent issue of "Instauration," a far-right publication, says: "In one sense, Pat Buchanan can be viewed as a clean Duke," and adds, "Two Dukes are better than one, provided they don't work at cross purposes."
"The Truth at Last," which is published by Ed Fields of Marietta, Ga., recently wrote that Mr. Buchanan "could well become the leader who eventually leads the struggle to save America from Zionist domination."
Tom Metzger, director of White Aryan Resistance, said: "It's time that we divide the truly sensitive Republicans, sensitive on the race issue, from the phonies. We are more interested in what Buchanan's doing than what Duke's doing. I think if he is truly honest, he could really be laying the foundation for something big."
Many on the racial right, though attracted to Mr. Buchanan, say their primary allegiance is to Mr. Duke.
"I would call Pat Buchanan an economic conservative and David Duke a racial conservative," said Mr. Fields of "The Truth at Last." But his publication is full of laudatory articles on Mr. Buchanan. A recent one was headlined, "Jews Launch Smear Campaign Against Pat Buchanan." Mr. Fields denied sending out Buchanan campaign literature and said he had no explanation for its distribution in his envelopes.
Still, many people on the far right maintain allegiances to both men.
Thus, Sam Dickson, a lawyer who is a longtime supporter of Mr. Duke, contributed money to Mr. Buchanan and attended a gathering for him the evening before the Georgia primary.
"Basically, I think they're appealing to the same fundamental concerns of the Euro-American majority, the concern about reverse discrimination, the concern about runaway tax and government, the concern about the changing demographics of the country."
Of course, there are some on the far right who see Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Duke as far too close to the political mainstream.
"We're not supporting anybody," said Carl Franklin of the Aryan Nations organization. "They're all establishment; they're all basically anti-Christ."
Mr. Buchanan's campaign says it is unfair to link him to extremist groups.
"It's the worst kind of guilt by association to tar Buchanan's campaign with accusations we're getting support from people we don't know, don't want and haven't had any contact with," said Jerry Woodruff, Mr. Buchanan's spokesman.
But critics like Mr. Zeskind, whose group does not take political stands on specific candidates, said Mr. Buchanan's campaign comes at a time when far-right groups from the Populist Party to the Klan are increasing efforts to run for office.
Mr. Zeskind said the campaign wasgoing on as the religious and racial right were finding common ground along many of the racial and cultural issues at the heart of Mr. Buchanan's campaign.
"Buchanan and every other candidate should know that when you play with racism as a drawing card, you're going to attract the worst elements in American civilization," Mr. Zeskind said.
William Moore, a professor of political science at the College of Charleston in South Carolina, and an expert on far right extremism, said he believed hate groups are looking for someone more conspicuously one of their own than Mr. Buchanan.
But, if Mr. Buchanan's campaign is touching on explosive issues and volatile constituencies, it's not a new phenomenon in American life, he said.
"We've seen this throughout American history, particularly in times of economic distress," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo:"I don't welcome the support of anyone who is voting out of hatred of any group or out of bigotry," said Patrick J. Buchanan. Critics say that he has done nothing to repudiate such supporters. He campaigned yesterday in New Orleans with Billy Nungesser, right, the state G.O.P. chairman. (Matt Anderson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Grande Dame Fasts for Haitians and a Suffering City Responds

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., March 6

 BODY:
In this island of urban desperation, where people know firsthand about poverty and suffering, a deeply personal crusade is under way to help the refugees of another desperate place in the hemisphere, Haiti.
At the center of the movement is Katherine Dunham, an 82-year-old grande dame of modern dance, who has homes both here and in Haiti, is in her second month of fasting to protest the deportation of Haitian boat people to what she and others here fear is certain death in their homeland. 
 For 35 days now, against the advice of doctors, she has consumed only bottled water, cranberry juice and Tibetan tea. She says she will continue her fast as long as the Bush Administration refuses entry to Haitians fleeing the military government that in September overthrew the country's first democratically elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
"It's embarrassing to be an American," Miss Dunham said, bedridden in her home here since the fast began. "The discrimination is becoming blatant. The lives of those people who half drown in those little boats are being equated to animals. It means I have to declare out-and-out war."
 
Expanding Movement
 Miss Dunham's is the most extreme example of a movement that has expanded nationally in recent months to include human rights advocates, civil rights groups, unions and religious groups all lobbying to change United States policy toward the Haitians.
The Bush Administration argues that the Haitians are fleeing poverty not political persecution, and that position was upheld by the Supreme Court last week.
Earlier this week, responding to a letter to President Bush from Miss Dunham, Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, wrote to her, "I want to assure you that the President shares your concerns on this most difficult problem and that we are taking every precaution to insure that no one is returned to Haiti who has a well-founded fear of persecution."
 
Nightly Vigils
 While opponents of the Administration's policy wage a campaign of faxes and news conferences, a front-stoop battle is going on in this city that, like Haiti, is overwhelmingly poor, black and powerless. Residents hold nightly vigils outside Miss Dunham's home, ministers have marched several blocks to the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Bridge over the Mississippi River to pray for the Haitians' safety, and protesters have chained themselves to the courthouse doors..
Since the September coup, at least 15,000 Haitians in packed and leaking boats have attempted the 700-mile journey to Florida only to be intercepted by the United States Coast Guard and taken to the United States Navy base at Guantanomo Bay, Cuba, to await forcible return to Haiti.
Groups as diverse as the American Jewish Committee, A.F.L.-C.I.O., the American Bar Association and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are urging Congress and President Bush to end the repatriations. They say the Haitians are trying to escape repression and violence at the hands of a dictatorship, and they accuse the United States Government of acting on a racial double standard in which it admits thousands of refugees from Cuba, the former Soviet Union and Southeast Asia but draws the line at Haitians.
"The Haitians don't have money like the Cubans," Miss Dunham said, "and they are blacker than the Cubans."
Congress has given mixed messages on the matter. The House of Representatives voted 217 to 165 last week to suspend the deportation of Haitians who arrived before early February. But the bill is too late for its intended beneficiaries, who have been turned back by the thousands. And an amendment to give the Haitians special status and allow them into this country pending political change in Haiti was defeated, 96 to 304.
If the bill is passed by the Senate, it would likely be vetoed by Mr. Bush. .
Miss Dunham has celebrated the Haitian culture in her work for 50 years. She grew up in Chicago, was trained in anthropology at the University of Chicago and later founded a dance company that gained international acclaim for its marriage of African and Caribbean culture to modern choreography. When she retired from the stage in the mid-1960's, she chose to settle in Haiti and East St. Louis.
"She chose two of the worst places in the Western Hemisphere and decided that was where she was needed most," said her spokesman, Mark Silverman.
She started dance schools for children in both places and has trained generations of disadvantaged children, including the Olympic gold medalist Jackie Joyner-Kersee.
Now her museum and studio here, a neoclassical brick mansion with barred clerestory windows and a nearby coach house, are virtually the only institutions left in East St. Louis. And they are struggling amid the ruin. The museum, open only by appointment, has a stunning collection of third world musical instruments, Haitian paintings and African carvings.
 
Will Remains Strong
 Unemployed men stand on nearby street corners. Directly in front of the museum, the charred skeleton of a once grand house is collapsing on itself as if it had been bombed.
Hospitalized for exhaustion last week, Miss Dunham has remained alert and her will has been undiminished. More than a month without solid food has left her weakened, her voice low and faint. As she lies in her bed in her large brick house, aides announce guests and bring her tea, slipping the salutation "madame" at the end of each sentence, like French schoolchildren.
She has taken calls from President Aristide urging her to stop fasting and has been advised by Dick Gregory and visited by the Rev. Louis Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam.
But whatever the effect of her crusade, it has probably been felt most by black East St. Louisans who have been given something bigger than themselves to fight for. "Some of the slave ships stopped in Haiti before coming to this country," said Wyvetter Younge, a local State Representative. "Those are our cousins being forced back."

HEADLINE: Athens Journal;
75 Years of Seed Ads and Free Advice

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, Ga.,

 BODY:
For the farmers who come into Howard McCants's milling operation here, The Market Bulletin is a fixture in their lives -- the place to get a line on anything from a cow dog to seven-shank plows to bales of high-protein coastal Bermuda hay.
For Linda Wish, an Atlanta lawyer, The Market Bulletin is the place to locate seeds for touch-me-nots and four-o'clocks and all manner of things she can use to adorn her suburban garden. And it is the place to correspond with other avid gardeners. 
 The Georgia Farmers and Consumers Market Bulletin, to call it by its full name, is a free weekly newspaper with a circulation of 250,000. Published by the State Department of Agriculture, it has been serving Georgia's farmers for 75 years -- and, more recently, bridging farm and garden, city and small town.
Bulletins like these, with their free classified advertisements and homespun columns, are a rich source of social history. In her book "Gardening for Love: The Market Bulletins" (Duke University Press, 1987), Elizabeth Lawrence writes that the history of a people is to be found "in the yellowed pages of the market bulletins where they sold their mules and their cordwood, their bales of sweet-smelling alfalfa, their old-fashioned daffodils and their yard plants with their poetic country names."
Georgia's bulletin, founded in 1917, is one of the oldest. Many other Southern states have also had market bulletins for decades, though they do not have the advertising volume and circulation of Georgia's.
The Georgia publication is often an outlet for information from the United States Department of Agriculture Extension Service on topics like livestock health and new strains of crops, but such articles and photographs of outsized onions clearly take a back seat. The paper's heart and soul is the classified advertising, a print marketplace with buyers and sellers from around the state.
"They sort of call it their lifesaver," said Mr. McCants, referring to how some of the farmers view the publication. "It's real common that a lot of these ol' boys who advertise an old tractor for sale will tell you that he sold it just minutes or hours after the paper came out. There's no question about it but that these farmers would get mad if they stopped putting it out."
Dan Gunnels, the Extension Service agent in Clark County, said that many of the Market Bulletin's readers are people who have roots on the farm but now live in cities or suburban areas and see it as a way to "keep in touch with their roots."
Ms. Wish, the Atlanta lawyer and gardener, agreed, but also recalled the person who responded to one of her ads for a shrub she was trying to sell.
"It was a droopy plant and I was real apologetic, but he said that was all right because he didn't want it for display, but for some genetic material," she said. "He was a Ph.D. in botany working on a research project."
The paper does not accept advertisements from out of state or from retailers, wholesalers, brokers, dealers and agents. The idea is strictly person to person.
Carlton Moore, editor of the paper for the last three years, said that over the years the paper's advertising columns have evolved, reflecting the changes in farming and the changes in farm living.
"In lean years, for example, we started columns to create a marketplace for people wanting to lease hunting rights on their land and things like that," he said. "People look for all sorts of alternatives to traditional farming when conditions are not good, whether it is because of the weather or the economy."
Along with the advertisements, regular features include a recipe, a column titled "Helping Each Other" in which readers seek information on rare plants or a quilt pattern, and a listing of livestock and gardening events.
The paper's annual production budget is about $1.25 million, with the bulk of that for the cost of mailing it to a quarter of million subscribers. About 2,000 classified ads appear each week.
For its 75th anniversary, the Market Bulletin asked some of its readers for letters telling of the role the publication had played in their lives.
"I doubt that I would still be in farming without it," wrote 70-year-old B. F. Bohannon of Chickamauga. Raymond Hughes of Carrollton, who said he used it as he was learning to read, described it as a "continued source of intellectual growth, entertainment and pleasure."
And Adelia Matthews, 74, of Douglasville wrote:
"When I have insomnia, I have discovered reading it that it helps me go to sleep. When I have squeezed all the good I can from it, I recycle it."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
Texas Town Sees the Race as Remote

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DEER PARK, Tex., March 6

 BODY:
Living in the shadows of oil refineries, the people of this Houston suburb are accustomed to economic booms and busts. Now, even though many express nagging worries about the future, they seem almost disconnected from the Presidential candidates who are trying so hard to address their concerns.
Stuffing her clothes into a washer at the Suds n' Suds coin laundry a few days before the Texas primary election, Alice Lawson, 56 years old, said: "I see that they're on TV a lot now, and I guess I'm interested, yeah. I've seen that a couple of them have had this sex stuff going on about them, but you know what I am really interested in is whether any of them will do anything to help the elderly, especially with our health care." 
 Asked whether she knew of any health care plans being put forward by any of the candidates, Mrs. Lawson seemed unaware of the debate on this issue that has preoccupied the Democratic candidates.
 
Call to Improve Tax Code
 A little farther down Center Street, Ray Sanchez, 36, was eating lunch at the Cattle Drive Bar-B-Que with fellow workers from a nearby grocery store. "There's no question in my mind that fixing the tax code is the No. 1 issue," he said, "and I say there should be a flat tax rate across the board for everybody."
Asked whether he liked the proposal for a 13 percent flat tax rate put forward by former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, Mr. Sanchez paused to chew on his sliced brisket sandwich and then said: "Brown? Oh yeah, Brown. He said that?"
With a population of almost 28,000 people, Deer Park is a scattering of subdivisions and shopping centers about 15 miles southeast of downtown Houston. Bordered on the north by the massive refineries and chemical plants that line the Houston Ship Channel, it is home to a mix of laborers, professionals and merchants.
Once solidly Democratic, like the rest of the state, the town has increasingly supported Republicans in Presidential elections over the last 20 years.
For people like Mrs. Lawson and Mr. Sanchez, the Presidential campaign has been remote until now, something conducted mostly in snowy New Hampshire, far from this steamy coastal plain. They seem to have bits of information but no fully formed impressions of any candidates except for President Bush.
The candidates and their television advertisements began appearing in Texas in significant quantities just this week, and even that exposure conveys a feeling that the campaign is just breezing through on the way to or from one of the other 10 states holding elections on Super Tuesday.
As is typical in many places at this stage of the campaign, only part of the electorate seems to be paying much attention.
Some voters like David Williams, 25, say they plan to sit out of the primary. "I don't really get interested until they go one on one in November," he said. "Now there are so many of them up on TV that I really don't have time to sort them out."
 
Concern About Future
 Most of the people in Deer Park weathered the bad years of the mid-1980's, when crashing oil prices devastated the local economy. Now they have seen steady improvement for almost five years. Even so, numerous people encountered on a recent sunny afternoon expressed ill-defined but deeply felt worries about the nation's future. Events overseas were not mentioned, except by those who said they were unimportant.
For example, Malcolm Prevost, a 70-year-old retired heating and air-conditioning contractor, was quick to say that he was voting for Mr. Bush. But then he added: "Some way or another we got to get a lot of help for this country instead of worrying so much about what goes on across the pond. I am disappointed in Bush on that score, but I don't see who else I can support."
An even more generalized unease was expressed by Frances Cobb, 50, who said, "All I know for sure is something drastic has got to change and somebody has got to decide where this country is going to go instead of getting up there and giving us the same old, same old."
Such sentiments seem tailor-made for almost any of the Democratic candidates, or for Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative challenger in the Rupublican race. But their varied messages seem to have only just started to penetrate.
Eating at the Cattle Drive, Jack Heath, 37, said: "I voted for Bush the last time. I'm a Republican, but I haven't decided yet what I'm going to do. The way Bush is running things, the middle-class people like us are just going to disappear, so something has got to change. Clinton says he's for the middle man. Maybe he can do something or one of others. We sure need someone to come up with a plan that really looks down the road, and I'd like to hear it."

HEADLINE: VIETNAM'S EXODUS APPEARS TO HALT

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, March 7

 BODY:
The number of Vietnamese boat people coming to seek refuge here dropped to zero last month in what officials called an encouraging sign that the exodus that scattered nearly 675,000 Vietnamese throughout this region in a dozen years may finally be ending.
February was the first month in seven years that no Vietnamese arrived in Hong Kong, which had been virtually the last place in Asia where the authorities would not quickly return them to Vietnam. Officials said they believe that people in Vietnam are at last beginning to understand that there is no longer much chance they can improve their lives by fleeing their country. 
 In recent years, a growing number of Asian countries have been closing their doors to Vietnamese refugees. Last year, 92 percent of the 22,000 Vietnamese refugees arrived in Hong Kong.
 
'Word Has Really Spread'
 "No arrivals is pretty remarkable," said a refugee official in Hong Kong. "In a country as primitive as Vietnam, with people living in conditions with poor communications, that everyone got the message is amazing. The word has really spread."
Halting the exodus to Hong Kong, which has a population of 5.5 million people, has been an emotional and controversial issue, and negotiations to resolve the problem took years. The British authorities in Hong Kong have continued to provide food and shelter to the refugees, with some living in special centers for at least 10 years and others who were born in them knowing no life outside the cramped and squalid quarters. There are about 58,000 refugees now in the camps.
Other countries adopted stricter policies earlier on and the results were striking. Malaysia, for example, took no Vietnamese last year, compared with 1,326 in 1990 and 16,718 the previous year. Indonesia received only 1,260 last year, compared with 13,833 in 1990. Thailand took only 164 last year after accepting 9,054 in 1990.
It is possible that more Vietnamese will try to come to Hong Kong during the spring season, when the seas are calmer, but officials will not know until May whether a new exodus will begin.
Most of those who come to Hong Kong now are regarded as economic rather than political refugees. They have little or no hope of finding resettlement in the United States, Australia, Canada or even Hong Kong itself. Instead, they are kept in the camps while the Government tries to encourage them to return home. The British authorities here initially sought to get them to return voluntarily, but recently they have also forced a small number to go back against their will.
 
Britain-Vietnam Agreement
 The refugee flow did not appear to ebb until Britain and Vietnam agreed in October on the mandatory repatriation of certain kinds of Vietnamese refugees. In January, the number of arrivals dwindled to four.
Under the agreement, those who arrived after Oct. 29 were interviewed and then returned immediately if they did not qualify as refugees who were politically persecuted by the Vietnamese Government. Those who arrived for a second time were also sent back.
In contrast, those who arrived before the cutoff date could remain in Hong Kong until their turns came in a line of nearly 35,000 Vietnamese to be interviewed and screened. The process of sending Vietnamese refugees back to their country or resettling them elsewhere is expected to take several years. Thus, it was the immediate returns that seemed to have driven the message home, officials here said.
The number of Vietnamese volunteering to return home seemed to be steadily increasing, with 2,085 returning so far this year, compared to 16,064 who have chosen to return in the three years since March 1989, when the first volunteers returned home, according to Hong Kong Government statistics.
The process was delayed when a riot and a fire in early February, in which nearly two dozen people died, resulted in charges against 173 Vietnamese. About 800 Vietnamese who had volunteered to return home will have their trips delayed pending the Government's investigation into the riot. Still, the Government says it plans to send back five more groups in March.
 
Quayle Causes a Problem
 The program also suffered a significant setback in mid-February after Vice President Dan Quayle referred to the Vietnamese in Hong Kong as "political refugees."
After Mr. Quayle's remarks, Vietnamese refugees here believed that there would be a policy change and that they would be reclassified as political refugees instead of economic ones. Most Governments will accept only those who are fleeing political persecution, not those who are seeking greater prosperity.
The Voice of America broadcast a program in Vietnamese, emphasizing that there would be no change in United States policy toward the refugees. Applications to return voluntarily, however, are still lower than they were before the Vice President's remarks. Moreover, about half of those who had already applied for repatriation changed their minds and decided to remain in the Hong Kong camps.
"A statement like Mr. Quayle's had an immediate impact," said Robert Van Leeuwen, chief of the Hong Kong mission of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. "Corrective statements take a longer time to have an impact."

HEADLINE: After Criticism by U.S., Mulroney Jabs Back

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, March 4

 BODY:
In remarks bristling with unusual censure of the United States, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has defended Canada's new policy of relying more on United Nations peacekeeping activities than on NATO's strategy of deterrence to maintain a stable and secure world.
He calls the approach "realistic" and says it was brought on not only by the collapse of the Soviet Union but by the remarkable recent experience in which President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia has been seeking billions of dollars of aid from erstwhile enemies. 
 In an interview on Wednesday, Mr. Mulroney bridled at criticism by Washington -- and other allies -- of Ottawa's recent decision to pull out all its combat units from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization command before 1995.
That decision was announced last week as 1,300 Canadians were being deployed in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Yugoslavia, the largest national component in that force. The two moves are key elements in Canada's new post-cold-war strategy.
As a special riposte to Washington, which said it was "very disappointed" by Canada's unexpected NATO action, Mr. Mulroney noted that the United States was years behind in its contributions toward the costs of United Nations operations.
"We don't believe you can be a member of a club and not pay your dues," he said. "Otherwise, you're a deadbeat."
He also accused the United States of engaging in "vexatious harassment" and "protectionism of the worst kind" for a series of recent trade actions that have had damaging impact on tens of thousands of Canada's beer, lumber and auto workers.
"If you had told me that some tinpot dictator in some tiny little country somewhere was engaging in this kind of harassment, I'd say, 'So what else is new?' But for the United States, this is most unworthy."
He warned that the continuation of such practices could damage the three-way negotiations under way among Canada, the United States and Mexico for North American free trade.
The use of such unusually sharp language by the 53-year-old leader, long considered the closest friend of the United States, was evidence of the political pressures he is under as Canada struggles out of a recession that is worse than the one in the United States, while edging into an election campaign of its own.
He is politically vulnerable on the trade issue. Many Canadians see freer trade between the United States and Canada, under a three-year-old tariff-cutting pact, as a cause of their economic woes.
The Prime Minister said Washington's aggressiveness was "bad news for any trading partner who sticks his neck out, like I do, in favor of free and fair trade."
Yet he was careful to draw a distinction between President Bush, whom he called "a free and fair trader," and the trade bureaucracy in Washington, which he said was "responding to low-level political pressures."
His comments also suggest a gulf between Ottawa and Washington in perceptions of the post-cold-war world.
Mr. Mulroney's fiscally strapped Government has just promised Mr. Yeltsin, a recent visitor to Ottawa, more than $2 billion of humanitarian assistance, which on a per capita basis is four to five times what the United States has committed.
"It occurred to our people," Mr. Mulroney said, "whom are we defending against exactly, the guy who just left here asking me for money? And we contributed over $2 billion to keep him alive. If he's the enemy, then we're going about this the wrong way. I really shouldn't be committing $2 billion to help a mortal enemy."
In fact, he said, "the enemy is unrest in Central Europe."
Despite the lowest public support for a sitting Prime Minister in opinion polling history -- a 16 percent approval rating in a January poll -- Mr. Mulroney is gearing up to lead his Progressive Conservative Party to what would be an unprecedented third term for the Tories. He has headed the Ottawa Government for eight years.
He reminded a reporter that he did not have to call elections for a year and a half, "and that's forever in politics."

HEADLINE: Brazil Welcomes Drop in Population Growth

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA

 BODY:
For the first time in half a century, Brazil's population growth rate has dipped below 2 percent, according to preliminary results of the country's latest once-a-decade census.
The falling growth rate, part of a trend in developing nations, is being welcomed by officials here because, they say, it gives Brazil, Latin America's most populous nation, more time to catch up with a yawning social deficit of schools, sewers and clinics. 
 The 1991 head count, which ended in February, gives Brazil a population of 146 million. Adjusting for undercounting, the real population figure is about 148 million, according to the census bureau, the Brazilian Institute for Geography and Statistics.
Even with 7 million fewer people than predicted a decade ago, Brazil is now the world's fifth most populous nation, slightly larger than Russia. The four most populous nations are China, India, the United States and Indonesia.
Drawing on reports from 189,000 enumerators, Brazil's census paints a picture of hidden population movements across a continent-size nation.
In the 1980's, the fastest population growth was on the Amazon frontier.
In Roraima State, where gold miners invaded lands of the Yanomami Indians, population grew at an annual rate of 9 percent, the highest in Brazil. Rondonia grew at 7.9 percent a year, and Mato Grosso at 5.4 percent.
For the first time, two Amazon cities, Belem and Manaus, broke into the ranks of cities with populations over one million. Brazil's 10 other cities in this category are, in descending order: Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, Salvador, Belo Horizonte, Fortaleza, Brasilia, Recife, Curitiba, Nova Iguacu and Porto Alegre.
The slowest growth rates were detected in the crowded, older states and cities on the Atlantic coast.
The census started a year late because of a Government hiring freeze. When many numbers released last month proved sharply lower than estimates, many mayors and governors demanded recounts, fearing cuts in federal revenue sharing.
Census officials admit only to a maximum undercount of 2 percent.
Officials attribute Brazil's declining birth rate to major social changes under way in the population.
"There are many factors at work: urbanization, more women in the labor force, and more access to family planning," David Wu Tai, coordinator of the census, said in an interview in Rio.
Indeed, Brazil's move toward smaller families is part of a worldwide trend. Annual growth rates have dropped in China to 1.5 percent, and in India to Brazil's level, 1.9 percent.
Brazil's Government, which supported population growth as late as the 1970's, has celebrated the drop as a step toward improving education and living standards.
The slowing population growth has been defined by special circumstances.
For one, the economy was largely stagnant in the 1980's, a condition that pushed couples to limit family sizes. In addition, falling fertility rates have come about without any Government program for family planning or sex education.
Birth control methods here are often drastic.
Although abortion is illegal in Brazil, the Alan Guttmacher Institute estimates that 1.4 million to 2.4 million abortions are performed annually. Abortions alone could account for the seven million population shortfall between today's reality and forecasts made a decade ago.
In addition, demographers estimate that nearly 30 percent of married Brazilian women of child-bearing age are sterilized. In contrast, the corresponding sterilization rate for United States women is 17 percent, and for Latin American women, 7 percent.
Brazil's high female sterilization rate is due to several factors: the high price and unreliability of local contraceptives, and a new discrimination by Brazilian companies against hiring unsterilized women of child-bearing age. This bias, usually expressed verbally but amply documented by union groups, stems largely from a requirement in the 1988 Constitution that mandates that employers pay for six-month maternity leaves.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Some Royal Insiders Feel Like Outsiders

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAINES CITY, Fla.

 BODY:
In the space of a week last month, George Brett gained a new wife and a new team.
"It felt like I was the one who had been traded," Brett said, referring to his arrival here at the Kansas City Royals training-camp clubhouse, not his marriage. "I walked in and didn't know 10 people. I was early and a lot of position players weren't here yet so I felt when they came in, I'd feel more comfortable. But they came and I still didn't know many of them. Someone said I walked by Gregg Jefferies and didn't know him." 
 The Royals executed one of the biggest face lifts of the winter, bringing in four new significant players in making over a lineup that had taken on the look of a dowdy matron.
"We needed to make some changes," said Mark Gubicza, who joins Brett as the only players left from the 1985 World Series champions. "The last couple years we were stagnant."
In the Royals' new look, Wally Joyner is at first base, Jefferies at third, Keith Miller in left field and Kevin McReynolds in right. Gone from the pitching staff is its leader, Bret Saberhagen, and gone from the starting lineup are a collection of first basemen, third baseman Kevin Seitzer and outfielders Danny Tartabull, Jim Eisenreich and Kirk Gibson.
"Bret and I were together 10 years," Gubicza said. "We were close off the field, and our wives were close. They went to school together. My wife and I are godparents of their little girl. I always thought if we weren't going to be together, it would be me who was traded."
Gubicza, though, said that neither he nor any of the other pitchers resents the trade that sent Saberhagen to the Mets for McReynolds, Jefferies and Miller.
"The pitchers are glad they're here," Gubicza said. "From what I see, they're aggressive players and they hit the ball. They come from a winning situation. I like having them. I look at our team this year, and I feel this is potentially the best offensive team we've had since I've been here. You get the feeling this team could contend for the championship. The past few years everybody would have had to have career years to win. Now they can just have good years."
Brett, at 38 years old and 18 years in the major leagues the elder statesman of the team, has no problem with the changeover. The only question he said has been raised is why competition for jobs was ruled out.
"Everything is written down in pen," he said. "The opening-day lineup is etched in stone."
Hal McRae, who shows signs of becoming an outstanding manager, readily explained his reasoning for establishing the starting nine before spring training. "I believe in these guys," he said. "I've seen them play."
The decision that has been most questioned is the insertion of Miller in left field over Eisenreich, a .301 hitter last year, and Gibson. At first, the Royals had said Miller would play second base, but McRae wanted Terry Shumpert there for defense and he wanted Miller in the lineup.
"We traded for Miller to be a major part of the ball club," McRae said. "We traded Saberhagen for three regulars, not for two regulars and a backup guy. We never would have done that. That would've been out of the question."
 
Shaky Family Affairs
 Family combinations have not fared well working for the Yankees in recent years. The Berras, the Niekros and the Perezes can attest to that.
With Yogi Berra their manager, the Yankees acquired Dale Berra in a trade Dec. 20, 1984. But the father-son setup lasted only 16 games into the 1985 season. That is when, after having said in the spring that he would be the manager the entire season, George Steinbrenner dismissed Yogi.
With Phil Niekro already on the club, the Yankees obtained his brother, Joe, in a trade Sept. 15, 1985. Their in-season time on the same pitching staff, though, lasted only three weeks. The Yankees released Phil the following spring, just before the start of the season.
The latest breakdown in family ties occurred last week. With Pascual Perez an infrequent but well-paid member of their pitching staff, the Yankees acquired his brother Melido in a trade Jan. 10. Pascual and Melido, however, spent only eight days in spring training in uniform together.
Pascual was suspended Friday for one year for cocaine use, and his career is in jeopardy.
Then there are the Steinbrenners. Hank, a son, worked for the Yankees for a few months in 1986, then fled to the family horse farm in Ocala, Fla., and has refused to return. George, the father, left the club in 1990 and keeps trying to return, but unsuccessfully.
 
Cubs Rocking the Boat
 It was not a good week for the Chicago Cubs. First, they catapulted the individual-salary scale another megalevel, from $5.8 million a year to $7.1 million, for Ryne Sandberg, and then they vetoed a realignment of the National League that virtually everyone else desired because it made economic and geographical sense.
Although just about every owner has been guilty at one time or another of contributing to the salary escalation, the owners severely criticized their Tribune Company colleagues for the Sandberg signing.
"No one was rude; they were all polite," said one man who attended the owners' meetings in Chicago. "But the resentment was staggering."
The Cubs might try to say the contract really is $30.5 million for five years, or $6.1 million a year, but that view doesn't fool anyone. They gave Sandberg $28.4 million for an additional four years. His $2.1 million salary for this year was his whether or not he signed an extension so it doesn't figure in the calculation.
Five of the previous 11 salary record-breakers (Bret Saberhagen, Dave Stewart, Don Mattingly, Jose Canseco and Roger Clemens) also signed extensions, and no one suggested including the remaining year of their existing contracts in the new deal.
 
Lasorda Favors Daniels
 Tommy Lasorda is running a sweepstakes for the Los Angeles Dodgers' first-base job, but he has his own favorite in the race: Kal Daniels, who is trying to move there from left field. Daniels was supplanted at his own position by Eric Davis, a former teammate in Cincinnati.
"One of the reasons I'm leaning toward Kal is I need a fifth-place hitter," Lasorda said. "It would be for the good of the lineup. The guy we got from Cincinnati" -- Todd Benzinger, who played for the Reds before the Dodgers obtained him from the Royals -- "is a heck of a first baseman, but Kal would make the ideal fifth-place hitter for us."
Brett Butler, Juan Samuel, Darryl Strawberry and Davis will be the first four hitters in the lineup.
 
Looks Like Bye-Bye Bo
 Bo Jackson's once-promising career appears to be over, unless additional rehabilitation over an extended period can improve his hip and enable him to run decently. Jackson courageously, stubbornly or foolishly insisted on playing football, along with baseball, ignoring the actuarial tables on National Football League running backs.
No one will have to stage any benefits for him, but Jackson has left untold millions on the 50-yard line.
Deion Sanders, the other major league two-sporter, continues to pursue both baseball and football jobs. He has not suffered a devastating injury, but he continues to undermine his chances to be a legitimate major league hitter by cutting his baseball season short each Aug. 1.
"He's doing pretty good," Bobby Cox, the Atlanta Braves' manager, said. "What he's doing now, he could make our club."
Sanders, however, has not performed impressively as a hitter in his abbreviated visits to the majors. In parts of two seasons with the Yankees and one with the Braves, he has hit .234 in 47 times at bat, .158 in 133 at-bats and .191 in 110 times at bat for a career .183 average.
"I'm not so sure he'd hit .180 if he played every day," Cox said. "One-hundred and ten at-bats is nothing. He's better than that. You don't see guys who can fly like that. He never makes a mental mistake. He has power. If he played every day, he's going to improve a lot. Deion is a fast learner."
But four years into his baseball career, the 24-year-old Sanders has squandered valuable learning time.
 
Between the Lines
 Some people think club owners struck a noble blow for higher education last week when they changed the rule covering rights to players selected in the amateur June draft. One lofty interpretation of the change was that by extending a club's rights to high school players throughout his college years and one year beyond, clubs were enabling and encouraging players to go to college.
The owners, however, did not enact the so-called Brien Taylor rule to induce the Brien Taylors of the country to pursue a college education. They did it to prevent successors to Taylor, the Yankee prospect, from getting the money they want from the drafting club by threatening to go to college and go back into the draft the next year. There's no nobility there.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the Royals' new look, Kevin McReynolds is in right field. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Scattering the Assets of the Team at Bridgeport

BYLINE: By BROCK MULLINS

 BODY:
Bruce Webster is dead serious when he says basketball at the University of Bridgeport has been his life.
Webster is concluding his 27th season as head coach of the Knights. There won't be a 28th. 
 "One of the reasons I stayed at Bridgeport was for the job security," Webster said. "That doesn't matter now. They're taking my team away from me."
The University of Bridgeport, beset with financial problems, will cease all sports at the end of the school year. The basketball team was to play its final home game last night, against Southern Connecticut in the final of the New England Collegiate Conference tournament. In the semifinals Friday night, the Knights beat Massachusetts-Lowell, 93-79.
 
Lost in 1991 Title Game
 The Knights, who had a record of 23-6 going into last night's game and are ranked No. 6 in Division II, are expecting a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association divisionional tournament. They reached last season's title game, losing to North Alabama, and they're hoping to make this year's championship game their triumphant finale.
After the season is over, Webster and his players will go in search of new lives.
"Reality hasn't set in," Webster said last week. "I was driving through campus the other day thinking, how could this university, which was once so prominent and so profitable, all of a sudden go down the tubes? Then you think this team is playing its final home game ever. That's a scary feeling."
Declining enrollment and the grip of the recession have contributed to Bridgeport's demise. The university needed a $2.2 million loan from a consortium of banks to open for the spring semester, and 31 degree programs will be dropped after the academic year if the school remains in operation.
Webster's phone began ringing in late February when it was announced there would be no more basketball at Bridgeport. The callers weren't offering condolences. They were looking for players. Bridgeport's athletes will be allowed to transfer to other schools without losing any eligibility.
"I promised the players I'd take care of them," Webster said. "I asked them not to do anything and we'd get together with their parents at the end of the season. I'm registering all the calls of who is interested in who, and I'm going to call in each kid one at a time and say which schools are interested in him."
The Bridgeport basketball team has 11 underclassmen that Webster will try to place at other schools.
"The problem is that three or four of my players are really wanted, and there are three or four players who are not wanted," Webster said. "The thing is, some of these coaches are under pressure to sign right away, because they're recruiting other people."
Webster will have to find a place for himself as well. First, he'll have to update the resume. The 54-year-old Webster, with a 472-284 record before last night, has accumulated more victories than any other Division I or Division II coach in New England.
"One of the marketable things I think I have, besides my record, is I want to take a couple of these kids with me," Webster said.
The most sought-after Bridgeport player will probably be sophomore Winston Jones, a 6-foot-4-inch, 210-pound forward from Queens. Jones has averaged 16 points and 6 rebounds a game this season as the only underclassman starter for the Knights.
For Jones, the possibility of moving up to Division I basketball is offset by a sadness for the waning of the Knights.
"I'm kind of disappointed because I made this my home," Jones said. "I'm sad to see it go. Now I have to start all over again, and that's tough."
Some of the Division I schools that have inquired about Bridgeport players are Central Connecticut State, Long Island University, Brooklyn College, St. Bonaventure and Baylor. Jones says he wants to go to a school where he'll play right away, be it Division I or II.
 
Bush Has 4 Years Left
 "Since I'm going to be a junior, I don't want to go anywhere where I have to sit," said Jones. "I want to work hard my first year and hopefully my senior year start, or something like that. I'd rather go in and be an immediate impact somewhere."
Freshman Bobby Bush, and his four years of eligibility, should also attract some attention from recruiters. As a Proposition 48 player from the talented team at St. Anthony High School in Jersey City, the 6-5, 210-pound forward never stepped on the court for the Knights.
Freshman Lamont Jones, a 6-2, 165-pound guard from Brooklyn, contributed 8 points and 3 assists per game as a backup point guard. He worried that having only three years of eligibility may hurt him in the recruiting game.
"I think I would've been better off coming out of high school, because I would've had four years to play instead of three," he said. "I guess I just have to be very careful where I go to make sure I get the playing time.
"I'm kind of upset that this is my only season here, but I don't have any regrets. We've been winning and doing really well, and that's kind of made up for all the problems."

HEADLINE: George Bush's Real Enemy

 BODY:
The stench of failure hangs over Ronald Reagan's White House.
New York Times editorial, Jan. 9, 1983 
 Given the rosy glow that supposedly lit up Morning in America, it's easy to forget that the Reagan years included some very tough times indeed. The Teflon President may have at times appeared to be invincible. His popularity occasionally brushed 70 percent. But not even he could avoid the political consequences of recession. In January 1983, with unemployment nearing 11 percent, Mr. Reagan's popularity in the Gallup Poll plummeted to 35 percent.
That recent history teaches how to evaluate Patrick Buchanan's challenge in the 1992 Republican primaries.
President Bush, whose popularity shot up to 90 percent just a year ago, is down to 40 percent in the last New York Times/CBS News Poll. Approval for his handling of the economy has now sunk to half that. That exposes him to harsh challenge from Mr. Buchanan, who denounces the President for supposedly deviating from conservative doctrine. Indeed, he thinks he is "driving the national debate" and winning a third of the Republican vote because his is the truer voice of the true faith.
Whatever one thinks of Mr. Bush's philosophy, a better explanation for his sinking popularity came from the Labor Department Friday when the number "7.3 percent" went up in lights. It's the February unemployment rate and it's the highest since mid-1985.
That may not be as bad as it looks. Total employment went up in February, offering a possible harbinger of recovery. But either way, the new figures demonstrate something most people know and yet, in the drama of a Presidential campaign, are quick to forget. Voters care far more about recovery than ideology.
Presidential popularity virtually defines the word evanescent. In times of international turmoil, Americans rally round the flag, and the President. They surely did last year. Before the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Bush's approval rating was 58 percent. Within days it soared to 90 percent, reflecting what John Mueller of the University of Rochester calls a "rally event." What has happened since shows the fragility of such popularity.
Just as it was shortsighted a year ago to assume that the acclaim would endure, it's probably shortsighted now to assume that the bottom will keep dropping. As Professor Mueller and other scholars find, what's decisive is the state of the economy just before an election.
President Bush's real enemy thus is not Patrick Buchanan, no matter what hyperbolic claims the Republican challenger makes. In no primary has Mr. Buchanan much surpassed the anti-Bush protest vote recorded where he was not on the ballot. The stench of failure emanates from tough times; the test of success is whether, because of or in spite of Mr. Bush, the economy recovers.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
A Far Better Thing

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
To: David Dinkins
Re:1993
Mr. Mayor,
I'm sure you're familiar with the final sentence of "A Tale of Two Cities." It's the one that goes: "It is a far, far better thing that I do, than I have ever done . . ." 
 Perhaps no one could have governed the city of New York in this time of recession, depression and urban disintegration. Last week in East New York, where the speakers were poor and African-American, the week before on the Upper West Side, where they were affluent and white, I heard the same thing: that people feel the city is running you and not the other way around.
Your administration seems to ricochet from one crisis to another, from the Korean grocery boycott to Crown Heights to the Thomas Jefferson High School shooting, as reactive as the silver sphere in a pinball machine. Its best-known official is the Housing Authority chairwoman you just replaced. Her pink leather couch and Marie Antoinette expense accounts have not made those pictures of you in the tuxedo any more palatable, especially as the poor get poorer and the middle class feel more pinched.
Maybe the fact that you were New York's first African-American mayor gave people false expectations. In East New York people talked about the hopes that you would be a savior for their community, a municipal Jesse Jackson. Since liberals tend to have a knee-jerk attitude toward race, some of them instantly saw you as a crusader simply because you are black. Everyone seemed to forget that you have historically been a go-along guy, City Clerk to Borough President and finally to Gracie Mansion.
In that sense you are the George Bush of New York City, and what's going on here is not unlike what's going on in the Presidential races. You have the advantage of incumbency, but it is whittled away by the fact that no one is sure what, if anything, you accomplished during your first term.
Like the President, you may be saved by the shortcomings of your opponents. If someone with all the right moves materialized, you would lose big. Instead you face Andrew Stein and Rudolph Giuliani.
Mr. Stein, who now holds a meaningless job, which is fitting, is nothing but a walking dollar sign. When he gave himself a $5,000-a-plate birthday party at the Waldorf and raised more than $2 million to finance an effort to seize your job, he said, "How you run a campaign reflects how you'd run a city." So now we know: Mr. Stein would have a government by rich people, for rich people, a Reagan Administration for New York.
Mr. Giuliani is hardly a thrilling alternative, with little to offer but his experience in law enforcement, which is beginning to seem warmed over, and a chilly persona that could use some heat. Nevertheless a Marist College poll at the end of January showed him leading you by 11 percentage points. That same poll showed that you would have a seven-point edge over Mr. Stein.
There are a sizable number of anyone-but-Dave voters out there, and despite what The Amsterdam News likes to say, they're animated not by your race but by your performance. Like the anyone-but-Bush crowd, their problem is alternatives. A common parlor game these days is Lesser of Two Evils: "All right, but say you have to choose between Stein and Dinkins." It has the flavor of deciding between ways to be executed.
There are people who will not get into this race because you are in it. If you stepped aside tomorrow, there would be a free-for-all. Ruth Messinger would surely jump in. She could be joined by Joe Hynes, Charles Schumer, even Elizabeth Holtzman if she can't nab that Senate seat. And there's the Harold Stassen of New York, Herman Badillo, and the Paul Tsongas of New York, Richard Ravitch. Rangel, Ferrer, Serrano -- who knows?
Right now some of those people, like some would-be Presidential contenders, are waiting until next time. Like the nation, the city cannot afford to wait. You have the opportunity to thwart a Stein administration or a Giuliani administration, not by offering a second lackluster Dinkins administration, but by clearing the way for alternatives. The way to do that is to announce that you will not seek re-election in 1993. It would be a far, far better thing than you have done in some time.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Soviet Trade Unions Retool for New Era

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While I applaud your coverage of events in the former Soviet Union, I am surprised that hardly a word has appeared about the emerging independent, democratic trade unions. 
 On Oct. 23-27, 1990, a congress of 2,300 trade unionists from across the Soviet Union voted to form a free, independent General Confederation of Trade Unions to replace the All-Union Central Council of Trade Unions, which had been under the domination of the Communist Party and the Soviet Government.
In a secret-ballot election, the delegates voted for a new set of officers (the top three are no more than 50 years old), and they proclaimed that the key priority of the new labor confederation was to "defend the rights and interests of workers in the context of the country's transition to a market economy."
The trade union confederation, in little more than a year of its existence before the breakup of the Soviet Union, got the Government to accept an unemployment insurance law that provides 26 weeks at average pay. At the legislative initiative of the union confederation, the Soviet Parliament adopted a trade union law, followed by a law establishing for the first time the right to strike. The confederation also promoted indexation of wages to protect workers against inflation and has fought to raise the minimum wage.
With its affiliated organizations in the republics, it represent about 130 million union members.
I was able to confirm the vitality and democratic character of this new trade union movement during a 24-day visit to Russia at the invitation of the confederation to lecture, engage in seminars and hold private consultations under the broad subject of democratic unions in a market economy. I found that the concerns of unions and their members in Russia and the other republics are similar in many ways to those of their American counterparts.
They want to safeguard the many benefits they enjoyed under the former Soviet Union, including free medical care, free education from elementary school through university, paid sick leave up to four months, paid maternity leave of 70 days before delivery, and 56 days post-delivery. They also want big discounts for vacations at union health resorts.
More attention should be paid to the trade unions in the republics of the new commonwealth. They have a major role to play in increasing the production of goods and revitalizing the economy.
 
HARRY KELBER
Brooklyn, Feb. 27, 1992
 
The writer, professor emeritus of labor studies at Empire State College, is editor of The Labor Educator.

HEADLINE: We Must Restore Higher Tax on Top Incomes;
Harmful Boat Fee

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The "no-new-taxes President" seems to have gone a step beyond rationality with his new recreational vessel fee. It is one thing to have to pay a tax or fee as a small-boat owner, but to do so and have the following statement attached to the sticker we receive to signify payment, verges on insult: 
 "The fee for which this document was provided was established under the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990. Persons paying this fee can expect no increase in the quantity, quality or variety of services the person receives from the Coast Guard as a result of that payment."
Do the revenues do anything at all for our waterways? I doubt that any boater would object to the charge, but should it not at least remotely serve those from whom it is extracted?
Boaters are for the most part not super-rich. We generally have to make sacrifices to enjoy a few days' recreation on our country's waterways. Since my family bought our boat, we have spent our vacations on United States waters and not abroad. I suspect the same is true for most middle-income boaters.
As a further insult to the American boater, the so-called luxury tax on boats over $100,000 produced little, if any, new revenue for the Government. It did, however, cost the United States almost all of its boat manufacturers and eliminated thousands of manufacturing jobs, as well as maritime service-related jobs in sales, maintenance and summer employment for students. Probably the biggest beneficiary of this tax was foreign boat builders.
Tax us if you must, but the taxes should both generate net revenues and help us to be a stronger nation. These fees and taxes have only hurt what was once a healthy industry and have sent their United States customers abroad or out of the market altogether.
 
WILLIAM J. LAWRENCE
New York, Feb. 16, 1992
 
The writer is a professor of economics, Pace University.
