HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Primary Debaters Become Brawlers

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 7

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas began his campaign day today in the most serene fashion, with a prayer and a gospel hymn.
But nothing is serene about this Democratic Presidential race anymore. 
 In the last few days, the candidates have begun slashing away at each other -- most frequently at Mr. Clinton -- with an abandon that was largely concealed during their pre-Super Tuesday televised debate on Thursday night.
It is a political fight that illustrates, much better than any sober discussion of health care or foreign policy ever could, just how high the stakes are in Tuesday's primary and caucus voting in 11 states.
After arriving here on Friday night and calling Mr. Clinton "cynical and unprincipled," former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts offered more criticism at a news conference today while asking in the next breath that negative campaigning stop.
 
Tsongas Assails Clinton
 "We're only helping George Bush," Mr. Tsongas said. "But this is one Greek who fights back.
"It is disruptive to my campaign, but it's more destructive to me as a leader to have the suggestion made that I cannot counterpunch."
Mr. Clinton responded in an interview today by saying: "I never thought he couldn't counterpunch. He punched. He's the guy that ran the ad saying Bob Kerrey and I were trying to increase the deficit by helping the middle class, which is baldly untrue. So I thought that was a pretty good punch, and it helped him a lot, too."
As usual, on one front, it is a television war. In Florida, where Mr. Tsongas is best positioned to score his most critical Super Tuesday victory, the attacks have become particularly nasty.
In Mr. Tsongas's newest advertisement being broadcast in Florida, an announcer says of Mr. Clinton: "Some people will say anything to get elected," and accuses Mr. Clinton of distorting Mr. Tsongas's record on limiting cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security recipients.
For Mr. Clinton's part, he is broadcasting an advertisement here that faults Mr. Tsongas for his support of increasing the Federal tax on gasoline. "Much of what Tsongas proposes smacks of trickle-down economics," an announcer says.
 
Harkin Makes a Stand
 But the battles are not limited to Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton. In South Carolina, where Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa is mounting what could be his last stand, his supporters have distributed a flyer that juxtaposes two photographs. One is of Mr. Harkin shaking hands with Jesse Jackson; the other is a photograph of Mr. Clinton with Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia at a prison boot camp. In the background are rows of mostly black inmates in uniform.
"While Tom Harkin and Jesse Jackson are fighting for social and economic justice," the handout reads, "Bill Clinton has been fighting for a national police force." Mr. Clinton has never called for a national police force.
But the real dispute, which threatens to grow as the next round of primaries approaches, is chiefly between Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton, both of whom are seeking to put the other on the defensive.
The war of words are especially harsh among the aides to the candidates. George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's Greek-American deputy campaign manager, took special umbrage at Mr. Tsongas's assertion that the Arkansas Governor had made an anti-Greek slur when he said Mr. Tsongas's economic plan was "not America."
Mr. Stephanopoulos said Mr. Tsongas was pulling an old political trick: "Whine about being attacked while you're leveling them against your opponent."
But Mr. Tsongas, while not citing specific instances of what he contended were Mr. Clinton's anti-Greek tendencies, said that he had been a victim of attacks by Mr. Clinton and his aides since he first surpassed him in the New Hampshire polls.
"I won't presume that, in a sea of malignant comment, this was innocent," he said. Any affinity the two men once shared, Mr. Tsongas said, has been "destroyed" by the back-and-forth sniping.
But Mr. Clinton said he does not take Mr. Tsongas's attacks personally.
"Am I bent out of shape about it?" he said. "No. This is, after all, a contest between two people who want to end an election."

Whine about being attacked while you're leveling them against your opponent."

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Dance Music Marries The Machine

BYLINE: By Jon Pareles

 BODY:
Electronic sounds are ricocheting all around the Limelight: TICK-a-tick-a POCK-a-tick-a
TICK-a-tick-a POCK-a-tick-a BIP bip bih-bip-bih BIP bip bih-bip-bih -- "Go!"
Moby, a skinny Englishman with close-cropped hair, pokes at a keyboard; down on the club floor, black-clad dancers are leaping, shouting, slamming. The rhythm takes Morse code to the verge of a backbeat. The only sound that wasn't entirely created with a microchip is a verbal soundbite gone electronic: digitally sampled and triggered from the keyboard. 
 Moby's music is called techno, and it is just surfacing from the dance-music underground. In the last few months, techno has moved into New York City clubs like the Limelight after gathering momentum in Europe, Los Angeles and the suburbs. It's a studio-made music in which producer-performers hide behind multiple pseudonymns, often with the alphanumeric terseness of computer abbreviations: Model 500, Altern 8, Program 2, Interactive, SL2.
At least for the moment, techno defines some new extremes for dance music. It has minimal lyrics; an average techno transcript wouldn't fill a fortune cookie. It dispenses with the vestiges of pop song structure, ignoring verses and choruses and bridges in favor of free-form, rhythm-driven expansion. And unlike synthesizer-driven pop of the last decade, techno takes machines strictly for granted; it's neither frightened nor intoxicated by them.
The rise of techno represents a recoil against urban, ethnic styles. Made with rootless synthetic sounds, techno doesn't refer directly to older songs (as hip-hop sampling does), and its rhythms steer away from the disco memories of house music. "It's white music," one record-store owner says, and the audience that turns out for techno events bears him out. On stage and on record, techno performers occasionally rap, but it is rap stripped of its connections to black culture, sanitized for the suburbs.
As with hip-hop and house music, techno has spawned and supported independent labels -- a December survey in Dance Music Report listed 25 in the United States, England, the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium -- and conglomerates are poised to move in. BMG has signed N-Joi and issued Quadrophonia's "Cozmik Jam," one of few full-length albums by a single techno entity, and Columbia has latched on to groups like T99, Eon and Midi Rain.
Techno is the latest evolutionary stage of dance music's fascination with the machine and the promise of tireless repetition. Tape loops, synthesizers and ever more proficient drum machines delighted dance-music producers, who were willing to sacrifice the subtleties of human rhythm sections in favor of machines that didn't need space, explanations, good acoustics or coffee breaks. Techno's most obvious roots are in the pumping synthesizer bassline of Parliament's "Flashlight" and in the early synthesized efforts of Kraftwerk, the deadpan German band that celebrated a cybernetic era with droning vocals and robotic rhythm tracks. Kraftwerk was recycled and re-funked for an early rap hit, Afrika Bambaataa's "Planet Rock."
During the 1980's, the arrival of MIDI (Musical Instrument Digital Interface) allowed producers to synchronize layer upon layer of electronic sound, and synthesizers conquered dance music in styles labeled synth-pop, electropop, hi-N.R.G., industrial. Self-described "modern rock" radio stations, like WDRE in Long Island, embraced the futuristic but ominous sounds of bands like Depeche Mode and New Order, which used machines to depict and decry a dehumanized society.
Techno itself arose in Detroit, where Juan Atkins, Kevin Saunderson and Derrick May, three high-school classmates (and Kraftwerk fans) who worked as disk jockeys and home-studio producers, began making stripped-down, synthesizer-driven dance records. A friend and early collaborator, Richard Davies, picked up the term "techno" from Alvin Toffler's book "The Third Wave." By the mid-1980's, the Detroit contingent was producing dance records that were distinct from house music and hi-N.R.G., though compatible, and soon they were widely imitated.
Europe embraced techno first, responding to the Kraftwerk connections. As the 1980's ended, techno became the sonic backdrop for huge, sometimes illegal dance parties called raves, where the combination of music and widespread use of the drug Ecstasy turned tens of thousands of people into dancing machines. As news of the good times overseas crossed the Atlantic, techno made its way to the United States. By now, its parameters have narrowed: techno is largely instrumental, entirely electronic and riff-based, clicking along at about 130 beats per minute. (Dance Music Report complains that the United States techno audience is actually hearing not just pure techno, but hardbeat, hardhouse and the slightly faster rave; so it goes.)
Within its parameters, however, techno comes up with sometimes startling creativity. Since words can't carry a song, the music has to; since the beat is repetitive and long-lined melody is unfashionable, composers have to keep devising new riffs and textures. In better techno tunes, the result is an outpouring of variations; a track like Program 2's "More Energy" (on Profile Records's "Best of Techno Volume 1," one of the few domestically available techno compilations) offers something different every four bars, or about every 15 seconds, and it rarely looks back.
Techno's musical ingenuity may not be as important as its atmosphere. Industrial rock also uses synthesizers and thumps away at the beat, with lyrics that are only slightly less laconic than those of techno songs. But the tone of industrial rock is dire and brutal; as the name suggests, industrial rock hears itself as a manufactured product, though one that rails against mechanization. Industrial's sounds are huge and resonant, as if taking place in colossal factories, and its singers howl and bark as if caught in pitiless assembly-line machinery.
Techno, by contrast, is crisp and almost perky. While it's not exactly playful, and often uses the same dark minor or modal harmonies as industrial rock, techno has a lighter touch; instead of cavernous resonances, its productions have the ambiance of an acoustic-ceilinged, carpeted office or a shopping mall. Where industrial rock suggests a manufacturing-based economy that's fast disappearing, techno evokes an age of bank machines and databases, with nearly all human effort invisible behind a benignly innocuous display.
To some listeners, techno may feel cold and inhuman, disconnected from living voices; earlier synthesizer-driven pop often pitted an empathetic human voice against seemingly impersonal electronics. But for its fans, techno's all-electronic soundscape doesn't feel so futuristic or threatening; the fans already have video games and pocket calculators, CD players and remote-control VCR's and they hang out at shopping malls that are disconnected from community or history but are as clean as a synthesizer blip. Techno doesn't point to an outside world; it creates an enclave where machines are mobilized for comfort.
Like house music in its early years, techno at the moment is largely functional stuff, made for club disk jockeys who can string together its instrumentals for as long as the dance floor stays busy. Techno's real impact will show up when pop and rock songs are produced or remixed in techno style (as has already begun), and when someone figures out a way to bring lyrics, extended melody and marketable personality to music that thrives on its anonymity. When techno's impersonality is breached, we'll find out whether its machines are really so user-friendly.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 22, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 8 about techno music misstated the nationality of the musician Moby. He is American, not English.

HEADLINE: The Persistence Of Inequality

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker; Tom Wicker is a former political columnist for The New York Times.

 BODY:

TWO NATIONS
Black and White, Separate, Hostile, Unequal.
By Andrew Hacker.
257 pp. New York:
Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95. 
 WAS Tocqueville right, as he was in so many of his other perceptions, when he wrote a century and a half ago: "The danger of a conflict between the white and the black inhabitants perpetually haunts the imagination of the Americans, like a painful dream"?
Not many contemporary whites know who Nat Turner was, and perhaps few could say with accuracy what John Brown's raid was all about. But to one who watched buildings burning and blacks looting in downtown Washington on the day after the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was murdered in 1968, Tocqueville's insight seems perceptive indeed.
Most of the depredations in Washington and in other cities during the long, hot summers of the late 1960's were suffered, as well as committed, by blacks. But that day in Washington, the endless lines of cars choking the streets, evacuating the city, heading lemminglike for the suburbs, were driven by whites. The rage was black; the fear was white.
On far more detailed and conclusive evidence of the racial situation in America today, Andrew Hacker writes in "Two Nations" that the fear sensed by Tocqueville still haunts not just Americans' imaginations, but "all phases of current life, from party politics to violent crime."
Thus, "to many white voters, the Democrats now look sufficiently 'black' to make them think twice about supporting its candidates," and "the Republicans have been happy to build on these beliefs." As for "further sacrifices on behalf of the nation's black minority," "about the only funding the public approves is for more police and prisons."
Mr. Hacker teaches political science at Queens College and has written prolifically on race and other American social problems. He devoted five years of study and writing to the compilation of statistical and other evidence to support the thesis of this challenging book -- that "from slavery through the present, the nation has never opened its doors sufficiently to give black Americans a chance to become full citizens."
But the real value of his book, despite its wealth of data, is in Mr. Hacker's calm, analytical eye, his unblinking view of American history and his unwillingness to accept cant and "common sense" as facts. Equally important is his compassion for the plight and sensibilities of those from whom white Americans ask "an extra patience and perseverance" that the same whites "have never required of themselves."
MR. HACKER is well aware that most whites see their country "beset with racial problems they feel are not of their making" and believe that they "bear neither responsibility nor blame for the conditions blacks face. Neither they nor their forebears ever owned slaves, nor can they see themselves as having held anyone back or down." In fact, Mr. Hacker concludes, "Most white Americans believe that for at least the last generation blacks have been given more than a fair chance and at least equal opportunity, if not outright advantages."
Therefore, in Mr. Hacker's view, few whites "feel obliged to ponder how membership in the major race gives them powers and privileges." But, he asserts, being white is the greatest privilege any American can have, for "no matter how degraded their lives . . . they can never become 'black.' " And the black presence "as a subordinate caste . . . despite all its pain and problems, still provides whites with some solace in a stressful world."
On the other hand, to be black -- not to be white -- is to be perceived by whites, in some cases unconsciously, more often deliberately, as "a degraded species of humanity." Mr. Hacker pulls no punches as to why he believes this is so:
"Being 'black' in America bears the mark of slavery. Even after emancipation . . . blacks continued to be seen as an inferior species, not only unsuited for equality but not even meriting a chance to show their worth. . . . There remains an unarticulated suspicion: might there be something about the black race that suited them for slavery?"
Why else, he asks, do other Americans still find it fitting that blacks serve so often as maids and janitors, but seldom as chief executives, senators, newspaper editors, brain surgeons or baseball managers?
So, despite Tocqueville's observation that black and white Americans "are fastened to each other without intermingling," Mr. Hacker argues that white Americans "show little inclination toward giving full nationality to the descendants of African slaves." Rather, he maintains, "It is white America that has made being black [in America] so disconsolate an estate. Legal slavery may be in the past, but segregation and subordination have been allowed to persist. Even today, America imposes a stigma on every black child at birth."
"Two Nations" offers ample evidence of where that stigma leads. For only a few examples:
* Black Americans are 12.1 percent of the tabulated population, but they got only 7.8 percent of the $3.6 trillion total personal income received by everyone in 1990.
* Among men with four years of college, blacks earn $798 for each $1,000 of income earned by whites at the same level of education; black college men earn only a few dollars more than white men who went no farther than high school.
* Nearly half -- 44.8 percent -- of black children live below the poverty line, compared to only 15.9 percent of white children.
* "For as long as records have been kept, in good times and bad, white America has insured that the unemployment imposed on blacks will be approximately double [that] experienced by whites."
* One of every five black American males will spend some part of his life behind bars -- perhaps not least because blacks in the most crime-prone age group (25 to 30) have a median income of $14,333, while whites in the same age group earn a median $20,153.
"Two Nations" also demolishes some of the familiar stereotypes whites cherish about black Americans. Some examples:
* Black women do have more children than white women, but from 1940 to 1988 the ratio of black births to white remained about the same. Black women had children about 1.33 times more often than white women in 1940, and only 1.38 times more often in 1988.
* Approximately half of all black single mothers, moreover, are fully self-supporting, not welfare recipients. And Aid for Dependent Children families are not dens of fertility; almost three-quarters of such families number only one or two children, and only a tenth of them have as many as four children. Fewer than a tenth of the parents have received Aid for Dependent Children for more than a decade, and no wonder -- the national average annual cash allowance for families receiving such aid is only $4,644, or about a seventh of the American average annual family income.
* Between 1969 and 1989, opponents of affirmative action say, blacks were being given jobs, opportunities and promotions that white workers deserved. If so, why did the average earnings of black men, relative to white men, increase by only $22 per $1,000, with only $1 of that increase coming in the decade 1979-89? And why did black college men's earnings decline by 11 percent from 1979 to 1989, while those of white college men increased by 11 percent?
Young black men now engage in violence on such a scale, particularly among themselves, that homicide has become for them the leading cause of death. Few white Americans would accept any responsibility for this "self-inflicted genocide," as Mr. Hacker aptly calls it. Yet, he argues, these violent young blacks suffer "a despair that suffuses much of their race. These are young men who do not know whether they will live another year, and many have given up caring."
It may seem contradictory that such a "subordinate caste," occupying such clearly inferior status, can inspire in the national life the fear of racial conflict that Mr. Hacker finds so prevalent. Besides, as he points out, "The United States is not South Africa, where whites are heavily outnumbered by indigenous blacks, who might mobilize their strength to dominate society."
BUT as Tocqueville noted in the 19th century, Americans of that period could rationalize the evils of slavery only by convincing themselves that Africans were inherently inferior and suited for bondage. If, as Mr. Hacker believes, that conviction has persisted long past emancipation, so has white fear of the world turned upside down -- of blacks taking power and exercising it, "the dread that blacks will treat whites as whites have treated blacks."
"Two Nations" runs strongly against what appears to be the temper of the times. Affirmative action programs are under heavy attack (suggesting, Mr. Hacker believes, the fear that they "will diminish the benefits of being white for those who have always believed that they could take that advantage for granted"), no Democratic Presidential candidate since Lyndon B. Johnson has won a majority of white voters, and the great object of concern for this year's aspirants, in both parties, seems to be the middle class rather than the underclass.
Andrew Hacker offers no antidote, no palliative, no 10-point program, not even rhetorical relief. He only looks at the nation's racial situation with a cold eye and finds it unworthy of American boasts about justice and equality. "The reader," he warns in a preface, "should be advised not to expect this book to end on an optimistic note."
The reasons for this bleak picture of two nations "separate, hostile, unequal," he concludes, "rest with a past that has shaped our present; and a present that makes use of that past. Race has made America its prisoner since the first chattels were landed on these shores. . . . A nation that has done so much to stress racial divisions should not be surprised if the result is not compassion and fellow feeling, but withdrawal and recrimination."
 
 
 
'UNCOMFORTABLE WITH TRADITION'
 Over a lunch of mussels and beer near Queens College, where he has taught since 1971, Andrew Hacker reflected on the genesis of "Two Nations." "It's been almost 50 years since Gunnar Myrdal wrote his study of the races in America, and hardly anybody reads him anymore. It seemed time to take another look at the subject. A very beguiling editor at Scribners was convinced that I should be the one to take that look. But Myrdal was given $350,000 and had a research staff of over 70. I was on my own. It took him four years to complete his work; it took me five."
A respected social scientist, Mr. Hacker considers himself a historian in the classical sense, "where you see humanity as history, just as Balzac and Dickens did -- as something to be observed and understood."
"People don't often ask themselves what it means to be white," he noted. "It's taken for granted. They don't often ask themselves what it's like to see if they have their sight -- only if it's taken away. What, then, would it mean to have our whiteness taken away?
"Of course, there's a black culture, a whole black literature, that must be left to others. This book is written by a white person, but at least I am prepared to tell you, just as I do with my black students, this is what America really thinks about you."
"Few of us are really Democrats or Republicans anymore," Mr. Hacker said. "We're all spectators. We're a nation uncomfortable with tradition, and that's a strength as well as a weakness. We're constantly looking around to see what's new. New immigrants in my class will quickly become Americans. But even with this influx, African-Americans are still being left behind. No one is coming in under them. The legacy of slavery persists." -- LYNN KARPEN

LENGTH: 1171 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
The Struggle to Provide Affordable Homes

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, CALIF.

 BODY:
The struggle to introduce low-income housing into a working-class neighborhood in this coastal city just west of Los Angeles illustrates the difficulties of providing such housing throughout the state.
The Community Corporation of Santa Monica, a nonprofit home builder, bought four separate parcels in a working-class neighborhood and planned a total of 30 apartments for renters of very low, low and moderate incomes. A group of nearby residents sued to block the project. When the home builder won in lower court, the homeowners appealed. 
 After three years of litigation, Community Corporation settled out of court with the homeowners' group for an undisclosed amount of cash and an agreement to build no more low-income units in the neighborhood for the next five years. Joan Ling, executive director of Community Corporation, said the developer was forced to negotiate "since we were on the verge of losing our building permits and our financing." The housing is currently under construction.
Political difficulties are among the many obstacles to the creation of very-low- and low-income housing, both for sale and for rent, in the nation's most populous state. (Very-low income is defined as households earning up to 50 percent of the median income of a particular community, while low income represents earnings of 50 to 80 percent of median income. Moderate income is 80 to 120 percent of the median.)
As a result of difficulties both practical and political, 79 percent of California cities have failed to comply fully with a state law requiring cities to adopt plans for affordable housing. About 31 percent of all cities in the state have either obsolete plans or no plans at all.
Those plans are inadequate, according to critics, because the state's housing laws do not rerquire cities to build housing, but merely to plan for it. That inconsistent policy is one reason California cities have not met their housing goals, according to one Marc Brown, a lobbyist for affordable housing.
"There is no mechanism to turn that paper analysis into housing -- the law has no teeth," said Mr. Brown, a director of the California Rural Legal Assistance Foundation, based in Sacramento.
Because of this, affordable housing of all kinds is an urgent issue in California, which has some of the nation's highest home prices. The National Association of Home Builders ranked 17 cities in California among the 20 least affordable housing markets in the nation. The least affordable of all, the association said, was San Francisco, where just 10.6 percent of the homes sold in the third quarter of 1991 were affordable to households earning the median household income of $49,900.
Financing is another, and possibly deeper, problem. Because very-low and low-income housing generate only a modest rental income, individual lenders are rarely willing to assume all the risk for such projects. Often, lenders prefer to take only a small percentage of any project, obliging the home builder to cobble together financing from many sources. Among these are subsidies and grants from public agencies, equity from tax-credit investors and multiple "gap" loans, to make projects work.
After attracting the lenders, home builders must get the different lenders and investors to agree on terms. The presence of more lenders causes more delay and increases legal fees, necessitating more subsidies and loans.
"Things have gotten way out of hand in terms of the complexity of financing these projects," said Ann Sewill, executive director of Los Angeles Community Design Center, another nonprofit home builder.
She recounted a recent conversation with a commercial developer. "He told me, 'We put up $1 million to make $1 million; you put up $1 million to make $100,000,' " Ms. Sewill recalled.
Beyond financing, politics may be the most stubborn barrier to affordable housing in the state. Many homeowners believe that low- and moderate-income units in their neighborhoods will hurt property values, and they oppose such projects bitterly with the help of their local political leaders.
"When it comes time to put the 'fair share' of lower-cost housing into cities, neighhbors are increasingly hostile," Mr. Brown, the housing lobbyist, said. He blames the rise of "nimbyism," or the philosophy of "not in my back yard," for the opposition to affordable housing in middle-class neighborhoods.
Sunne Wright McPeak, a Contra Costa County supervisor and housing activist, concurs. "Any one at the local level who has had to vote for affordable housing realizes there is no constituency for it," she said.
Sometimes opposition to affordable projects comes from home-buying newcomers who want to maintain and enhance property values in older neighborhoods. In the case of the troubled project in Santa Monica, people had "moved into a neighborhood recognizing that it was a low-income area but wanted to prevent the creation of new low-income housing," according to Ms. Ling of Community Corporation, the home builder.
She said that two neighborhood groups were involved in the controversy over the proposed low-income housing: longtime blue-collar residents who generally favored it, and white-collar newcomers who fought it.
In other cases, the protest comes from people sensitive to environmental issues, who perceive some projects as engines of urban sprawl and traffic congestion.
Ms. McPeak described the political resistance to affordable housing as a Catch-22 situation. "If you build on the suburban edge, you get less opposition from neighbors but more from opposition environmental groups," she said. On the other hand, projects in existing residential areas "bother environmentalists less but irritate the neighbors more."
Although it may be impossible to quiet all neighborhood protest, Ms. McPeak said certain strategies can reconcile some neighbors to affordable housing developments. Often, infill projects that occupy only one or two residential lots, and bring about little increase in the existing density, may seem less objectionable than a high-density apartment building.
Architectural compatability with the existing neighborhood is another element often insisted upon by residents, according to Ms. McPeak.
In Santa Monica, one Community Corporation project mimics the two-story stucco apartment buildings that surround it, while another displays the clapboard siding that echoes that of surrounding 1940's-era homes.
And projects that provide some community amenities may also help win acceptance for low-income projects, according to Ms. McPeak.
She cited a 200-unit project in unincorporated Contra Costa County that drew fire from both residents and environmentalists when first proposed; half the units were to be market rate, with the remainder to be below-market.
The developer, Bridge Housing Corporation of San Francisco, appeased environmentalists by preserving a riparian habitat on the site, and won over some neighbors by creating a child-care center.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 2; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1311 words

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: HAMPTON;
Landowners Endorse an Effort To Preserve a Scenic Riverside

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THE Little River in Hampton is well known among anglers as one of the state's premier trout streams, a wild and scenic stretch of water through one of Connecticut's most rural areas. And an effort by Earth Care, a local environmental group, could keep it that way.
The organization recently persuaded the owners of six tracts along the Little River to grant conservation easements to Joshua's Tract Conservation and Historic Trust Inc., preserving more than a half-mile of the river for the future. 
 "We got the easy people first, the people who have always supported what we're trying to do," said an organizer of the effort, Thomas A. Gaines. "Now we have nine and a half miles to go."
 
'I Love the Land'
 Mr. Gaines said Joshua's Trust already had a start on the process, because it owns the 100-acre Preston Sanctuary, on the river in the northern end of Hampton. Most of the new easements are in the town's south.
Kevin Kavanagh, who owns about 10 acres in Hampton, signed an easement to an acre along the river, with 200 feet of frontage. "I love the land and appreciate that it was kept the way it was before I got it," Mr. Kavanagh said. "As long as I'm alive, I'm going to keep the river as it is. And this gives me a chance to make sure it stays that way after I'm gone."
The people who donate the easements -- no one has been paid for them -- incur no expense. But if they ever decide to sell the property, the conservation easement could affect the price, since use of the property would be limited.
Mr. Kavanagh's agreement says that he cannot develop the property commercially, log it or otherwise damage the watershed. "As far as I'm concerned, those were never options for me anyway," he said. "So what am I losing?"
For others, the easements offered a way of preserving a precious past. Margaret Fox is a widow, and her husband owned the seven-acre tract along the Little River before they were married 35 years ago. He often walked by the river, she said, and she still walks there, particularly in the spring, on the road that leads by the hemlock grove he planted when they were newlyweds.
The Little River begins at the Hampton Reservoir in the extreme northern part of town, and half of the river's 20-mile length meanders through Hampton, where about 70 properties go down to its banks. After leaving town, it goes through Scotland, Canterbury and Sprague, before dumping into the Shetucket River in Norwich. In Hampton the river is classified by the state Department of Environmental Protection as having the quality of drinking water. This is the town where the naturalist Edwin Way Teale chose to live, and many people there share his zeal for the environment.
Hampton's First Selectman, Walter A. Stone, attended the signing ceremonies for the easements. In some towns the chief elected officials would rail against something that might inhibit economic development, but Mr. Stone said he supported the project.
Five farmers have sold development rights to more than 1,000 acres of agricultural land in town under a state protection program, Mr. Stone said, and about 2,000 acres in the Goodwin State Forest are within Hampton's borders.
 
Named for 17th-Century Indian
 "I was on a bus from Atlantic City to Tolland recently, and the first spot of real green I saw was when we got to eastern Connecticut," Mr. Stone said. "Hampton is fortunate to have a lot of this type of land, and we should do what we can to keep it."
David L. Wagner, president of Joshua's Trust -- the organization was named for the Indian who bequeathed to settlers in the 17th century the land that is now the 10-town Windham region covered by the organization -- said the effort in Hampton will be a model for others. He said he knew of no other effort to keep an entire river pristine.
"It's acting out the idea that we should think globally but act locally," Mr. Wagner said. "This is a great example of that theory in action."
Mr. Wagner said an easement is better for Joshua's Trust than outright ownership of the land, because the trust does not have to maintain the property or be liable if it turns out that a former owner dumped toxic materials there.
"It's a way of circumventing development without having ultimate legal liability," Mr. Wagner said. "This is the quickest, easiest way to preserve corridors along a river. In fact, rather than buy property, we encourage just the opposite. We encourage people to give us an easement and put up an endowment for the future maintenance of the property."
Daniel K. Lamont, a lawyer in nearby Mansfield and the legal adviser to Joshua's Trust, said people do not give up many rights when they grant the easement.
"It really is, from the standpoint of the use of the property, a fairly innocuous thing," Mr. Lamont said. "Most of what they agree not to do they could not do anyway, without going through planning and zoning, and inland-wetlands and other approvals processes. Because of that, it really has very little impact on the value of the land."
In some situations these types of conservation easements, granted in large blocks, can be attractive to people who want to live in an area that is guaranteed to remain unspoiled, Mr. Lamont said, thereby increasing the value of the land.
Joshua's Trust has an impassioned preservation partner in Earth Care, a group that is an outgrowth of Ecology Action, formed during the first Earth Day more than 20 years ago, said one of its founders, Alison B. Davis.
"Initially what we did was waste management at the dump," Mrs. Davis said. "We were recycling things in Hampton long before most other towns."
The group acquired a trailer for newsprint recycling, then expanded into bottles, cans, tires and other materials.
"After a while the enthusiasm from that first Earth Day waned, and the group sort of disbanded," Mrs. Davis said. But resurrected as Earth Care, it has tried to focus attention on the environment through projects like a booklet that lists places where furniture, appliances and other items can be repaired, sold or donated, as an alternative to sending such items to a dump.
"We have to learn how to live the old Yankee adage, 'Use it up, wear it out, make do or do without,' " Mrs. Davis said. "We also know you have to talk and talk for years and years before you change people's way of thinking." Mrs. Davis and her husband, Wendell, own nine acres along the river, she said, and were eager to participate in the easement program.
"It's part of my whole way of looking at life," said Mrs. Davis, who is also the town historian. "We have to save some green space, some beauty. We have a responsibility to our children and grandchildren to save this space."
The permanent easement specifically prohibits sewage disposal, burning, dumping, woodcutting except for landscaping purposes, billboards, most agricultural activities, road building, obstruction of the water, and excavation of topsoil, sand or gravel.
"The people who are donating these easements are not going to do any of these nasty things along the river bank, you can be sure," Mr. Gaines said. "What they're doing is making sure no one does these things for generations to come."
If the owner of the property violates the agreement, the covenant allows Joshua's Trust to take him to court -- at his expense.
Mr. Gaines said he likes to compare Hampton to the farmland where George Washington fought with the British when he landed in New York during the Revolutionary War. Washington was traversing a dirt road flanked by fields. The road is still there, but now it is known as Broadway in Manhattan.
"A couple of hundred years from now, this is going to be prime property, a million bucks an inch," Mr. Gaines said. "You can be sure in 200 years we're going to have the same thing as Broadway -- except for our little greenbelt."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 44; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2518 words

HEADLINE: Green Teens

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better; Nancy Marx Better, a New York-based freelance writer, specializes in business issues.

 BODY:
It's 11 on a cool Fall morning, and Sol Solomon, an 18-year-old native of Santa Monica, Calif., is pacing back and forth before some 900 students in an auditorium at Martin Luther King Jr. High School in Manhattan. Dressed in faded jeans and a T-shirt, his long black hair flowing from a baseball cap worn backward, Solomon is complaining about the environment's destruction. "The ocean I'm surfin' in is like a toilet that hasn't been flushed," he laments. "The sky has got colors in it Picasso couldn't even paint. What's going on here? Who's in control? Some corporate dude who wants to get rich? Some corporate dude who doesn't care about me?"
Amid cheers from his audience, Solomon reels off a dizzying list of ecological disasters: global warming, ozone holes, acid rain, toxic waste, vanishing wildlife. He tells how young consumers forced Star-Kist to stop buying tuna from fishermen who ensnared dolphins, how they stopped McDonald's from using foam containers and how they stopped Burger King from importing beef harvested from tropical rain forests. 
 "I know a lot of companies that are good, and I know a lot of companies that are bad," Solomon says. "So I'm going to speak out and boycott companies I don't like, because I can make a difference." Intoxicated by the potent juice of ecological righteousness, the Martin Luther King Jr. students clap wildly.
Solomon is a member of YES -- Youth for Environmental Sanity, a troupe of eco-crusaders that travels around the country preaching an evangelical mission with a funky mix of skits, slides and songs. Founded two years ago in Santa Cruz, Calif., YES, which is financed by Earth-Save and other environmental groups, has already reached more than 100,000 junior- and senior-high-school students, inspiring many to establish their own eco-clubs. The YES performers deliver an impassioned plea to their peers. "Who says we can't save the earth?" asks Solomon. "If we don't save it for ourselves, nobody's going to save it for us."
Earth Day is more than two decades old, and many adults have felt their ardor for the environment cool off. Not teen-agers. In a recent survey of 10,000 young people, the Bedford Kent Group, a New York consulting firm, found that more than 75 percent championed the environment as their favorite cause -- over homelessness, AIDS, illiteracy and drug abuse. Hundreds of groups are cropping up around the country, with punchy acronyms like HOW (Help Our World), STOP (Students Tackle Ocean Plastics) and LIFE (Let's Improve Future Environment). Just as the civil rights struggle and Vietnam shaped the baby-boom generation, global catastrophes like the Valdez oil spill or local crises like overflowing garbage dumps make their children brood darkly. They've adopted the movement their parents abandoned, convinced it's their job to turn back the tide.
To fight the good fight, so-called green teens have turned to tactics their parents should recall from college days. According to a survey by Alexander W. Astin, a U.C.L.A. education professor, the percentage of college freshmen who have taken part in protests is higher than ever -- surpassing even the late 1960's. Across America, teen-agers are nagging their parents to cast aside disposable diapers, disposable razors, disposable lighters. Chanting their movement's anthem -- "Reduce, Reuse, Recycle!" -- they conduct environmental audits of their households, examining how much trash is produced, how much energy is consumed, how much water is used. At school, they lobby teachers to substitute ceramic mugs for foam cups. Even their little brothers and sisters are getting in on the act, shunning felt-tip markers with ingredients like toluene (bad) and ethanol (very bad) in favor of beeswax crayons.
It's a reversal of the age-old generational war: now children are bullying their parents into changing their behavior. At the Bel Air Elementary School in New Brighton, Minn., 17 sixth graders were suspended in 1990 for boycotting disposable trays. Barred from class, the malcontents cleaned up a local park. At the next board meeting, the administration capitulated and agreed to buy reusable trays districtwide.
Even an innocent picnic can become a test case for the green police. Barbara A. Lewis, a Salt Lake City schoolteacher and mother of four, remembers the look on her 13-year-old son's face when she brought home plastic cups. "It was as if I'd committed a crime," she says.
Before too long, it may be. In Closter, N.J., a handful of elementary-school students founded Kids Against Pollution (KAP) four years ago to protest foam containers. After speaking before the local Board of Education, the Mayor and the Town Council, the students succeeded in getting the substance banned from the entire community. Today KAP numbers more than 1,000 chapters across the country and abroad, in junior and senior high schools as well as elementary schools.
KAP is now lobbying Congress for an "environmental bill of rights." Their proposed statute, sponsored by Representative Frank Pallone of New Jersey, proclaims: "We believe we are entitled, by law, to clean air, land and water. It does not appear that our right to a clean environment is being upheld."
VERY POLITICAL movement has its heroes, its martyrs, its myths. Looming large in the green-teen pantheon is 17-year-old Joel A. Rubin, now a junior at Phillips Exeter Academy. In January 1990, as a freshman at Cape Elizabeth High School in Maine, he saw a TV film shot by Sam LaBudde, a San Francisco biologist who worked aboard a Panamanian tuna boat to document dolphins being slaughtered in tuna nets. "I didn't see how humans could murder them so brutally," says Rubin. "Maybe it's because I was taking biology at the time, and I knew dolphins were intelligent."
Rubin blames the blunder, in part, on the generation gap. "If my parents had seen the program on TV, they would have said, 'That's too bad about the dolphins, but that's life,' " he says. "They weren't taught how to save the environment when they were growing up."
With the help of his biology teacher, Rubin got the home addresses of three senior executives at H. J. Heinz, the parent company of Star-Kist, the largest producer of canned tuna in the world. He sent letters and received no reply. Frustrated, he enlisted 75 other biology students and deluged the Star-Kist executives' mailboxes with postcards. Says Rubin: "We wanted to affect these people on a personal level. We wanted them to come home every day to those postcards."
In April 1990 -- 10 days before Earth Day's 20th anniversary -- Star-Kist announced that it would no longer buy, process or sell tuna caught at the expense of dolphins. At the press conference, Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, president of Heinz, read a handful of postcards from the Cape Elizabeth students, including one that carried a single line: "How can you sleep at night knowing your company is doing this?"
The Star-Kist saga galvanized teen-agers everywhere. It also helped set the movement's confrontational tone. In the fall of 1990, KAP members mailed 3,000 letters to McDonald's headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill., begging the company to banish its foam containers. Last winter, McDonald's announced a switch to paper-based wrappings. The company also agreed to work with the Environmental Defense Fund on a waste-reduction program.
McDonald's was lucky; it succeeded in shoring up its image among young consumers. Other businesses haven't been so fortunate. In March 1990, a group of junior-high-school students in Walnut, Calif., persuaded the State Legislature to pass a bill banning the mass release of balloons at the beginning of football games and the like. Testifying before the state's Natural Resources Committee, the students argued that after balloons pop, tiny pieces float to earth, choking small animals and birds. The students won their vote -- dealing a severe blow to the balloon business in California.
If teen-agers have been remarkably successful at forcing concessions, it's probably because they have intransigence on their side. In April, 100 high-school students were invited to Pepsico's headquarters in Purchase, N.Y., for an environmental conference sponsored by the Volunteer Center of United Way. They refused to attend if box lunches were served, objecting to the excess packaging. It would have to be a buffet. "These kids were extremely strong-minded," says Louise Leeds, coordinator of the conference. "They weren't going to give an inch."
 GREEN TEENS AREN'T the first group of young people to threaten corporate America. But they may be the most effective. Opposition to Vietnam couldn't easily be expressed as a point-of-purchase decision, but opposition to environmental degradation can. "I think boycotting is something that allows you to make a real statement," says Ryan Eliason, who helped create the YES tour as a high-school senior in Santa Cruz, Calif. "It feels powerful. If you're saying to a company, 'No, I don't like what you're doing and I'm not going to support it,' you feel strong."
Thus far, only a handful of adults have capitalized on youth's enthusiasm for the environment. The most prominent is John Javna, author of a best seller, "50 Simple Things Kids Can Do to Save the Earth." Last fall his Berkeley, Calif.-based publishing firm, the Earthworks Group, brought out a sequel, entitled "Kid Heroes of the Environment," a collection of stories celebrating eco-victors. Prompted by the success of adult eco-magazines like Garbage and E, Marvel Comics introduced Captain Planet, a comic book based on an international band of teen eco-heroes who battle earth polluters. There's more to come: in 1993, New Line Cinema will release "Toxic Crusaders," a feature film based on a band of characters who are "faster than a nuclear meltdown, stronger than the Environmental Protection Agency and able to blow away radioactive fallout in a single breath."
"50 Simple Things" has spawned a flurry of junior self-help books, most of them advising teen-agers to help the earth by acting nice, not by acting up. In early 1993 the New York-based Council on Economic Priorities will publish, with Ballantine Books, a youth version of its best seller, "Shopping for a Better World," which rates the makers of 2,000 grocery products, based on companies' social, political and economic policies. "Our aim is to have consumers of every age turn their shopping carts into vehicles for social change," says Alice Tepper Marlin, president of the council.
That's no idle threat. According to the Rand Youth Poll, the 28 million teen-agers in the United States from ages 12 to 19 have almost $60 billion to burn. While the number of teen-agers has declined over the last decade, their purchasing clout has doubled. What's more, busy parents dole out $28.3 billion to kids for family grocery shopping. All told, the Rand group estimates the impact of teen-agers on the United States economy at about $230 billion per year.
Not surprisingly, green marketing is booming -- for adults and children alike. Some 600 new "green" products were unveiled in 1990, which means such introductions are increasing at a rate 20 times faster than the overall rate for new packaged goods. Many of these introductions are targeted at children. Animal Grahams, a line of crackers made by the Small World Products Group, depicts 11 endangered species, including pandas, elephants and rhinoceroses. Made from organically grown flour, they're packaged in biodegradable cardboard boxes with soybean ink. The Small World Products Group plans to donate 2 percent of the wholesale price of the crackers to environmental causes.
Some companies, like Chevron, Exxon, Scott Paper, Weyerhaeuser, and Procter & Gamble -- are setting up environmental-education programs to improve their image among young consumers. Sebastian International, a hair-care manufacturer based in Woodland Hills, Calif., recently began a project called Little Green, which includes "eco-literacy" contests in elementary schools.
But corporations should be wary about sprucing up their reputations with a coat of green paint. "When a company spends money trying to convince people it's a good citizen instead of trying to actually alleviate pollution, kids nose it out," says Peter Bahouth, former executive director of Greenpeace.
THE MOLDING OF THE green mind generally begins at school, where, since the giant eco-disasters of the early 80's, teachers have been struggling to explain environmental issues. Ari Raisa, who teaches science at Brooklyn Friends School, is an example. "I told them to come up with a product they feel is strongly connected with environmental problems, and then research how it's made and how it's disposed of," he says.
The strategy seems to work. Tara Satahoo, a sophomore, says her family no longer buys juice in plastic jugs or coated-paper containers; they make it from concentrate, in glass jars. When she goes grocery shopping, she carries a reusable plastic bag. "We talk about products at school, so I know what's okay to buy," Satahoo says.
When these teen-agers hit college, their activism tends to intensify -- and occasionally goes right off the rails. When a Shell Oil recruiter visited the University of Minnesota, Eric Odell, a senior, donned a gas mask and poured blood-colored paint from a gasoline can over a pile of fake money stacked on a table in front of a Shell Oil recruiter. "I'm one of those people who needs reining in at times," he says.
Today, Odell is affiliated with the Student Environmental Action Coalition, the nation's biggest and bold est youth-run ecological organization. Founded in 1988 by students at the University of North Carolina, the coalition now has 1,500 chapters on college and high-school campuses. In October 1990 it sponsored the largest gathering of young environmentalists in history, attracting 8,000 students.
The conference kicked off the coalition's Corporate Accountability Campaign, in which members conduct environmental audits to change the behavior of the business world. Students at Ohio University plan to boycott British Petroleum, requesting reforms in its waste-management process. The coalition's members at the University of Colorado boycotted Coors beer, demanding less pollution in the Rocky Mountains. Students at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque boycotted acid- and stone-washed jeans, which are made with pumice, a lightweight volcanic rock produced by strip mining. The main target: Levi Strauss & Company, which holds 49 percent of the jeans market. "We want to use public pressure to make corporate America clean up its act," says Randolph L. Viscio, the coalition's national outreach coordinator.
The group recently called for a boycott of Mitsubishi, the giant Japanese conglomerate, which finances logging in South American rain forests.
Today Mitsubishi, tomorrow the world. "I think S.E.A.C. represents the future of environmentalism," says Viscio. "We're trying to broaden the definition to include everything that surrounds us."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries and Caucuses;
HARKIN ENDS QUEST AS CAMPAIGN RISES TO NEW INTENSITY

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 8

 BODY:
The Democratic field will narrow to three on Monday with the withdrawal of Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, signaling a new intensity of the Presidential race as it moves through the battlegrounds of the South and on to the industrial Midwest.
Mr. Harkin, who campaigned as a "real Democrat" and a tough voice for traditional liberalism, told supporters today that he intended to withdraw, said senior Democrats who spoke on condition that they not be identified. The decision will trigger a scramble for Mr. Harkin's backing among the ranks of organized labor. And it is emblematic of the grim winnowing now under way in the Democratic field, coming only three days after the withdrawal of Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. 
 Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California all hustled across the South today, seeking votes in the Super Tuesday contests in 11 states.
 
Tempering Expectations
 Mr. Clinton campaigned in Texas, one of seven Southern or border states voting on Tuesday. Mr. Clinton hopes to replicate his showing in the South Carolina primary, in which he captured 63 percent of the vote Saturday.
Mr. Tsongas returned to Florida today, where he hoped to make his best stand in the South. But he is trying to temper expectations for his showing across the South on Tuesday, after placing a distant second in South Carolina with 19 percent of the vote.
"I think Tuesday will be his day, I acknowledge that," Mr. Tsongas said of Mr. Clinton at a news conference earlier today in Nashville. "I think he'll do well in his territory." Mr. Tsongas, who has fought bitterly with Mr. Clinton in recent days, added, "After Tuesday, we go into neutral territory."
Mr. Brown today showed once again his ability to compete in this unpredictable political terrain, collecting 35 percent of the support to win the Democratic caucuses in Nevada. With more than 95 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Clinton had 26 percent of the vote and Mr. Tsongas 20 percent
Senior Democrats, who spoke on condition that they not be identified, said Mr. Harkin began informing top supporters about his decision to withdraw this afternoon. The political math had been grim for Mr. Harkin for several weeks now, with his resources dwindling and his rankings in the primaries and caucuses never giving him the lift he desperately sought.
His campaign spokeswomen declined to comment on his plans, saying only that Mr. Harkin had scheduled news conferences Monday at Gallaudet University in Washington and later in the day in Des Moines. John Roehrick, the chairman of the Iowa Democratic Party, said in an interview today that Mr. Harkin's candidacy had succeeded in that "he got folks to look at domestic issues and the lack of attention focused on them by the President."
Mr. Harkin had, in fact, been one of the most aggressive voices in the party in the summer of 1991. At a time when President Bush was still towering in public opinion polls, the Iowan was insisting that his party had nothing to fear in a battle against Mr. Bush in 1992.
 
'Where Does Labor Go?'
 Mr. Harkin had attracted considerable labor support, and many Democrats had expected him to stay in the race until Michigan's primary on March 17, the same day as Illinois's. "Right now, the big question is where does labor go, as we head into Michigan," said a Democratic official.
George Stephanopoulos, deputy campaign manager for Mr. Clinton, said, "Governor Clinton is going to do everything he can to gain support among Tom Harkin's constituencies, and we think they'll be attracted to Mr. Clinton's message of people-first economics."
Mr. Brown is also building some appeal among labor, some Democrats said. And Mr. Tsongas said at a news conference here tonight, "I'm the candidate of economic growth," an argument meant to be appealing to labor. Still, Mr. Tsongas has disagreed with unions on legislation to outlaw the hiring of permanent replacements for striking employees.
This stage of the Democratic primary campaign features struggles on a variety of fronts, but the underlying dynamic is simple: the accumulation of the 2,145 delegates needed to win the nomination.
In general, delegates pledged to a candidate who withdraws are free to commit to someone else, although the wish of the departing candidate can play a role.
After Saturday's primary in South Carolina, and the caucuses in Wyoming and Arizona, a delegate tally by The New York Times showed Mr. Brown with 51 delegates, Mr. Clinton with 293, Mr. Tsongas with 141, Mr. Harkin with 86 and Mr. Kerrey, who dropped out of the race on Thursday, with 27. The tally includes the preferences of superdelegates, who are national committee members, governors and distinguished former leaders.
In addition to his strong showing Saturday in South Carolina, Mr. Clinton won Wyoming with 28 percent of the vote, followed by Mr. Brown with 23 percent, Mr. Harkin with 14 percent and Mr. Tsongas with 12 percent. Mr. Tsongas won Arizona.
A poll conducted by Voter Research and Surveys of people leaving voting booths in South Carolina showed Mr. Clinton forging a powerful coalition for a Democratic primary in the South, capturing 77 percent of the black voters and 55 percent of the white. Mr. Tsongas received just 5 percent of the black vote in South Carolina, and he acknowledged today, "We are way behind the curve on this."
As in Georgia and New Hampshire, Mr. Tsongas's strongest showing in South Carolina was among the voters with the highest incomes. Ten percent of the voters in the Democratic primary there had incomes over $75,000 a year, and Mr. Tsongas captured more than half of their votes. He split the voters with the highest level of education with Mr. Clinton.
Stan Greenberg, the poll taker for Mr. Clinton, asserted that Mr. Clinton had succeeded in putting together "the closest thing to a Robert Kennedy coalition we've seen in a long time," combining black voters with "white Democrats with moderate means and moderate views to form a very large coalition in the South." Clinton allies seem increasingly optimistic about the strength of their candidate's showing on Super Tuesday.
On the Republican side, Mr. Bush received 67 percent of the vote in South Carolina, considered one of his strongholds, while Patrick J. Buchanan won 26 percent and David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader and Louisiana State Representative, won 7 percent.
Mr. Buchanan, the conservative political columnist who has not won a primary, campaigned in New England today and tried to slough off Mr. Bush's showing. "In South Carolina, his very best state where we could only campaign two days, he lost a third of the vote and 40 percent of the men," Mr. Buchanan said.
 
Hoping to Undercut Duke
 Still, Mr. Buchanan acknowledged that he would soon have to win a state. He clearly hopes that the results in South Carolina will undermine any credibility Mr. Duke has as a candidate.
The exit poll in South Carolina showed a continued protest vote against Mr. Bush: 22 percent of Republican primary voters said they were sending a message, and among that group 66 percent voted for Mr. Buchanan and 22 percent voted for Mr. Duke.
Again, Mr. Bush prospered from the votes of women: 59 percent of the men voted for Mr. Bush, 32 percent for Mr. Buchanan and 8 percent for Mr. Duke. But 76 percent of the women voted for Mr. Bush, 18 percent for Mr. Buchanan and 6 percent for Mr. Duke.
Moreover, the exit poll showed that economic concerns ranked high among those voting in the Republican primary: Nearly three-quarters said they considered the nation's economy either not so good or poor.

How the Poll Was Conducted
The Election Day poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout South Carolina on Saturday.
The poll was conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN, and NBC News.
The results are based on replies by 970 voters in the Democratic primary, and 1,368 voters in the Republican primary from 30 randomly selected precincts around the state.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results from such polls should differ by four percentage points in either direction for both Democrats and Republicans from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all voters in the South Carolina primary.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting a survey of voter opinion on Election Day, like the reluctance of some voters to take time to complete questionnaires, may introduce other sources of error into the poll. (pg. A14)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

HEADLINE: The Gun Culture: Fun as Well as Life and Death

SERIES: 200 Million Guns -- Second article of a series

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz.

 BODY:
It is sunny and in the low 60's on a winter's Friday afternoon. Bruce W. Nelson, a leathersmith who specializes in gun belts and holsters, and his wife, Sandra S. Froman, a lawyer, have invited friends to their home in the cactus-studded foothills of the Catalina Mountains for some pistol shooting.
Starting with .22 revolvers, moving on to .45-caliber and 9-millimeter semiautomatics, they shoot soda and beer cans, hitting them low so they pop into the branches of a paloverde tree. 
 Over at the Tucson Rod and Gun Club, Les Blevins, a water well operator, helps his 10-year-old son, David, align the sights of their rifle and fire at paper targets 100 yards down range. They are preparing to hunt javelinas, spindly legged wild boars that weigh about 40 pounds. "He's going on his first hunt," Mr. Blevins says. "I get to see how good a coach I am."
At Jensen's Guns and Ammo, which does about $11 milllion a year in sales, James Jennings, a sheet-metal worker at the Lockheed Corporation, is looking for replacement parts for an old rifle. "I collect World War II stuff," he says. On weekends, he says, he fires 200 bullets into the desert, about $60 worth. "I enjoy it, just going out and shooting a nice quality weapon."
In the national debate over crime control, a gun, depending on one's view, is either an agent of evil that ought to be banned or restricted, or a constitutionally enshrined defense against evil. But in Arizona as in much of the country, there is a large American culture of gun owners for whom firearms are primarily agents of fun.
Some members of the gun culture here can recite the Second Amendment, which in their interpretation confers upon a citizen the right to bear arms against anyone from burglars and alien armies to a government gone berserk. But the right they pursue the most is the right to indulge in a pasttime that they find as benign and exhilarating as other people find shooting birdies on golf courses.
They see their ownership of firearms as something apart from the escalating violence of city streets around the country, or even from the drug wars that leave bodies in Tucson's desert outskirts.
What becomes clear in conversations here is a yawning gap in beliefs between the many Americans who see little use for guns and those who see them as an enjoyable part of their lives -- a gap that explains why it has been so hard for the country to agree on measures that might curb criminals' access to firearms.
For all their other uses, guns here are venerated levelers. A proverb of the frontier had it that "God made man, and Sam Colt made him equal," people here say.
"Man or woman, old or young, fat or thin, everyone on your right and everyone on your left has the potential to be as good as you are," said Phillip Murphy, a celebrity in the National Rifle Association for having twice used guns to trap burglars at his home, both times without firing.
Tucson, a city of sand, asphalt, the stately saguaro and the spaghetti-like cholla cactus that is said to fire its needles into the hides of the curious, seems no more a community of gunslingers than the Holy See. Federal law requires licensing of automatic weapons, like machine guns, but Arizonans can buy anything else on the spot, just by showing a driver's license. Outdoors, they can legally saunter about town packing pistols on their hips. But few do, and retiree golfers, much more than gun owners, set the tone of life.
The Tucson Police Department says the rate of property crimes here is one of the nation's highest, in part because many retirees vacate their homes in the hot summer. But the rate of violent crime is one of the nation's lowest for cities with more than 250,000 people. (The population of Tucson and its spreading suburbs is about 680,000, almost double the 1970 total of 352,000.)
Still, the police worry about people's caches of guns and how easy guns are to get.
 
The Targets
Bottles and Cans, Deer and Burglars
 In the gun culture here, some people merely collect guns. A few have hundreds, valued for their age and artistry, which they exhibit on walls of specially built walk-in vaults as big as a dining room. Thousands of other people have an interest no deeper than the gun in the table drawer, kept for self-protecton. Among active gun users, those who have scruples about hunting javelinas, deer, quail and other game are target shooters.
They go to the rod and gun club, the Tucson Trap and Skeet Club, the Pima Pistol Club or the two indoor ranges in town, where they compete in a sport that can be as rigorous and precise as any. Seth Nadel, a guest at Ms. Froman's and Mr. Nelson's and a serious competitor, explains a typical match:
"You shoot at a man-like silhouette with Olympic scoring rings on it. The center ring is the size of a pack of cigarettes." Standing 7 yards back, a contestant has 20 seconds to pepper the silhouette with 12 bullets. From 15 yards, he fires 12 more rounds within 20 seconds. From 25 yards, he has 90 seconds to fire 18 rounds, but from four positions. From 50 yards, he fires 24 rounds in 2 minutes 45 seconds, also from four positions.
One could hardly compete in a contest like this, shooters say, without a semiautomatic pistol, which holds 10 to 15 cartridges and fires a bullet with each squeeze of the trigger -- the very kind of gun some want to ban as being lethal in the hands of criminals.
More often, shooters in Tucson go "plinking" at cans and other objects in the desert. "Plinking's got to constitute 60 percent of all the ammunition that's fired out there," said Robert E. Jensen, president of Jensen's.
Whatever the uses of guns, shooters here recognize an etiquette they all seem to respect. Ms. Froman said, "You assume all guns are loaded, and you never point at a person, and you keep your finger off the trigger until you're ready to fire." And you hand someone a gun with the chamber open and empty.
 
The Merchants
A Business Built On Gun Culture
 If any one institution defines the gun culture of Tucson, it is Jensen's. With 70 employees, it is the biggest gun retailer in Arizona and one of the nation's 10 biggest.
Mr. Jensen, approaching retirement at 62, got started here 34 years ago, after leaving Indiana in quest of work and a better place to shoot.
Mr. Jensen said he did not know how many people in town have guns. Anyone who has a gun for purposes other than protection, he said, tends to have at least four or five.
He has 9,000 customers on his mailing list, and he sells 15,000 guns a year. The No. 1 seller is a Colt .45 semiautomatic pistol for $500.
"The typical customer is upper blue-collar, married, with two incomes," Mr. Jensen said. But customers include doctors, lawyers, business owners and two local television celebrities.
Besides guns, the shop sells truckloads of ammunition, including five million reloaded shells, which are much cheaper than new ones, a year. It used to sell home-storage cases with glass doors to display guns. But home burglaries have driven the cases out of the market, and now Jensen's sells heavy steel safes -- about one a day -- for an average price of $500.
Jensen's nurtures the gun culture by catering to the young. "We have BB-gun contests for 6-to-10 year-olds," Mr. Jensen said. "If a parent buys a .22 for his child, we give the child a free box of ammunition a month for six months."
Once a year, the store sponsors a javelina hunt for parents and children. It conducts gun-safety classes.
Crime and gun abuse are problems, Mr. Jensen granted. "We know if we sell 15,000 guns a year, a few are going to be misused. Automobile dealers know a few of the cars they sell will be involved in a certain number of fatal accidents. It doesn't mean the gun culture condones it."
Mr. Jensen said the average customer bristles at proposals to regulate guns. "He says: 'I'm not the problem. Why are you unloading on me?' "
 
The Shooters
Lessons Learned From Grown-Ups
 Jensen's customers' involvement with guns covers quite a range. Mr. Jennings said his World War II collection includes survival gear, like camouflage uniforms and a gasoline cooking stove, as well as guns. "You never know, the economy could collapse," he said. "I like the idea of going to the wilderness and roughing it."
"I feel every household should have a gun," he went on. "If somebody breaks in, you're more likely to deter them. But I do kind of feel that if you have a gun in the house you should have a soft-point bullet so it won't go through your house into your neighbor's."
Another customer, Guyla Boswell, there with her sons Byrdeen, 6, and Bernie, 5, bought a rifle with a bayonet for her husband. Mrs. Boswell said she doesn't shoot, "but I can load one up if I need it. Protecting your family, I believe in that."
Byrdeen and Bernie have BB guns at home. At 10, when the law allows, they expect to trade up to .22's. "Go hunting, that's what me and my dad's going to do," Byrdeen said.
"Me, too," Bernie said.
Like the Boswell boys, many shooters here trace their attachment to guns to their fathers and their fathers' fathers. "We always had guns in the house," said Donald Burtchin, a Pima County environmental official.
Mr. Burtchin still has his first gun, a lever-action .22-caliber Winchester, and he has the first gun he bought himself, a pump-action .22 Winchester, called a gallery gun because it was used in amusement parks. He has a lever-action Winchester .30-30 that his paternal grandfather owned and a gallery gun that belonged to his maternal grandfather. He will pass them on to his child, Eva.
Ian Truex, who is 12, was at the Rod and Gun Club practicing shooting with his 4-H club. "My dad and I and my grandfather go hunting deer and bird," he said. "Never hit anything yet. I started last year. I would be real happy if I just got a shot at one." But even missing is more fun than anything else.
Sandra Froman got into shooting for quite different reasons. She was single, alone and living in Los Angeles when a man tried to break into her house. Her screams frightened him off, she said. "But I realized I was responsible for my own safety."
"I decided I was going to buy a gun and learn how to use it," she said, thus becoming one of a tiny minority of women who are active shooters.
Ms. Froman went to the American Pistol School at Gunsite Ranch in Paulden, north of Phoenix. "Shooting was a lot of fun because I was good at it," she said. At her Tucson home, she keeps a gun by the bedside, loaded. "If you don't keep it loaded and ready to shoot," she said, "it's not a self-defense weapon."
Ms. Froman and another shooter, Mr. Murphy, are leading members of the rifle association. They argue against gun control. They consider gun registration, giving the Government access to personal information about shooters, an invasion of privacy. And they argue that requiring a waiting period before buying a gun could jeopardize as many victims as it helps by denying a gun to a person who faces imminent danger. "You might protect a nut from getting a gun," Ms. Froman said, "but what about the victim?"
But like the uses of guns in Tucson, views about guns and gun regulation are diverse. "They think registering a gun is the first step in taking away their freedom," said Ian Truex's father, Dick. Mr. Truex has two rifles and two shotguns at home, and they are strictly for hunting. "I'm not political about it," Mr. Truex said. "The waiting period, that wouldn't bother me. I'm not going out to buy a gun the day I go hunting."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Six of the dozens of magazines that appeal to gun fanciers and dealers; Sandra S. Froman and her husband, Bruce W. Nelson, shooting at the range at their home in Tuscon, Ariz. They often invite friends over for shooting sessions. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times) (pg. A10)

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk
