HEADLINE: The Politics of Declining Incomes

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
Americans' after-tax income is lower than it was three years ago, when George Bush became President, the Government has reported.
Many economists say the decline in this income gauge during the Bush Presidency could be an ominous portent for his re-election chances, and they cite the so-called pocketbook index to prove it. 
 For more than four decades, the correlation between personal income after taxes and Presidential re-election rates has been tracked. Derived from the work of Edward Tufte, a Yale University professor, the index found that incumbent administrations had won 50 percent of the popular vote only when incomes had risen by annual rates of 3.4 percent.
The increase, after taxes and adjusted for inflation, is measured by comparing the personal income rates of the third quarter of 1988 with those of the July-to-September quarter of the previous year.
 
'It's Not Possible'
 But with incomes over the latest four quarters contracting at an annual rate of six-tenths of 1 percent, and the economy still struggling to mount a sustainable recovery, many economists think there is practically no chance this standard can be met.
"I would think it's not possible" even if a solid recovery took hold this spring, said Lynn O. Michaelis, the chief economist for the Weyerhaeuser Company, the wood-products concern based in Tacoma, Wash. "Zero" possibility, added Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.
Jay N. Woodworth of the Bankers Trust Company is one of the analysts who asserts that Mr. Bush is in danger of suffering the fate of the incumbent parties "in 1952, 1960, 1968, 1976 and 1980 who lost the election chiefly because of the poor performance of the U.S. economy."
Consumer sentiment and Gallup Poll popularity ratings are both "reasonably correlated" with incomes, Mr. Woodworth said, noting that in all five elections, incomes had risen by less than 2.8 percent a year. The losers, in some cases a President's would-be successor of the same party, rather than the President himself, were Adlai E. Stevenson, Richard M. Nixon, Hubert H. Humphrey, Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter.
To be sure, several analysts are more sanguine in their economic outlook for election time, thinking the recovery is already under way. They point to the nation's total output, or gross domestic product, having risen, albeit at an average rate of less than 2 percent, for the latest three quarters. And other politico-economic barometers suggest brighter prospects for Mr. Bush.
Take the formula for predicting election outcomes created by Ray C. Fair, also a Yale professor, that stresses output and inflation. The more important of the two, he said, is the growth rate of the country's gross domestic product, adjusted for population growth, in the six to nine months before Election Day. The other is the inflation rate in the two years before Election Day.
Assuming recovery takes hold and pushes the gross domestic product up this year at a 2 percent to 3 percent clip -- somewhat higher than the 1.6 percent consensus of the economics fraternity -- Professor Fair figures the President to get 53 percent to 59 percent of the vote.
Inflation is quite favorable, with consumer prices rising by 3.1 percent in 1991 and producer prices actually falling slightly, and Professor Fair's formula also includes a factor for the advantages of incumbency.
"It's hard to defeat an incumbent Republican running again," he said. On the other hand, "if there's a double-dip, negative growth starting now, then there's a considerable chance Bush could be defeated."
Another method of tying political fortunes to economic conditions rests mainly on the unemployment rate. Michael S. Lewis-Beck, a political scientist at the University of Iowa, has observed that an incumbent or his party won on all five postwar occasions when the unemployment rate was falling in the second quarter of the election year. These involved Harry S. Truman in 1948, Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, Mr. Nixon in 1972, Ronald Reagan in 1984 and Mr. Bush in 1988.
The simplest gauge is probably the so-called misery index, devised by the late Arthur Okun, which merely adds the unemployment and inflation rates. This is barely in double digits now, compared with a reading of almost 20 in 1980.
 
Different Circumstances
 Even the many economists who seem partial to consumers' disposable income as the most crucial factor in election results acknowledge that the traditional guides may not work this year because of different economic conditions.
"A 3 percent standard is a lot harder to make today than it was before," said Richard D. Rippe, the chief economist for Prudential Securities Inc. Perhaps, he implied, people have gradually become accustomed to skimpy growth in spendable incomes, partly the result of rising state and local taxes, and thus would not blame Mr. Bush for a jolt.
And Joseph W. Duncan of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, the information-services company, said that while consumer wallets would not fatten much this year -- mainly because of low returns from interest, rents and proprietorships -- this may not be particularly important.
"I don't think the equation will work this year," said Mr. Duncan, a former Federal policy maker on statistics. He said he was inclined to look at what happens to jobs.
And what happens with jobs, can, of course, be seen in more than one light. "If you look at the 93 percent of the population still employed, you see their incomes are doing very poorly," said Lee Price, a senior economist for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. The decline in income, many analysts say, is an important factor in the low state of consumer confidence, which in turn is holding back recovery.
However they view the numbers, economists generally agree that the figures will not get dramatically better for the President and that each month the recovery is delayed will make re-election less likely.
Already, said Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch, "It's a contestable election."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
Clinton-Tsongas Ads Provide a Little Drama in Florida Contest

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla., March 8

 BODY:
For all their griping about the clogged airwaves, Floridians ought to be grateful for the commercials that Paul E. Tsongas and Bill Clinton have put on television here. What little drama there is to this state's fly-by Presidential campaign, they are providing.
It is true that the commercials are not particularly sensational when compared with, say, ones about furloughed murderers. But for Floridians watching the campaign on television, they are pretty much all there is to see. 
 On the newscasts here in Florida's second-largest metropolitan area, the state's upcoming Presidential primary has trailed far behind items with more local interest, like the rape trial of a young Tampa man -- a sort of William K. Smith trial redux -- and the recent firing of the St. Petersburg police chief.
 
Uncluttered Setting for Ads
 What primary coverage there has been has tended to be dominated by reports of how the voters have been uninspired by the candidates and how few are expected to vote on Tuesday. Candidates who appear in Tampa, as former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California did Saturday, can expect to get about 45 seconds on the evening news. Those who do not have to content themselves with less.
This paucity of television news coverage has reduced a lot of the clutter that often surrounds advertising campaigns. With the other Democratic candidates too poor to advertise and the Republicans forgoing commercials, the television battle between the once-friendly Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton has taken on an intriguingly intimate quality, like a private spat being carried out in public.
After listening to the two men harp at each other for a few days running, one cannot help feeling somehow implicated in their dispute. Perhaps, one wonders, it is time to find them professional counseling.
The techniques that Mr. Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, and Mr. Tsongas, a former Senator from Massachusetts, are using against each other should be familiar to most married couples. Each man has found the other's vulnerabilities and has tried to make caricatures of them.
 
Frog in His Chair
 Mr. Clinton went first with a commercial that attempts to discredit Mr. Tsongas's economic policies while at the same time taking advantage of his sometimes schoolmarmish expression.
"Time Magazine says, 'Much of what Tsongas says smacks of trickle-down economics,' " the narrator intones, while in the corner of the screen there appears a picture of Mr. Tsongas looking as if he has just discovered a frog on his chair.
The screen then flips around, and a friendly looking Mr. Clinton takes Mr. Tsongas's place. "Bill Clinton wants change," the narrator says. "More education and job training and making the rich pay their fair share."
The commercial closes with a full-screen shot of Mr. Clinton bathed in a warm orange light.
Mr. Tsongas responded to this advertisement with one that plays off Mr. Clinton's ill-concealed ambitions. The first shot is a black and white picture of Mr. Clinton looking like a circus barker. "Some people will say anything to be elected President," the announcer says.
Then a black and white shot of Mr. Tsongas appears. He is poring over his work in a pose reminiscent of the young Abraham Lincoln. "Isn't it time we sent a message that we've had enough negative campaigning?" the announcer asks as a full-color Mr. Tsongas emerges onto the screen shaking hands with supporters.
 
Insuring Viewership
 Both of the candidates have been trying to amplify their commercials by using the same themes on the stump. Thus, the other day Mr. Tsongas held up a stuffed bear and said, "This is my opponent: pander bear." Mr. Clinton meanwhile has been traveling around with a clipping of a New York Times article reporting that the richest 1 percent of Americans took in about 60 percent of the increase in after-tax income in the 1980's. At the same time he accuses his opponent of espousing "growth first, fairness later."
Aides to Mr. Clinton say he has spent roughly $500,000 to broadcast his commercials in Florida; Mr. Tsongas's aides say he has spent about $300,000. By Presidential campaign standards, this is not a heavy budget for a state with half a dozen media markets. But it is enough to insure that most television viewers have seen the exchange at least a few times.
Several potential voters interviewed in the indoor cool of University Square Mall in Tampa recalled having seen Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton cut each other down on television. But it was unclear whether either candidate had achieved anything, since few of those interviewed could recall what it was the two men were fighting about.
"I tell you how it is," said one Tampa resident, who would give her name only as Ann. "I hear them, but I'm not listening."

HEADLINE: Trump Casinos May File Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, March 8

 BODY:
Two of Donald J. Trump's casinos, Trump's Castle and Trump Plaza, could file plans on Monday in Federal Bankruptcy Court to restructure $538 million in debt.
Bondholders completed voting Friday to approve the plans for filing a prepackaged Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The New Jersey Casino Control Commission had been told in the past two weeks that sufficient support was in place. 
 The advance creditor approval helps avoid a long and costly stint in bankruptcy court. Mr. Trump's other Atlantic City casino, the Trump Taj Mahal, emerged from bankruptcy court last year with a prepackaged plan similar to that proposed for Trump's Castle.
Under the Castle plan, Mr. Trump would give bondholders half the casino's equity in exchange for lower interest rates on $288 million in bonds, some of which now pay 13 3/4 percent.
The Trump Plaza plan would swap $225 million of bonds at 12 7/8 percent and $25 million in long-term debt for $200 million in debt at 12 percent and 4 million shares of preferred stock.
The Plaza plan does not relinquish any equity because the casino hotel is not in default.

HEADLINE: Isolated Washington Neighborhood Keeps Wary Eye on Its New Subway

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
For Anacostia, a neighborhood separated from the rest of the nation's capital by the river that bears its name, the recent opening of its first subway stop could mean the end of decades of isolation.
But many residents worry that the long-awaited arrival of the Metro's Green Line could engender a rush of gentrification in a neighborhood that has seen its turn-of-the-century grace diminish over the years, supplanted by drugs and crime. 
 The Anacostia station, which nearly 11,000 people use on weekdays, is the final stop of a $286 million, three-station extension of the Metro subway line that opened in December. Stations on an extension of that line are planned to open in 2001, a spokeswoman for Metro said.
The subway whisks Anacostia residents to downtown Washington in a matter of minutes, in contrast to the slow buses that were a mainstay in the neighborhood before the subway.
But the subway's advent did not come easily. There was a great deal of wrangling over the placement of the station on the edge of the neighborhood and the accompanying cutback in bus service.
 
Not on the Map
 Though few residents believe the subway's coming heralds an overnight renaissance, many view it as a lifeline, another link to pull Anacostia closer to the rest of Washington and draw Washingtonians across the river to a neighborhood so isolated it sometimes does not even appear on city maps.
In the bleak area near the station, where most merchants work behind the safety of bullet-proof glass, business owners are counting on the subway to bring in more business and speed up revitalization.
"It will help tremendously," said Roy Distad, who owns a garage near the station. "This has always been such an out-of-the-way place to get to."
The further one goes from the station, however, the less enthusiastic the responses often become.
Many residents say that the geography, poverty and dearth of political clout that have always separated them from the rest of the city will not be solved by a new subway station.
"It's not going to help black people at all," said a merchant, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, in Anacostia's main business district, more than a mile from the new station. She says she worries, as do others, that the subway may bring a rash of land speculation and gentrification that will displace longtime residents and shopkeepers, most of whom are black.
"In my neighborhood, it won't change anything," said Robert Adams, a neighborhood representative. "You're only talking about one subway station."
 
Changing Neighborhood
 Built in the late 1800's by craftsmen who commuted across the river to work in the Washington Navy Yard, Anacostia is still distinguished by its historic district of hundreds of Victorian, Empire, Queen Anne and Italianate houses, many with large yards surrounded by low, wrought-iron fences.
But in the decades since the demise of the pontoon bridge that linked Anacostia and the Navy yard, the area has changed significantly, with some streets little more than boarded-up shops and run-down housing. An occasional battlefield for drug wars, it is a place where cab drivers sometimes refuse to go.
Dorn McGrath Jr., a professor of urban and regional planning at George Washington University, acknowledges that the new stop could encourage speculation and gentrification. But Mr. McGrath, who directs a team of graduate students that has tried to minimize the impact of subway construction on the historic district and protect the area from overdevelopment, is counting on the recession to help curb a renewal process that has drastically changed other black areas in the city.
Mr. McGrath said that Anacostia had been home mostly to black and white working-class people until 1968, when whites fled many parts of the city after racial disturbances.
He remains optimistic about the prospects that will come with the subway. "We will see more new buildings," he said. "With that will come amenities, little parks, a more attractive building environment."
And some businessmen say that if the subway does draw people from other neighborhoods here, it's all for the better.
"It's the most beautiful neighborhood of the city, believe it or not," said Andrew Washington, who runs a drapery shop and several other small businesses in Anacostia. "If you just look around on this side, you've got the park, you've got the river. If you get into a fifth-floor office, it's like a little Miami, the way the river curves."
Now that the station is in place, many residents say they are resigned to it, though still unsure of what it will mean.
"I don't know," said Irwin Ruben, who has run a drugstore in Anacostia for more than 30 years and is known as "Doc," when asked if he thought it would be a boon to the neighborhood. "I can't give you a yes or a no. I hope so."

HEADLINE: Colrain Journal;
Peace Advocates Turn Tax Resistance Into a Ritual

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLRAIN, Mass., March 5

 BODY:
Every Thursday morning for 14 weeks, a small group of out-of-towners has trudged down a dirt road in this quiet Berkshire community carrying colorful hand-sewn banners to the doorstep of a small white farmhouse.
Stopping in the front yard, they are greeted by others, who form a circle and join hands to sing songs of defiance and world peace in a ceremony evocative of the 60's. They have come to protest the size of the nation's military budget in a house that has become a symbol of tax resistance. 
 The participants have two things in common: they do not believe in paying Federal taxes to finance the United States military, and, pointing to the end of the cold war and evidence of social unrest in the nation, they believe the time is ripe for a revival of their cause.
"Everybody's become more restless and disgusted with the major parties in government," said David Dellinger, who was a defendant in the Chicago Seven trial and who came to Colrain with a group from Vermont. The Chicago Seven were anti-war protesters charged with various offenses related to disruptions at the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
"Everywhere people go now, there's crime in the cities, homelessness, drugs, poverty, unemployment," said Mr. Dellinger, now 76 years old. "I think people are going to decide we didn't win the cold war. The Soviet people lost and we lost."
Mr. Dellinger and others have come from as far away as California to the Colrain house, which was seized by the Internal Revenue Service in 1989 because its owners had not paid $27,000 in Federal taxes and interest. The tax-resister owners, Randy Kehler and Betsy Corner, did pay their local and state taxes.
Mr. Kehler and Ms. Corner continued to live in the house until they were arrested by Federal marshals last December. Since then, friends and supporters of the couple have arrived to occupy the almost empty house in weeklong shifts marked by the Thursday "changing of the guard" ceremony.
Because the house was sold in a Government auction in February, all who go inside risk arrest for trespassing. Seven protesters were arrested on the day the house was auctioned but were released after the auction.
For Bonney Simons of St. Johnsbury, Vt., sleeping on a bedroll in the house is her first official act of civil disobedience. At 72 years of age, she said, it is time to "put your body where your mouth is."
Others, like Purusha Obluda, come to resurrect values of their past. Mr. Obluda met Mr. Kehler in California in 1967 after being jailed for blocking the Oakland induction center.
During his week's stay at Colrain house, Mr. Obluda, 64, typed a letter to the Government saying he would not pay his income tax this April. "I don't expect to file for the rest of my life," he told others before he left to go home to Palo Alto, Calif.
The I.R.S. says it stopped counting tax refusers in the mid-80's because the numbers were so small.
The sale of the house to Danny Franklin, a 22-year-old part-time police officer from the nearby town of Greenfield, has added a twist to the protest, which seeks among other things more attention for housing needs.
The house sits on land owned by the Valley Community Land Trust, a private trust formed to preserve open space and affordable housing in the area, said John J. Stobierski, Mr. Franklin's lawyer. Mr. Franklin is waiting for the trust to confirm that he can assume the 99-year lease before moving into the house with his fiancee and 5-month-old child.
From his office in the Traprock Peace Center in nearby Deerfield, Mr. Kehler said that he felt sorry for the young couple who bid on his house but believed that they had made a "mistake."
"In our view, they have wittingly or unwittingly assisted the Government in collecting taxes from us," he said.
Mr. Kehler, 47, a self-employed public policy researcher, spent 10 weeks in jail after his arrest in December and was released on the day the house was sold. He and his wife, Ms. Corner, and their 12-year-old daughter are staying at a friend's home near their former house.
Ms. Corner, a self-employed landscape architect, still returns to tidy up the house she lived in for 13 years. She bristles at those who have written letters in the local paper saying she is setting a bad example for her daughter, Lillian.
"We aren't paying for bombs and she understands that," Ms. Corner said. "People can't get away from the fact that we're breaking the law. But this country was founded by breaking the law."

The house was seized by the Internal Revenue Service because the couple refused to pay Federal taxes. Friends and supporters have occupied the house in shifts since then. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Companies Find Rewards In Hiring G.E. Executives

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
So many companies have been rejuvenated by the arrival of a new chief executive drawn from the management of the General Electric Company that many investors feel as if they have hit a jackpot when their companies announce such recruiting coups.
Companies that hire G.E. executives usually get managers who have experience running businesses that would be among the nation's largest companies if they were independent. Most have also been through G.E.'s widely admired management training courses and have absorbed G.E.'s global perspective. 
 "It takes a special leader to rise to the top of G.E., or near it," said Howard A. Rubel, an analyst who follows the company for C. J. Lawrence Inc. "Anyone who gets there has faced a host of demanding circumstances and has seen more than one industry."
Analysts call the good fortune that often follows G.E. executives to other companies the halo effect, and it has been particularly strong in the last year.
In June, when Allied-Signal Inc. announced that Lawrence A. Bossidy, G.E.'s co-vice chairman, would replace Edward Hennessy as chief executive, the company's share price immediately jumped 13 percent, to $29.375. And that was just the start.
As Mr. Bossidy embarked on a cost-cutting overhaul of Allied-Signal's operations, the stock climbed. It closed Friday at $49, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Bossidy joined Allied-Signal less than a month after one of G.E.'s best-known alumni, Stanley C. Gault, took over at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. Mr. Gault, who had risen to be head all of G.E.'s industrial products businesses, left in 1980 to manage Rubbermaid Inc., the rubber-products company in Wooster, Ohio, that his father co-founded. By the time he left Rubbermaid for Goodyear, sales had jumped to more than $1.5 billion from about $300 million, and earnings had grown even faster.
Goodyear's stock was already up to $28, from a low of $17, when Mr. Gault arrived, and the share price jumped $3 when his appointment was announced. Since then, it has bolted upward, closing Friday at $60.50, down $2, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Gault has brought a new marketing focus, as opposed to production focus, to Goodyear," said Saul H. Ludwig, who follows the company in Cleveland for Roulston & Company. "And he's convinced employees at all levels that they are on a winning team."
Just as impressive is what Glen H. Hiner has delivered to shareholders of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation since moving there at the end of December from his position as head of G.E. Plastics.
Shares of Owens-Corning Fiberglas, based in Toledo, Ohio, rose $2.25, to $23.25, on the day Mr. Hiner's appointment was announced. A month later, the shares leaped 27 percent in a single day, to $36.325, as Mr. Hiner announced plans to take an $800 million charge against earnings in 1991's fourth quarter to cover all of Owens-Corning's uninsured asbestos liabilities for the rest of the decade.
Wall Street liked Mr. Hiner's effort to put the asbestos problem aside so much that it ignored lower-than-expected quarterly earnings announced the same day. The jump also signaled confidence that Mr. Hiner would deliver on his goal of producing quarterly gains throughout 1992 and 1993. The stock closed Friday at $36.875, down $1.625 on the Big Board.
Old-line industrial companies are not the only ones that seem to respond to the G.E. touch. Roger Schipke, the top G.E. appliance executive when he left in 1990 after 29 years, became chief executive of the Ryland Group Inc., a home-building company in Columbia, Md., after a short transition period as president.
Despite the recession in the housing industry, Ryland's shares have risen to $26.50, down 25 cents, on Friday from $15.25 on Dec. 18, 1990, the day before Mr. Schipke's appointment was announced.
Analysts said that Ryland was a well-managed company before Mr. Schipke arrived, but that it has benefitted from the global perspective he brought from G.E. by winning its first international contracts.
What other companies would currently make up a mutual fund of companies led by former G.E. executives? General Dynamics (William Anders); Wang Laboratories (Richard Miller); Sundstrand (Harry C. Stonecipher); Rubbermaid (Walter Williams); M/A-Com (Thomas A. Vanderslice), USF&G (Norman P. Blake Jr.); Zurn Industries (George Schofield); Clean Harbors (Clyde Keaton), and Systems and Computer Technology (Michael J. Emmi).
Many of these companies enjoyed healthy stock gains in the early months after former G.E. executives took control. The Sundstrand Corporation, an aircraft and components maker based in Rockford, Ill., rose 60 percent in the first seven months after promoting Mr. Stonecipher from president to chief executive in 1989. He had joined Sundstrand two years earlier after 26 years with G.E.
Zurn Industries Inc., a manufacturer of pollution control equipment, rose more than 34 percent in Mr. Schofield's first six months as chief executive in the latter half of 1985. The USF&G Corporation, a deeply troubled insurance company, climbed from $7.875 when Mr. Blake took over on Nov. 26, 1990, to $12.50 the following April.
But the record is not perfect. M/A-Com Inc., a military electronics concern in Burlington, Mass., saw its stock fall during the early months of Mr. Vanderslice's control. So did Clean Harbors Inc., an environmental cleanup company in Quincy, Mass., when Mr. Keaton began serving as co-chief executive with the founder, Alan S. McKim.
And the stocks of companies led by former G.E. executives have not always sustained their gains. Sundstrand gave up most of the original advance under Mr. Stonecipher before recovering, closing Friday at $43.375, down 37.5 cents. And USF&G fell Friday to $9.125, down 25 cents.
"You don't turn insurance companies around overnight," said Myron Picoult, who follows insurance stocks for Oppenheimer & Son. "It could take 10 years. I'm urging investors to steer clear of USF&G."
The Systems and Computer Technology Corporation, which develops computer systems for universities and other institutions, has been on a roller coaster since Mr. Emmi was recruited in 1985. Mr. Emmi's arrival at the company followed a scandal that led to the conviction of Frederick Gross, the previous chief executive, on charges of insider trading and securities violations. One decline took the stock down as low as $1.75 in late 1988; it was at $10.75, down 62.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading Friday.
In addition, as prospectuses always warn, past performance is no guarantee of future profits. Owens-Corning, for example, could easily stumble if it turns out that Mr. Hiner was overly optimistic about the company's ability to take asbestos off its financial agenda for the rest of the decade with the $800 million write-off.
Stephen J. Dobi, who follows the company for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, urges investors to avoid the stock because he thinks it is too risky relative to others in the construction group.
And Owens-Corning will still be burdened by litigation costs. The company told analysts that it had a plan to cut legal costs by two-thirds, from $150 million to $50 million annually, but it has been vague about how such huge savings could be achieved.
What about G.E. itself? The stock of the conglomerate, based in Fairfield, Conn., was at $77.50, down 25 cents on the Big Board on Friday, a far cry from about $14, adjusted for splits, when John F. Welch Jr. became chief executive on April 1, 1981. The annual rate of return including dividends averages out to more than 15 percent.
Still, G.E. shares have underperformed the market since the beginning of this year and trade at about a 30 percent discount to the Standard & Poor's index of 500 major stocks, based on the ratio of price to projected earnings. Many analysts now rate the company as an undervalued buy, especially for long-term investors.
But others, like Howard A. Rubel at C. J. Lawrence, say G.E. is fully valued. Among the stocks Mr. Rubel prefers is Allied-Signal under Mr. Bossidy, Mr. Welch's former top lieutenant. "There's more potential for upside surprises at Allied," Mr. Rubel said.

HEADLINE: Senate Candidates Smile for the Cameras

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
For three candidates for the United States Senate who scheduled news conferences yesterday, it was a picture-perfect day for photo opportunitiies and sound bites.
Two of the three went to locked government office buildings where they sought to dramatize Federal policies they want changed. A third had coffee with John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, and later chatted with reporters outside an instantly recognizable Manhattan landmark, St. Patrick's Cathedral. 
 Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican seeking a third term in Washington, spent a half-hour standing in front of a midtown Manhattan unemployment office that was closed for the day, talking about the need to create jobs, stop "the economic hemorrhaging" and reduce the tax burden on businesses.
 
Posing With Jewish Leaders
 One of his would-be Democratic challengers, Elizabeth Holtzman, held her news conference in the windy courtyard outside a Federal office building in lower Manhattan that was also closed for the weekend. She posed with a group of Jewish leaders and said the Government should open its files on Nazi war criminals.
Another Democrat, the Rev. Al Sharpton, the self-styled civil rights crusader, gave Cardinal O'Connor a letter asking for help with his application to march in the St. Patrick's Day Parade. Two other Democrats, Geraldine A. Ferraro and Representative Bob Mrazek, had no events scheduled in New York City yesterday.
Outside the unemployment office on West 54th Street, Mr. D'Amato reviewed figures released last week that showed that joblessness in New York State climbed to 10.9 percent in February. He noted that New York State had had one-fifth of America's job losses in the last year, even though it has only about 7 percent of the country's population.
He said that a cap on state and Federal spending could lead to a tax reduction within 18 months. And, citing figures he said came from a State Senate Advisory Commission, he said that $5.7 billion could be saved if some Government services were turned over to private investors. He wants the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to sell the region's three major airports and the World Trade Center, because, he said, they would generate tax revenues in private hands.
Mr. D'Amato also blasted one of his favorite targets, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and the state's "bloated bureaucracy," saying state costs are "choking" suburban communities. "We've got a population little more than half of California, but we spend twice as much on Medicaid," he said.
As for the Republicans' presidential prospects, he said the conservative challenge presented by Patrick J. Buchanan was not hurting President Bush or, indirectly, his own campaign.
"The Buchanan campaign has been a blessing in disguise, sending a message to the President that many people who supported him were disappointed with his tax agreement with the Democrats," Mr. D'Amato said.
Miss Holtzman, who wrote the law authorizing the deportation of Nazi war criminals, said that it was time to open files on the Government's involvement with them.
"We know that Nazi war criminals who committed some of the most brutal crimes against humanity were brought to this country by Government officials, were employed by U.S. Government agencies and were sheltered abroad," she said. She said that Argentina had opened its files, and Washington should follow suit.
Inside Cardinal O'Connor's residence behind St. Patrick's, Mr. Sharpton drank two cups of coffee while the Cardinal had tea. Mr. Sharpton said his letter sought a place in the St. Patrick's Day Parade for himself and "a contingent of African-Americans who protest the Bush Administration's exclusion of Joe Doherty and Haitian refugees from the United States."
Mr. Sharpton said he did not believe that the Cardinal controlled the parade, but has influence over those who do.
In the past, Cardinal O'Connor has spoken out for both the Haitians, who were denied asylum after they fled their country for an American military base in Cuba, and Mr. Doherty, a former Irish Republican Army soldier whom the Federal Government deported last month.
"It smacks of a blatant double standard, and smells of racism," Mr. Sharpton said in his letter, "that all Senatorial candidates have been given dignitary status, but myself and the African-Americans who support Doherty, Haitians and gays have not been included."

HEADLINE: Exports Rise For U.S. Tools

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
Exports of American machine tools posted a record year in 1991 despite the global recession, increasing 1.3 percent, to $1.08 billion from the previous high of $1.06 billion in 1990, the Association for Manufacturing Technology has reported. It was the eighth consecutive annual increase.
Machine tool imports, reflecting the depth of the recession in the United States, declined 7.3 percent in 1991, to $2.14 billion, from $2.31 billion in 1990. It was the second consecutive annual decline after a record high in 1989. 
 The leading export market for machine tools from the United States last year was Canada, at $134.6 million, down 26 percent from 1990, followed by Mexico, which increased 14 percent to $124.9 million, and Germany, which advanced 10 percent to $100.2 million.
Japan was No. 4 at $94.4 million, an increase of 13 percent, followed by South Korea, up 14 percent, to $93.2 million; China, up 90 percent, to $70.7 million, and Britain, down 30 percent, to $58.4 million.

HEADLINE: Israelis Say They May Drop Bid for U.S. Loan Support

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 8

 BODY:
Israeli Government leaders have strongly suggested in a series of recent statements that they are ready to abandon their request for United States loan guarantees in the face of American demands that they stop building Jewish settlements in occupied territories.
A growing number of senior officials have actively urged the Government to withdraw its aid request, which involves $10 billion in loan guarantees to help resettle hundreds of thousands of new immigrants from the former Soviet Union. 
 The most recent such advice came from Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, the driving force behind a boom in settlement construction that has taken place over the last two years.
"I would give up on the matter," said Mr. Sharon, who strengthened his political position last week as the governing Likud Party picked its candidates for June parliamentary elections.
"I would announce, 'Thank you very much,' " he told a group of high-school students on Friday, "and make a very big effort to raise these funds from other sources."
 
No Dictating by U.S.
 Other Likud Cabinet ministers have said that if the Bush Administration insists on telling Israel to choose between loan guarantees and settlements, they would tell the Americans to keep their aid. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir sounded a similar note this weekend with a warning that Israel would not allow Washington to tell it what to do, either in this case or in the Middle East peace talks, which ended another inconclusive round in Washington last week.
"I think almost all the political factions in Israel would not accept a situation in which the American Administration would dictate our policy, whether about settlements today or about other territorial issues tomorrow," he told the army radio.
Mr. Shamir's advisers say he still wants the loan guarantees, and believes that a compromise can somehow be worked out despite the unbending insistence of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d that settlement-building must first come to an end. But on a not-for-attribution basis, senior officials acknowledge that they have essentially given up hope for the aid, certainly until after the June 23 elections here.
In a further sign that the Israeli Government was ready to pass up the assistance, its Ambassador to the United States, Zalman Shoval, said in Washington that if there were "tough conditions" in a compromise bill being worked on in Congress, it was possible that "Israel will have to reassess its request."
 
Mistrust of Baker Deepens
 The Israeli Government's mistrust of Mr. Baker seems to have deepened in the last few days. It follows press reports -- denied by Mr. Baker's office -- that he discussed with senators the possibility of cutting Israel's regular economic aid of $1.2 billion a year if it does not freeze settlements, and that he used a vulgar Anglo-Saxon verb in talking about American Jews with Bush campaign advisers.
The obscenity was reported on Friday in a column written for The New York Post by former Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York City. Although the report was dismissed as "garbage" by Mr. Baker's spokeswoman, Margaret Tutwiler, it was carried today in all Israeli newspapers. One of the more sober dailies, Haaretz, splashed the supposed remarks, in English and startlingly uncensored, across the top of page one.
Another newspaper, Maariv, said in an editorial that whether or not the Koch report was accurate, "those who claim that the man cannot serve as an honest broker in the Israeli-Arab conflict will use this as proof."
Israel has sought the guarantees so it can borrow money from private banks at more favorable interest rates than it would normally get. The United States is not being asked to lend the money itself but rather to stand by as a guarantor. In that position, it would probably be required under the law to set aside several hundred million dollars to be used in the event -- an improbable event, officials here say -- of an Israeli default.
Senior officials here accuse Mr. Baker of interfering in their domestic politics, seeking, they charge, to create a climate that would enhance the opposition Labor Party's chances for electoral victory in June. Labor is calling for the settlement freeze that Washington wants.

HEADLINE: From Tiananmen Square to New York Sweatshops;
One Woman's Fight to Better the Lot of Workers Under Communism and Capitalism

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Lu Jinghua moved excitedly among the garment workers sitting awkwardly in undersized chairs at Public School 105 in Brooklyn, passing out leaflets and preaching worker solidarity.
"The union is for the benefit of the workers," Ms. Lu told them in Chinese, as she circled the classroom decorated with alphabet letters and paper snowflakes. "It will fight for benefits for you. Unionize!" 
 The workers, mostly women and recent arrivals from China, listened intently. They had come to the school in Sunset Park, as they do each Sunday morning, to study English -- and along the way to learn about workers' rights -- in classes organized by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
 
Family Left Behind
 What Ms. Lu does not tell them is how she came to work for the union, how as a young garment-shop owner she was drawn inexorably into the protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989, how she became a leader of a labor federation born on the Square, or how she fled after the bloody crackdown, leaving behind her husband and baby daughter.
"I do not tell them my story," Ms. Lu said through a translator later. "It has nothing to do with what they need at this point. If they gain benefits, then their lives will be secure, then there will be hope in their lives."
Ms. Lu believes she is simply carrying on in Brooklyn a struggle that began in Beijing three years ago when she impulsively joined a long march of students that would eventually sweep her into the international labor movement. Instead of fighting the hard-line Communists in China, she fights exploitative owners of sweatshops in New York City. But the cause, she says, remains the same.
"You should know your rights," she told the workers, "and fight for them."
 
A High-Profile Symbol
 In the nearly two years since the garment workers' union hired her, she has not only been a high-profile symbol of the union's efforts to foster international worker solidarity, but has also become an effective rank-and-file organizer.
While reluctant to recount her story to workers, she has been eager to tell it at human rights forums, demonstrations at the United Nations and elsewhere.
"When I first spoke to her, I got chills," said Jay Mazur, the president of the garment workers' union. "She's a real hero. She believes in what she's doing, and she's paid a price for it."
For Ms. Lu, who is 31 years old, that price has been high. Her husband, Li Zhilang, served seven months in prison for harboring her after the crackdown. She has not seen her daughter, who is now 4, since the early morning three years ago when she slipped out of Beijing. She lives in an apartment in Elmhurst, Queens, cut off from her family, except for an occasional telephone call. She fears arrest if she returns home.
Ms. Lu's initiation into the labor movement was as abrupt as it was unlikely. Born and raised in Beijing, she was a garment worker for several years before opening a small garment shop of her own near Tiananmen Square in 1986 -- an enterprise made possible only by the Government's tentative easing of economic rules in the 1980's.
 
Joined a Union
 A month after students began protesting in Tiananmen Square on April 15, 1989, she joined them. Her reasons, she said, were more naive than political. "Everybody felt we should support the students," she said. "I participated hoping the Government would change in terms of the serious social problems."
On May 24, she joined the Workers' Autonomous Federation, an unofficial labor union that issued a constitution in the headiest days on the protests. Ms. Lu became the group's spokeswoman, reading its demands over blaring loudspeakers.
On June 4, it all ended.
In the days after the crackdown, in which many members of the union were killed or arrested, Ms. Lu hid in a friend's apartment. Later, she fled with only a small bag to Hebei Province in the south, where her husband was working, then to Hong Kong and finally to the United States after receiving political asylum.
For a time she worked in a grocery store in Los Angeles. Through her work with human rights organizations, she came to the attention of the garment workers' union, which represents 75,000 workers in New York City, a quarter of them Chinese.
Michelle Briones, director of the union's international relations department, said Ms. Lu has been "a charismatic and symbolic spokeswoman," as well as a committed and energetic organizer.
Ms. Lu, who works in the union's headquarters on Broadway at 54th Street in Manhattan, is compiling a book of interviews and writings from Tiananmen Square. She is also learning English.
 
New Immigrants
 At the school in Sunset Park, she takes the roll and otherwise serves as a union representative to more than 200 workers, union and nonunion. As Chinatown has become overcrowded, thousands of Chinese have moved to Sunset Park, which now has the largest Chinese population in Brooklyn.
Employers have subsequently followed, and a thriving garment industry has sprung up in storefronts, warehouses and, in some cases, sweatshops, where workers must contend with substandard conditions and employers who disregard labor laws, said Dan Yun Feng, who runs the union's school program.
Ms. Lu said the immigrant workers are vulnerable. "Because the Chinese here, especially the immigrants from the villages, have very little education, they do not know how to fight back," she said.
Between their lessons, workers beckon her to their desks and bashfully ask her questions about the union. Some, she said, whispered to her what they would like to see done in their shops. "That's progress," she said, "from just being silent."
Ms. Lu said she was never an ideologue, but in the years since Tiananmen, she has become more committed to the idea of fundamental rights for workers, for all people. She has learned a lot, she said, but considers her work here temporary.
"The only place I can use the skills and knowledge I have learned," she said, "is China."

HEADLINE: A Boom Town's Slumping Fortunes

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILTON KEYNES, England

 BODY:
If any place is a gauge of just how much the recession has knocked the confidence of Britons, it is Milton Keynes. A gleaming city of low-rise, mirror-glass office buildings, warehouses and light-manufacturing factories about 50 miles north of London, it was one of the Thatcher era's boom towns.
As a train pulls into town, visitors are still greeted by a slogan scrawled on a wall declaring, "Tomorrow belongs to us." But with foreign investment slowing, housing prices down by 25 to 35 percent and unemployment at what is here considered to be an astronomical 7.5 percent, uncertainty pervades the city. 
 Large British and foreign companies came here in droves in the 1980's to escape an overcrowded and increasingly expensive London. There are 88 American companies, including Unisys, Motorola, Dana, Cooper Industries and Coca-Cola, and 43 Japanese companies, including Minolta, NEC and Alps Electric.
 
Symbol of Slump
 But what propelled the local economy were the hundreds of so-called Thatcher entrepreneurs who came and started companies. With its abundance of commercial space, cheap rents and eagerness to help new companies get off the ground, many saw Milton Keynes as an ideal base from which to serve large London corporations. Others saw the opportunities created by the local boom.
Since 1980, the borough's population has grown by 56 percent, to 187,400. Everything was so new and successful that the community -- with its huge covered shopping mall, modern houses with thatched-roofs and outdoor sculptures of cows -- became both the butt of humor and the object of envy throughout Britain. Now, the local slump mirrors what has happened throughout the south of England as the boom in real estate, construction, retailing and financial and business services has gone bust.
It used to be that the great majority of people who came to Milton Keynes Business Ventures, an agency that helps entrepreneurs get off the ground, were people with jobs who were looking to strike out on their own. "That has radically changed in the last eight months," said Colin Offor, its chief executive. "Now over 50 percent are unemployed."
Most jobs have been lost because small businesses went under or retrenched. With bad loans piling up, banks became reluctant to lend to small companies, raising fears that many more cash-starved enterprises would join the growing pile of failed businesses.
"Advertising agencies don't have the work, so we don't have the work," said Ian Douse, manager of Harvest Studios, a small company that does commercial photocopying and processing. His sales dropped by about 20 percent in the last 18 months, and he cut his staff to 6 from 15. But he was luckier than most. There were 25 small graphics and computer-services companies in his building; now there are 8. "The Government says the recession is almost over," Mr. Douse said. "I can tell you it's still far from it."
William Burnes's small company, which installs doors, windows and conservatories in houses, still thrives because people are refurbishing their homes instead of trading up. Also, he has a lot fewer competitors. "When we started four years ago, there were 15 or so companies; now there are 3," he said, adding that he was lucky because he had not borrowed heavily.
 
Personal Worries, Office Glut
 Indeed, many residents of this once-confident city are consumed with worries about their jobs and meeting loan payments. "People may have mortgages greater than the value of their houses and that's not just a Milton Keynes phenomenon," said Philippa A. Eccles, chief executive of the Milton Keynes Chamber of Commerce.
About 20 percent of office space in central Milton Keynes is vacant. "That's the highest it's ever been," said Robert Hill, commercial director of the Milton Keynes Development Corporation, a Government-financed agency.
An eternal optimist, Mr. Hill says foreign investment will rebound. He says the main reason it slowed was recessions elsewhere, like the United States, Germany and Sweden and the slowdown in Japan. But some here worry that with the creation of the European Community's single market and the opening up of Eastern Europe, investment will be harder to attract.
"It's difficult to see at the moment what is going to make things turn around," Mrs. Eccles said.

HEADLINE: Thatcher's Miracle: Victim of Its Own Excess

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 8

 BODY:
When the Conservatives led by Margaret Thatcher won a landslide victory five years ago, Britain was booming, and Britons believed that their economy, which had long suffered from anemic growth, high inflation and militant unions, had been transformed.
Now, with Britain slogging through what is by some measures its longest recession since World War II, the so-called Thatcher miracle is looking a lot less miraculous. 
 Last year, Britain's economy suffered its sharpest one-year contraction since the 1930's. Unemployment, on the rise for 22 months, totals more than 2.6 million people, or 9.2 percent of the work force. And economists expect it to rise to nearly 3 million, rivaling the postwar record.
 
No Sign of Recovery
 After more than a year of recession, there are no concrete signs of a revival in business or consumer spending. And slowdowns or recessions in America, Japan and Western Europe mean Britain cannot expect much help from exports, which have been one of the few bright spots.
What happened here has a familiar ring in America. Years of expansion in the 1980's accompanied by lavish bank lending, tax cuts and spirited entrepreneurship eventually caused the economy to overheat. To dampen things down a bit, interest rates climbed as high as 15 percent at one point. Consumer spending plunged and business spending followed.
Some examples of the 1980's excesses are well known, like the collapses of Robert Maxwell's publishing empire and Asil Nadir's conglomerate, Polly Peck International P.L.C. There are also real estate boondoggles like the sprawling Canary Wharf development in East London, where 40 percent of the 4.6 million square feet of office space that has been built or nearly so is not rented.
But Britain's biggest problem is the tens of thousands of people who got in over their heads. College students were bombarded with credit cards. Entrepreneurs found it easy to borrow for new businesses. And home buyers found banks all too willing to lend them as much as 100 percent of their mortgages at floating interest rates that wound up soaring.
"Banks were throwing money at people," said Donald Lee, owner of VIP Type Ltd. in Milton Keynes, a city 50 miles north of London, where entrepreneurs flourished in the prosperous 1980's. "But when times are tough, they tighten up."
Mr. Lee's small company, which prepares material to be printed, had been growing at 30 to 35 percent a year until last April. Then sales plunged. His bank cut his overdraft and reneged on a promised mortgage to replace the temporary financing used to buy his building. Mr. Lee saved his business by selling his invoices at a discount. He now has no cushion. "I'm still on a knife edge," he said.
Later this week, when the Government's annual budget is announced, it is widely expected to contain initiatives, including tax cuts, to pump money into the economy and ease the recession. But Prime Minister John Major, Mrs. Thatcher's successor and protege, is resigned to facing a general election, which must be held by July 9, with the economy still in recession. The Prime Minister is expected this week to announce an election for April 9.
"The latest data," said Patrick J. Foley, chief economist at the Lloyds Bank, "indicate that there probably won't be an improvement in the first half. There may even be a slight deterioration."
Leaders of Labor, the main opposition party, are reminding Britons that the country went through two severe recessions in the 13-year rule of the Tories, as the Conservatives are known. So far, the gross domestic product has fallen 3.7 percent since the third quarter of 1990. But the 1979-81 double-dip recession was worse; a 5.5 percent drop.
 
Recovery's Course: An Important Test
 Beyond this year's election, business leaders, economists and other experts say that how Britain lifts itself from this slump could be pivotal to the nation's economic future. Will this country of 57 million people regain its historic presence among the first tier of industrialized nations or will it slip back into decline?
"We're at a turning point," said Sir Denys Henderson, a leading British industrialist and chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries. After the union problems, high taxes, excessive Government intervention and lack-of-enterprise culture of the 1960's and 1970's, the pendulum swung too far the other way in the go-go Thatcher era, he said.
"One has to hope that that when we get through this period of stringency," Sir Denys added, "we will see the pendulum centering -- that taxes will not rise again to the point they become penal, that people will say, 'Yes, we still want the enterprise culture, we have to keep inflation low because we've got to be competitive in world markets and we will not be quite so ready to overextend ourselves in terms of borrowing.' But at this point, it remains to be seen which way the British economy goes."
 
Surplus in 1980's
 In the 1980's, the Tories greatly reduced Government borrowing and even ran a surplus for a while thanks partly to North Sea oil proceeds and the sale of state-owned companies. But personal and business debt soared.
The Tories boast about the record number of new businesses formed in the 1980's, when there was a net increase of 1.2 million. But they do not like to talk about two records last year: 47,777 companies failed and 75,540 homes were repossessed.
While personal income taxes and business taxes fell, other taxes, including the value-added tax on most goods and services, were increased. As a result, the overall tax burden for families with average or below-average incomes rose in the Tory era.
 
Productivity Gap: Behind the Pack
 Several large British companies, however, are much healthier than a decade ago. Most state-owned companies were closed or hammered into shape and then sold. Similarly, private-sector companies that had suffered from years of overstaffing, inefficient work practices and too little investment were put through the wringer. The result is a collection of world-class companies like British Airways, British Steel, SmithKline Beecham and Wellcome.
But as a whole, British industry remains encumbered by factories with less sophisticated equipment and workers who are less skilled and much less productive than rivals in Continental Europe, America and Japan.
 
Needs Much More
 Edward J. Roberts, chairman of a small maker of springs and clips in England's West Midlands, Britain's industrial heartland whose biggest city is Birmingham, boasts of the equipment his company bought in the last 10 years. But like most British manufacturers, he knows he must buy much more.
Pointing to a wondrous $220,000 machine that is twisting wire into springs, Mr. Roberts said: "Ten years ago, there was not a machine like that in the U.K." He wanted to buy two more, but the recession forced him to cut planned capital expenditures by 80 percent.
Besides being better equipped, German competitors generally have workers with better skills. To be competitive, Mr. Roberts pays his 130 workers a third less than comparable German workers. "Many of us in the West Midlands might survive the recession but not long term unless things start to pick up," he said. "Another year of this could be very dangerous."
Foreign companies, drawn by Britain's free-market attitudes, low wages, widely spoken language and eagerness to have them, plowed some $170 billion into Britain between 1981 and 1991. That investment is helping to revitalize formerly declining industries like autos and to build new ones like electronics.
But with Communism's fall in Eastern Europe, Britain now seems remote from the center of the European market. It must not only worry about vying with the likes of France, Germany and Italy for investment but also with some Eastern European countries with well-educated, low-wage work forces.
 
The Tory Legacy: Measure of Success
 What does all this say about the Tory era? "It's not easy to give a definitive answer," said David Kern, chief economist of the National Westminster Bank.
"If you take inflation, economic growth and productivity growth over the period compared with the previous 20 years," he said, "you can easily give the answer that things have gotten worse. But if you look at the average performance of the U.K. economy relative to that of other countries, the gap between us and the others has narrowed a lot."
From 1980 through 1991, Britain's economy grew at an average annual rate of about 1.7 percent, trailing the 2.6 percent average for the 24 industrialized countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. But in the previous 20 years, the gap was a percentage point greater, with Britain's economy growing at an average annual rate of 2.8 percent versus 4.7 percent for the O.E.C.D. countries. Britain's inflation in the 1969-1979 period averaged 7.9 percent, but eased only slightly in the 1980-91 period to an average of nearly 7.5 percent or 1.7 points higher than the O.E.C.D. average.
British manufacturing productivity grew in the 1980's at an annual average rate of 4.1 percent -- the highest of any leading industrialized country and 1.5 times Britain's average rate in the previous 20 years.
 
A Borrowing Binge
 One reason was that the Government pacified unions by requiring that many key decisions like strikes be made by the rank-and-file instead of merely at the discretion of union leaders. Other steps limited the ability of the unions to disrupt the economy.
Meanwhile, interest rates were low and the Government put more money into people's pockets by cutting the basic tax rate to 25 percent from 33 percent and the top marginal rate to 40 percent from 83 percent. In addition, the Government sold a large portion of public housing to tenants, which not only saddled them with mortgages but also made them feel richer -- and thus willing to borrow more -- when housing prices took off.
Financial institutions then went overboard in lending.
 
Sales, Closings and Layoffs
 "We shared in the optimism about continued growth that characterized that period and there were undoubtedly some departures from sound lending," Lord Alexander, chairman of National Westminster, said recently when he disclosed that his bank had added a record $3.71 billion to reserves to cover bad debts.
Although interest rates have fallen sharply and debt has declined to a more manageable level, business and consumer confidence remains low.
In London, scores of stores on Oxford Street and in other shopping districts are empty or display signs announcing spectacular sales.
Companies are also contending with forces their counterparts in the United States know only too well: deregulation; foreign competition; worldwide cuts in military spending and economic slowdowns or recessions abroad. And some of the handful of remaining state-owned companies are laying off people as they prepare for life in the private sector.
Companies that have announced big job cuts this year include British Telecommunications, British Aerospace, British Steel, state-owned British Coal and some big banks.
 
Plan of Action: Nothing Too Drastic
For now, Mr. Major is reduced to reminding Britons that his Government cannot be blamed for the global slowdown and that the ingredients for a recovery -- lower interest rates and inflation and more manageable levels of business and consumer debt -- are in place. Nor can the Government deeply cut the base or prime interest rate, which is now 10.5 percent, until the Germans cut theirs: the pound is linked to the mark in the European Monetary System.
 
4.1% Inflation Rate
 Private economists say the Government will be reluctant to go overboard with tax cuts and spending increases in the budget. That would damage its hard-won reputation for being serious in the last few years about bringing down inflation, which is now 4.1 percent on a year-on-year basis. It is also unlikely that such largess would have a noticeable impact on the economy before the election.
"I think we're pretty clear what the state of the economy will be in the election," an aide to Mr. Major said glumly.

HEADLINE: Farmers Wary of Efforts to Manage Growth

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Spring has arrived only in the heated greenhouses on New Jersey's vegetable farms, where seedlings are set out to start the season's crop of melons, cucumbers and cabbages. But farmers like Erwin Sheppard are already raising a political crop of objections over New Jersey's efforts to manage growth in the state.
New Jersey's pioneering state land-use plan, which is intended to direct growth to already-developed areas, has won over nearly all of the state's fractious business groups except the farm community. As now written, the plan frowns on any development in farm-designated areas that is not directly related to agriculture. Farmers like Mr. Sheppard say that if they cannot sell to real-estate developers, the price of their land will be depressed. 
Lower land prices mean less equity for the farmer and a harder time borrowing the money to put in a spring crop, the farmers say, although some planners dispute it. The farmers want to keep the right to sell at least a portion of their land to the highest bidder or have the state pay them for the loss.
"The equity issue is the biggest problem with the plan statewide," said George Horzepa, director of the Division of Rural Resources for the state Agriculture Department.
"Equity is the basis for a farmer's borrowing for next season's crop, and it is potentially his retirement. So the farmer's reaction to the plan is sort of like the reaction of a suburban community when they want to put a halfway house in their neighborhood, and everybody starts talking about housing values."
 
Future of Farming Debated
 Mr. Sheppard, who with his father and two brothers operates a 1,100 acre vegetable farm outside of Cedarville, in southern Cumberland County, insists that the future of farming in the Garden State is at stake.
"If we lose our equity in the land the viability of a lot of farm enterprises is going to be in question," he said. "If agriculture is viable and farmers can make money, none of this land will be sold for development anyway. All the farmer wants to do is make a living and pay his bills."
After nearly six years of work, the State Planning Commission may find the speculative value of farm land the biggest remaining stumbling block before it publishes a final state plan this summer.
Before then, at least six meetings will be held around the state to debate the plan, and the State Board of Agriculture, an official advisory panel, expects to stress the issue of farm equity. The state has 8,300 farms.
"What astounds me is that this group of several thousand people have managed to absolutely befuddle the rest of the whole state," said Sam Hamill, a planning consultant who heads the Policy Committee of New Jersey Future, a group formed to support statewide planning.
The state plan, one of the most advanced of several statewide efforts under way around the country, will be nonbinding. But it could, at the Governor's direction, have the force of state controls over roads, sewers and other improvements, without which large projects cannot be built.
 
Winners and Losers
 In addition, county plans and township zoning rules, which govern land use in New Jersey, will be encouraged to conform to the state master plan and to focus growth into designated areas.
Supporters of the state plan reject the farmers' argument: people gain or lose every time government makes land-use decisions, they say, so why should one group be singled out for compensation? Besides, they add, perhaps half of the state's 870,000 acres of agricultural crop land is already owned or optioned by speculators, whose profits the public has no duty to protect.
Even the amount of money the farmers stand to lose over the next two decades from lost sales of land under the plan, put at $350 million in an economic impact study released Friday, is dwarfed by the billions in tax expenditures saved elsewhere by having the state grow in a plannedway, they say.
 
A Little Bit Developed
 "Equity is not an issue in the plan. Equity is an issue for the authorities to decide," John W. Epling, director of the state Planning Commission, said during Friday's commission meeting. "If the legislature and the people make the decision that they want to purchase all of that land so that nobody gets hurt, there are plenty of savings under the plan to cover the cost."
One solution under discussion would have developers who build in growth centers contribute to a fund that would pay farmers not to develop their land.
Mr. Sheppard, a member of the state agriculture board, insists that more is at stake than speculators' profits.
"They have not allowed any development that isn't pertinent to agriculture," he said. "Does 'non-pertinent' mean that my son who doesn't work on the farm cannot build a house on the farm? That is really restrictive."
Mr. Sheppard wants a compromise that would still allow farmers to develop a corner of their land, using the most current design rules for clustering houses in compact, land-saving patterns.
But while no state plan would object to a child's building on the family farmland, to allow each farmer to put a townhouse development on his land would produce the same kind of scattered development the plan was born to combat.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "If we lose our equity in the land the viability of a lot of farm enterprises is going to be in question," said Erwin Sheppard, a farmer outside Cedarville, N.J., about a state land-use plan that farmers say would cause land prices to drop, reducing farmers' equity and making it more difficult for them to borrow. (Art Wilkinson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Geer, DuBois Hires a Chief In Time for Jaguar's Review

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
GEER, DuBOIS INC. has hired a president and chief executive, and not a moment too soon. The agency's second-largest client, Jaguar Cars Inc., has announced a review of its account.
Joining Geer, DuBois is Stephen G. Bowen Jr., who had been president of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. until April of last year, when the agency said he had resigned "because his career objectives are not in accord with the current opportunities here." Translation: his departure followed a political tussle. 
 For Mr. Bowen, 48 years old, time to settle in will be as much of a luxury as -- well, a Jaguar. He must immediately deal with the review on the British luxury car maker's American account, which has been at Geer, DuBois since June 1986.
"What we will do is give Jaguar the best work they've ever seen in the remainder of the 1992 model year," said Mr. Bowen, echoing the slogan the New York agency has created for Jaguar advertising: "The best Jaguars ever built." Geer, DuBois has accepted an invitation to participate in the review, he added.
Jaguar's announcement on Friday was no shock. The company's American sales slide, in the wake of the recession and the onslaught of Japanese luxury-car competition, made a review likely. So, too, did a skein of imported car companies that had reviews since last year; Jaguar becomes the fourth, after American Isuzu Motors, Mercedes-Benz of North America and Subaru of America -- all of which changed agencies.
"We may be the first incumbent in all these pitches to win," said Rodney Underwood, Geer, DuBois's chairman and creative director.
An even more compelling reason for the review is the 1989 purchase of Jaguar Ltd. in Coventry, England, by the Ford Motor Company. Advertising executives have long expected that Ford would nudge Jaguar's American operation into a review that would include Ford's four global agencies: Ogilvy & Mather, Wells Rich Greene BDDP Inc., Young & Rubicam Inc. and Thompson, where Mr. Bowen worked from 1969 until last year.
"I'll have to give them a call," Mr. Bowen said of his former Thompson colleagues.
Neither John Crawford, a spokesman for Jaguar in Mahwah, N.J., nor Neal Gilliatt, a New York advertising consultant hired by Jaguar to advise on the review, would discuss which shops other than Geer, DuBois might participate.
Nor would they discuss the account's billings. According to the Leading National Advertisers tracking service, Jaguar spent $17.1 million on advertising during the first 11 months of 1991, compared with $22.6 million during the corresponding period of 1990. Geer, DuBois's billings are estimated at $120 million.
The only Geer, DuBois client larger than Jaguar is the Paddington Corporation, which imports brands like Bailey's Original Irish Cream liqueur and Cinzano. The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation was the largest client until it withdrew its $30 million account over a computer error that resulted in overcharges.
That loss, and the departure of the agency's president and chief executive, John Hayes, have cast a pall over Geer, DuBois, overshadowing recent gains of additional billings from current clients, like Paddington, and new accounts like the Northrop Corporation and the New York Zoological Society.
"That's the agency business," Mr. Underwood said philosophically.
He added that choosing Mr. Bowen from a long list of candidates to succeed Mr. Hayes, who left unexpectedly last month to become president of Lowe & Partners, stemmed from a belief that Mr. Bowen "is someone who could bring big-agency marketing thoughts to a boutique agency that's creatively driven."
Mr. Bowen becomes a partner in Geer, DuBois, joining Mr. Underwood and Peter Geer, chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Underwood dismissed a report in a trade newsletter that Mr. Bowen would buy the agency, which has recently received inquiries from shops like Bloom FCA about being acquired.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Analysts Still See Room For Fed to Ease Further

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Some credit market analysts maintain that the Federal Reserve Board needs to lower short-term interest rates further, even though recent economic statistics point to a revival in business activity.
That view is not popular with most market participants, who have pushed up short-term and long-term rates sharply over the last two months. Indeed, at current levels, short-term rates suggest that traders expect that the next move by the Fed will be to tighten monetary policy. 
 In large part, analysts' expectations about additional Fed easing are based on the belief that the rise in interest rates since mid-January is probably sapping strength from the modest recovery that seems to have been building since the start of the year.
"The pickup in activity we experienced over the past two months was triggered by the declines in rates we saw in December and early January," said Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers. "But with rates backing up significantly, that will be enough to slow the recovery down considerably, and perhaps get the Fed back into an easing mode."
 
Yields Flirt With 8%
 Despite continued news of low inflation, traders have responded to the modest rebound in consumer demand and signs of a recovery in manufacturing by driving up yields on two-year Treasury notes by more than 80 basis points since December. Bond yields, which fell to as low as 7.40 percent in January, continue to flirt with 8 percent.
As of Friday, the interest rate differential between three-month Treasury bills and 30-year bonds stood at 3.80 percentage points, up from 3.53 percentage points at the end of 1991 and more than double the 1.82-point average differential that prevailed from 1985 through 1991.
"The economy was so depressed at the end of last year that some sort of bounce was inevitable," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence Inc. "But the bond market is so paranoid about a recovery that they are not willing to look at things objectively."
 
No Confidence From Jobs Data
 Debt traders did seem to interpret the February rise in non-farm payroll employment as a further sign of economic weakness.
They pointed out that virtually all the 164,000 new non-farm jobs came in the retailing and automotive industries, two businesses that are severely depressed. Moreover, when combined with the revised 149,000 drop in payroll figures during January, the figures show that a mere 7,500 net new jobs were generated in each of the last two months. And the rise in the unemployment rate, to its highest level since July 1985, was seen as little help in bolstering consumer confidence.
"It's way too much to interpret the employment report as a harbinger of strong employment growth ahead," said William Melton, a vice president and chief economist at IDS Financial Services Inc. in Minneapolis.
"It does seem that some industries, notably lumber and chemicals, have bottomed out and are beginning to show some increases," he continued. "But there are 20 different industry components in manufacturing, and those are just 2. That doesn't look very broad-based to me."
Nevertheless, the reported gains in employment and hours worked last month almost certainly mean that personal income and industrial production also rose during February. And most Wall Street economists are expecting that February retail sales figures, due out on Thursday, will show another healthy increase after the rise of six-tenths of 1 percent recorded in January.
Analysts said the expected strength in retail sales is likely to be skewed because this year February had five Saturdays, the busiest shopping day of the week.
"Any rebound in retail sales will be slower than what the January and February numbers are showing," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation.
 
Fed May Have Time to Wait
 With the exception of Mr. Yardeni, who says that within a month the Fed will need to cut its discount rate by a full point from the current level of 3.5 percent, analysts agree that the brighter economic numbers have given the Fed more time to ponder its next move.
"It remains far more likely that the Fed will ease again this year than it will tighten," Marc W. Wanshel, an economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, wrote in a weekly letter to clients.
"There is still considerable risk that the February gains will prove short-lived and that the economy will sputter after a month or two," he said. "And even if the economy has entered a firm upward course, it would be difficult for Fed officials to justify moving up short-term rates any time soon, given the virtual lack of growth in the economy over the past three years."
