HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New Reuters Rates Upset British Clients

BYLINE: By SUZANNE CASSIDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 8

 BODY:
The Reuters news agency has angered some of its most important British clients by sharply increasing the rates it charges some publications at a time when they are struggling to get through a severe recession.
Faced with rates that have more than doubled, The Daily Telegraph, the largest of the broadsheet British dailies, has dropped the Reuters World Report, which carries mostly foreign news. Instead, it will rely on Agence France-Presse and The Associated Press. 
 And The Economist magazine, whose rates more than quadrupled, may drop the Reuters World Report. It is subscribing to Agence France-Presse on a trial basis.
 
Telegraph's Complaint
 Nigel Wade, foreign editor for The Daily Telegraph, said his newspaper and The Sunday Telegraph had dropped Reuters solely for economic reasons.
Calling Reuters "a superb news agency," Mr. Wade said: "This is not about quality at all. It's about price. It's about pricing one's self out of the market, basically."
Susannah Amoore, managing editor of The Economist, called the rate increase "unpalatable, especially at a time when we're trying to cut budgets."
The new rates for Reuters are based on a publication's circulation and marketplace. They were instituted to bring Britain in line with Reuters's pricing practices in the United States, where subscribers' rates have always been based on circulation.
 
Old Pricing System
 Barry Simpson, the Reuters news products manager for Britain and Ireland, noted that before Reuters Holdings P.L.C. went public in 1984, one of its principal shareholders, the Newspaper Publishers Association, paid Reuters on behalf of its member papers. It then charged those papers uniform rates, regardless of circulation and the amount of Reuters coverage they actually used.
In 1986, Reuters began dealing directly with the individual newspapers, but the old pricing system remained intact until this year.
Mr. Simpson called the old system illogical. He said it was "ridiculous" for a tabloid that carries little foreign news to pay the same rate as The Telegraph.
Under the new rate structure, implemented earlier this year, "quality" broadsheet dailies like The Telegraph and The Times of London are required to pay a monthly rate of 20, or nearly $35, per 1,000 circulation; mid-market dailies like The Daily Express and The Daily Mail pay 5, and popular tabloids like The Daily Mirror and The Sun pay 2. Weeklies like The Sunday Telegraph and The Economist pay a quarter of the daily rate in whatever category they are in.
As such, Mr. Simpson said, the Telegraph newspapers would have paid 17,500, or about $30,000, a month; previously, they were paying about 8,000. The Economist, which had been paying a monthly rate of less than 500, is now paying more than 2,000.
 
Savings for Some Papers
 Some newspapers like The Evening Standard of London and the tabloid Today, however, are paying less. For example, The Evening Standard's rate dropped to 2,455 a month from 3,720.
Still, several papers that agreed to pay higher rates have their own complaints. At The Sunday Times, for example, Roger Eglin, the managing editor, said he understood the rationale behind the new rates, but was "not terribly enthusiastic" about the higher bill.
"In this sort of recession and with all the pressures to cut costs, any increase causes you some distress," he said.

HEADLINE: Control Data To Sell Unit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 8

 BODY:
The Control Data Corporation will sell its money-losing lottery systems business to Video Lottery Technologies Inc. Terms were not dislcosed when the agreement was announced last week.
Control Data's automated wagering division supplies computers to state-authorized lottery games in eight states. 
 Last year, the unit generated $114 million in revenues, down from $126 million the previous year. The drop was attributed to recessionary pressures on the sale of lottery tickets. Last year the division provided about 8 percent of the company's $1.5 billion in revenues.
The buyer, Video Lottery, based in Bozeman, Mont., had 1991 revenues of $31 million. Its primary business is the sale and management of video gaming terminals -- touch screen video games for blackjack, poker and keno that are placed primarily in taverns in the 27 states that permit them.

HEADLINE: Finding Hemingway's 'Lost' Articles

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 8

 BODY:
He covered economic summit conferences, jailbreaks, the sacrifices of a single mother for her three small children, the death of oak trees in High Park, the decline of Jack Dempsey.
In three years at The Toronto Star his byline was Ernest M. Hemingway, although not all the hundreds of articles that he wrote for Canada's biggest-circulation newspaper carried his signature, or even were published. 
 He left The Star's payroll on Dec. 31, 1923, staying just long enough to collect his Christmas bonus. He then sailed from New York to Paris to work on "The Sun Also Rises." He was 24 years old.
To mark its 100th birthday this year, The Star, after dogged research in its archives and elsewhere, published a special section on March 1 of "lost" articles by its most famous employee, dispatches that have not appeared in any Hemingway collections.
James D. Brasch, associate professor of American literature at McMaster University, said the material "makes us all richer" and means that scholars will have to rewrite the biographical material of the writer's Toronto period. It also means, he said, that the Charles Scribner's Sons "Dateline, Toronto: The Complete Hemingway Toronto Star Dispatches 1920-24" will have to be re-edited.
Hemingway turned up at The Toronto Star in 1920 after a brief stint at The Kansas City Star. He had served in the Ambulance Corps in Italy during World War I and had been wounded.
 
'Loose-Jointed Youth'
 Greg Clark, one of the first Star journalists to meet him and who later helped Hemingway land the reporting job, described him as "a large, rather heavy, loose-jointed youth, with a flushed face, dark loose hair and a big red mouth."
"He perspired easily along under his hair on the forehead and under his lower lip. He appeared to be shy, anxious and restless."
The reason Hemingway came to Toronto, his closest friend on The Star, Morley Callaghan, a Canadian novelist, recounted in his memoir "That Summer in Paris," was because Hemingway's wife, the former Hadley Richardson, was having a baby, "and he had heard that Toronto doctors were very good."
Hemingway called his days on The Star a "stern apprenticeship." Although he later became famous for bulls, boxing and booze, he shows up in the newly discovered articles as a sensitive feature writer, an environmental reporter and even a Santa Claus Fund columnist. Star reporters had to take turns composing the Santa Claus appeals. Hemingway's effort was about a woman whose husband had abandoned her with three small children and who earned $6 a week as a domestic.
"She had worked until she had become a shadow," he wrote. "Her big eyes in sunken lids seemed to hold flame as they glowed from the pallid transparency of her thin face. Her lips were colorless. There was not a spare ounce of flesh on her nor a spare gill of blood in her veins. Her bones showed as knobs and hollows in her gaunt cheeks."
 
A Concern for Trees
 Writing on the environment 70 years ago, he focused on the impact that automobiles, even then, were having on the "sullen and rigid" oaks of High Park and Queen's Park: "Stripped of their leaves by the wind, they stand stiff and despairing looking against the sky. For the oaks are dying." He had found an expert, Dr. C. D. Howe, dean of forestry at the University of Toronto, to explain that the dust constantly stirred up by cars settled on the oak leaves and formed a film that stopped the pores' breathing.
"The trees suffocate," Hemingway's professor said. "They must have air to breathe just as an animal must."
He returned to Italy for the paper to cover the Genoa economic summit conference in April 1922 and wrote that he found the city "scrubbed cleaner than it ever was before or ever will be again." The Genoa meeting was crowded with journalists "all speaking different languages, and all pounding ridiculously small typewriters with a look of concentration on their faces, or else writing in illegible longhand."
While in Europe he interviewed the French wartime leader Georges Clemenceau, but the long account, including compelling description of Clemenceau and his home on the French Atlantic coast, was rejected by The Star's managing editor, John Bone. In the interview, Clemenceau had accused Canada of rejecting compulsory military service and refusing to help France during the war. Neither statement was accurate.
The Star reproduced a letter from Bone to Hemingway explaining the rejection: "As his reference to Canada constitutes the most interesting part of the interview, I don't think we should use it at all although I hate to pass up your excellent color to be found throughout the article."
 
'Looking the Tiger'
 Hemingway introduces Clemenceau: "A bulky man, thickened by age, wearing a brown tweed suit, a funny flat cap, his face as brown as an Ojibway, his white mustache drooping, his white eyebrows bushy, looking the tiger his pictures show him, his eyes twinkling as he talked to his plump daughter-in-law, he came plodding through the sand."
Later in the piece he describes Clemenceau's face as "remarkably like a Chinaman's. If the mustache, instead of being large and drooping, was cut in a narrow line, he would look exactly like a Mandarin."
The pugilist in Hemingway comes out in an article that deflates Jack Dempsey, then heavyweight champion of the world, and anticipates some of the attitude and mood of "Death in the Afternoon," about the decline of a great matador.
"Jack Dempsey is not the man today that he was in Toledo," he wrote. "Two years of championship life coupled with whatever effects there might be from his wild years as a bum and tramp fighter have made a change in him. The public are rarely told these things."
The article provided background on an approaching fight with Georges Carpentier of France. Although Hemingway predicted Carpentier would take Dempsey, Dempsey actually knocked Carpentier out in the fourth.
 
Written His Heart Out
 Hemingway's most embarrassing moments on the paper were when he was unceremoniously yanked off the coverage of British Prime Minister Lloyd George's visit to the United States in October 1923. He had written his heart out on the tour, 6,200 words in two days, but ignored an event that editors later thought was newsworthy. That was a welcoming speech by New York City's acting mayor that had been seen by other journalists as insulting to Lloyd George.
"He was in disgrace," wrote William McGeary, a Star editor, who chronicled Hemingway's career at the paper and who found much of the new material. Hemingway resigned a few weeks later.

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
The Beauty of the Flat Tax

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

 BODY:
Jerry Brown's upset victory in the Colorado primary has forced his opponents to pay attention to his campaign proposals, even those that sound oddball. Take the tax plan he extols in every debate: Scrap all Federal taxes and replace them with a 13 percent "flat tax" on each taxpayer's personal and corporate income. Mr. Brown is able to set such a low rate because he would eliminate nearly every deduction and exemption. Families would be allowed to deduct only mortgage interest, rent and charitable contributions.
Mr. Brown says his plan would cure nearly every national ailment. Because Congress would be taken out of the business of dishing out tax breaks, the political choke hold wielded by most powerful special interests would be broken. And because the marginal tax rates would be low, investment should spurt -- bringing rapid rises in productivity and wages. 
 O.K. Mr. Brown exaggerates. But by less than seems obvious. While Mr. Bush and Congress are mired in petty debate over small-bore tax cuts, Mr. Brown is onto something wonderful.
To see why, first note that the existing tax code is riddled with wasteful contradictions. Everyone agrees, for example, that the U.S. desperately needs higher rates of saving and investment. Yet the existing code singles out investment income for double taxation: first at the corporate level, then again at the individual level when profit is distributed to shareholders as dividends. Congress builds in progressive tax rates so the rich will pay more than the poor. Then it builds layers of complexity and loopholes so that the progressive rates are effectively undone.
Enter Mr. Brown. Actually, enter Robert Hall, an ingenious economist at Stanford University who co-authored a dazzling tax plan that forms the basis of Mr. Brown's flat tax. Mr. Hall's plan shows how to build a code that taxes every dollar of income only once, subsidizes saving, favors the poor and is simple, simple, simple. Mr. Brown had the vision to seize a smart idea.
Under the Hall plan, individuals would pay tax on all labor income -- wages, salaries and pension distributions. Corporations would pay tax on all capital income -- interest and dividends -- paid to creditors and shareholders and all fringe benefits provided to workers. Thus every dollar of income would be taxed once and only once. One more wrinkle: Corporations would be allowed to deduct the full cost of investment in the first year.
What's the beauty of the plan? For starters, Mr. Hall's (and Mr. Brown's) plan would cleverly exempt saving. How so? To economists saving and investment are mirror images of the same activity; investment funds come from savings. By fully deducting investment, Mr. Hall and Mr. Brown thereby exempt savings. Mr. Brown rightfully boasts that investment should spurt, pulling wages up with it.
But tax codes that exempt savings are notoriously unfair to the poor, who typically save only a small percentage of their income. To make sure the poor come out ahead, all Mr. Brown would need to do is build generous tax credits and exemptions into the personal income tax. He'd no longer have a perfectly flat tax, but it would nonetheless work beautifully.
Look further. By exempting investment, corporations would no longer need to calculate allowances for wear and tear -- depreciation. Gone would be a zillion pages of tax complexities. Also gone would be the need for individuals to pay tax on capital gains -- which would be indirectly captured by the corporate levy. Throw out another zillion pages of tax code.
Indeed, under Mr. Hall's plan, tax forms would be no bigger than a postcard. Simply brilliant.
There are problems with the Hall plan, especially in figuring out how to make the transition from the current code to the new code. But the problems are solvable, leaving America with a code that would be simple, fair and -- the President would be wise to listen -- pro-growth.
The Hall plan does, alas, embrace one flaw, almost certainly fatal. If passed, it would create a small but devastating form of unemployment: among the 56 members of the House and Senate tax-writing committees. Hall-Brown is dead even before arrival.

HEADLINE: Space Bargains From Russia

 BODY:
How shortsighted can the United States get? The Soviet space program, once the best in the world and long a feared competitor, has put most of its products and many personnel up for sale. The offer comes when the West is seeking ways to prop up the disintegrating Russian economy and keep Russian scientists from selling their services to renegade nations.
So what's the response of timorous Federal officials? They are hanging back, worried that any purchases of Russian space hardware or expertise might keep alive the Russian defense industry. Their ingrained reluctance persists even though the cold war is over and the chief threat in the former Soviet empire is disintegration, not military revival. 
 The Russian space program, though weak in electronics, leads in some technologies. It has the world's most powerful rocket, with an especially advanced first stage; the world's only operating space station; the world's only compact nuclear reactor for generating power in space; exquisite tiny plasma thrusters that are used to change the orbits of satellites, and other advanced hardware of potential value to spacefaring nations. All that is backed by some of the most experienced and talented space scientists in the world.
Russian officials have been trying to peddle hardware and expertise for months. They have attracted interest from some defense officials and industrial companies. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is also studying the feasibility of using the Soyuz spacecraft as a crew-rescue vehicle for its own space station and will examine, though not necessarily use, an automatic rendezvous and docking system that even NASA acknowledges is "elegant engineering."
But so far no significant deals have been consummated. As was disclosed in a recent article by William J. Broad of The New York Times, key officials have blocked any purchases by refusing import licenses. Some officials express concern that many space technologies, like rockets, have potential military uses; they seek to force the Soviet military-industrial complex into a decline so steep that it will pose no future threat.
Others want to protect the U.S. aerospace industry from competition at a time of recession and cutbacks. And some experts say NASA is reluctant to purchase any hardware or services that might reduce the need for its own programs.
The impasse is heightened by the Administration's failure to set forth a comprehensive strategy for dealing with the evolution of the former Soviet Union. As a result, Washington now risks missing a chance to buy technologies that could save the United States billions in development costs while saving the Russian economy and scientific establishment from disintegration.
Surely Russia's Energia rocket could carry America's space station aloft in far fewer flights than the space shuttle, and at far less cost. And perhaps other cheap, reliable Russian rockets could loft American payloads instead of the finicky shuttle. Russian space experts might well conduct assessments of American space projects, as they do already for Europeans.
The opportunities are not unlimited. Some Russian hardware is primitive, and there are always difficulties in blending one nation's technologies with another's. But this is a time for boldness. Just as the American space program profited mightily from the contributions of German scientists after World War II, so might it benefit from Russian contributions at the end of the cold war.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Whine, Women, Tsong

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
Let us now phase out famous myths.
Myth 1. President Bush's popularity will rebound as economic growth resumes this summer. 
 A whining question permeates the Bush campaign: Why are people unfairly blaming him for hard times that statistics show are not really here?
The Federal Reserve "hit the gong," as central bankers say, last Dec. 20, at the culmination of a quarter in which interest rates were lowered dramatically and other stimulants were administered. The economic consensus is that real economic growth will resume six months afterward, and that come Fiscal New Year's Eve -- June 30 -- the economy will be merrily popping its cork again.
But economics ain't beanbag. As we come out of recession or stagnation, the last statistic to show good news is the unemployment rate.
Perking-up sales with lean payrolls mean productivity and profits, which will help the stock market, but the President's performance will be judged on the lagging unemployment figures. A summer turnaround, even if it develops, may be too late to do much for the jobless figures or for Presidential popularity.
Myth 2. Governor Clinton's campaign has overcome the worst of the bimbonic plague.
The word is around that at least one young woman has been stripping for political action to illustrate her magazine memoirs. Punchy Clinton supporters are hoping it is only a past Miss Arkansas, which would at least show gubernatorial state loyalty.
The brighter side: The number of voters lost to Clinton on this characterless issue will probably remain the same. They demand marital fidelity, period, and it matters not to them if a candidate slipped once or a dozen times. However, the unforgiving judges can only walk out on him once.
As night follows day, any new life given the peccadillo brigade will encourage it to go for even more prestigious game. At a full-scale Presidential news conference (and whatever happened to them?) some reporter -- ostensibly in the interests of fairness -- will ask the dread have-you-ever question of the President of the United States.
If he denies it -- thereby condoning the asking -- the great hunt for even a hint of refutation will begin. But if Mr. Bush coldly denounces the fishing inquisition as unworthy of a place in politics, he will be doing what is right but will help level the playing field for Governor Clinton.
Myth 3. The health issue has been laid to rest by the candor of former Senator Tsongas and his doctor.
The most knowledgeable and responsible medical journalist in our business, Dr. Lawrence Altman of The New York Times, was given access to both the candidate and his personal physician. He wrote a straight news story that, despite its upbeat headline, had to be troubling to any serious voter.
I read it closely and reached two conclusions: first, that Mr. Tsongas has greater inner strength than most of us realized, making his political comeback after his cancer went into remission all the more admirable. His emergence from the shadow of death to the spotlight of national prominence is nothing short of inspirational.
Second, several leading cancer specialists expert in the lymphoma that nearly killed Mr. Tsongas do not share the hopefulness of his doctor's prognosis. As I read the story that bears careful study and follow-up, this candidate may be in greater danger of not surviving his term than the younger Mr. Clinton or even the older Mr. Bush.
If Mr. Tsongas becomes the Democratic nominee, his complete medical record should be subject to inspection by doctors who could then make their independent judgments public. We need to learn more about his claustrophobia, too, the existence of which he freely asserted in his interview with Dr. Altman. (Perhaps a fear of confined spaces would be good in a President.)
With unemployment remaining high for Mr. Bush; with Mr. Clinton under continued sexual harassment; and with Mr.Tsongas's health to be more closely examined -- does this mean a fault-free last-minute entrant will scoop the pools?
I think not. Let's pin on our "Nobody's Perfect" buttons, recognize a choice of three pretty good candidates and stop sniveling. This is shaping up into the best campaign in 12 years.

HEADLINE: Did Cancer Battle Shape Tsongas's Character?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Candidate's Cancer" (editorial, Feb. 23) attempts to defuse Paul Tsongas's medical history as a political issue, but it doesn't go far enough. In the view of this undecided Democrat, Mr. Tsongas's battle with cancer does more than simply not disqualify him from the Presidential race; it actually distinguishes him as a candidate worth a closer look.
Paul Tsongas was forced in his 40's to confront his own mortality, to find courage and the will to fight in the face of understandable terror. Surely, if he is a thoughtful man, he has emerged from those experiences with some of the insights and sense of priorities that make a wise leader. 
 Having relied on state-of-the-art health care for his recovery, might he be more sensitive to the unmet needs of millions of Americans for adequate insurance? Because he owes his life to a bone-marrow transplant, a treatment considered highly experimental until quite recently, is he more willing to finance biomedical research and scientific education generously?
Having leaned heavily on his own loved ones in a time of great need, will he be more of an advocate for social and economic policies to help sustain the family? Dare we hope that his hard-won appreciation for the value of human life might even make him less willing to march a generation of young people to war?
While no one would deliberately choose illness as a tool for developing new perspectives, the value of Paul Tsongas's medical experience should not be underestimated. A life-threatening disorder can be an extraordinary teacher.
 
KARYN L. FEIDEN
New York, Feb. 24, 1992

HEADLINE: The Other Hamptons: Jobs and Food Lag

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAG HARBOR, L.I., March 3

 BODY:
At the First Presbyterian Church, a squat white frame structure built by prosperous whalers in the 1840's, hungry people began lining up along a dark staircase even before a volunteer unlocked the door to a small room where the emergency food was stored. The shelves were almost bare.
Thomas Haskins was one of the first on line. Thirty-five years ago in South Carolina, he boarded a bus of migrant farm workers to pick potatoes on Long Island, and stayed. Now he earns $7.50 an hour at a riding stable, in season, and goes hungry in the winter as he struggles to survive on an unemployment check of $166 every two weeks. 
 "I got to work, a guy like me got to work," he said, as he selected some groceries, a package of spaghetti, some sauce, tuna fish and a bulk wrapped pound of butter. "But there ain't no work in the winter time. If I could get a job I would be working around the clock."
It is the far side of an unusually harsh winter in the Hamptons, a time when the summer people have shuttered their houses, the motels are closed and restaurants have posted signs saying "reopening in April," a time when hundreds of people living on the cusp of poverty struggle to survive until business picks up in the spring and the hiring starts again.
While the Hamptons evoke images of luxury and grandeur, side by side with the fancy summer cottages and estates of the well-to-do are the homes of the less fashionable and the less visible -- the gardeners, fishermen, field hands, construction workers, painters, house cleaners and waiters, who struggle to get by despite the exorbitantly high costs of living in a resort community.
 
A Shorter, Sadder Season
 This winter, volunteers at churches and emergency food pantries from Westhampton Beach to Montauk say that the demand for emergency food is soaring -- doubling in many cases -- and they are struggling to keep up.
"All the places you think of as the glitzy Hamptons are bearing a tremendous load of trying to feed the hungry," said Martyde DiPierro, a former supervisor of the town of East Hampton, who is raising money for the food pantry in the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Quogue.
"The only good news is that people are very generous and are trying very hard," she said, "but no matter how many times they stock the shelves they are empty."
Despite its image of affluence and leisure in the summer, when the population of about 16,000 rises four-fold, East Hampton town, which includes Sag Harbor, has one of the highest poverty rates on Long Island. In the 1980 census, one of 10 residents was living below the poverty level. The 1990 figures are not yet available.
In this winter of recession, many seasonal workers were laid off earlier than usual, social workers say, adding to the distress. Now the workers worry that they will not get their jobs back at all when the warm weather arrives.
On the coldest days of winter this year, social workers say that they found three people living in their battered old cars in Montauk, at the farthest reaches of Long Island, without money, but unwilling to leave town. Others face hunger, social workers say, because of the crushing cost of rental housing, or because of delays in the processing of applications for welfare in a county where the welfare case load has risen by 35 percent in the last two years.
 
The Food-Bank Circuit
 Mr. Haskins, for instance, pays $400 a month rent for a box-like house on the Bridgehampton-Sag Harbor Turnpike, across from luxury homes built on what used to be a potato farm. The walls are as thin as paper, and he has to pay more than $600 each winter to refill the gas cylinders that run the gas heater, Mr. Haskins said.
When he is out of money, he said, he goes back to the riding stable, where he can get some gas for his car, and do some odd jobs for a few dollars to tide him over.
"People think everyone here uses money for toilet paper," he said.
Edna Steck, director of human services for the town of East Hampton, said that three new food banks have opened in the town in the last year.
"We are finding that people are going from one to another; they seem to be running out of food more often," she said.
 
The Work Dried Up
 In Sag Harbor, in the white frame church built to evoke the grandeur of an Egyptian temple, Susan Gonzalez, scrutinized the dates on jars of baby food before putting some of them in a brown paper grocery bag.
Outside, her husband, Frank, waited in a battered sedan, while their 9-month-old daughter, Hannah, slept, strapped into her car seat. Mrs. Gonzalez's two other daughters from her first marriage, Jennifer, 12, and Emily, 6, were at school.
Mrs. Gonzalez grew up in and around Sag Harbor, where her father worked for years at the local supermarket. She cleaned houses three days a week, but was laid off when she was pregnant.
Her husband, an immigrant from Costa Rica, earned $11 an hour working as a landscaper and house painter. The work dried up in November. Later he learned that some of his coworkers had agreed to work for lower wages to keep their jobs.
Now, the Gonzalezes struggle through the winter on welfare, donated food and the money they raise driving up and down the back roads of the Hamptons, collecting cans for the 5-cent deposit. "We had to cash in some cans at the A.&P. to get money to buy some soap so I could take a shower," Mrs. Gonzalez said. "We have no money. Sometimes I don't want to get up in the mornings."
 
Waiting for Spring
 What makes their predicament particularly acute is the starkly modern weathered wood house they rented in a wooded neighborhood outside of Sag Harbor last October, just before Mr. Gonzalez lost his job. They receive $891 a month in welfare benefits -- because of its high housing costs Suffolk County has the highest housing allowance in the state -- but pay $800 a month in rent.
First they lost their cable television connection and then their telephone and now they worry about the $793 bill they owe for electric heat. In a sprawling yard outside, scavenged plywood boards and tree branches are stacked to be burned in a cast iron stove for heat. At first the Gonzalezes used a chain saw to cut the wood. When the chain saw broke, they used an axe. Then the axe handle came off. Now they use a saw.
"My daughter came home with a list of books to buy from the book club, and I couldn't buy her even one book for 95 cents," she said.
The Gonzalezes are not alone. At the old whaler's church in Sag Harbor, 400 Thanksgiving dinners were provided last year compared to 75 two years earlier. The minister, the Rev. Christine B. Rannie Grimbol, said the emergency food pantry, operated by volunteers from churches throughout Sag Harbor, is giving out two to four times as much food as it did last year.
Despite the hardships of living in a place with no industry and a seasonal economy, many of the poor of East Hampton say they are better off staying where they are.
Shelton Thompson, who arrived at the Sag Harbor food pantry wearing a faded tuxedo shirt and a worn bow tie and carrying a cane with a brass duck handle, said it was far easier to be poor with dignity here than in New York City.
An unemployed chef with years of experience at restaurants that have long since closed, Mr. Thompson, his wife and daughter got by last year on welfare, food donations and some free-lance catering jobs in the summer.
"You work all summer for the winter, then you survive all winter for the summer," he said. "Everybody is very beautiful and very nice, thank you, because without God's grace and food pantries we would starve to death."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 10, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about poverty on the East End of Long Island referred incorrectly to a fund raiser for a food bank and misidentified her former position. She is Mardythe DiPirro, the former supervisor of Southampton, not East Hampton.

HEADLINE: Nixon Scoffs at Level of Support For Russian Democracy by Bush

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Former President Richard M. Nixon has sharply criticized President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for what he calls the Administration's pathetic support of the democratic revolution in Russia. He says one of the historic opportunities of this century is being missed.
In a memorandum circulated among friends and foreign affairs experts, Mr. Nixon faults Mr. Bush and other candidates for virtually ignoring the issue in the Presidential campaign. 
 Mr. Nixon argues passionately that if President Boris N. Yeltsin fails in his effort to transform Russia into a free-market democracy, everything that has been gained in the peaceful revolution there in 1991 will be lost. He says that would weaken democratic forces and embolden dictators from China to Eastern Europe and from the Middle East to Korea.
 
'As If a Penny-Ante Game'
 Despite having so much at stake, Mr. Nixon says, the Bush Administration's support for Russia in some areas is comparable to assistance extended to a small country like Burkina Faso, formerly Upper Volta.
"The stakes are high, and we are playing as if it were a penny-ante game," Mr. Nixon said.
While not mentioning Mr. Bush or Mr. Baker by name in his critical passages, Mr. Nixon leaves no doubt about the way he feels they have inadequately supported President Yeltsin. The Administration's support has been primarily $3.75 billion in commercial credits to buy American grain, and an international aid conference in Washington that produced a onetime airlift made up of medical supplies and enough leftover Persian Gulf war rations to feed Moscow for one day.
 
'Photo-Opportunity' Parley
 "What has the United States and the West done so far to help Russia's first democratic, free-market oriented, non-expansionist government?" Mr. Nixon asks in the memo. "We have provided credits for the purchase of agricultural products. We have held a photo-opportunity international conference of 57 foreign secretaries that was long on rhetoric but short on action."
"We have decided to send two hundred Peace Corps volunteers -- a generous action if the target of our aid were a small country like Upper Volta but mere tokenism if applied to Russia, a nation of almost 200 million people covering one-seventh of the world's landmass," he added. "This is a pathetically inadequate response in light of the opportunities and dangers we face in the crisis in the former Soviet Union."
Mr. Nixon argued that the United States and its Western allies should provide much larger amounts of humanitarian aid, reschedule the debts incurred by the former Soviet Union until the new market economy begins to function, and create a multi-billion dollar fund to help stabilize the Russian ruble as soon as Russia gets control of its money supply.
His critique comes at a time when Mr. Bush has almost forsaken the foreign policy front as he concentrates on re-election. Administration foreign policy experts have been complaining privately that the President has become so concerned about the isolationist trends in the country -- which his main Republican rival, Patrick J. Buchanan, has encouraged -- that he has not only muted his support for foreign aid and increased assistance to the former Soviet lands, but has also virtually stopped talking about foreign policy at all, except to extol the victory in the gulf war.
The only reason that the Administration now has $400 million to spend in helping the former Soviet Union dismantle nuclear weapons is because the money was pushed through by Congressional Democrats last year, without the support of Mr. Baker or Mr. Bush.
 
Taking Issue to Voters
 Congressional leaders have told the Administration that if it wants a 1992 foreign aid bill that will include such things as money for international peacekeeping operations and increased contributions for the International Monetary Fund so it can help Russia, the President is going to have to get out and fight for it in Congress and with the public.
"The American people overwhelmingly oppose all foreign aid because they want to see that money spent on solving our problems at home," said Mr. Nixon, who published a sanitized,less critical version of his memo in Time magazine this week. "But the mark of great political leadership is not simply to support what is popular, but to make what is unpopular popular if that serves America's national interest."
"What seems politically profitable in the short term may prove costly in the long term," he added. "The hot-button issue in the 1950's was 'Who lost China?' If Yeltsin goes down, the question 'Who lost Russia?' will be an infinitely more devastating issue in the 1990's."
The Democratic Presidential candidates, none of whom have much foreign policy experience, have not been much more aggressive than the President on the Russian aid issue. While all have said that the other former Soviet republics should be helped in their move toward democracy, none have made the issue a centerpiece of his election campaign or pushed it as major item in his campaign advertising.
 
Refurbishing the Image
 Mr. Nixon's memorandum is the latest of many public policy pronouncements that have helped to refurbish the image of the former President, who resigned in disgrace in 1974 over the Watergate scandal. It was his Administration that established relations with Communist China and initiated detente and nuclear arms control treaties with the Soviet Union. Mr. Nixon has also just published a book, "Seize the Moment: America's Challenge in a One-Superpower World."
He begins his analysis in the memo by writing, "While the candidates have addressed scores of significant issues in this Presidential campaign, the most important issue since the end of World War II -- the fate of the political and economic reforms in Russia -- has been virtually ignored."
He added, "The Communists have lost the cold war, but the West has not yet won it."
What will determine whether "the final battle of the cold war will be won or lost," he argued, is whether "President Yeltsin's economic reforms succeed in creating a successful free-market economy."
If Mr. Yeltsin fails, Mr. Nixon said, "war could break out in the former Soviet Union as the new despots use force to restore the 'historical borders' of Russia."
"The new East European democracies would be imperiled," he continued. "China's totalitarians would breathe a sigh of relief. The new Russian regime -- whose leaders would cozy up to the Soviet Union's former clients in Iraq, Syria, Libya and North Korea -- would threaten our interests in hot spots around the world."
"The bottom line," Mr. Nixon said, "is that Yeltsin is the most pro-Western leader of Russia in history." He said the West must help the Yeltsin Government in six ways:
*By providing humanitarian food and medical aid to get the Russian Government through the critical months until reforms start working.
*By creating a "free-enterprise corps" that will send thousands of Western managers to Russia to infuse newly independent enterprises with capitalist tools.
*By rescheduling Soviet debt incurred under President Michael S. Gorbachev and deferring interest payments until the new market economy begins to function.
*By allowing greater access to Western markets for Russia's exports.
*By joining with other industrial nations "to provide tens of billions of dollars for currency stabilization through the I.M.F. as soon as Russia gets control of its money supply."
*By creating a single Western-led organization to coordinate government and private aid to Russia and other republics, as the United States did in rebuilding Europe after World War II.
The Nixon Library is holding a two-day foreign policy conference in Washington starting Wednesday, and Mr. Bush will be giving the keynote address. This may explain why his last paragraph contains the only explicit reference to the President:
"President Bush is uniquely qualified to meet this challenge," Mr. Nixon said, because the leadership he exhibited in the gulf war "can insure that the cold war will end not with just the defeat of Communism but also with the victory of freedom."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
President Focuses on 'Family Values'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
With Presidential primaries fast approaching in the Midwest's most urban states, President Bush declared today that the problems of big cities were rooted in the collapse of the family, and that the need for new solutions to the crisis was urgent and clear.
At the same time, Mr. Bush appeared to argue against more Government programs directed at families, saying that many of them have hurt more often than they have helped. His own prescription, delivered in a speech here to a meeting of officials in the National League of Cities, was limited. 
 "We needn't look far for principles to guide us," Mr. Bush said. "There are old home truths: rely on what works, discard what doesn't, never be afraid to innovate, remember the government closest to the people responds best to the needs of the people."
White House and Bush campaign officials said today that the President was considering a series of speeches and campaign events to sharpen his economic debate with the Democratic Congress and lay out more detailed plans for a second term.
The events, under discussion for several weeks, range from an Oval Office address to the nation to a barnstorm-style trip across the country to chide the Congress for refusing to pass the White House's economic growth package, one official said today.
Other options include a televised news conference on prime-time television -- a showcase that the President has rarely used in his three years in office -- and another address to the Congress, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
In today's comments, Mr. Bush called for innovations in the welfare system, which he said was sapping family strength, but the President did not suggest any other specific Federal action to deal with the breakdown of the family, a social problem many experts say has been worsening for at least three decades.
 
Embellishing a Theme
 Mr. Bush's speech today was the White House's effort to embellish a campaign theme -- the restoration of "family values" -- that the President first tried out in his State of the Union Message in January and that he has sounded in recent political speeches throughout the South.
In those stops in the weeks before the group of Southern primaries known as Super Tuesday, the President often denounced welfare cheats and child-support dodgers, called for the receipt of welfare to be conditioned on some form of work, and talked about the family's task of teaching children commitment to principals like morality and patriotism.
In part, those speeches have responded to criticism of Mr. Bush from his conservative opponent, Patrick J. Buchanan. But strategists also say that emphasizing the White House commitment to traditional family values will have an appeal beyond the South this fall, especially if Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, already scarred by accusations of sexual misconduct, becomes the Democratic nominee.
Today's address, delivered eight days before Presidential primaries in Illinois and Michigan, centered on the problems of urban families and big cities. Mr. Bush called for a bipartisan approach in curing the ills of the family, a contrast to the far harsher and partisan theme that Vice President Dan Quayle sounded last month in a speech denouncing Democratic-controlled New York City as an example of the failure of the welfare state.
A shift in campaign tactics would come as the most hectic series of primaries draws to an end.
At the same time, the March 20 deadline that Mr. Bush's gave Congress to pass his economic growth legislative package will expire, requiring some new White House action to make it clear that Mr. Bush is waging political war on behalf of his economic agenda.
The forum for Mr. Bush's appearances remains under debate, but he is expected to have a series of speeches in coming weeks "that will lay out the themes he'll pursue over the next several months," that official said.

At Mr. Bush's left was Commissioner Glenda Hood of Orlando, Fla., the chairman of the league, and at his right was Mayor Sharpe James of Newark. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Afghan President Says U.S. Should See Him as Ally Against Militant Islam

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 9

 BODY:
Abandoned by his former benefactors in Moscow and cast somewhat adrift in the new politics of the region, Afghanistan's President made an impassioned appeal to the United States today to help his country become a bulwark against the spread of Islamic fundamentalism in Central Asia.
In an interview here, President Najibullah also pleaded for immediate economic and humanitarian assistance from Washington, which long backed the Afghan fundamentalist guerrillas fighting his Government. He also promised that he would release four Afghans who worked in the United States Embassy and were convicted of espionage in 1983. 
 The Afghan President's praise for the United States and his attempt to enlist Washington in common cause against fundamentalism marked the sharpest departure yet from the open hostility that has characterized relations between Kabul and Washington since Afghanistan's leftist coup of 1978.
 
An Uncertain Future
 His appeal reflected not only the loss of support from Moscow and the vastly changed politics of the region but also his sense of uncertainty about his place in a future Afghanistan as well as his acute awareness of his country's desperation.
"We have a common task, Afghanistan, the United States of America, and the civilized world, to launch a joint struggle against fundamentalism," said Mr. Najibullah, who then described what he thought would happen to his country if Islamic extremists took power in Kabul.
"If fundamentalism comes to Afghanistan, war will continue for many more years," he said, the rush of his words repeatedly overwhelming his translator. "Afghanistan will turn into a center of world smuggling for narcotic drugs. Afghanistan will be turned into a center for terrorism."
 
Support for U.N. Plan
 Mr. Najibullah has promised to support a United Nations plan to summon a wide spectrum of Afghans -- including the Islamic fundamentalist guerrillas -- to a gathering that would lead to a political accord to end Afghanistan's years of civil conflict.
But his call for immediate aid left open to question whether he wants Washington to extend assistance while he is still in power or after a United Nations-sponsored transition from his Government is irreversibly under way. Mr. Najibullah has grown increasingly uneasy about the expected outcome of the United Nations process, which almost certainly would mean his removal from office and the dissolution of his Watan, or Homeland Party, the successor to the Soviet-inspired Communist Party he once led.
[In Washington, a senior State Department official said that the United States has long viewed Mr. Najibullah as an obstacle to peace and for that reason has felt that he should leave office, although that is a decision for the Afghans to make. The official, who asked not to be named, said that Mr. Najibullah's plea for funds notwithstanding, Washington already provides large amounts of aid from a humanitarian program administered from Pakistan.
[A department spokesman said there would be no direct public response to the interview.]
After 13 years of war, waged by Islamic rebels against various leftist governments and the Soviet forces, Afghanistan is a country in tatters. The years of conflict have driven six million refugees into Pakistan and Iran, prompted the country's educated classes to migrate to Europe and America and fractured the country along its already fragile ethnic fissures.
With the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan in February 1989, virtually all Western nations abandoned their embassies here and ostracized Mr. Najibullah's regime. And then, with the final disintegration of the Soviet Union in December, Afghanistan's last source of economic assistance disappeared. Mr. Najibullah found himself alone in the world, and all but ignored.
In recent months the United Nations peace plan has begun to show signs of life. Pakistan, the principal benefactor of the Afghan guerrillas and the main conduit of Western arms to them, cut off its assistance in late January and said it was supporting the United Nations plan. In doing so, Islamabad abandoned its insistence on installing a fundamentalist government in Kabul, seeking instead a government that could serve as a stable bridge to fruitful economic and political ties with the new Central Asian republics formed from the old Soviet Union. Many leaders in those republics are wary of Islamic fundamentalism.
Some of the fundamentalist guerrillas have condemned the peace efforts, declaring that only the imposition of an Islamic government will bring peace to the country. But others among the splintered guerrilla movement have agreed to participate in the peace efforts.
Mr. Najibullah spoke fervently today of his hopes for a dialogue with the United States, which at one time was shipping hundreds of millions of dollars of weapons to the fundamentalist guerrillas largely in the interest of countering Soviet dominance over the country. Repeatedly during the 40-minute interview, the President echoed a concern underlying the swing through Central Asia last month by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d -- that Islamic fundamentalism poses a significant threat to stability in the region.
"You may think that the Central Asian Republics are significant for the United States of America," he said. "That's right. But I must say that the strategic and political significance of Afghanistan is much more than these republics. If Afghanistan is lost and is turned into a center of fundamentalism, you will lose the Central Asian republics."
Mr. Najibullah, a burly man with a brush mustache, spoke in a wood-paneled conference room dominated by a huge map of the country and lighted by a chandelier made up of five glass globes. Dressed in a subdued blue suit and dark blue tie, the president, normally quite reserved in his discussions with journalists, gesticulated frequently, especially during his discussion of his hopes for a renewal of contacts with the United States.
 
'What Is the Obstacle?'

Most disappointing, the President said, was the refusal of the United States to talk to his Government at any level. The guerrillas, he said, had held talks with the Russian Government in Moscow, and Mr. Baker had visited the newly formed governments in Central Asia, "so what is the obstacle that the United States of America is not opening its embassy in Afghanistan?" he asked.
The last American ambassador to Afghanistan, Adolph Dubs, was killed in 1979 during an attempted kidnapping. Mr. Dubs was never replaced and American representation in Kabul continued at a reduced level until the embassy closed in 1989.
In a gesture intended to demonstrate his sincerity, Mr. Najibullah said that he would offer pardons to four Afghans who worked in the old American embassy. The four were arrested in 1983 and charged with spying for the Central Intelligence Agency. "When we receive a letter from an official source of the Government of the United States of America, we will do this," the President said. "For instance, this letter could be sent through any embassy in the region, or some department in the United States of America, or through Benon Sevon," a reference to the special representative of the United Nations Secretary General to Afghanistan and who is orchestrating the latest peace effort. When asked how long it would be after receiving such a letter that the men would be released, Mr. Najibullah simply said, "Immediately."
American officials have steadfastly denied that the four men -- Ghulam Sakhi Ahmadzai, Jalaludin Talibee, Mohammed Esa and Fazal Ahmad Maulana -- ever engaged in espionage. Several years ago, another embassy employee who also had been imprisoned for spying was traded in a deal for several Afghan officials who were captured in Pakistan.

More than in any other state, Congressional redistricting in New York is a high-stakes game of political survival. HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Bowing Out;
Congratulating the Remaining Candidates, Harkin Ends Campaign

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, as expected, withdrew today from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, still embracing his unabashed message of liberalism that failed to catch fire during his six-month campaign.
In departing the race, Mr. Harkin became the third Democratic casualty of the season; Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska withdrew Thursday and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia withdrew Jan. 8. 
 "My advisers told me not to peak too soon," Mr. Harkin said. "I think I took them too seriously."
Mr. Harkin said he would do all he could for the party's nominee in November. Paraphrasing John F. Kennedy's inaugural address in 1961, Mr. Harkin said, "I will pay any price, bear any burden, learn to speak Greek, develop a Southern accent, or learn to wear a turtleneck to insure that a Democrat is elected President in 1992."
At a final appearance before returning to Iowa, the Senator told an audience made up mainly of students at Gallaudet University, a liberal arts institution for the deaf, that running for President had been the "privilege of a lifetime." Mr. Harkin, whose brother, Frank, is deaf, delivered a brief message in sign language before addressing the crowd.
 
3 Caucuses, No Primaries
 During his campaign, Mr. Harkin failed to win a single primary although he won caucuses in Idaho, Minnesota and Iowa. Congratulating the surviving contenders, he said, "As a result of their success, after today, I will no longer be a candidate for President of the United States."
In a sometimes wistful speech tinged with self-deprecating humor, Mr. Harkin seemed to dismiss the verdict that voters had rejected the liberal politics he represented. "Our campaign was based on the belief that America is not some at the expense of many, but many to the advantage of all," he said. "This is still our cause. Nothing that has happened in this campaign has or could ever change that."
Mr. Harkin, who had referred to himself as the "real Democrat" in the race, had gauged his appeal to traditional constituencies within the Democratic Party, in particular organized labor, in what he said today was a campaign "about keeping the progressive agenda alive for our party."
But that base proved too fragile to sustain him through the early primaries, while candidates like Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massaschusetts, and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, swiftly shouldered him aside. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, though running a shoestring campaign, also remains in the race for the nomination.
Mr. Harkin advocated deep cuts in military spending and a large-scale costruction program to revive the flagging economy. "The poor may be out of political fashion, but they are not without human needs," he said. "The middle class may be angry, but they have not lost the dream that all Americans can advance together."
Mr. Harkin had hoped to last until the primaries in Michigan and Illinois on March 17, but his campaign was in debt and seemed stalled after doing poorly last Saturday in the South Carolina primary and caucuses in Arizona, Nevada and Wyoming. A delegate tally by The New York Times on Sunday showed Mr. Harkin with 86 votes, trailing Mr. Clinton with 293 and Mr. Tsongas with 141. Mr. Harkin won 14 percent of the vote in Wyoming, 8 percent in Arizona, 6 percent in South Carolina and about 1 percent in Nevada.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Tom Harkin spoke yesterday in sign language during a visit to deaf students at Gallaudet University in Washington before returning to Iowa. Mr. Harkin became the third Democrat to withdraw from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Unusual Use of the First Amendment Overturns a Killer's Death Sentence

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The Supreme Court overturned a death sentence today on the ground that the prosecution violated a convicted murderer's First Amendment rights by telling the jury that he belonged to a white racist prison gang called the Aryan Brotherhood.
The vote was 8 to 1, with Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist writing for the majority and Justice Clarence Thomas casting the dissenting vote. 
 The convicted murderer, David Dawson had just escaped from a state prison in Delaware when he killed a woman and stole her car. The prosecution introduced evidence of Mr. Dawson's membership in the Aryan Brotherhood at the sentencing phase of his trial without trying to show that the information was relevant either to the crime or to Mr. Dawson's character. The woman he killed was white.
 
Freedom of Association
 In his majority opinion today, Chief Justice Rehnquist said that because the evidence indicated nothing more than Mr. Dawson's "abstract beliefs" the state violated the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of association by providing the information to the sentencing jury.
"We have held that the First Amendment protects an individual's right to join groups and associate with others holding similar beliefs," Chief Justice Rehnquist said. His opinion emphasized that the First Amendment would not bar the use of "associational evidence" that was relevant either to the crime itself or to an aspect of the defendant's character, like an indication that a defendant was committed to violence and would be dangerous in the future.
But in this case, the Chief Justice said, Delaware failed to show that Mr. Dawson's membership in the Aryan Brotherhood was relevant to his sentencing. "On the present record one is left with the feeling that the Aryan Brotherhood evidence was employed simply because the jury would find these beliefs morally reprehensible," he said, and in that circumstance, the introduction of the evidence was a "constitutional error."
The First Amendment has rarely if ever been a factor in a death penalty decision. As circumscribed as the majority opinion was in this case, the outcome was still somewhat surprising from a Court that has seemed in recent cases to be intent on clearing away obstacles to the death penalty.
Justice Thomas, in his dissenting opinion, objected both to the Court's discussion of relevance and to the majority's analysis of the First Amendment issue.
 
'Forbidden Activities'
 Mr. Dawson's membership in the Aryan Brotherhood "had relevance at sentencing," Justice Thomas said, because a jury could have used it to draw inferences about his character. "In my judgment, a jury reasonably could conclude from Dawson's membership in a prison gang that he had engaged in some sort of forbidden activities while in prison," he said. Also, he said, it was relevant in countering the defense effort to portray Mr. Dawson as a kind person who had earned credit for good behavior while in prison.
Justice Thomas said he had "difficulty seeing what the First Amendment adds to the analysis." He accused the other Justices of adhering to a "double standard" in death penalty cases, in which defendants are given more leeway than prosecutors.
The Supreme Court has recently expanded information that the prosecution can bring before a jury in death penalty cases. Last year, Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote the opinion in Payne v. Tennessee, which overturned earlier rulings and permitted evidence about the character of the murder victim that assisted the prosecution. Today, the Chief Justice cited that case, making it clear that the Court was in no way retreating from that ruling.
Justice Thomas's dissenting opinion was notable for the solitary position in which it placed him, without even the company of his apparent mentor, Justice Antonin Scalia. Justice Scalia joined Chief Justice Rehnquist's opinion without comment. This was the first case that found Justices Thomas and Scalia on opposite sides.
When he was an Associate Justice, Chief Justice Rehnquist was often the Court's lone dissenter, a role that more recently seemed to fall to Justice Scalia. Justice Thomas's opinion today may indicate his willingness to assume the role.
The decision, Dawson v. Delaware, No. 90-6704, sends the case back to the Supreme Court of Delaware, which had upheld the death sentence in a 1990 opinion. That court can now order a new sentencing proceeding that excludes the Aryan Brotherhood evidence. Alternatively, the majority said today, the Delaware court can decide whether use of the evidence was a "harmless error" in light of other evidence of Mr. Dawson's eligibility for the death penalty.
By implying, without directly holding, that the "harmless error" analysis might be appropriate, the Court appeared to exclude the First Amendment problem in this case from the category of constitutional errors that require an automatic reversal even if other evidence is overwhelming.
The Bush Administration filed a brief in the case in support of the state. The American Civil Liberties Union and the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers filed a brief for Mr. Dawson.
 
Faulty Instruction of Jury
 The Court set aside a second death sentence today, ruling 6 to 3 that a Mississippi man was entitled to a new sentencing proceeding because his 1982 death sentence was based on an unconstitutional jury instruction.
The instruction permitted the jury to impose a death sentence if it found that a murder was "especially heinous, atrocious or cruel." Though the Supreme Court had found as long ago as 1980 that this language was unconstitutionally vague, it was not until later rulings that the Court made clear that the use of this instruction invalidated a death sentence in cases like the one before the Court today.
The question in the case, Stringer v. Black, No. 90-6616, was whether the inmate, James R. Stringer, was entitled to the benefit of the later decisions in the petition that he filed in Federal court in 1987 challenging his sentence. The Supreme Court has ruled that an inmate may generally not benefit in a habeas corpus petition from a "new rule" contained in a decision issued after his conviction becomes final.
In a majority opinion by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, the Court today said that the later decisions on the jury instruction were not "new rules" but were based directly on the 1980 decision.
Justice David H. Souter dissented in an opinion that Justices Scalia and Thomas joined. They said it was not clear at the time of Mr. Stringer's sentencing that the doctrine the Court announced in 1980 would apply to death sentence statutes such as Mississippi's.
There were also these other developments at the Court today:
 
California Term Limits
 Without comment, the Court refused to hear a challenge by the California Legislature to the limits on legislators' terms that California voters adopted in a 1990 referendum. The California Supreme Court upheld the term limits in a ruling last October.
The limits, which do not apply to members of Congress, will require all current members of the California Legislature to be out of office by the end of the decade. In its appeal, Legislature v. Eu, No. 90-1113, the legislative leadership argued that the limitation violated the First Amendment rights both of those who want to run for office and of voters who want continued representation by the incumbents.
Though the Justices rejected this case, which involved only state offices, the Court may well be more interested in challenges to limits on Congressional terms. Voters in Washington State rejected a Congressional term-limit measure last year, but a similar measure will appear on the Florida ballot in November.
 
Commercial Speech
 In a case with important implications for advertisers and businesses, the Court agreed to decide whether a city that permits newspapers to place their vending machines along public streets must give the same privilege to publications that consist almost entirely of advertising.
The Court has ruled in cases over the last 15 years that though speech offering or advocating a commercial transaction was protected under the First Amendment, the government could regulate it in ways prohibited for "pure" speech. But the dimensions of the "commercial speech" doctrine remain unclear.
In this case, Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, No. 91-1200, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled that in granting permits for newspaper vending machines Cincinnati could not discriminate against two publications that are distributed for free and that advertise real estate and adult education classes.
 
Workers' Compensation
 The Court ruled unanimously that a 1987 Michigan law imposing retroactive liability on employers for a category of workers' compensation benefits did not violate the employers' rights. The decision, by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, affirmed a 1990 ruling by the Supreme Court of Michigan.
The case, General Motors v. Romein, No. 90-1390, was seen as a possible vehicle to revive the Constitution's "contract clause," which prohibits a state from breaching a contract. The clause has been little used in modern times, and economic and legal conservatives have looked to its revival as a curb on government regulation.
The Court essentially sidestepped the issue today, ruling that the contract clause did not apply in this case because the state workers' compensation law was not part of the contract between the employers and their labor unions.
 
Private-Property Rights
 The Justices dismissed another closely watched case without an opinion. The case, PFZ Properties v. Rodriguez, No. 91-122, was a constitutional challenge growing out of the refusal of planning officials in Puerto Rico to issue a construction permit for a proposed development. The case was a potential test of the Court's new interest in private-property rights. But the Justices apparently decided after hearing arguments last month that the case was flawed and should not have been accepted for review.

LENGTH: 757 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Democrats' Diplomacy: They Need Each Other

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 9

 BODY:
Welcome to the N.F.L.
There are 13 Democratic primaries and caucuses over the next eight days, 11 of them on Tuesday. They will produce 31 percent of the pledged delegates to the Democratic National Convention. 
 What drives this campaign now, as the primaries tumble one after another, are real, flesh-and-blood, "How does this affect me?" Democratic constituencies: the condo dwellers of South Florida, the black voters of the Deep South, the auto workers of Michigan, the white ethnic voters of Chicago. This is complicated and messy and hard. All the theoretical constructs for this year's election fell away somewhere on the way to Super Tuesday and next week's primaries in Illinois and Michigan.
Gov. Bill Clinton, who spent much of the last year as the darling of the "new thinkers," is now campaigning across the South with what looks like an old-fashioned, lectern-thumping, working-class populist coalition -- one that Walter F. Mondale might have felt at home with. He has been carefully organizing and positioning for months to pull these groups in.
His allies call it smart politics, his critics cynical expedience. (Remember Bill Clinton, chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council, that fierce challenger of politics as usual?) Whatever, at this stage of the campaign, these groups matter.
Here in South Florida, the Clinton campaign has blanketed the condos, home to many Jewish retirees, with leaflets accusing former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of being lukewarm in his support of Israel. On Monday night, more Clinton volunteers were in the field with new leaflets attacking Mr. Tsongas's record on Social Security ("Paul Tsongas -- Older Americans -- The Facts").
On television, the Clinton campaign highlights Mr. Tsongas's support for an increase in the gasoline tax (this is a big commuter state, dependent on tourism), and his suggestion that cost-of-living adjustments for 'entitlement' programs might have to be curbed (no explanation needed).
Suddenly, "I'm no Santa Claus" is a message with a downside. ("Why not?" some Democrats might ask.) Mr. Tsongas often seems angry and defensive these days as he battles to hold the line in Florida against a Clinton sweep of the South.
"He's been knocked off his message," says Jeff Eller, Mr. Clinton's Florida coordinator. In person and in his television commercials, the former Senator rails at Mr. Clinton for negative politics.
Still, even if he seems outmatched in conventional politics, part of Mr. Tsongas's appeal is simply that -- the idea that he is something other than another politician who knows how to play the game. He keeps drawing the upscale suburban, Volvo vote; even in South Carolina, which was a Clinton blowout, Mr. Tsongas ran well among voters who make over $75,000 a year. This vote is critical to Democratic chances of retaking the White House. Many smart young Democrats believe their party went awry when Gary Hart, who also drew this kind of voter, self-destructed in 1987.
But Mr. Tsongas, as Mr. Hart did, faces a problem in this phase of the primaries: the Democratic Party has a base, and it includes black voters and organized labor. Mr. Tsongas carried 5 percent of the black vote in South Carolina, 14 percent in Georgia and 25 percent in Maryland, a state where he otherwise ran very strong. Next week, when the race moves to Michigan and Illinois, he faces a heavy labor presence -- and labor has not exactly swept to his side.
And Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton have one more thing to worry about: former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., who endured against all predictions when others walked away.
The broader problem for the Democrats is that the party needs both the Clinton and Tsongas vote. "The campaign that has to be run against George Bush is a campaign that combines the appeal to suburban voters who have substantial economic interests, with strong support from traditional Democratic groups such as black voters," said Thomas E. Donilon, a veteran Democratic strategist and a supporter of Mr. Clinton's.
If Mr. Clinton wins in Florida, he can head North with considerable drive and try to demonstrate on neutral turf, that he can unite old and new in the Democratic Party. He would also have new evidence that he has triumphed over questions about his finances, fidelity and draft status.
If Mr. Tsongas prevails in Florida, it would feed the doubts about Mr. Clinton and demonstrate the power of these new Democrats. Too much is at stake here for the debate to be anything but hard, wary and angry.

HEADLINE: Lone Superpower Plan: Ammunition for Critics

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
The Pentagon's draft policy statement that foresees a one-superpower world in which no collection of allies or foes is allowed to become a rival reflects intense pressure in the American military establishment to define a robust mission for itself in the post-cold-war era.
Should this draft policy be issued this month to the military chiefs under Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's signature, the Bush Administration will find itself at odds with a number of its international allies and, domestically, with the Democratic majority that controls Congress. 
 And, perhaps more problematical for the President, the Pentagon vision of the new American role sharpens the debate within the Republican Party, where Patrick J. Buchanan lashed out today at the Pentagon prescription for the United States' becoming the ultimate guarantor of world security.
"This is a formula for endless American intervention in quarrels and war when no vital interest of the United States is remotely engaged," Mr. Buchanan told reporters on his way to Memphis, Tenn. "It's virtually a blank check given to all of America's friends and allies that we'll go to war to defend their interests."
Mr. Buchanan called on Mr. Bush to repudiate the draft document. The White House was silent on the matter, and a State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said he would not comment on a document that was internal to the Pentagon.
The Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, today characterized the document as a "low level" draft, but defended its contents. He said the statements were very similiar to public statements and Congressional testimony by Mr. Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Democratic reactions to the draft document were as strong as those from Mr. Buchanan on the Republican right, indicating that Mr. Buchanan's opposition converges in this instance with Democratic calls for greater reductions in military spending and for greater collectivism in international security.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware and a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said he agreed with some of the objectives stated in the policy draft, like combating the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
The problem, he said, was that "the Pentagon vision reverts to an old notion of the United States as the world's policeman -- a notion that, not incidentally, will preserve a large defense budget."
 
A 'Pax Mundi' Is Urged
 He criticized what he termed was an inappropriate Pentagon instinct to erect a "Pax Americana, a global security system where threats to stability are suppressed or destroyed by U.S. military power."
As an alternative strategy, Mr. Biden suggested that the United States pursue "the next big advance in civilization," which he described as "collective power through the United Nations," an option that is effectively rejected by the Defense Department draft.
Among Democratic candidates for President, Paul E. Tsongas has most pointedly addressed the question of whether the United States should take an overarching role in world security.
In his political manifesto, "A Call to Economic Arms," Mr. Tsongas says he would pursue a policy not of Pax Americana, but of Pax Mundi, under which collective security would be a matter of equitable risk sharing and burden sharing so that each nation seeking to protect its vital trade or security interests would make contributions in forces and financial resources to reflect those interests.
"Efforts are going to have to be made to provide a United Nations Security Force with real teeth," Mr. Tsongas writes. "Pax Americana must give way to Heal Thyself. This is not isolationism. It is participation in a new internationalism truly based on the principle of collective security."
 
Draft Called 'Low Level'
 George Stephanopoulos, deputy campaign manager for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, said the first reaction to the Pentagon document was that it seemed to be "one more attempt" by defense officials "to find an excuse for big budgets instead of downsizing."
John D. Steinbruner, director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution, and an advocate of significant reductions in the President's $1.2 trillion five-year defense plan, said that while many of the goals stated in the policy statement were laudable, its somewhat chauvanistic tone might prompt allies "to challenge us in terms of military procurement."
"People will develop capabilities designed to offset ours," he said, especially if the United States takes a position, as the draft does, that no collection of nations can aspire to regional dominance because that would put them on the path to global rivalry with the American superpower.
"This is very likely to happen if we assertively pursue this kind of superiority," Mr. Steinbruner said.
Caught off guard by the publication of extensive excerpts from the draft defense planning guidance in The New York Times on Sunday, the Pentagon seemed at a loss today whether to embrace the document or reject it. Mr. Cheney was said to have complained to aides that his public testimony on defense strategy gets scant coverage in the news media while classified documents relating to policy formulation underlying those public statements get greater attention.
Mr. Williams called it a "low-level draft" that had not been seen by Mr. Cheney nor been approved by any senior official. "Undoubtedly it will be revised," he said, adding that he had not seen the document, but had instructed his staff to prepare examples of where the document "overlaps" with the public testimony of senior defense officials.
 
Who Got the Document
 On Feb. 18, the draft "Defense Planning Guidance," prepared under the supervision of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the Pentagon's Under Secretary for Policy, was circulated to General Powell, who serves as the President's principal military adviser, the secretaries of all four military departments, Mr. Cheney's under secretaries and assistant secretaries of defense and the chiefs of all four military services.
A week after the draft document was circulated, Adm. David E. Jeremiah, the vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the Senate Armed Services Committee that the document would be issued by Mr. Cheney in early March, thus indicating it was in an advanced drafting stage. A cover memo from Mr. Wolfowitz's deputy, Dale A. Vesser, also indicates that the policy statement is near final form and asks recipients to "focus your comments on major substantive concerns."
One 15-page section of the guidance states that it has been approved by Mr. Cheney and begins, "This section constitutes definitive guidance from the Secretary of Defense" to be used in conjunction with "fiscal guidance published by the Secretary on 15 February 1992."
Today, Mr. Williams declined to say when the final policy document would be issued. But owing to its classification as a secret document, the public may not discover for some time how Mr. Cheney resolves the questions that have been raised about the draft.
