PUB-DATE: March 11, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1578 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Assessment;
Super Tuesday Transforms Campaign

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 10

 BODY:
Southern Democratic leaders achieved today what they sought in vain to do four years ago: They gave a mighty heave forward to the Presidential bid of a moderate candidate from their own region.
Whether the heave will prove decisive, and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas will capture the nomination in New York this summer, remains to be seen, of course. But his sweep of the Southern states on Super Tuesday 1992 established him as his party's undisputed front-runner with a big lead in convention delegates and gave him a shot at clinching things for all intents and purposes this month. 
 It was a grim day for former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts. Having failed even to come close in Florida, the only Southern state where he had a fighting chance, he must now win next week in either Illinois or Michigan, with their big blue-collar voting blocs, both ethnic and black.
Neither today nor in earlier primaries have those voters been much attracted to him, and one of his advisers, Ted van Dyk, said tonight that Mr. Tsongas was facing "a Stalingrad in the Midwest" in whose snows his candidacy could easily perish.
The Democrats' system of proportional representation insured the former Senator, even in defeat, of some delegates from all the major Super Tuesday states. Even if he lost both Michigan and Illinois, he would probably get delegates there, too, and Mr. Clinton would not be able to put a mathematical lock on the nomination until many more states had voted.
But without at least one victory in the big Great Lakes states next week, Mr. Tsongas would run short of money quickly and Mr. Clinton might look unstoppable. Mr. Tsongas's next chance to win a dramatic, image-reversing victory would not come for three weeks, in the New York primary on April 7.
The question that lurked in many minds, even as Mr. Clinton won six primaries in the South, including the hard-fought contest in Florida, was whether the Democrats were playing into the Republicans' hands. The Arkansas Governor, in the view of many political professionals, would be highly vulnerable to assault by the Republicans this fall because of questions about his extramarital relations, his draft status during the Vietnam war and his financial dealings while Governor.
"He looks like Jack Dempsey at the moment," said a Senator from a border state, "but the Republicans haven't started punching yet."
 
Situation in the Fall
 Richard Murray, a professor of political science at the University of Houston, said that "fear about jobs trumps concerns about character in really hard times." But with Mr. Clinton as its nominee and the economy ticking along a bit better, he continued, the Democratic Party might find itself this fall "having problems not with its message but with its messenger."
As if in response to such comments, Mr. Clinton said in a victory speech in Chicago tonight, "The true measure of character in politics can never be perfection, because if it were, no one could pass."
President Bush also won everywhere in the South, but once again, he failed to decisively dispatch his main challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan. In the two electoral powerhouses of the region, Texas and Florida, the President once again lost 30 to 35 percent of the vote, as he has around the country. Only in Tennessee was Mr. Bush able to overwhelm his rival's protest votes.
As a result, he is closer to the nomination, in a numerical sense, but no closer to party mastery.
Voters who backed Mr. Buchanan in Texas and Florida were mostly people who think the economy is stumbling, who are angry about Mr. Bush's breaking his pledge not to increase taxes and who want "to shake things up." But nowhere were there enough of them to put him close to victory, and Republican Congressional leaders began urging Mr. Buchanan tonight to fold his campaign.
In this campaign as in most, expectations and perceptions play a large part, and at the moment they are working against Mr. Bush and for Mr. Clinton. For the President to lose a third of the vote in state after state, most of it to a television commentator who has never run for office, seems a signal of weakness to many. But for Mr. Clinton, a much less well-known figure than Mr. Bush, winning 50 or 60 percent of the vote constitutes quite a success.
 
Why Super Tuesday
 Super Tuesday was created as an antidote to the tendency of early-voting states to make inevitable the nomination of liberals like former Senator George McGovern, in 1972, and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, in 1984. Convinced that they were unelectable, the Southerners grouped their primaries early in the political year as a means of getting leverage. But in 1988 the Southern hope, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, was buried in the South by the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, both liberals.
Mr. Clinton learned something from Mr. Gore's experience. Although he never seemed likely to beat Senator Tom Harkin in Iowa and knew he faced a fight from Mr. Tsongas in New Hampshire, he plunged into a number of early tests, unlike Mr. Gore, who hung back until Super Tuesday, allowing his rivals to become far better known.
Even when he was taking a daily battering in the newspapers and on television on the character issue, even when it was all but impossible to get any attention for his substantive points, Mr. Clinton gritted his teeth and carried on, knowing that every day brought him closer to the South.
Like Mr. Dukakis, he invested money and manpower in Florida and Texas, creating an organization that Mr. Tsongas, like Mr. Gore before him, could not match.
Mr. Tsongas lacked a skill that proved valuable to Mr. Dukakis: his ability to appeal in Spanish to Hispanic voters. Mr. Dukakis scored heavily among such voters four years ago, but a poll of Texas voters leaving the booths by Voter Research and Surveys, a cooperative venture by four television networks, showed Mr. Tsongas gaining the support of only about 20 percent of the Hispanic electorate.
Surprisingly, the same survey showed Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton splitting the Jewish votes in Florida, one of the main building blocks of the Dukakis victory here in 1988. Mr. Clinton had sought to convince Jewish retirees, of whom tens of thousands are clustered in South Florida, that the former Senator was lukewarm in his support of Israel and Social Security.
In some ways, Florida was a demographically ideal state for Mr. Tsongas, certainly far more suited to him than Illinois or Michigan, with their urban wards filled with Polish-, Ukrainian- and Italian-Americans.
According to the exit poll, more than 60 percent of the participants in the Democratic primary in Florida had some college education. Those were the kinds of voters among whom the former Senator had done best in previous elections. He easily carried those with undergradute and graduate degrees, but Mr. Clinton trounced him among the large group with only some college.
In the end, Mr. Clinton appeared to have won the bitter debate over whose economic plan would do more for the country; in both Texas and Florida, the Governor got a majority of the votes of those who said they thought the economy was in poor shape.
About 20 percent of the voters in the Democratic primaries said that Mr. Clinton's draft experiences made them think less of him, and it cost him some support. Even so, he managed to capitalize on an electoral schedule that was created to help put someone like himself in the White House.
Mr. Clinton's sweeping triumph in the day's eight primaries, broken only by Mr. Tsongas's victories in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, means trouble not only for Mr. Tsongas but also for the third Democratic contender, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California. He, too, needs to make a better showing next Tuesday than he did today to avoid seeming irrelevant.
A handful of influential figures will now come into focus as power brokers in the Democratic race.
One is Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago, a less commanding presence than his father, but still, even without a machine, a good man to have on one's side. Another will be Mayor Coleman Young of Detroit, one of the nation's leading black politicians. And then there are the leaders of the trade unions who had been backing Mr. Harkin before he pulled out and who are now hard-pressed to find a candidate.
Mr. Tsongas has offended organized labor by advocating the right of companies to hire permanent replacement workers for striking employees. And Mr. Clinton, who comes from a right-to-work state, has never been popular with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. at home, which accuses him of promoting low-paying jobs.
Although Mr. Brown causes labor few ideological problems, he is a long way stylistically from the kind of lunch-bucket voter the unions represent.
Owen Bieber, the head of the United Auto Workers, rattled by news of plant closings at General Motors and by the slump at all of the Big Three manufacturers, has kept his counsel so far. But the 15 national unions that had backed Mr. Harkin are planning to meet Thursday to see if they can agree on a new candidate.
Both Jay Mazur, the president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and William Bywater, president of the electrical workers, have suggested that labor would eventually see Mr. Clinton as the lesser of two evils. But if their support is lukewarm, it may produce few votes for him.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 550 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Privately owned savings and loans posted their first profit in five years last year, earning almost $2 billion, regulators reported. They said the turnaround represented the clearest sign so far that the bailout had pulled the industry out of its crisis. [Page D1.] 
 Passage of a tax cut for families was called for by Senate Republicans -- the same cut President Bush had proposed and then de-emphasized. [D1.]
Members of the F.C.C. are moving away from a proposal that would have greatly increased the number of radio stations a single company may own. [D6.]
Non-farm productivity grew for the first time in three years last year. [D6.]
New York City is investigating whether First Boston, which is underwriting $1 billion worth of city debt, purchased city bonds improperly. [B3.]
 
Companies
Northwest Airlines revived its 30-day advance purchase fares, and American, Delta, United and USAir matched the discounted, nonrefundable fares. [D1.] Alarmed by the recent encroachment of U.S. airlines, more foreign carriers are fighting back. [D1.]
Continental Airlines said it was expanding service at a number of its hubs, partly because of an increase in passenger traffic. [D4.]
Victor J. Riley, Keycorp's chairman, turned westward when he was frustrated at not being able to expand into New England, a change of course he does not regret. [D1.]
Dell Computer said its profits rose 79 percent for the quarter, exceeding most estimates, and announced a 3-for-2 stock split. [D4.]
Corporate Partners, a $1.6 billion investment fund run by Lazard Freres, is reportedly negotiating to invest an estimated $250 million in Continental Cablevision. [D22.]
 
Business Technology
Eastern Germany will have one of the most modern telephone networks in the world after a $30 billion modernization program. [D1.]
 
International
Western Germany's inflation rate rose sharply, diminishing the chances that interest rates will soon be lowered to stimulate the slumping German economy. [D2.]
Japan's electronics industry denied American charges that a semiconductor trade agreement with the U.S. was "on the verge of failure." [D4.]
The Administration is likely to change its antitrust policies to allow Justice Department lawsuits against the U.S. operations of foreign cartels. [D6.]
 
Markets
Stocks made modest gains in heavy trading, with program buying adding volatility. The Dow rose 15.87, to 3,230.99. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates rose in thin trading, ending a two-day rally. [D15.]
A three-day rally in wheat prices stalled as concerns over crop damage from harsh weather gave way to profit taking. [D16.] The dollar rose and gold prices were mixed. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
Could Uncle Sam again be caught holding the bag in a banking scam on the scale of the savings and loan debacle? Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Exxon announced a plan that enables investors to buy its shares without ever talking to a broker, or ever paying any commissions. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
Vogue is celebrating its 100th anniversary with a record number of pages for its April issue, a hardcover book and a party at the New York Public Library. Advertising. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Nixon's 'Save Russia' Memo: Bush Feels the Sting

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
By warning that the United States has provided "pathetically" insufficient assistance to Russia, former President Richard M. Nixon has stung the Bush Administration and focused attention on an issue that the Administration and Congress have been hesitating to address for months.
President Bush's discomfort was evident today when he was asked about Mr. Nixon's critique just before a meeting with Republican leaders. First, Mr. Bush said he and Mr. Nixon had spoken and they were actually in total agreement. Then Mr. Bush said his Administration had already done a great deal -- contradicting Mr. Nixon's whole critique. 
 In arguing forcefully that the Administration is missing the opportunity of the century to transform Russia into a democracy, Mr. Nixon has raised the possibility of a "who lost Russia" debate if the infant democratic institutions in Russia and other former Soviet republics are toppled.
That is perhaps the worst fear of senior Administration officials: that all their foreign policy successes -- from German unification to the gulf war -- could be washed away in assertions that they "lost Russia" if President Boris N. Yeltsin is ousted by hard-liners.
 
'Who Lost Russia?'
 As Mr. Nixon put it in his memorandum circulated to foreign-policy analysts: "The hot-button issue in the 1950's was 'Who lost China?' If Yeltsin goes down, the question 'Who lost Russia' will be an infinitely more devastating issue in the 1990's."
That is a question that virtually every policymaker in this Administration has in the back of the mind. While they will never say so publicly, officials acknowledge that they could be vulnerable to a harsh historical judgment on whether they did enough to insure that the democratic revolution in Russia led by Mr. Yeltsin succeeds. Even those who favor Mr. Bush's cautious approach say they know that if Mr. Yeltsin goes down they will be blamed.
Mr. Nixon, of course, is an expert in "Who lost . . ." arguments, and he knows their political power. It was he and a coterie of post World War II Republicans who began their political careers by leveling such arguments against government officials who they said were responsible for letting China slip into Communism. And yet it was Mr. Nixon who also understood the power of reversing himself in reopening relations with China 25 years later.
The response of Bush Administration officials up to now has been to suppress any fears and try to make as much as possible out of the relatively little that the Administration has done. But at the same time, they are refraining from asking Congress or the American taxpayers for anything more substantial, which they consider politically unwise at this time, and are somehow hoping that Mr. Yeltsin will muddle through.
 
Democrats Back Memo
 Speaking to reporters today at a White House meeting of Republican leaders, Mr. Bush defended the Administration's record, which Mr. Nixon described as "penny ante."
"There are certain fiscal financial constraints on what we can do, but we have a huge stake in the success of democracy in Russia and in the other C.I.S. countries," said Mr. Bush, referring to the Commonwealth of Independent of States. "And so we will be working in every way possible to support the forces of democracy. Certainly we've done a lot in terms of supporting the people that might be afflicted by starvation, real hunger, and similarly on medicine. So there's a lot of taxpayer money going into this already -- a lot of it in terms of guarantees for agricultural products, which was their emergency requirement."
Speaking generally of the Nixon memo, Mr. Bush said, "I didn't take it as personally critical, and I think he would reiterate that it wasn't."
Mr. Nixon's critique has won the respect even of some Democrats, or as Senator Joseph R. Biden, chairman of the Senate Europe subcommittee put it: "It seems to occur randomly, but this time Mr. Nixon has it right. What we need from the Bush Administration is a comprehensive plan to buttress democracy from Prague to Vladivostok. I have urged Secretary Baker to submit such plans to Congress and I have pledged to support the Administration in the bipartisan spirit that these crucial issues demand."
 
'They're Afraid'
 Yet Democratic Presidential candidates have not shown much enthusiasm for spending a great deal of money at the moment to support Russian reforms, and tend to get a little vague when the issue is raised.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, asked about the Nixon memo, said: "I think Baker and Bush have good instincts on what to do in the former Soviet republics, but I think they've been a little too timid in doing it. I think they know they ought to be with the republics. They know they ought to be trying to dismantle nuclear weapons. They know they ought to be trying to help convert the currency, but I think they're just a little timid on it. I think they're afraid of looking like they're too preoccupied with foreign policy."
Brad Mackenzie, assistant press secretary for former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, said the candidate's position is that given the enormous amount of money spent during the cold war to counter Communism, the least the United States could do now is to take $2 billion immediately out of the defense budget and put it into a large-scale humanitarian effort to get the former Soviet republics through the winter.
Over the long term, he said, Mr. Tsongas supports the establishment of an "Executive Peace Corps," that would be made up of retired businessmen and entreprenuers who would go to Russia and other republics to help new capitalist enterprises there.
 
Talks Wwwith I.M.F.
 Asked where Mr. Tsongas stood on the big ticket item -- the question of the United States contributing to a multi-billion dollar fund to stabilize the Russian ruble, an essential ingredient for economic reform there, Mr. Mackenzie said, "We are taking a look at that, but don't have a position yet."
While that debate was swirling in Washington, Konstantin Kagalovsky, Mr. Yeltsin's chief negotiator with the International Monetary Fund and other international financial institutions, was just completing a round of negotiations at the fund's headquarters here on Russia's financial needs.

HEADLINE: Cuba Seeks Friends and Tourists in Caribbean

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINGSTON, Jamaica

 BODY:
For many in the Caribbean, the most readily visible face of Cuba was long represented by olive-green military advisers, or young bearded doctors sent abroad from Havana to share the fruits of the revolution in the hopes that others might deecide to emulate it.
But as leaders of the English-speaking Caribbean gathered here recently to discuss issues of common concern like tourism and regional economic integration, they were joined by what Havana hopes will rapidly take hold as its new image. 
 As they have at other recent regional meetings, nattily attired Cuban officials worked the hallways here at a February summit of Caricom, as the Caribbean Community is known, buttonholing business leaders, exploring investment possibilities and renewing political contacts that have in many cases lay dormant for years.
Cuba's rediscovery of the Caribbean has become a centerpiece of Havana's high-priority push to build bridges to the rest of the hemisphere at a time when the island needs new friends.
And after years of wariness toward Cuba, at least in part for fear of invoking Washington's displeasure, many of the Caribbean's leaders are tentatively reciprocating Havana's interest.
"There is quite a widespread view that we would like to see some measure of reintegration of Cuba," Prime Minister Michael N. Manley of Jamaica said. "We are a democracy and they are not, but we have always felt it was good to cooperate in ways that do not compromise our principles."
Mr. Manley's friendship with Cuba brought him Washington's hostility from when he previously served as Prime Minister in the 1970's, but he and other Caribbean leaders suggested that with most of the region consisting of democracies that are pursuing free-market style reforms, contact with Cuba no longer araouses the same suspicion it once did.
With its sugar industry in serious decline, the cooperation that most interests Havana involves finding ways to tap into the Caribbean's multi-billion-dollar tourism industry.
Deprived of regular airline connections with the United States, which were severed as part of Washington's three decade-long embargo, Cuba is seeking to help its travel industry by building links to other Caribbean islands in the hope that more vacationers, including Americans, will take side trips to the island.
Already, in the last year Cuba's strategy has produced payoffs in the form of hotel investment from Jamaica and both chartered and scheduled flights with a growing number of islands, including the Bahamas, the Cayman Islands and Jamaica.
"We have always felt the solution for tourism is to create a regional market," Deputy Foreign Minister Ramon Sanchez Parodi of Cuba said.
But Cuba's full-scale integration into the region, whether in tourism or other areas, has been blocked by factors ranging from hard feelings that date to the island's former interventionist policies to concern for human rights and an eagerness in many Caribbean capitals to avoid incurring the displeasure of Washington by granting Havana too many favors.
Some participants at the Caribbean meeting, however, invoked fear of economic competition from a tourism- and investment-hungry post-Castro Cuba, the region's largest country, to explain their hesitation about accepting Havana's overtures.
Others said Cuba is aproaching what could be a dramatic transition and they preferred taking a wait-and-see attitude before significantly altering their attitude toward the island.
"If it were a transition to a market economy and liberal democracy, I think Caricom would be very eager to help Cuba," said Sir Shridath Ramphal of Guyana, who is head of the West Indian Commission, a Caribbean Community advisory group. "But right now I don't quite see how we could."
Others, however, said that far from fearing the competitive consequences of Cuban liberalization, if it were to come, Caribbean investors should scout opportunities in Cuba now before a change of government or economic policy attracts large corporations that would leave them little place.

HEADLINE: Tight Budgets Bring Abandonment of Pets

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
As the region's economy continues to sputter, increasing numbers of household pets are being turned over to animal shelters, animal-welfare officials say.
"People who have lost jobs are saying they can't afford their pets anymore," said Marc Paulhus, a vice president of the Humane Society of the United States. "In the last six months, we've heard from animal shelters that an increased number of animals are being turned over because of direct or secondary effects of the recession."
 
Statistics Are Scarce
 Statistics on the abandonment of pets are scarce. But the Bide-a-Wee Home Association, which operates three shelters in Manhattan and on Long Island, said 1,701 animals were given up for adoption from September through February, compared with 1,295 in the comparable period last year, a 31 percent rise. As a result, for the first time Bide-a-Wee now has a two- to three-month waiting period for accepting animals for adoption, said George Wirt, a spokesman. 
 At the Central Westchester Humane Society in Elmsford, N.Y., "More people are coming in, saying 'I can't afford to feed them,' or 'My animal is ill, so I can't afford the vet bills,' " said Mimi Stone, the director. "For people who have been laid off, pets seem to be the first thing to go. They say they have to feed their children."
Animal-shelter directors say older animals, which are prone to illness, and large dogs, which can eat as much as 30 pounds of food a week, are the ones most likely to be dropped off at shelters.
Although pet-food costs may seem nominal, feeding several pets can be expensive, and veterinarians' bills can be overwhelming, pet owners say. These can be as much as $50 for an office visit, $100 a year for rabies or feline-leukemia inoculations, $150 for spaying and many times that amount for surgery.
 
Feeding 4 Dogs and 6 Birds
 "Dog food is 79 cents a can, and with vet costs, I spend $2,000 a year," said Miriam MacGregor, who lives in Milford, Conn., with her four Shih Tzus. Because she is on a limited income since her husband's death, she said, she has cut her dogs' daily rations in half.
Mrs. MacGregor, who also has five parakeets and a cockatiel, has been able to keep her pets with the help of a pet-food bank that recently began operating at a center for the elderly in Milford. In this makeshift adjunct to an existing food bank, bags of Natural Life dry dog food and cans of 9 Lives cat food are piled high beside shelves stocked with canned vegetables and boxes of macaroni and powdered milk.
"With the recession and the new state income tax, we're concerned that people who are so marginally surviving are probably sharing their food with their pets," said Kathi McDonnell-Bissell, a founder of the pet-food bank and executive director of the Milford Council on Aging.
"Originally our concern was mainly for the elderly," she said. "But now, it's reaching across the board. The elderly only account for about three percent of those who come to the food bank. We're seeing people with three mortgages, single parents, people in their 30's, 40's and 50's, who are so embarrassed they can't look you in the face when they come in for food."
 
Feelings of Shame
 Linda Reilly, who also lives in Milford, acknowledged that she felt some shame about coming to the pet-food bank with her 12-year-old poodle, Martea. But even though she buys generic dog food and feeds Martea table scraps, her $422 a month in public assistance still makes it hard to find money to spend on her aging pet's veterinary bills.
"People who have had pets for years that then get sick are broken-hearted at the cost of veterinary care," said Kathy Johnson, director of the Bergen County Humane Society/Lost Pet Inc., a nonprofit group in Hackensack, N.J. "Vets aren't cutting their prices or trying to help. They aren't even giving us discounts."
To Ms. Johnson, one of the most disturbing trends is the increase in the number of pet owners who are forced to give up their animals because they have been evicted for failing to pay their rent. Just last week, her organization had five animals put up for adoption by people being evicted in Bergen County, she said.
As far as pets' being dumped in parks or along roads, the evidence is contradictory. While some animal shelters say they are picking up more stray dogs and cats, others say the number of roaming dogs has actually declined.
"The number of strays we pick up has increased slightly," said Patricia Liptak, the Milford Animal Shelter warden. "What really surprises me is that we're now seeing a lot of pure breeds being found."
What becomes of pets given up for adoption varies quite starkly. In general, public dog pounds and local chapters of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals can sometimes keep animals alive for only a few days because of the sheer volume of animals they handle, although these organizations usually provide care for as long several weeks. In New York City, about three-fourths of the 59,000 animals turned in to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were "euthanized" last year, said Herman Cohen, executive vice president of the national organization. Humane societies and other "no kill" shelters like Bide-a-Wee keep animals alive until they are adopted.

HEADLINE: A University Provost Is Named at Harvard

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The president of Harvard University, Neil L. Rudenstine, has appointed a provost to oversee academic planning and fund-raising for the university's 11 schools, fulfilling a promise he made when he became president last July.
The new provost is Jerry R. Green, a professor of economics at Harvard, who becomes the second to hold the post in Harvard's 356-year history. 
 The appointment of a provost, or universitywide academic administrator, is a major change for Harvard, which has long been characterized by its decentralized organization. Each of Harvard's schools and colleges, including the undergraduate college, the business school, the law school and the medical school, is responsible for its own finances and academic decisions.
While each school will remain independent, the provost will oversee academic planning between schools and help establish interdisciplinary curriculums as well as organize joint fund-raising ventures for universitywide improvements, said Mr. Rudenstine, a former provost himself at Princeton University.
Most universities have provosts, but Harvard had one only from 1945 to 1953, when major changes at the university, including coeducation, required more cooperation between departments.
"The major public policy problems of the day require cooperation between disciplines," said the 45-year-old Mr. Green.

HEADLINE: '91 Productivity Gain Was First in 3 Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Helped by a surge in the fourth quarter, America's non-farm productivity last year grew for the first time in three years, as businesses tried to maintain output with a smaller work force during the recession, Government figures showed today.
Productivity rose 1.7 percent at an annual rate in the fourth quarter and three-tenths of 1 percent for the full year, the Labor Department said. The yearly figure was higher than the Government's last estimate of a two-tenths of 1 percent gain. 
 "In the midst of a recession, employers try to get by with fewer people," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "This was especially true for 1991, when we tried to shed some of the fat we acquired in the 1980's."
 
More Improvement Seen
 Some analysts said productivity would continue to improve modestly as the economy strengthened.
Norman Robertson, an economist with the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said he expected significant improvement in manufacturing productivity in the second half of this year.
Others were not so sure. Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington economic forecasting company, said growth would be restrained by a lack of business investment in new equipment, a decline in education and a rash of inhibiting Government regulations.
The Labor Department said the 1991 gain in productivity was the first for a full year since a nine-tenths of 1 percent rise in 1988. Productivity fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in 1989 and one-tenth of 1 percent in 1990 as the economy slid into recession.
Increased productivity, defined as getting more output per hour of work, is considered vital to increasing Americans' standard of living without increasing inflation. It also helps the competitiveness of United States goods overseas. Exports are one of the few strengths in the economy as it wrestles with the recession.
Annual productivity growth averaged 2.4 percent in the 1960's, 1.3 percent in the 1970's and eight-tenths of 1 percent in the 1980's.
Last year's fourth-quarter productivity growth of 1.7 percent followed an increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter and a 1.9 percent gain in the second quarter.
The full-year increase resulted from a 1.6 percent drop in output at the same time that the number of hours worked fell 1.8 percent.
Full-year manufacturing productivity increased faster than that of non-farm workers generally. It rose 1.4 percent in 1991, after an advance of 2.5 percent in 1990.
Output rose at a six-tenths of 1 percent rate in the fourth quarter, while the number of hours worked fell at a 1.1 percent rate. Fourth-quarter productivity growth was initially reported to have been 1.1 percent.
Productivity of factory workers rose at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter after a 4 percent gain during the previous three months.
Total business productivity, including farming, was up two-tenths of 1 percent for the year, matching the growth in 1990. It rose at a 2.2 percent rate during the October-December period, compared with 1.1 percent from July through September.
The report also showed that unit labor costs, a key barometer of business costs, increased 3.7 percent among non-farm workers in 1991, well below the 5.3 percent increase in 1990 and the smallest rise since 1988.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "U.S. Productivity" shows index of output per hour of all people in non-farm businesses from '87-'91. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: For Some in U.S., Peace In Salvador Brings Fear

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAKOMA PARK, Md.

 BODY:
Six weeks after the war ended in El Salvador, tens of thousands of Salvadorans in the United States are worried that peace may make their already tenuous position here even worse.
"Everyone is shaking," said Manfredo Granados, a 31-year-old refugee in the Washington suburb of Langley Park, Md. "People don't know what is going to happen to them." 
 Despite lives of poverty and longing for family and friends left behind, the refugees are not ready to return home and are not sure they will ever be. The Government of El Salvador also prefers that they stay away because they send back millions of dollars that the country desperately needs and because the country can barely take care of the people already there.
The Salvadoran Government estimates that the refugees sent back about $700 million last year, financing an estimated 60 percent of all home purchases in the country. The Salvadoran Ambassador to the United States, Miguel Salaverria, said the total was more than the foreign aid from the United States or the profits of El Salvador's largest industry, agriculture.
 
For a Time, No Fears
 At the end of 1990, about one in five Salvadorans in this country, 186,000, signed up for an 18-month safe haven, offered because of the civil war. Some had survived as illegal aliens in the United States for as long as 10 years, but the temporary residency freed them from fears of being deported. It also gave them work permits that made it a easier to look for jobs, typically as dishwashers, housekeepers and other low-paying occupations.
This safe haven, officially known as "temporary protected status," is scheduled to expire June 30, and many Salvadorans believe that the cease-fire, which took effect Feb. 1, will prevent it from being extended. The Justice Department, which oversees the Immigration and Naturalization Service, declined to comment on its plans.
Last month the immigration service began warning the Salvadoran refugees with temporary residency status, ordering them "to show cause for why you should not be deported." Although it says hearings will not begin until next year, the wording in large type at the top of the page -- "Warrant for arrest of alien" -- has spread panic.
Mr. Granados said he did not worry about deportation before he signed up for temporary residency. "But this is different," he said. "Now the I.N.S. knows where to find me."
To register for the temporary protected status, Mr. Granados and others had to give their names, addresses and other personal information to the immigration service. Every six months, they must return to an immigration office to update it.
Mr. Granados, a construction worker who came to the United States in 1983, said he signed up for the temporary status when he was having difficulty finding a permanent full-time job and his wife was expecting a child. It did little good; he still works only part-time.
"I have a lot of friends who are now saying 'I told you so,' " Mr. Granados said. "People think there's going to be a mass deportation, like the Haitians."
But Duke Austin, a spokesman for the immigration service, dismissed the fears of a mass deportation as "ridiculous," saying the agency cannot round up 186,000 people.
 
'Be Pacing the Floor'
 Attorney General William P. Barr could still choose to extend the safe haven for Salvadorans. In recent months, Mr. Barr has granted temporary residency to people from three other countries that have been embroiled in civil wars: Lebanon, Liberia and Somalia. But he has denied it to the Haitians and refused to extend it for the Kuwaitees.
James McGovern, an aide to Representative Joe Moakley, the Massachusetts Democrat who is widely credited with gaining passage of the special status legislation, said, "If I were a Salvadoran, I'd be pacing the floor."
He went on: "The whole thrust of the temporary protected status is that you're here because there's a reason not to send you back. If there's peace, and it looks like it's for real, the justification is no longer there."
The Salvadoran Government and leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front signed the peace agreement on Jan. 16. It ended a 12-year war that left more than 75,000 people dead and was marked by a series of tragedies, from the assasination of the Archbishop Oscar Romero in 1980 to the murders of five Jesuit priests in 1989.
Mr. Salaverria, El Salvador's Ambassador to the United States, said his Government had requested an extension of the safe haven because the arrival of thousands of refugees could harm the Salvadoran economy and thus "would endanger the peace process."
"The Salvadorans who live abroad are a strong part of our economy," Mr. Salaverria said. "They are the middle class upon which we will build a strong democracy."
Opponents of an extension said jobs should not be used as foreign aid, and they called the plea for temporary residency a ploy by the Salvadorans to achieve permanent residency status.
"They're being disingenuous," said Alan C. Nelson, a former Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service who is now a consultant to the Federation of American Immigration Reform, which opposes letting the Salvadorans stay. "They think that they can chip away at the laws until they can stay permanently."
"Things may not be perfect in El Salvador now, but most of the world is fragile," Mr. Nelson said. "What do you do? Not require them to go back?"
In interviews with two dozen Salvadoran refugees from across the United States, all said that they planned to remain in this country for the next few years. They said that El Salvador, devestated by bombings and the cost of waging a long war, offered them little opportunity for work.
The refugees also described their difficult lives in the United States: they share crowded homes, go years without seeing parents and spouses and spend much of their days looking for work. Several refugees told of households where a half-dozen or more people used the beds during the night, only to give them up to another group in the morning who had worked night shifts.
"Everybody feels fearful about what's going to happen," said Gloria M., 30, a refugee who would not give her last name because she did not want to draw the immigration service's attention. "I miss my country, but I honestly don't want to go home. It's difficult here, but we're comfortable."
Another refugee, Juan A., a 42-year-old janitor in Takoma Park, said he would lose his work permit if his temporary residency status ended. That, in turn, would mean that he could not legally keep his $18,000-a-year job as a janitor at a local church and that he might have to stop sending the monthly $300 checks to relatives in El Salvador that helped them put a new roof and walls on a house that had been strafed with machine gun fire and hit by mortar shells.
Although Juan's wife and other children remain in El Salvador, it is hard for him to imagine returning to live among the people who, he said, fired bullets through his door and then threatened him with death.
"When I left El Salvador in 1985, a life was not worth more than a penny," he said. "I want to go back, but it is too soon. The peace agreement is still only a piece of paper. I want to save some money. I want my son to graduate high school."

HEADLINE: The View From the Bench;
Once a Prosecutor, Now a Federal Judge: A Harried but Happy Life in the Law

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
At 5 A.M., he wakes to down a bowl of cold cereal in an otherwise sleeping house in the remote northern suburbs. By 6:05 he is on his Metro-North train, another harried commuter balancing legal briefs and statute books on his lap.
A little more than an hour later he is waiting on the Grand Central subway platform for a No. 4 or No. 5 express to Brooklyn Bridge, and by 7:30 he is at his desk on the fifth floor of the columned United States Court House on Foley Square, sipping from a container of steaming tea. 
 So begins another workday for Louis J. Freeh, the newest Federal District Judge in the Southern District of New York, another day of juggling accident claims, prisoner lawsuits and criminal charges -- another day in the making of a judge.
 
A Basement Courtroom
 It is a day that will see him exiled once again to a temporary basement courtroom while his is torn apart for renovation. It is day that will be filled with the intricacies of civil law, a noontime three-mile run, a jury trial, last-minute plea talks and ultimately, a missed train home.
To follow the 42-year-old former Federal prosecutor and F.B.I. agent through a random day is to gain an unusual glimpse into the harried and hallowed life of a special kind of public servant -- a judge who need never fear unemployment but who must deal short-handed with a backlogged court calendar, a man who has spent a career in law but is now viewing the system through the fresh eyes of a rookie.
Sometimes it seems as if Judge Freeh is drowning in the minutiae of disputes that are more appropriate for a rural justice of the peace or a psychotherapist to resolve than a Federal judge. But he claims, with persuasive enthusiasm, to find every case absorbing. "Being a trial judge is the greatest," he exulted during a series of interviews since taking the bench in September. "There's something about the ebb and flow of human events, ordinary and sublime, all the different hues of human nature."
His is a road that other nominees are likely soon to tread. Four more candidates -- including the latest, Richard Conway Casey, 59, a blind lawyer who would be the first judge with such a disability on the Federal bench -- are in various stages of confirmation for lifetime appointments to the Southern District bench, where 7 of the 28 seats are vacant.
For most of the judges in the eight-county region from Manhattan north to Dutchess County, the civil caseload exceeds 300 in addition to criminal trials and motions. One overburdened judge was recently clocked with a civil caseload approaching 500.
 
Impressive Credentials
 Judge Freeh (pronounced FREE) comes to the job with impressive credentials, colleagues agree. He went from Rutgers Law School to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, where from 1976 to 1980 he helped run the waterfront racketeering investigation that convicted the former longshore boss Anthony Scotto and more than 125 labor leaders, shipping executives and underworld figures.
In 1983, having left the bureau to become an assistant United States attorney in Manhattan, he headed the prosecution team that severed a billion-dollar Sicilian Mafia heroin ring. The case became known as the "pizza connection" because of the ring's use of pizza parlors to mask drug trafficking. And last year he served as the special Justice Department deputy who built a complex circumstantial case to convict a Georgia man, Walter Leroy Moody Jr., in the mail-bomb murders of a Federal appeals court judge and a civil rights lawyer.
He took the bench admittedly wary of still thinking like a prosecutor and struggling to master the complexities of civil law that are new to a longtime criminal litigator. There have been some gaffes. Barely a month into his appointment, he was listening to a lawyer's motion when he announced, "The Government will grant your application."
There was a puzzled silence until the lawyer asked, "You mean the court?"
"The court," Judge Freeh said. "The court."
Admittedly wobbly in what he called "the interstices of the civil docket," he pores over civil statute books in spare moments. He has also collected catalogues listing how-to manuals and pamphlets and tapes from the Federal Judicial Center in Washington, resources with titles like: "Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Hearsay But Were Afraid to Ask," "The Art of Judging," and "How to Remember Names and Faces."
 
Oral Arguments on Mondays
 While the job has meant a rise in status and a raise to $129,500 a year, from the $96,000 he was paid as a Government attorney, much about him has not changed, longtime associates say.
Athletically built with closely cropped hair and dark-hollowed eyes, he still wears scuffed shoes, starts work compulsively early, eats lunch at his desk or at a Chinatown pizza parlor, worries about not spending enough time with his wife and three young sons, and speaks with an adenoidal Jersey City accent that turns "time" into "toyme," "job" into "jawb," "court" into "koo-urt" and "law" into "lohr."
A recent day began with Judge Freeh's courtroom deputy, Paul Blumberg, a 12-year court veteran at age 38, heralding the judge's arrival at his temporary basement courtroom No. 35 with three hearty slaps on the door and a robust "All rise."
From Judge Edward J. Devitt, a mentor and the senior district judge in Minnesota who presided over the mail-bomb case after a change of venue from Georgia, Judge Freeh has adopted the method of hearing oral arguments on Mondays. A case is never as fresh as when both sides argue it out in court, he said.
Before coming to court, Judge Freeh had read all the briefs pertaining to the day's cases and discussed them with his two 28-year-old law clerks, Burke Doar, who had worked briefly in the organized crime unit of the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, and Eileen Minnefor, a Harvard Law School graduate who had previously clerked for a New Jersey Supreme Court justice.
First before him was a motion to dismiss a lawsuit over a three-year-old truck accident on the Cross Bronx Expressway. The case had landed in Federal Court because the two trucks involved came from different states. The Founding Fathers thought that a state court might not give an out-of-stater a fair shake so they gave the Federal courts jurisdiction over all civil suits above a threshold, now $50,000, in which the parties come from different states. The doctrine is known as "diversity."
When one lawyer started arguing particulars, Judge Freeh cut him off. "I know the underlying facts," he said drily. "Why don't you discuss the legal issues?" He later ruled from the bench that the diversity doctrine did not apply and remanded the case to State Supreme Court.
 
Discussion With Decorators
 Then there was a lawsuit about a bicycle accident that hinged on whether the plaintiff had been a resident of Indiana and whether Indiana law applied at the time of the injury. He put the parties on the "ready trial" calendar, subject to 48-hour call.
After lunch, Judge Freeh took his daily run, a route he varies day to day for security reasons.
He ate his lunch, a bologna sandwich, banana and bottle of mineral water, while discussing legal points of a liability case with his clerks. A former manager of B. Altman, who had a chair collapse from under her two and a half years ago, was suing the department store, which has since gone out of business, and the out-of-state chair manufacturer.
In two hours he and the lawyers selected a six-member civil jury with six alternates and began the trial. There was a flurry of excitement as the accused -- the chair -- was wheeled in.
The trial was adjourned for the day at 5 P.M. Judge Freeh was wrapping up when Mr. Blumberg said the lawyer for a defendant in a large drug conspiracy case had arrived with his client and the prosecutor to offer a guilty plea.
The judge re-robed and called home. "Hello darling, I'm going to take a plea in one of the cases so I'm going to be late." Pause. "Yeah, this is one of the cases, so I'd better take it." Pause. "No, not real late." Pause. "The boys O.K.?" "Ah, that's cute."
Back in the courtroom, there were two lawyers, each claiming to represent the defendant. Each had a different view of the proposed deal. "I think you have to do more homework," Judge Freeh said.
"You're quite right, your honor," said one of the lawyers. "I'm sorry, your honor," said the other.
"I just missed my train," said Judge Freeh.

 Hobbies: Running, reading biography and history. (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Bond Broker Is Target Of Inquiry

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City is investigating whether the investment bank underwriting $1 billion worth of city debt improperly bought city bonds with the intent of selling them back to the city at a premium, officials said yesterday.
The focus of the investigation is the First Boston Corporation. In late February, the company bought $13 million of $84 million of bonds that the city planned to repurchase. That could have given First Boston a profit at the expense of the city. 
 As the city's main underwriter of the bond transaction, First Boston is responsible for insuring that the city obtains the best possible deal on both the sale of the new bonds and repurchase of the outstanding debt. City officials are counting on the proceeds from the bond transaction to help reduce the city's swelling budget deficits.
At issue here is whether First Boston violated its fiduciary duty to the city by failing to disclose its purchase of the bonds quickly and whether First Boston intended to sell the bonds back to its client at a premium.
It would be a major embarrassment to Mayor David N. Dinkins if the city's investigation determines that First Boston had acted improperly, as Mr. Dinkins is a close friend of Ron Gault, a top official in First Boston's public finance division. Mr. Gault declined to comment on the inquiry last night.
 
Repurchase Plan
 The investigation of First Boston by the city's bond counsel -- Lord, Day & Lord, Barrett, Smith -- involves a series of financial transactions that First Boston is undertaking on the city's behalf to decrease the interest that the city pays on $84 million worth of taxable bonds. Under the transaction the city will use proceeds from an offering of more than $1 billion in bonds issued at low interest rates to repurchase the $84 million worth of bonds at a higher interest rate. The transactions were expected to save the city about $100 million.
But First Boston insists that it bought the bonds for the city, with the city's permission, and that it planned to sell them back to the city at cost. City officials said, however, First Boston did not notify them of its purchase.
Records from the investment bank are ambiguous, city officials said yesterday. They ask why it took First Boston several days to report the multimillion-dollar purchase to the city if it was being done on the city's behalf. That failure has created suspicions among many city finance officials that First Boston may have been trying to profit from the buyback.
The city has also investigated whether First Boston misappropriated information not available to the public for use in making its decision to buy the $13 million in bonds. The city's Corporation Counsel, F. Peter Sherwood, said last night that the city has concluded that no insider trading occurred.
 
Seeking the Motivation
 But Mr. Sherwood said that the city is trying to determine First Boston's motivation for buying the bonds. "What we are unable to determine is precisely what First Boston intended to do with the bonds," he said, "and we believe that they should have notified us of the purchase earlier."
While the city's investigation began on March 3 when First Boston notified city officials of its bond purchase, details of the case were disclosed for the first time yesterday in a letter to William R. McLucas, head of the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission. A telephone call to Mr. McLucas's Washington office last night was not answered.
Archibald Cox Jr., president and chief executive of First Boston, strongly denied in a statement that the his concern had done anything improper. "There is no ambiguity," Mr. Cox said. "First Boston bought the bonds as agent for the city and as such we would not have marked up the bonds in question." He added that First Boston had provided all the information pertinent to the bond purchase to the city and its lawyers.

HEADLINE: Study Says 'Spring Borrowing' Ban Has Little Effect

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 10

 BODY:
The 1990 law aimed at halting New York State's practice of borrowing billions of dollars each spring for routine expenses has had just a minimal effect on improving the state's troubled financial picture, a watchdog group said yesterday.
The report by the group, the Citizens Budget Commission, on the spring borrowings was disputed by the Cuomo administration and State Comptroller Edward V. Regan. They said the law was achieving its aim and represented a significant first step toward insuring greater fiscal responsibility. When it was enacted, the law was hailed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo as "the most sweeping fiscal reform in a generation." 
 Under the law the state will ultimately convert its debt, which had risen over 30 years to nearly $5 billion, into long-term bonds and impose severe restrictions on its ability to resort again to the borrowing.
 
$1 Billion Last Year
 The spring borrowing, which grew nearly every year and helped the state make payments to school districts and local governments, is a complex transaction that essentially involved the state's lending increasing amounts to itself to pay off the previous year's loan with interest. It is perhaps the most infamous of all the measures used to achieve at least technical balance in budgets during years when the state routinely spends more money than it is taking in.
The study today found that the law had been largely ineffective because it did not actually insure that the state will end any particular fiscal year without an operating deficit. Indeed, last year a gap in the budget forced the state to borrow $1 billion in a transaction that was entirely separate from the spring borrowing, and similar borrowing for about $500 million is expected this year.
Cynthia Green, a senior research associate with the Citizens Budget Commission who wrote the report, likened the law to "moving the bill from the left side of your desk to the right side of your desk." She said that although it had accomplished the goal of phasing out the spring borrowing, it had "nothing to do with real fiscal reform."
A more meaningful package of laws, she said, would mandate balanced budgets each year and set aside money to reduce the state's accumulated deficit, which will grow to nearly $7 billion this year, when the state issues deficit notes to cover a $531 million deficit in the current budget.
Administration officials said that the law was never intended to wipe out those deficits and that it was misleading to suggest that it was ineffective. The law "has been a success," Mr. Cuomo's budget director, Patrick J. Bulgaro, wrote today in a letter to the commission.
"It was designed to reduce the spring borrowing," Mr. Bulgaro added. "And that is exactly what it has done."
 
Covenants on Borrowing
 Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin said that although the law was one of several measures needed to improve finances, it was clearly a step in the right direction. "We cannot simply get off of the train just because someone thinks the train is not moving fast enough," Mr. Weprin said.
The 1990 law established the Local Government Assistance Corporation to be responsible for the debt with long-term bonds. The covenants in the bonds strictly limit the ability of state leaders to borrow their way out of problems, and the law stipulates that when the leaders did borrow, they would have to adopt a plan to pay back the money in three years.
But the persistence of huge deficits, which state officials attribute to the recession, means that even as the spring borrowing is curtailed, a new form of financing can undercut those gains. When there is an operating deficit, officials issue "deficit notes" at the end of the year. Those notes are supposed to be paid back immediately, but continuing deficits can amount to a form of permanent borrowing.
Mr. Bulgaro said it would be impractical to set aside huge reserve funds now that would guarantee there would never be any deficit in future years. The reserve funds, he said, "would not educate any child, build any bridge, house any homeless person, or provide any care to the needy people of this state."
"But," he added, "it would satisfy a few accountants."

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Chief Vows Broad Authority to Deputy

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Robert M. Gates has ordered the man chosen as his deputy to go over his head and report directly to the President should Mr. Gates ever be seen to be violating the law in his position as Director of Central Intelligence.
Vice Adm. William O. Studeman, the nominee for Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, told a Senate panel during his confirmation hearing today that Mr. Gates "has given me full authority to essentially go around him -- in fact enjoined me -- and stated under the strongest possible terms that that should in fact occur if in fact it is my belief that he is not behaving in the proper manner as it relates to covert action, illegal activities" or other questionable actions. 
 Admiral Studeman added that if such transgressions occurred "clearly you have to go up essentially to the level of the President."
The 52-year-old Admiral was responding to a question by Senator David L. Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who heads the Intelligence Committee. He asked what the nominee would do if faced with the situation Mr. Gates found himself in in the mid-1980's.
As Deputy Director in those years, Mr. Gates received reports about the possible diversion of profits from illegal arms sales to Iran to Nicaraguan rebels, and he took that information to William J. Casey, who was then Director of Central Intelligence.
The issues of what Mr. Gates knew about the Iran-contra affair, whether he did enough to stop it and whether he misled Congress about his role dominated much of Mr. Gates's confirmation hearings last fall. He was repeatedly asked why he took such a passive role and never made his suspicions known to President Ronald Reagan. Mr. Gates testified that he thought that making his discomfort known to his immediate superior was sufficient.
In his testimony today, Admiral Studeman said Mr. Gates "has clearly been, I think, significantly impacted by this experience."
When Mr. Boren again asked the nominee if he would go to the President if he felt that Mr. Gates was "acting improperly," Admiral Studeman replied, "Absolutely."
 
Most Senators Skip Hearing
 Today's hearing revealed more about the confirmation process and the committee members than about the thinking of the nominee. Unlike Mr. Gates, who was subjected to a six-month confirmation process and grueling hearings that examined in detail his years as a senior intelligence official, the admiral was questioned for only 90 minutes.
Only 3 of the 15 Senators on the committee were at the hearing despite the importance of the job at stake. In addition to Mr. Boren, Senator Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who is vice chairman of the committee, and Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, questioned Admiral Studeman. He is expected to win swift and easy confirmation by the committee as well as the full Senate later this month.
Although the admiral, who now serves as the director of the National Security Agency, said in his prepared statement that the cold war had dominated the focus of his career, there were no questions about such subjects as his assessment of instability in the former Soviet Union or the danger of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Nor was he asked about his public statement in July 1990 that the security agency's electronic espionage network could be asked to gather economic intelligence on the United States' allies.
The National Security Agency is the largest and most expensive of the country's intelligence agencies. It monitors communications around the world and keeps official United States' communications channels secure.
Admiral Studeman presented himself as a seasoned career military intelligence officer who knows little about covert operations or how to manage them. "Covert action and the details of national clandestine operations management will be virtually new to me," he acknowledged.

HEADLINE: Keycorp, by Looking West, Skirts Pitfalls Close to Home

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
In the mid-1980's, Victor J. Riley, chairman of Keycorp, wanted very much to expand his Albany-based banking company into neighboring New England, but was generally excluded by state laws that fostered mergers of local banks and kept New York rivals locked out.
Frustrated, Mr. Riley turned westward and starting acquiring banks in the Northwest states. It was a change of course he does not regret. 
 While New England banks are still licking their wounds from the recession, Keycorp is enjoying record profits and has the financial strength to be among the buyers in the merger and acquisition movement now sweeping the banking industry. Under an agreement announced Monday, Keycorp will acquire the Puget Sound Bancorp in Tacoma, Wash., with $4.9 billion in assets, and merge it with Keycorp's existing $1.5 billion Washington bank. The deal will make Keycorp the second-largest bank company in Washington and one of the 25 largest in the country.
With banks in eight states and 765 branches, once the latest deal is completed, Keycorp is one of only a handful of banking companies that can label itself as more than a regional company. That geographic diversification means that an economic downturn in one state or region is not necessarily crippling in another. With its acquisition of Puget Sound, Key expects its cluster of Western states will provide about 44 percent of profits, up from 32 percent.
But the diversification strategy has not been widely imitated by other banking companies that have preferred to grow in their own regions. Mr. Riley had said two years ago that in New England, for example, local banking companies "promoted the idea of super-regional banks -- they judiciously protected it -- and in the long run, it has been their downfall."
In all of the states where it does business, Keycorp follows a similar strategy: focus on small cities and towns where competition is sparse and it can collect good prices for its services, and concentrate on consumers and local businesses.
"We don't try to compete on the basis of price, and people who shop around will find we are not the cheapest," said Lee Irvin, senior vice president and treasurer of Keycorp. But the expenses of operating a large branch network in small towns -- the average town for a Key branch has a population of only 17,000 -- "requires that we charge a bit more and keep people satisfied with good service."
 Keycorp's recent success is an example of how the stronger banking companies seem to be growing stronger while the weak are languishing. The growing disparity between the industry's best and worst was noted on Monday by William Taylor, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. He observed that there was a "very, very large chunk of the industry earning quite a bit of money, actually more than has historically been the case," while "a significant portion of the industry is not doing well at all."
In Keycorp's case, success has bred success. Because of the company's history of reasonably good earnings, the company could raise $122.5 million in early 1991 from the sale of new shares. That extra capital helped persuade Federal regulators that Key could readily absorb a large part of Goldome, a failed savings bank in Buffalo. In acquiring $7 billion of Goldome deposits, Key both solidified its position as the No. 2 bank in Buffalo, after the Manufacturers and Traders Bank, and laid the groundwork for much faster earnings growth in subsequent quarters as it made loans and investments with the deposits it acquired cheaply.
With record earnings in 1991 of $188 million, Keycorp's stock price rose sharply, making it easier to buy Puget Sound without issuing so many new shares that existing stockholders would be hurt. Because its stock price has doubled in the last 15 months, and its dividend has been increased three times, other bankers are inclined to view Keycorp favorably when it offers to buy their banks with new shares of stock.
 
 
Expects Much Higher Profits
 The acquisition of the Puget Sound bank promises more rewards. Key expects to reduce costs of its newly created Washington bank by $37 million a year beginning in 1994, mostly by consolidating Puget Sound's computer center with operations Key already has in Tigard, Ore., and by closing about two dozen overlapping branches in Washington state.
At a meeting with bank analysts on Monday, Keycorp executives said they expected sharply improved profits within a few years, with the company earning $1.20 of profit for every $100 of assets -- the banking equivalent of hitting .300 in baseball.
Analysts are inclined to believe the projections. For example, Frank Barcocy at Advest, a Hartford securities firm, raised his recommendation on Keycorp yesterday from "accumulate" to "strong buy." "The acquisition of Puget Sound puts Keycorp in an even better position to bid for the Washington deposits that Bank of America and Security Pacific are selling as part of their merger," Mr. Barcocy said.
Mr. Riley's penchant for diversification also extends to lending policies under which his banks concentrate on many small loans to consumers and local businesses, leaving large loans and risky ventures in real estate and corporate takeovers to other banks.
 
 
Culture of Avoiding Risks
 Although Keycorp gives its local bankers leeway to pick and choose customers, policies set in Albany set a risk-avoiding tone that reaches all parts of the company. In the credit-card business, for example, the banks issue cards only to checking-account customers. A decision in 1988 to limit condominium lending of all Key banks to a total of no more than $75 million is one reason the company has weathered the last few years without the sharp rise in loan losses that have hurt other banks.
Although Keycorp is large enough, conceivably, to make loans as large as $250 million, it has approved only 20 loans of more than $12.5 million. As a rule, no loans above $25 million are considered; its largest loan, for $37 million, is to a company that owns two Albany office buildings where Keycorp is the primary tenant.
Because any loans above $12.5 million must be approved in Albany, "the local bankers are encouraged to concentrate on smaller credits," said Mr. Irvin, the treasurer. "It's a policy that encourages people to hit a lot of singles, but no home runs."

HEADLINE: Bush Plans Trade-Policy Change Soon

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 10

 BODY:
Despite a chorus of objections, the Bush Administration is expected to change its antitrust policies within 7 to 10 days to allow Justice Department lawsuits against the American operations of foreign cartels, senior Administration officials said today.
Attorney General William P. Barr said on Feb. 21 that he foresaw such a policy change, but today's comments put a specific time frame on the Administration's action. The comment provoked criticism from Japanese officials, who called the plan unacceptable, and complaints from the State Department, which had not signed off on the decision. 
 The change, which would revive a policy in force until the end of the Reagan Administration, is intended to prevent foreign companies from conspiring to avoid buying American exports. It is aimed as much at jawboning the Japanese to enforce their own antitrust laws more vigorously as it is at filing immediate cases, Administration officials said.
 
No Cases Planned
 Although investigations of foreign companies have begun, the Justice Department has no immediate plans to file any cases. The department is changing its policy in principle while waiting to develop a case that it feels sure of winning.
While the policy change is politically opportune during an election campaign in which criticizing Japan has proved popular among candidates, Administration officials insist that the change has been two years in the planning and is not aimed at any particular country.
Although the Justice Department has stopped filing such lawsuits, a case in the early 1980's illustrates how they work.
The department sued the American operations of a group of Japanese corporations led by C. Itoh & Company, a Tokyo-based conglomerate. Government lawyers contended that these Japanese companies had secretly agreed to buy only small quantities of American shellfish from the Pacific Northwest and to offer only very low prices.
The Justice Department contended that even though the decision to limit purchases might have been made in Tokyo, the case could be brought in United States courts because the American operations of the Japanese companies actually purchased the shellfish. The case never went to trial because the Japanese companies signed a consent decree in 1983 in which they did not admit guilt but agreed not to collude in the future.
Companies are already able to sue the United States subsidiaries of foreign groups of companies that they assert collusively refuse to buy American goods. But few have done so because of the exorbitant cost of antitrust lawsuits, the risk of offending foreign partners in joint ventures and the poor likelihood of success as long as courts can look to a Justice Department policy of not filing such cases.
Hiroshi Hirabayashi, the deputy chief of the Japanese Embassy here, said his Government wanted the United States to consult with the other 23 industrialized nations in the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development before changing any policies.
"We think -- many countries think -- that it's a violation of established international laws and practices," the diplomat said of the proposed Justice Department change.
A committee of the international organization has been reviewing differences in member countries' antitrust laws for many years, with the United States consistently arguing that countries should be able to apply their laws more often to foreign companies. An American official said today that the planned policy change was not broad enough to be included in the O.E.C.D. talks.
 
Plan Worries Diplomats
 The Justice Department's planned policy change has pitted diplomats worried about possible damage to diplomatic relations with foreign governments against Administration trade officials frustrated by the reluctance of Japanese companies to buy American goods even as the Japanese Government eliminates legal and regulatory barriers to imports.
The Commerce Department and Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative and a former head of the American Bar Association's antitrust section, both endorsed the policy change last year.
The State Department was unhappy when Mr. Barr made his remarks on Feb. 21 because it had not endorsed the policy change and wanted to set up an interagency process to review all such cases before they are filed, a department official said.
Charles F. Rule, the former Assistant Attorney General for Antitrust, who banned cases filed on behalf of exporters at the end of the Reagan Administration, said that eliminating the ban now would be a mistake. The Justice Department risks reawakening bitter disputes with its allies over international lawsuits and offending Japanese law enforcement officials whose cooperation is needed on many other cases, he said.
